title: Easton has other priorities
author: Staff Writer
content:
Easton has other priorities

 July 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I cannot speak for everyone in our town or county but for me, enough with the whole "Pride" obsession.Easton has plenty of important issues to address within our own community. Everyone should have pride in our town and community.
Since when does sexual orientation take up more time at our town meetings than critical issues like education, health care or our local finances? That is called priority.
Why are people from outside of Easton using our town meetings to address their personal agenda and issues? Have these people tried their efforts in Denton, Ridgely or Cambridge? Do the residents of Easton want to be a hub or centerpiece for the "pride group" on the entire Delmarva Peninsula?
Easton's positive reputation has been established over many many years without flag waving and shouting from outside groups. Money has been invested by private citizens to successfully beautify our downtown. Thank You. That is good for Easton and for tourism.
Positive efforts, as shown, will help to improve life for Easton residents while small "groupthink" from outside does not. Our town leadership needs to lead not follow. Easton town officials were elected to represent all Easton residents first not their own personal or political agenda. Certainly not the agenda of outside influences that waste town time and energy.
Let's get down to business at our meetings and let the outside Delmarva group and others find somewhere else to disrupt.
RICH ADRIAN
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - Wait, Wait, but not for too long
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Wait, Wait, but not for too long

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A21 | Section: News 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I like the weekly NPR news quiz "Wait, Wait, Don't Tell Me." On some deals, it is a good idea for the declarer to wait until he has sufficient data to determine how to tackle the key suit. The declarers who are good at that are used to saying to partner, "Don't tell me - the suit is splitting badly yet again." How should South have planned the play in three notrump on today's deal? West, after overcalling in spades, led the diamond king: two, 10The bidding was pushy.North's two-spade cue bid showed at least gameinvitational values with club support. South was not happy rebidding two no-trump, but he knew his partner did not have four hearts (no negative double over one spade), and five clubs was a long way away. North raised because he had a fifth club and a vulnerable game bonus was very tempting.South saw six top tricks: three hearts, one diamond and two clubs. If clubs were 2-1, there were nine easy winners. So, declarer assumed they were 3-0. Who had the tripleton? Surely it was East because West already seemed to be marked with at least nine pointedsuit cards. However, before immediately playing a club to dummy's king, he silently said to himself, "Wait, wait." He could acquire more data by first cashing his heart winners.Well, well - West had only one heart. If he had been void in clubs, he would have had something like 6=1=6=0 distribution and surely would have bid three or four diamonds over two no-trump.South cashed his club ace and claimed when East discarded.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Oct. 15
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Oct. 15

 October 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Oct. 15, 2017, actor and activist Alyssa Milano tweeted that women who had been sexually harassed or assaulted should write "Me too" as a status. Within hours, tens of thousands had taken up the #MeToo hashtag (using a phrase that had been introduced a decade earlier by social activist Tarana Burke).Also on this date:
In 1815, Napoleon Bonaparte, the deposed French emperor, arrived on the British-ruled South Atlantic island of St. Helena, where he spent the last 5 1/2 years of his life in exile.
In 1945, the former premier of Vichy France, Pierre Laval, was executed for treason.
In 1946, Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering fatally poisoned himself hours before he was to have been executed.
In 1954, Hurricane Hazel made landfall on the Carolina coast as a Category 4 storm; Hazel was blamed for about 1,000 deaths in the Caribbean, 95 in the U.S. and 81 in Canada.
In 1976, the first debate of its kind took place between vice-presidential nominees. Democrat Walter F. Mondale and Republican Bob Dole faced off in Houston.
In 1991, despite sexual harassment allegations by Anita Hill, the Senate narrowly confirmed the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the U.S. Supreme Court, 52-48.
In 1997, British Royal Air Force pilot Andy Green twice drove a jet-powered car in the Nevada desert faster than the speed of sound, officially shattering the world's land-speed record.
In 2003, 11 people were killed and 70 were injured when a Staten Island ferry slammed into a maintenance pier. (The ferry's pilot, who had blacked out at the controls, later pleaded guilty to 11 counts of manslaughter.)
Today's Birthdays: Baseball Hall of Famer Jim Palmer is 80. Musician Richard Carpenter is 79. Film director Mira Nair is 68. Britain's Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, is 66. Chef Emeril Lagasse is 66. Actor Dominic West is 56. R&B singer Ginuwine is 55. Singer-TV personality Keyshia Cole is 44. Actor Bailee Madison is 26.

title: Orioles sending nearly $8.5 million to teams involved in trade-deadline deals
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Orioles sending nearly $8.5 million to teams involved in trade-deadline deals

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 855
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Baltimore will be sending nearly $8.5 million to four teams as part of five deals made ahead of the trade deadline.The Orioles will give San Diego $3,324,300 along with All-Star first baseman Ryan O'Hearn and outfielder Ramón Laureano, who were dealt last week for right-handers Tyson Neighbors and Tanner Smith, left-hander Boston Bateman, infielders Brandon Butterworth and Cobb Hightower and infielder/outfielder Victor Figueroa.
O'Hearn was owed $2,537,634 of his $8 million salary and Laureano $1,268,817. Baltimore will pay two installments of $1,662,150 on Sept. 15 and 30, according to trade details obtained by The Associated Press. The money reduces San Diego's expense to $482,151, which comes to a prorated share of the $760,000 minimum for each.
Baltimore will send Detroit $2,758,065 on Sept. 30 as part of the trade that sent right-hander Charlie Morton to the Tigers for minor league left-hander Micah Ashman. Morton was owed $4,758,064 of his $15 million salary, and the cash reduces his cost to the Tigers to $2 million. In addition, the Orioles will send the Tigers $100,000 on Aug. 15 as part of the trade to acquire left-hander Dietrich Enns.
The Orioles also are sending Toronto $1.75 million on Sept. 30 as part of the July 29 trade that sent right-hander Seranthony Domínguez to the Blue Jays for minor league right-hander Juaron Watts-Brown — a deal announced between games of a doubleheader between the teams. Domínguez had $2,645,161 left from his $8 million salary at the time of the trade.
Baltimore is giving Houston $520,000 along with infielder Ramón Urías, who was dealt for minor leaguer right-hander Twine Palmer. The money is due in equal payments on Sept. 15 and Oct. 15. Urías was owed $1,016,129 of his $3.15 million salary.
Money in the five trades totals $8,452,365. Baltimore opened the season with a $169 million payroll, 15th among the 30 major league teams.
Minnesota is paying $33 million to Houston in the July 31 trade that returned All-Star Carlos Correa to the Astros for minor league left-hander Matt Mikulski, by far the largest amount among 14 deadline trades involving cash transactions. That covered a significant portion of the $103,419,355 remaining in the contract of the three-time All-Star, who left the Astros to sign with the Twins ahead of the 2022 season. Houston gets $3 million this year and $10 million each in 2026, 2027 and 2028, with installments due each Dec. 15.
Arizona will pay Milwaukee $5,258,000 as part of the July 31 trade that sent right-hander Shelby Miller and left-hander Jordan Montgomery to the Brewers for a player to be named or cash. Arizona will send the money in four installments of $1,314,500 on Aug. 15, Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30. Montgomery was owed $7,137,097 of his $22.5 million salary and Miller $317,204 of his $1 million salary.
Milwaukee is sending San Diego $2,169,000 as part of the trade that sent left-hander Nestor Cortes and minor league infielder Jorge Quintana to the Padres for outfielder Brandon Lockridge. That offsets part of the $2,410,753 remaining from Cortes' $7.6 million salary. The Brewers will send $361,500 each on Aug. 15 and 29, Sept. 12 and 26 plus $723,000 on Oct. 10.
Cincinnati is paying Pittsburgh $1,935,484 as part of the July 30 trade that sent left-hander Taylor Rogers and minor league shortstop Sammy Stafura to the Pirates for third baseman Ke'Bryan Hayes. The cash covers half the $3,870,968 Rogers was owed from his $12 million salary, and the Reds paid $435,484 on Aug. 1 and owe $500,000 each on Aug. 15, Sept. 1 and Sept. 15.
Rogers was dealt the following day to the Cubs for outfielder Ivan Brethowr, and Pittsburgh agreed to give the Cubs $1,903,226. That offset half the $3,806,452 then left on Rogers' salary after the $64,516 he earned during his one day with Pittsburgh, for whom he never threw a pitch. The Pirates pay $423,226 on Aug . 15 and owe $500,000 installments on Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30.
San Francisco will give Kansas City $1,934,100 as part of the trade that sent outfielder Mike Yastzemski to the Royals for right-hander Yunior Marte. Yastzemski was owed $2,934,140 of his $9.25 million salary, and the Giants will make four payments of $483,535 on Aug. 15. Aug. 31, Sept. 15 and Sept. 30.
Tampa Bay is sending Milwaukee $1.1 million in the July 28 trade that sent catcher Danny Jansen to his hometown Brewers for minor league infielder Jadher Areinamo. Jansen was owed $2,833,333 of his $8.5 million salary. The Rays will make six payments of $183,333, on Aug. 1, 15 and 29, Sept. 12 and 26, and Oct. 10. Tampa Bay agreed to send an additional $500,000 if a $12 million mutual option for 2026 is declined, which carries a $500,000 buyout.
St. Louis agreed to pay Atlanta $2.28 million as part of the July 27 trade that sent right-hander Erick Fedde to the Braves for a player to be named or cash. Fedde was owed $2,455,645 from his $7.25 million salary. The Cardinals will make equal payments of $1.14 million on Aug. 11 and Sept. 22.
Detroit will pay Texas $100,000 on Aug. 15 as part of the trade to acquire right-hander Codi Heuer.

title: Author pens first two Western novels
author: Staff Writer
content:
Author pens first two Western novels

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland author Judy Hannigan recently released her first two novels "Lost in Prosperity" and "Everything in Prosperity."According to a news release the books are set against the backdrop of the 1875 Wyoming Territory and is a "riveting tale of a woman who longs to trust her heart to a man she doesn't remember and a man who refuses to lose the love of the woman who completes him."
The book contains some graphic language and violence.
The St. Leonard writer moved to Calvert County from Michigan 35 years ago. She and her husband stay active in the community by supporting the local St. Leonard Volunteer Fire Department, of which her husband Richard is the company's training officer.
When she's not writing, she's reading, designing her book covers, and occasionally editing fundraising letters or offering advice and encouragement to other independent authors. She is currently working on the third book in the series, which as of now is untitled.
The books are available at www.amazon.com/author/judyhannigan.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?
Always a voracious reader, I drafted the first chapter of "Lost in Prosperity" while in high school, but I didn't finish the story until recently. I penned the second novel, "Everything in Prosperity," last year.
What inspires you to write?
I write historical westerns because in that era you could reinvent yourself. My characters do what's right instead of what's told, exemplifying justice can triumph. I believe honor, courage, and loyalty are the principles by which to live.
Do you consider writing to be a career?
Writing is my third career. I started as a high school and college teacher before becoming a technical editor. Now I write full-time, and every day is an adventure.
What kind of writing process do you use?
I center my stories around a major event before I begin layering in backstories and challenges. I see scenes as if watching through a camera lens, so when the unexpected happens or characters pop up I investigate the possibilities, which means I rarely stick to an outline.
Who are some of your favorite authors?
"Lonesome Dove" author, Larry McMurtry wrote one of the most beloved westerns. I want readers of his novels and fans of television shows like "Yellowstone," "The Virginian," and "The Rifleman" to experience an era in which perseverance, loyalty, forgiveness, and the enduring power of love could redeem a wounded soul. Rosanne Bittner's "Savage Destiny" and "Outlaw Hearts" series feature flawed but courageous characters that fulfill their potential when forced into the gray zone wedged between black and white.
Please include a brief description of the book
Set in the 1870s, "Lost in Prosperity" opens the series by blending adventure, romance, and suspenseful mystery to tell the story of Sam Hilliard Stone, a rich and beautiful heiress with a temper as fast as her quick draw, and Providence "Jackson" Knight, the handsome, rugged rancher determined to protect the woman he loves, as they struggle to build a dynasty in the wild, Wyoming Territory. Together, they navigate threats from an unknown enemy to uncover why events from their past are converging to destroy their future.
In "Everything in Prosperity," Sam and Jackson risk everything to protect the town citizens from a notorious gang and survive the tangled web of deceptions threatening them.
Please include an excerpt from the book
"Jackson's face was pale. He tried to brush her hands away. Failing, he grabbed her wrists and pulled her close. "Sonofabitch, Sam — even shot up, all I think about is how much I love you and ache for you to love me."
Sam's eyes filled with tears as she gently wriggled her wrists from his grasp. It wasn't difficult."

title: Talbot County removes DEI statement amid funding concerns for airport
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County removes DEI statement amid funding concerns for airport

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 752
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council voted Tuesday to remove the diversity, equity and inclusion statement from the county's employee handbook, reversing course from March, when the council upheld the diversity statement.Tuesday's decision came amid concerns for millions of dollars in federal funding for an ongoing Easton Airport project. Those worries stem from an April directive from U.S. Department of Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy outlining the Trump administration's view that DEI programs violate federal law.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher and council member Dave Stepp sponsored Tuesday's resolution, which passed 4-1 with council member Keasha Haythe opposing. Haythe, Lesher and council member Lynn Mielke had voted down Stepp's attempt to remove the DEI statement in March.
Lesher, a Democrat, said it was a difficult decision, noting he changed his tune on the measure due to a "vindictive and maleficent federal administration."
"The risk is that some incompetent political appointee will read only the title of our statement, misconstrue it as an illegal policy and deny a federal grant on that basis," Lesher said. "In an event like that, even if we win on appeal, it could leave us in a state of construction limbo for an unacceptably long time."
Lesher added, "We simply need to ensure that we are using none of the language that could trigger some snowflake in Washington."
Mielke, a Republican, said she agreed with Lesher and that Talbot County has always been a merit-based employer.
Stepp, a Republican, said council members "fell short" and put the county in a vulnerable spot when they rejected his original proposal in March.
"It's very frustrating that we even need to be discussing this here today. It should've been dealt with months ago," Stepp said. "This matter has been highly politicized and turned into something it is not."
"Today's action is fiscal in nature," he added.
Council President Chuck Callahan, a Republican, voted to remove the statement in March and did so again Tuesday. He said the controversial topic — which garnered strong resident opposition and led to two heated meetings — has been "tough on council."
"I know we all have our own beliefs, one way or the other with the DEI stuff," Callahan said. "But at this time I think we've made the right decision and the right statement."
Haythe, the council's only non-white member and a Democrat, asked county attorney Patrick Thomas about an opinion letter he provided on the DEI statement and Duffy's directive. Duffy's directive to all DOT funding recipients referenced the U.S. Supreme Court's 2023 rejection of affirmative action programs at Harvard University.
"I do not believe that the statement is discriminatory, and I do not believe that the Supreme Court (case) being referenced in the secretary of transportation letter applies to that statement," Thomas said.
Tuesday's resolution, effectively immediately, voids Talbot County's DEI statement. Two 2020 diversity resolutions are also "of no further force and effect," according to the newly approved resolution.
Those resolutions had facilitated the creation of the diversity statement and required the county manager to provide an annual diversity training report to the council, respectively.
The new resolution states nothing in it "shall be construed as a repudiation of the intent and desire" of the county to ensure a "welcoming workplace" in which employees are treated fairly based on race, sex, national origin, etc.
Lesher asked county staff to work on a "replacement welcoming statement" for the county's employee handbook.
AIRPORT PROJECT
Easton Airport's ongoing modernization project — which will relocate and expand the airport's main runway — is 90% funded by the Federal Aviation Administration, an organization within the Department of Transportation. The airport is owned and operated by Talbot County.
Airport Manager Micah Risher said he consulted with county staff after the April DOT letter. In an interview Tuesday, Risher said he has "absolute faith" in the council's support of the airport. Risher added that the airport ensures it is always abiding by federal and state laws.
"To have Easton Airport have any sort of funding at jeopardy, it's a bigger deal than the average person may think," Risher said, citing the airport's large economic impact on the community.
According to Risher, the airport received around $17 million from the FAA for the first two phases of the project. Estimates on the remaining federal funding for the rest of the project aren't available since bids are out, he said, but over $30 million of work remains.
"We're up here against our greatest milestone that is really going to ensure that we have a viable airport, and this great economic engine, succeed here in Talbot County for another 80-plus years," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton election cycle has been charged, political in nature
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton election cycle has been charged, political in nature

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 869
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton saw a heated election the last time the council president seat was up for grabs. This year's race is no different.Since campaigns for the three open Town Council seats began this winter, there have been stolen and vandalized campaign signs, tense debates on campaign finance transparency and, most recently, political mailers from Republican-endorsed candidates calling out Mayor Megan Cook.
The tenor of the election cycle — which culminates with voting Tuesday — is largely influenced by the race for Town Council president between incumbent Frank Gunsallus and current Ward 2 representative Don Abbatiello.
At a town hall Tuesday, both candidates offered thoughts on civility.
"In the past two years, the council members overall, have been almost always conducting themselves in a civil manner," said Gunsallus. "There are times where debate may get heated. That is the nature of democracy."
"Arguing is fine, I get it. Disagreements occur," Abbatiello said. "But it needs to be done in a respectful manner."
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry, who has endorsed Abbatiello, said the charged nature of this election isn't normal for Easton. And it's hurting the town, she says.
"Anytime you create an environment based on animosity, it becomes counterproductive, fairly quickly," Curry said. "And I think that's sort of where we are today."
Talbot County Republican Central Committee vice chair Shari Wilcoxon believes a reason the race is so intense is that it's a fight to preserve Easton's charm.
"People love our little town. It's a jewel," she said. "And we had a lot of people move here during COVID because they wanted to get out of the crud to come to this little town. A lot of us want to preserve that."
ENDORSEMENTS
As Gunsallus and Abbatiello square off, they have racked up endorsements from local politicians and even fellow council members.
Abbatiello received endorsements from Curry and, in a surprise to some, Ward 3's David Montgomery, who had sided with Gunsallus on several contentious matters discussed by the council in the past year.
"It would be very hard for us to move forward productively for the next four years under that kind of leadership," Montgomery said of Gunsallus.
Curry says Abbatiello's experience and knowledge make him the best candidate. "He has the right temperament," she said.
Meanwhile, Gunsallus' main endorsements come from Republican leaders — the Republican Central Committee, Sheriff Joe Gamble, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Dels. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson.
Wilcoxon said the committee looked at values — not necessarily party affiliation — when endorsing Gunsallus and mother-and-son newcomers Lynn and Cameron Keefe, who are running in Wards 2 and 4, respectively.
"To me he's a phenomenal leader," Wilcoxon said of Gunsallus, citing his thoughtfulness and transparency.
"He's not afraid to ask questions," Mautz said. " ... Sometimes, the questions may seem silly. And other times, they may reveal things that most people aren't aware of."
Abbatiello and his supporters have denounced the involvement of political parties in the town's election, which is nonpartisan and doesn't list candidates alongside a party.
"I do not think that the Republican Party platform has anything to do with the issues that we face here in Easton, and so I don't understand why the party has decided to intervene so strongly in a local election," Montgomery, a Republican, said.
Mautz said while the election is performed as nonpartisan, it is political in nature. "Every election has got politics baked into it," he said.
"I think that everybody fools themselves if they say it's nonpartisan," Wilcoxon said. "Everybody knows. Everybody knows everybody's party. We can just cut the pretending, right?"
Flavio Hickel, an associate professor of political science at Washington College, sees both sides of the argument.
"Broadly speaking, I don't think it's a good idea to allow for local party endorsements or to make nonpartisan elections partisan, because you are allowing partisanship to interfere in local town government," Hickel said.
However, Hickel said knowing which parties candidates align with is informative for voters, especially at a local level.
"Most voters probably aren't familiar with the candidates running," he said. " ... What party identity does at all levels of elections is it provides a very quick information shortcut for voters."
Curry and Montgomery's endorsements have raised questions, too.
Wilcoxon said she views Montgomery's opposition to Gunsallus as personal and said she believes Montgomery and Cook's sponsorship of a campaign finance ordinance was "100%" an attack on Gunsallus' campaign.
At the town hall Tuesday, Gunsallus spoke of council endorsements: "I would not want an endorsement from a fellow council member because I believe that that is out of bounds," he said. Then he made a remark seemingly concerning Montgomery.
"And especially one of them, I would not accept it."
Montgomery disputed that claim, telling The Star Democrat Friday that Gunsallus asked for his endorsement a few months ago, but that he declined.
Curry said she hadn't before made an endorsement as a sitting council member, but that she gave a "great deal of thought" in endorsing Abbatiello.
In her eyes, the discourse around endorsements and political sides are making the campaign heated, instead of what she'd rather the election be centered on: issues such as growth and housing.
"There's too much of the 'he said,' 'he said,' and he's backed by this guy and he's backed by this guy," Curry said. "The issues have taken a back seat, and that's wrong."

title: This Juneteenth, let's prioritize education policy
author: TROY ROLLING
content:
This Juneteenth, let's prioritize education policy

 June 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TROY ROLLING | Section: Columns 
 
 703
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On June 19, the United States will commemorate Juneteenth, or National Independence Day — the federal holiday celebrated annually to commemorate the ending of slavery. Scholars have described Juneteenth as a celebration of the legacy of Frederick Douglass, the famed Maryland abolitionist, orator and writer who influenced tens of thousands of people about the evils of slavery and urged the nation to abide by its espoused principles.Time and time again, Douglass demonstrated education's importance in breaking the cycles of poverty and oppression.
Born into slavery on the Eastern Shore, he secretly learned to read and write, realizing that knowledge was vital to freedom. His journey from bondage to intellectual empowerment confirmed his lifelong assertion that education is the essential ingredient to liberation and equality.
Through his speeches, writings and political actions, Douglass emphasized that ignorance was a tool of oppression, and that education was crucial for social and economic advancement. His mentorship and influence inspired future generations to use education to combat racial injustice and achieve greater equality, demonstrating how education is vital in the fight for civil rights and equality for all.
Our organization has worked tirelessly to ensure these principles permeate every aspect of our society. Unfortunately, however, two centuries later, some of Maryland's elected representatives appear to be forgetting the lessons that Douglass taught us on the importance of taking accountability for education to give our citizens the opportunity to succeed.
Upon review of these statistics, we should all be alarmed and demand that those currently and seeking to represent us provide their educational plans. Prince George's County served as a salient example. Although one of the wealthiest majority African American counties in the United States, with a median household income of nearly $100,000, the county is dead last in statewide education rankings. The graduation rate is less than 75%, the second-worst ranking in the state, behind only Baltimore City, where 23 schools have existing challenges.
Instead of improving, too many of the children are being left behind. Last year, the county's high schools underperformed every single state education target and four of the schools lost a star in the state's ranking system. Given these starting statistics, it is little wonder why, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, income inequality and other social injustices continue to increase in the county year-over-year.
It will take committed elected leadership to make the changes required to make a difference. Yet, when asked about the school system's challenges, County Executive Angela Alsobrooks responded, "Not my responsibility."
This answer is especially worrisome because Ms. Alsobrooks is now a nominee for the U.S. Senate. As a senator, she would have the power to break the cycles of educational bankruptcy by pushing for these policies on the federal level, but her comments should make all of us pause. Worse yet, Ms. Alsobrooks recently announced that she opposes charter schools and school choice, which rescue marginalized students from failing schools.
Patrick Wolf, a professor in educational policy, found that "the 19 most rigorous scientific studies of private school-choice programs find that they tend to have positive effects on student achievement, especially several years after students have entered a private school of their parents' choosing," increasing their chances of graduating from high school, attending college and receiving a college degree.
African Americans and underserved communities are the primary beneficiaries of these policies. Recent polling shows that 79% of Black parents support school choice and 74% support charter schools.
As Frederick Douglass once profoundly stated, "It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men." Indeed. Education creates a cycle of success for future generations, leading to a more informed, resilient, and prosperous society. By breaking the chains of ignorance and poverty, it builds the foundation for strong, thriving communities that can overcome challenges and achieve collective progress.
On this Juneteenth, let us pay tribute to his legacy by recognizing and acting upon Douglass' vital lesson. By re-prioritizing education policy in the Maryland political landscape, we will honor Douglass' memory and sacrifice while paving the way for a more just and equitable future, filled with hope and opportunity.
Troy Rolling is chairman of the Frederick Douglass Foundation, a Washington, D.C.-based national education nonprofit that does Christian work based on the life and legacy of Frederick Douglass. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Legislators, local officials differ on unhoused individuals bill
author: Konner Metz
content:
Legislators, local officials differ on unhoused individuals bill

 February 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A bill filed in Annapolis to enshrine rights for homeless individuals is drawing differing opinions from advocates and local officials.House Bill 487, and its paired Senate Bill 484, would protect the ability of homeless individuals to partake in "life-sustaining activities" such as sleeping, eating or drinking, in public places so long as traffic is not obstructed.
If passed, any civil or criminal punishment against an unhoused individual who is on public land without an "adequate alternative indoor" space would be considered cruel and unusual punishment.
According to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's most recent data, Maryland's homeless population in 2023 was 5,865 individuals, both sheltered and unsheltered.
Del. Bernice Mireku North (D-Montgomery), the bill's sponsor, and other advocates say the proposed legislation comes in response to a Supreme Court decision last June that ruled it was not cruel and unusual punishment for local governments to civilly and criminally penalize homeless people for setting up encampments on public land.
Mireku-North wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat that the proposed bill has "brought to light the heart-led efforts" of local governments to support unhoused individuals. An emphasis of the bill is to prevent immediate arrests, she said.
"At a minimum, we are asking law enforcement to prioritize inquiring whether an alternative indoor space exists for unhoused people engaging in life-sustaining activities before resorting to arrest," Mireku-North wrote.
The delegate said legislators are "committed" to working with local officials and stakeholders on the bill.
Allie Post, director of development and communications for The Women's Law Center of Maryland, said the bill would be a measure in which the state "(stands) up for folks proactively" following the June Supreme Court ruling.
"Especially for survivors (of domestic violence) and survivors of color, homelessness is often a price of leaving an abuser," Post said. "And folks who have less financial means and less flexibility in those means are really put between a rock and a hard place, and this is an opportunity for Maryland to step up and start taking seriously the homelessness problem that we have."
While advocates say it's a needed step forward in the path to address Maryland's homelessness crisis, some Easton and Talbot County officials say the bill is endangering the efforts already being taken.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and the Sheriff's Office released a video on Facebook last month depicting what they believe a potential encounter could look like with a homeless individual if the bill is passed.
"If these were to pass, we could have homeless encampments in Idlewild Park, (the) courthouse," Gamble said in a separate video the department shared. " … You literally could set up a tent on the 50-yard-line at Easton High School before an Easton football game and call it your home, and we would not be able to move those people."
Gamble said the homelessness issue is serious in Talbot County and that he's not against addressing it. However, he believes the bill as written will strip away authority of locally elected officials.
"They will not be able to follow the zoning laws that they've put into place to make downtown Easton the place it is, or downtown St. Michaels or downtown Oxford to be those nice places that people want to come to visit and spend their hard-earned money," Gamble said in an interview. "They will have absolutely no control over it."
Easton Mayor Megan Cook addressed the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee in a Feb. 5 letter opposing the bill.
Cook wrote that the bill "would supersede local ordinance and policies that have been carefully crafted to address the needs of both unhoused individuals and the broader community."
"By prohibiting local and state officials from enforcing reasonable regulations on the use of public spaces, the bill could lead to unintended consequences that compromise public safety, hinder economic development, and create significant enforcement challenges," Cook wrote.
In her letter, Cook asked legislators to instead focus on policies that would provide funding for housing assistance, mental health and job programs.
"Our community is committed to addressing homelessness with dignity and care—through outreach, support services, and housing initiatives—while also ensuring that public spaces remain accessible and safe for all," Cook wrote. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland stories: College hosts Memorial Day ceremony and flag planting
author: WHIG STAFF REPORT
content:
Maryland stories: College hosts Memorial Day ceremony and flag planting

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WHIG STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Cecil College Student Veterans Club hosted a Memorial Day Commemoration Ceremony on the school's campus honoring those who died during war and in military service to the U.S.Cecil College faculty, staff and students were joined by the members of the local community as well as local veterans, who gathered to plant flags in memory of a veteran special to them on Monday, May 20, and Tuesday, May 21.
At noon during both ceremonies, TAPS was played. The traditional closing bugle call honored the sacrifice of those who gave their lives in defense of America.
The college also put up a "Static Flag Display" featuring the flags of different branches of the military surrounding the American flag. According to college officials, the display will remain on exhibit through Memorial Day on Monday.
Alongside the ceremony, the Student Veterans Club hosted a contest which asked community members to answer the question: "What does Memorial Day mean to me?"
Contestants were encouraged to submit written, video and photographical entries, which were reviewed by a panel of judges.
The winning entries were an essay by Gavin Roger and a drawing by Ashley Kifer, both students at Bohemia Manor High School. Both Roger and Kifer attended the event.

title: Local chef nominated for James Beard Award
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Local chef nominated for James Beard Award

 February 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although Bas Rouge is getting national attention, it is a local restaurant at its core.On its menu, passion for the Chesapeake takes center stage, says Executive Chef Harley Peet. His efforts to celebrate the Eastern Shore's people and ecology have helped land him on the shortlist for one of the culinary industry's most prestigious awards.
The James Beard Foundation has named Peet as a semifinalist for best chef in the Mid-Atlantic region. Just getting considered is a "huge deal" for the team at Bas Rouge, the executive chef said.
"I have never pursued it because I was so intimidated by it. But then I built this amazing team, and Mr. (Paul) Prager, the owner, helped me build this amazing team and put this amazing restaurant together," Peet said. "... Then we started getting the influx. Going for the James Beard built a lot of confidence in myself and in my team."
Established in 1990 and first awarded in 1991, the James Beard Foundation's Restaurant and Chef Awards recognize exceptional talent and achievement in the culinary arts, hospitality, media and broader food system, as well as a demonstrated commitment to racial and gender equity, community, sustainability and a culture where all can thrive, according to the James Beard website.
Nominees for the award will be announced on Wednesday, April 3, and winners will be announced at the James Beard Restaurant and Chef Awards Ceremony on Monday, June 10.
The Bas Rouge team draws inspiration from the endless bounty of the Chesapeake to inform its menu, which offers European-style dishes made with local ingredients.
"Every year, every turn of the season it absolutely floors me with something that tastes even better," Peet said. "The natural shift of final products that are coming out of the Bay or coming out of the fields in the summer, they continuously always get better. The purveyors, and the growers and the foragers that we deal with are constantly trying to find something better, something more mind blowing."
"This is a miraculous thing about this area. It never disappoints," he said.
These local ingredients are transformed into elegant dishes in Bas Rouge's kitchen, including the restaurant's lunchtime favorite wiener schnitzel, an array of oysters and, when the chefs have it in, a Dover sole that Peet says draws diners from as far as D.C.
"It is food that we love and have a passion to cook and eat," Peet said. "I think the idea of taking a raw ingredient from the Chesapeake Bay or from a field delivered to the back door by a forager. What do you do in these small towns? You fish, you hunt, you gather because it is fun. It is part of the lifestyle here. So as far as what the food is about and has to say, the food is about myself and my team taking as much local (as we can), accented with fine imported ingredients because of course you have to have some diversity."
"We have a hyper focus on what we have right here," he said.
But beyond the Chesapeake's flora and fauna, Peet said that he has decades of lived experiences on the Eastern Shore from which he draws inspiration.
He recalled one time 20 years ago when he was just out of culinary school and his first assignment was on Tilghman Island. He was using oysters in a dish, but he wanted to know where the ingredients came from.
There was a bus boy who also worked as a waterman. Peet got an invitation to go oystering.
"So I am up there in my sailing gear. And these watermen are laughing at me. They are in white rubber boots and Grundens, and I am out there in Haley Hansen and Patagonia. They said, 'You know we are about to get dirty?' And I said, 'Alright, let's do it.'"
He learned by doing. He learned how oyster tonging works, how dredging works and how patent tonging works. He even learned how certain boats are rigged.
"If you don't understand that, then preparing (the ingredient) and serving it lacks a little passion. We have a round-about 360-degree connection with that. Terroir is a number one," said Peet.

title: Scheffler wants it all at Tour Championship
author: Roberto Jozef
content:
Scheffler wants it all at Tour Championship

 August 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Roberto Jozef | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 353
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The culminating event of the PGA Tour is upon us, as the 2023 PGA Tour Championship tees off Aug. 23 to 27 at the East Lake Golf Club in Atlanta. Preliminary rounds air live on the Golf Channel, while CBS offers live coverage of the final rounds Saturday, Aug. 26, and Sunday, Aug. 27.Born June 21, 1996, in Ridgewood, New Jersey, Scheffler spent most of his young life in Dallas. Before turning pro, Scheffler won the individual state title three years in a row and further sharpened his skills at the University of Texas, where he earned multiple all-American honors and helped his team win a national championship.Bursting onto the professional golf scene in 2018, the American hasn't missed a beat, climbing the ranks and proving to the golf world that he's here to stay. One of Scheffler's standout moments came during the 2020 PGA Championship when he made history by shooting the lowest score ever recorded in a major by a rookie.This season, Scheffler is at it again, sitting at the top of the standings in both the world rankings and money leaderboard, earning over $18 million.He has had seven consecutive top-five finishes - the longest streak since Tiger Woods - and his 2.81 strokes gained tee-to-green this season is one of the best single-season paces for any player in the PGA since tracking began two years ago. Adding to an already impressive season, Scheffler is making a bogey or worse just 10.1% of the time, keeping him on pace for the lowest rate since - once again - Tiger Woods in 2000 (9.8). 
 
 Memo: Full name: Scott Alexander Scheffler Birthdate: June 21, 1996 (27) Birthplace: Ridgewood, New Jersey Height/weight: 6-3/200 pounds PGA Tour wins: 6 Family ties: Has three sisters, Callie, Molly and Sarah - sister Callie played golf at Texas A & M and caddied for her brother when he competed as an amateur in the 2017 U.S.
 
Open Honors and achievements: PGA Tour Rookie of the Year (2019), PGA Tour leading money winner (2021-22), PGA Tour Player of the Year (2021-22), Best Golfer ESPY Award (2023), winner of the 2023 Solution is on page 19. Players Championship

title: celebrityfacts

celebrityfacts

title: A fresh look: Northern Ireland's troubled history is traced in PBS documentary
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
A fresh look: Northern Ireland's troubled history is traced in PBS documentary

 August 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Typically and logically, some of the most telling documents of history are those related by people who actually lived through the given times.The timeline of the strains of life in Northern Ireland is well-known, and it gets first-person treatment in a PBS documentary that spans five parts and three nights. After first being presented as a streaming offering via the network's digital avenues last May, "Once Upon a Time in Northern Ireland" makes its broadcast premiere nightly from Monday, Aug. 28, through Wednesday, Aug. 30 (check local listings).Co-produced with PBS with England's BBC and BBC Northern Ireland, the program by filmmaker James Bluemel showcases the memories of individuals who experienced daily challenges over the course of more than three decades, from the late 1960s - and the start of what were known as The Troubles, which ultimately cost an estimated 3500-plus lives - to the signing of the Belfast/Good Friday Agreement in 1998.The Troubles technically began in 1966 with the Ulster Volunteer Army's opposition to the Irish Republican Army punctuated by several attacks on Catholics.As detailed in the program's opening hour, "It Wasn't Like a Movie Anymore," the situation festered over several years and ultimately erupted into Bloody Sunday, the 1972 event that saw British soldiers shoot 26 unarmed civilians during a protest in Derry, Northern Ireland. Thirteen of the wounded died on the exact day, and one more succumbed to his injuries after several months.Part 2, "Do Paramilitaries Lie Awake at Night?," picks up in the immediate aftermath of the massacre as other instances of violence occurred. While Catholics and Protestants were very divided in the face of bombings and rigid paramilitary patrols, young people on each side of the conflict found punk music to be a respite, particularly in giving voice to their emotions.The third part, "So Many Broken Hearts," recalls how alarmingly common the discord in Northern Ireland became - encompassing assassinations and car bombings. Also, a hunger strike was waged by IRA prisoners to protest the policies of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.In Part 4, "The Dirty War," the documentary moves along to the late 1980s. The ongoing violence was supplemented by an increase in the information war while the physical one raged on, with efforts to infiltrate paramilitary groups used as attempts to stop the conflict from within. Considerable paranoia resulted, as very few people were sure who to trust.The concluding portion, "Who Wants to Live Like That?," involves a major diplomatic controversy: namely, U.S. President Bill Clinton's 1994 White House invitation to Gerry Adams, the then-leader of the Sinn Fein party, which was associated at the time with the Irish Republican Army. That move drew sharply differing reactions, but the same year, the IRA announced a ceasefire (which would last until 1996). Later in 1994, loyalist paramilitaries also issued a ceasefire, contingent on "the continued cessation of all nationalist/republican violence." History bears out that the legacy of The Troubles continued for years, but "Once Upon a Time in Northern Ireland" covers much of the essential information comprehensively. And a great deal of it remains troubling today. 
 
 Caption: James as featured in "Once Upon a Time in Northern Ireland"

title: Easton Postal Service short staffing causes late mail deliveries
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Easton Postal Service short staffing causes late mail deliveries

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton resident Bart Pelstring has experienced late mail delivery for about two months now, and he believes his neighbors and other Easton residents have experienced the same issue.Pelstring said that he has consistently received his mail between 1 and 3 p.m. But for the past few months, Pelstring said delivery times have been "unacceptable."
"I noticed that there were times when no mail was delivered," Pelstring said. "I have neighbors that said the same thing, and then we noticed that mail was being delivered at seven or eight o'clock at night, and sometimes later than that."
Pelstring called the Post Office to speak to the post master and the response he got alarmed him, he said.
"I called to speak to the postmaster, and they told me he was out delivering mail," Pelstring said. "The girl I talked to, she said, 'well we're short staffed, we don't have enough people anymore, and we don't have backup people.'"
Mark Wahl, a strategic communications specialist for the postal service in Washington, D.C., Maryland and Virginia, detailed the Easton location's recent challenges.
"We recently experienced challenges with employee availability that did impact mail deliveries," he said. "We have taken specific actions to continue service to our valued customers."
The actions Easton Post Office plans to take include:
Authorizing overtime to allow employees to work the time necessary to deliver mail.Expanding mail deliveries to earlier in the morning and later in the evening.And using additional carriers from nearby offices to maintain mail deliveries.
"We appreciate customers' patience and understanding and expect staffing to be restored to normal levels soon," Wahl said. "With our carriers delivering later in the evening, often when it's dark, we kindly ask customers to keep porch lights on for our employees' safety."

title: Rankin and Davis: The Star Democrat's picks for Wards 2 and 4
author: Staff Writer
content:
Rankin and Davis: The Star Democrat's picks for Wards 2 and 4

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Star Democrat recommends votes for Robert Rankin in the Ward 2 Easton Town Council Election and for the Rev. Elmer Davis in Ward 4.ROBERT RANKIN
Robert Rankin is a newcomer to Easton politics, yet he displayed a firm grasp of the issues facing the town.
We liked his stands on issues, and most importantly, we liked that he admitted when he needed more information before voicing a conclusive opinion on issues we asked about.
Rankin's professionalism was evident. He called for a multi-faceted approach to increasing affordable housing in Easton, stressing the need to get more housing that is affordable for young families. His suggestions included working with developers to provide incentives, looking for more projects with townhomes and apartments, and redeveloping existing properties. It was a thoughtful answer.
Rankin also talked about his concerns on how new residential developments impact traffic, parking, schools and public safety. He wants an emphasis on a more strategic approach to approving future projects.
He wants to see more pedestrian-friendly and traffic calming features throughout the town. One suggestion included more crosswalks and sidewalks to better support pedestrian safety.
He was the only candidate to talk about increasing recreational opportunities on the east side of Route 50 where the majority of Ward 2 is located.
He suggested looking at retirement packages to assist in recruiting and retaining police officers in Easton.
One last note: Rankin has managed trade associations during his career. He knows what it is like to build consensus among many competing interests. Those will be valuable skills on the council.
THE REV. ELMER DAVIS
The Rev. Elmer Davis has long been a voice for people in the 4th Ward. He is also a voice of reason in the city during council meetings. Davis is not afraid to speak his mind, but his background as a preacher and pastor helps him look for common ground.
Davis noted his position on the Town Council dais. As the Ward 4 council member, he is the last one called to voice an opinion on discussion topics. This gives him a chance to hear all of the other council members. Often his message is one of finding consensus in disparate views.
"I aim to continue bridging the gap between the council and the people I represent, ensuring every voice is heard and valued," he said.
Davis was prophetic when he asked the question in our interview: "What do we want Easton to be?"
His multi-part answer is a walkable community with sufficient traffic infrastructure to keep the town moving. He suggested a bus service from hotels to downtown to get visitors to the shops that make Easton special. He was solution oriented.
Davis called for ensuring that first responders have the equipment and resources to respond to any incident.
He offered the best option we have heard for building affordable housing in the community — having the town purchase land and then partnering with organizations such as Habitat for Humanity to build the homes, involving the future homeowner in the process.
He said the town needs affordable housing "that people working at WaWa and McDonald's can afford."
He wants the council involved in approving housing projects in Easton. The Planning Commission, he said, should be making recommendations, not granting approvals.
One of his two opponents, Moonyene Jackson-Amis, would be our pick if Davis had not been doing such a fine job during his five years on the council. She is a former council member, an attorney and a community leader with multiple college degrees. She spoke passionately in our conversations about underrepresented communities in Easton. She continues to be a foundational rock in our town.
But Davis is our pick to continue his work on the council. He has done well these past five years, and he has become the face of Ward 4 with deep connections throughout the community.
Davis has experience, civility and strong ties to the community. He talks about his close-knit connection to his roots in the community shaping his values.
"I believe there is still much work to be done to enhance the quality of life for our residents," Davis said. We agree, and the reverend is the person to do that.

title: Defense fuels Cambridge-SD past Warriors
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Defense fuels Cambridge-SD past Warriors

 February 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 739
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cambridge-South Dorchester High's boys basketball team arrived in Easton Thursday night having already won the North Bayside.The way the Vikings played, you would have thought the division title was still on the line.
Sophomore Semaj Pinder scored a team-high 19 points and four others finished in double figures, as Cambridge-SD, behind an overwhelming defense, rolled to a 79-60 victory over the Warriors.
The Vikings (19-1 overall, 15-1 North Bayside) now prepare to play Stephen Decatur for the Bayside Conference championship next Tuesday at the Wicomico County Civic Center in Salisbury.
"Old fashion butt kicking," Easton head coach Dionte Hynson said after the Warriors' second most lopsided loss of the season. "Congratulations to them. They were the better team tonight. I thought they brought a whole lot of energy. We didn't match their energy tonight. First quarter, came out, played well. And then after that."
Easton (14-6, 13-3) led 12-5 with a little over 3 minutes remaining in the first quarter. Cambridge-SD sophomore Sterling Perkins (17 points) converted a steal into a layup. Darren Belizare turned another steal into a layup. Pinder then buried a 3-pointer to forge a 12-12 tie heading into the second quarter.
Cambridge-SD continued to hound the Warriors defensively and took control of the game, outscoring Easton, 21-11 in the second quarter.
"We got a chip on our shoulder," said Cambridge-SD head coach Shawn Tucker, who was minus starting point guard LaShaun Moody. "We're the underdogs we feel like every game we're going in. There's so much negativity that goes with these C-SD boys. And they just fight and fight. They're resilient. And they represent me. I'm wild. I'm passionate. I'm full of energy."
So were the Vikings.
Easton shaved a seven-point deficit to 25-21 when sophomore guard Marshall Bailey (18 points) hit a pair of free throws with 2:36 left in the second quarter. But Perkins and junior Koby Ennals (12 points) drained back-to-back 3-pointers before a Kamarion Hall's bucket capped an 8-0 run, that helped the Vikings to a 33-23 halftime lead.
"I give all props to my assistant coaches, also my defensive coach, Ryan Waters," Tucker said. "He has those guys locked in on defense. And we've been pressuring teams for the last seven games. We're just relentless on that."
After letting a 17-point third-quarter lead get away in a 58-57 loss to Queen Anne's on Feb. 1, Cambridge-SD has reeled off seven straight wins.
Easton scored the last five points of the third quarter to pull within 50-41 at the end of the third quarter. But the Warriors wouldn't get any closer, as the Vikings outscored their longtime rival, 29-19, in the fourth quarter.
"They were shooting the heck out of the ball tonight," Hynson said of the Vikings. "Their zero (Perkins) and their number 12 (Pinder), they were shooting the ball real well.
"Our defense was horrible," Hynson added. "We were just sitting there watching their shooters. And we were giving up too many straight line drives to the basket. We'll learn from it. Like I told them, it's over and done with. Just got to move on and get ready for playoffs."
Ja'Kai Brooks led Easton with 19 points.
Jaden Harris had 12 points for Cambridge-SD and Anthony Hughes added 10.
"We got four goals and we just accomplished one of them," said Tucker of winning the North Bayside.
QUEEN ANNE'S 76 KENT ISLAND 73
CENTREVILLE — Vince Gilberto scored 19 points and Collin Woolford went over the 1,000-point mark for his career as the Lions outlasted their county rival in overtime.
Amari Baynard had 15 points for Queen Anne's (16-4, 14-2) and Jadereon Thompson had 13.
SSPP 56, JEMICY 41
OWINGS MILLS — Brayden Smith had 18 points and Aaron Ewing netted 10 as Saints Peter and Paul improved to 14-8 overall, 7-3 in the Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association C Conference.
COL. RICHARDSON 93 NORTH CAROLINE 75
AMERICAN CORNER — Dreden Lake scored 23 points and Jazir Dickerson added 20 to pace the Colonels.
Makiah Batson had 15 points and Manny Wallace 12 for Colonel Richardson.
North Caroline's Nasai Bell led all scorers with 24 points. Jarvis Thomas had 17 and Tyson Weber and Quinell Gross each had 12.
GIRLS BASKETBALL
QUEEN ANNE'S 49 KENT ISLAND 33
CENTREVILLE — Kariana Hickson scored 18 points as the Lions clinched the North Bayside title.
Freshmen Laila Coles had 13 points for Queen Anne's (19-1, 16-0) and Bea Holthaus had 11.
NORTH CAROLINE 58 COL. RICHARDSON 28
RIDGELY — Ashleigh Lawry scored 18 points and Selaya Garrison finished with 16 to power the Bulldogs (13-6). Malayah Phillips finished with 12.

title: Caroline Cares connects community with services at Resource Day
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Cares connects community with services at Resource Day

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Multiple vendors at Caroline Cares Community Resource Day Wednesday were reminded how amazing it is to do community work and help others.His Hope Ministries Youth Director Desiree Jefferson distributed winter clothes at the event. She was one of many vendors who had previously attended the event not to distribute resources, but to receive them.
"It's really refreshing to be able to give back," Jefferson said. "Just a couple years ago, I was somebody that was coming through the doors and receiving services myself, so it's good to see that we can help families in need."
The Caroline Cares Community Resource Day featured around 40 vendors providing information, help and food to the community.
"This is what it's all about," said Stephanie Johnson, His Hope Ministries' executive director and board member for Resources Day. "Just getting all the resources in one building so that it can be kind of an easily accessible for those who need them the most. Being able to bring those providers under one roof, on a specific day, to get those services out to everybody who needs them is huge."
One of the main focuses for Resource Day is providing many different types of help for many different people.
Some attendees face expenses they can't afford or are just in a bad financial situation, and some people are homeless. Resources Day helped with a variety of situations.
Directors expect 100 to 150 county residents experiencing homelessness to attend Resources Day every year, and they have a plan to make sure homeless residents can find shelter.
"With this particular event, they have access to walk around, talk to the vendors and see what exactly what their services are that they provide," Johnson said. "However, like when it comes to those who are actually experiencing homelessness, we have a separate room set aside for them to really dig into what their needs are and see how we can connect them with services."
Caroline County Public Schools officials attended, providing information for children on enrollment in school and many different resources for mental and physical health. United4Caroline provided free diapers for families with infants.
Chesapeake College's nursing program provided free blood pressure checks for all people in attendance. Nursing students gained experience and enjoyed serving the community.
"Oh, I love this, and I'm actually from Denton myself, so to give back to the community is amazing," Katie Reuwer, an assistant professor at Chesapeake College, said. "It's a great experience for the students to really learn about community service and helping others. I've already had some really good feedback from the students about how much they enjoy it."
Staff from Studio 107 Hair Salon in Kent Island and Edwards All Star Barbershop in Denton enjoyed providing free haircuts and styles at Resource Day, something both shops provide every year.
"There's no better feeling," Lisa Milligan, owner of Studio 107, said. "You're helping people that are maybe down on their luck or they're just getting out of jail or they're just going for jobs. It's every aspect, older people that can't afford to get their hair cut especially in this economy. So it's great to give back."

title: Hosler at 100 and counting
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Hosler at 100 and counting

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As Queen Anne's County High's boys soccer team prepared for its victory jog across the field Wednesday night, a handful of Lions coaxed head coach Wade Hosler to find a place in line and join the run.Hosler made it halfway across the field then started applauding.
"It's senior night," he said. "Let them have it."
It was also the night Hosler earned his 100th career victory, as Jamison Kendall's first-half goal proved enough in a 1-0 victory over a no-quit North Dorchester bunch, keeping the Lions atop the North Bayside.
"I guess it means I'm getting old," said a smiling Hosler of his milestone. "I didn't really sit down and think about it too much. It's been a lot of tremendous players, a lot of great assistant coaches, administration. A lot of people have helped me along the way.
"It's been an amazing journey," continued Hosler, now in his 13th season at the helm. "We have great kids. They come out and they work hard every year. We graduate good kids, and good kids fill their shoes. So it's a good place to be. If it wasn't I wouldn't have lasted this long."
With their fourth win in five games, the Lions (5-3 overall, 5-0 North Bayside) remained in first place in the division via their fourth one-goal win of the season.
"It's always a little stressful," Hosler said of senior night. "We didn't finish the ball, which makes it difficult. We finish a couple more early (chances) and it would be a different game. But we don't put the ball in the back of the net and it becomes a struggle."
Queen Anne's got four corner-kick chances in the opening 15 minutes but couldn't convert. And though the Lions controlled possession for much of the first half, the Eagles (4-4-1, 1-4-1) found openings and opportunities, the biggest coming with 26 minutes, 18 seconds remaining, when Christian Chase drilled a strike off the crossbar.
The Lions cranked up the intensity on the offensive end, with James Rath sending a pair of shots on goal that North Dorchester keeper Jayden Coleman stopped. But with just under 18 minutes left before half, the Lions worked the ball down the right side and over to Kendall, who steered a left-footed shot past Coleman for a 1-0 lead.
"We had good pressure," Eagles head coach Gabe Guzman said. "It's one of those nights where things don't fall your way and you have to live with the results. Unfortunately, we had one mistake in the back end."
Queen Anne's continued building chances toward padding its lead in the second half. Coleman stopped Trey Moore's header with 27:27 to go. Kendall was denied with 13:30 remaining and Rath unloaded a drive wide left 2 minutes later.
North Dorchester pushed into the Lions end in the final 5 minutes in a bid for the equalizer. Senior captain Chris Sanchez, who booted a number of long clears and balls into the Queen Anne's end throughout the game, drove a direct kick wide left with a little over 5 minutes left. The Eagles got a corner with 3 minutes to go, but couldn't muster a shot.
About a minute later, the Eagles sent a through ball into the box. But Lions sophomore keeper Braeden Livingston sprinted off his line and scooped the ball before anyone else could get a touch.
"It makes it stressful," Hosler said of his team's one-goal wins. "But hey, we're playing well. We're still undefeated in the North. And I'm proud of the way we grind. It's not pretty. We're not finishing as many opportunities as we would like, but we keep grinding. We keep fighting. And we find a way to win."
Guzman also liked his team's fight, and with a little work, hopes to be a force in the Class 1A East playoffs.
"We're still working things out," said Guzman, whose team is 4-1-1 against 1A competition this season. "Finishing is still a little bit of an issue. It's a work in progress. Hopefully come playoff time we won't have that issue.
"Kudos to them," Guzman added of Hosler and Queen Anne's. "Hundredth win. That's a wonderful feat. Hopefully one day I'll be there. But they did their job."

title: Religion Calendar
author: Angela Price
content:
Religion Calendar

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Angela Price | Section: Religion Calendar 
 
 2762

title: Easton leans away from annexing new land in comprehensive plan update
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton leans away from annexing new land in comprehensive plan update

 September 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 728
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As planners draft Easton's new comprehensive plan, the town's direction on annexing new land is becoming clear: slow down.At a workshop Monday, the Easton Planning Commission chose to retain language in the comprehensive plan update that discourages new annexations in the next 10 years.
As recently as last year, Easton annexed around 17 acres of county land east of U.S. Route 50 between the Royal Farms and Unitarian Universalist Fellowship. It's expected to become an affordable housing project, though the developer will still need town approval on an application.
Town Council members have indicated concerns about annexing additional land into town, especially as Easton deals with the question of whether it's maxing out on residential growth.
The comprehensive plan, last updated in 2010, is undergoing revisions before potential council approval later this year or early next year. It outlines how the town aims to grow in the next decade, touching on areas such as annexation, population growth and traffic.
On Monday and at a workshop last month, commission and council members noted that there may be exceptions to the no-annexation rule.
"I would have a hard time with being absolute about annexation, saying that that's not happening," Ward 2 Councilmember Robert Rankin said on Aug. 25. "Because there may be exceptions."
The main exception to completely halting annexation seems to be Easton Point, the development project that seeks to revitalize Port Street and the area around the Tred Avon River. The effort hasn't significantly progressed in recent years, council members say.
Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry said at last month's meeting that Easton Point's redevelopment is "an enigma." She advocated that annexation of the county land in that area be excluded from any no-annexation directive in the new comprehensive plan.
"The Easton Point development project's been on the board for almost 20 years," Curry said. "We have to find a way to move that forward if we can."
Town leaders largely agreed that a project like Easton Point rises to the level of an "extraordinary" annexation that should be permitted under the comprehensive plan's guidance.
Still, the plan should emphasize that annexation generally is "not a priority for the town," said Planning Commission member Victoria McAndrews on Monday.
GROWTH RATE
Hesitation to approve future annexation requests stems, in part, from the town's growth. From 2000 to 2010, the town's population increased 36%, according to census data. In the next decade, growth slowed to 7%, bringing Easton's population from 15,945 to 17,101.
When commission and council members met for a joint workshop in August, the council maintained that the comprehensive plan should include a target growth rate for population. The 2010 version has a 1% annual growth rate, which for the most part hasn't been exceeded. Bumping it up to 1.75% was discussed.
Michael Ports, the commission's vice chair, said Monday that 1.75% "makes the most sense." But other commission members leaned toward a 1.14% annual growth rate, which is based off of historical trends.
Commission Chairperson Phil Toussaint agreed with the 1.14% rate, emphasizing that it needs to be at a mark so the Town Council feels comfortable approving the plan as a whole.
TRAFFIC
When housing projects come to the commission or Town Council for approval, they include traffic impact studies. Developers typically hire a traffic engineering firm to conduct the study of the development's potential impact on traffic backups.
Planning Commission members said moving forward, the comprehensive plan needs to demand more thorough traffic reviews. Klein said studies often choose a few intersections next to the project and ignore the town's main arteries, where traffic is already an issue.
Easton Planning and Zoning Director Miguel Salinas said the best way to expand the scope of a traffic impact study for a development is if town engineers or the State Highway Administration request a larger scope during meetings with the project's traffic engineer.
Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said he wants to continue requiring developers' traffic studies to include a percent change in traffic based on if the development were to be built.
Toussaint said he wants the studies to include more consideration on the impact to pedestrians, not just vehicles. He added that studies should be framed around the town's ongoing Complete Streets study, which is assessing Easton's roads on a large scale.
"What we've received in the past as a traffic impact study is going to be worthless for us going forward," Toussaint said. "It's propaganda at this point, prepared by the applicant's engineers."

title: Cambridge establishes land bank authority
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge establishes land bank authority

 March 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge City Council unanimously voted to establish the Land Bank Authority of Cambridge at a meeting March 25.With a land bank, the city hopes to advance its housing goals through taking an interventionist approach to the Cambridge housing market.
The land bank authority will have the power to take on, manage and sell vacant land in order to stabilize neighborhoods and encourage redevelopment.
The passing of this ordinance means the articles of incorporation for the land bank authority can now be filed.
The next steps to getting the land bank up and running will include deciding the structure of the board — including the number of representatives and how they are appointed — and searching for qualified residents to serve on the board.
In a Feb. 23 memo, Cambridge Program Specialist Gavin Woolford said city staff hopes to begin the search for residents who can serve on the board in the coming months.
At the meeting March 25, City Attorney Patrick Thomas said the ordinance identifies the mayor, city manager and himself by name as the incorporators for the original board before the actual board is selected.
"I would just ask that if there's a motion to pass the ordinance, that it just be clear that the articles should read the individuals holding those offices," he said.
Thomas said this is important due to Tom Carroll, the city manager having submitted his resignation. Carroll said his last day as city manager will be no later than May 17.
Commissioner Jameson Harrington made the motion to adopt the ordinance with a language amendment regarding the incorporators.
At a council meeting Feb. 26, Thomas said that to his knowledge, Cambridge would be the first municipality in the State of Maryland to establish a land bank.
He also said that because the land bank authority would be a corporation, it would be able to acquire and sell land "a little bit more nimbly" than the government because the authority wouldn't have to follow the same process outlined in Cambridge's charter.
Before the council voted unanimously to adopt the amended ordinance at the March 25 meeting, Harrington thanked Carroll and city staff for making the project happen.
"It's something I've pushed for since being elected," he said. "And it's really cool to see some progress."
