title: ‘A dumping ground’: Despite new state regulations, Caroline County still wrestling with impacts of DAF residuals
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘A dumping ground’: Despite new state regulations, Caroline County still wrestling with impacts of DAF residuals

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1766
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — When walking around his Ridgely residence and the Tuckahoe State Park, Al Martinez holds grave worries about the health of his neighbors and the environment.As president of the Tuckahoe Equestrian Center, he's mindful of the cleanliness of riding trails throughout the park, along with the park's bodies of water. Martinez's concerns for the environment led him to join other Caroline County residents who publicly spoke out regarding tanks storing "food processing residuals."
He has taken notice of the large companies outside of the state that often bring the materials to Maryland. It's a trend he doesn't want to see harm the park or Adkins Arboretum, a 400-acre native garden across from his house.
"Big name companies with big pocketbooks are quietly paying other agents to get this stuff into our state," Martinez said. "We kind of know that, even though it's not said so. We know that Big Brother with big money is behind all this."
Dissolved air flotation, a method for processing wastewater from food processing plants, leaves behind a sludge-like byproduct, or DAF residuals. State legislation, which referred to the material as "food processing residuals," went into effect July 1. It requires a permit to use, store or haul the material.
While the state's actions will bring some relief, county leaders still are grappling with mitigating the health and environmental drawbacks of the materials. Those drawbacks include increased flies and pungent odors for neighbors, along with the potential for polluted waterways.
On the Eastern Shore, much of the material generated from DAF comes from poultry processing plants, though some comes from industrial and wastewater treatment sludge. In Maryland, it is an approved soil amendment or fertilizer.
According to a 2023 study by the University of Maryland, more than half of the industrial sludge land-applied in Maryland in recent years came from other states.
Since December, Caroline County leaders have held packed public hearings and extended moratoriums on DAF storage tanks. For county commissioners, the main hurdle has been cracking down on a few "bad actors" that store the residuals irresponsibly.
Martinez and his wife, Stacy Frank, each commented at a January hearing on DAF residuals in Caroline County.
"The sludge created by this process emits the foulest, nauseating, noxious stench you have ever smelled," Frank wrote to county commissioners.
The turnout for that January meeting was more than significant — it was historically high, with nearly 70 pieces of spoken and written testimony. It caught the attention of state legislators, who raised the issue during this year's General Assembly.
THE STATE BILL
House Bill 991 and its paired Senate Bill 1074 were signed into law by Gov. Wes Moore on May 9. The legislation doesn't prohibit the usage of food processing residuals by farmers, but it requires a permit to store, use or haul the food processing residuals.
The bills introduce increased penalties for those who willfully violate Maryland's nutrient management regulations and allow the state to inspect any site where residuals are used.
While HB991 was introduced and sponsored by delegates on the western shore, Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) also introduced DAF-related legislation in February.
His legislation aimed to give local jurisdictions the authority to regulate storage of DAF residuals. Ghrist eventually withdrew his legislation, stating in a letter to Del. Marc Korman (D-Montgomery) that HB991 would "give the necessary control to local governing bodies."
The now-signed bill gives responsibility for the permitting program to the Maryland Department of Agriculture.
The MDA program is expected to be self-sufficient by collecting fees to support the program's funds.
Holly Porter, executive director of the Delmarva Chicken Association, said DCA supported the final version of the bill and was "pleased to see" the permitting process fall under MDA's purview.
"We wanted to make sure that all of our farmers had the ability to utilize food processing residuals because it is a great source of nutrients," Porter said. "… It's an organic material, and it's really one of the best forms of recycling you can do. And it lowers input costs for our grain farmers, which is very important in today's economy."
The exact extent of the benefits of land-applying DAF residuals isn't always agreed upon between industry and environmental experts.
Matt Pluta, the Choptank riverkeeper at ShoreRivers, said that DAF could have "such little available nutrients for the crops," causing it to often be applied in large quantities at once.
"Because this material is often applied in large quantities, we have concerns over the potential of runoff," Pluta said, adding that the waters on the Shore are already polluted due to other agricultural forms of runoff.
Alan Girard, Maryland advocacy director at the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, emphasized the importance that the state caught up to neighboring Virginia and Delaware in regulating the residuals. Companies from those areas had been trucking the product to a less-restricted state like Maryland.
"It's really sort of created a dumping ground for the material in Maryland (that is) generated elsewhere," Girard said.
PERMIT PROCESS
Hans Schmidt, assistant secretary of resource conservation at the Department of Agriculture, said the department worked with sponsors of the bill, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, Shore Rivers and more groups during the legislative process. The department drafted regulations and presented them to MDA's Nutrient Management Advisory Committee.
Girard said "the department deserves a lot of credit" for its work on drafting regulations to satisfy the bill, which officially took effect July 1.
"The department will know ahead of time when and where these products are going to be applied," Schmidt said. "… We have authority now to go on the farms where these products (are) without prior approval from the landowner."
Since the time between the bill passing and the July 1 effective date was limited, Schmidt clarified that the final permit regulations are not active. Instead, the department finalized a set of emergency regulations that was sent to a state legislative committee.
The emergency regulations, posted on MDA's website, will be effective once approved by that administrative, executive and legislative review joint committee. Those regulations will last for six months, during which MDA will submit proposed final regulations, Schmidt said.
"Hopefully by Jan. 1, the proposed regulations will be approved," he added.
Porter said the Delaware Chicken Association offered suggestions to the first draft of regulations, adding that the group is "very much engaged" in conversation with MDA.
In a recent Caroline County Commissioners meeting on July 9, Porter said she believes the state regulations aim to ensure "tracking, reporting and accountability." However, she added that the emergency regulations — which are currently being reviewed by the joint committee — "still (have) some things we're a little concerned on."
"It's more restrictive than I'm sure the industry likes," Schmidt said. "But I think it still meets the intent as far as limiting the number of applications that these products can be applied to the land."
'BAD ACTORS'
While not opposed to the usage of food processing residuals, the Caroline County commissioners have taken significant steps in the past year to aleve concerns from residents like Martinez and Frank. Many of the complaints relate to odors and flies.
County resident Russ Yates owns Holiday Park Campground near Greensboro and has expressed concerns during public hearings about the prospect of using the structures at a neighboring former dairy farm to store DAF. He doesn't want non-permitted materials stored next to his campground and corn fields.
Commission President Travis Breeding said the problem became apparent last winter as the yearly deadline for permitted land application of DAF residuals neared. From Dec. 15 to March 1, the residuals cannot be land-applied under state law, which is the reason for much of the DAF storage.
"There was a mad dash to get as much of this material out on the fields as they could get on the fields up until that Dec. 15 cutoff," Breeding said. "And then they started to store this material in these structures."
Breeding said that trend led the county to call meetings over the winter to discuss placing moratoriums on the storage of DAF residuals. Moratoriums are still in place until later this fall.
"We knew that we had to be well educated in this decision … because of how important the industry is to our local economy," Breeding said. "But just because an industry is a vital part of your economy doesn't give them the right to become a nuisance. We had to try to balance that."
At a July 9 county commission meeting, a county bill to create a food processing residuals storage permit was introduced. Notably, if passed, it would require closed-top storage, going a step further than the state's recently introduced regulations.
During the meeting, Breeding said he visited a Goldsboro resident who "had never experienced flies like that before" due to nearby food processing residuals.
Speaking on behalf of the Delmarva Chicken Association and as a Denton resident, Porter expressed disappointment with the legislation and raised concerns that it'll hurt the agriculture and poultry industries.
"You potentially open up the door that five years or 10 years from now, people are going to come in and complain about other odors (and flies)," Porter said.
In an interview with The Star Democrat, Porter said part of the reason for her opposition to the county legislation is that it "does not grandfather in" farmers who use open-top storage.
"I don't anticipate that our elected officials are experts in all things," Porter said to the commission, "… but I do expect our commissioners to be leaders. As leaders, you don't manage to the exception and develop a policy for one person."
Porter has emphasized that the vast majority of farmers store and apply the residuals properly. "We had a bad actor in this county," she later said.
"It's more than one," Commissioner Frank Bartz responded.
Breeding, who has previously acknowledged that he expects "players from the poultry industry" to "have heartburn" with county legislation, admitted to Porter during the meeting that he believes they are "a ways apart" on the debate.
At a Caroline County Planning Commission meeting on July 10, the legislation passed with two yes votes from Breeding and Chair Jeff Jackson. Hannah Cawley, the commission's vice chair, voted no, while commission member Keith Bilbrough abstained.
The bill will return to the desk of the Caroline County Commissioners on Aug. 6 for a public hearing.
"It is still an issue for a lot of residents in the county," Breeding said at the July 9 meeting. "… That is why we have taken a very hard-line stance that you're not going to be allowed to affect your neighbors."
Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado contributed to this story.
A previous version of this story incorrectly stated the date of the Caroline County Commissioners public hearing. The hearing will be held on Aug. 6 at 9:15 a.m. in the Health & Public Services Building in Denton.

title: Tapping away: Author pens children's book using 'early 100-year old Royal typewriter'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Tapping away: Author pens children's book using 'early 100-year old Royal typewriter'

 July 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 693
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Author David Wright recently published his first book, "Marty McSwirl," through Dorrance Publishing.Wright grew up in Sudbury, Mass., graduated from the Air Force Academy in 2000 and have been serving since. He has flown the F-15, F-22 and A-10 and is currently the deputy commander of the 175th Wing, Maryland Air National Guard.
He and his family live in North Beach.
The 30-page book retails for $39 — the eBook is $34 — and is available at https://bookstore.dorrancepublishing.com/.
How long have you been writing, and how did you get started?It was [Sudbury, Mass.- based Josiah Haynes Elementary School teacher Lee] Jones, my fourth grade and to this day, favorite teacher, who inspired me to be a writer. Despite my rambunctious nature which was not ideally suited to being a student, he managed to tease out a bit of creativity. I must have a penchant for alliterative titles because my favorite project that year was story about a Viking named Pudgy Pinkinson. Yet I think my path was set when Mr. Jones assigned us to create an auto-biography, the last chapter being a prediction of what we would be in the future. In that last chapter I said I would go to the Air Force Academy, become a fighter pilot, and finally become an author. Thus far the first two have come true and I suppose that "Marty McSwirl" is the first step towards making the latter come to fruition.
What inspires you to write?My children John, Anna and Andrew and a lone, tired-looking squirrel inspired me to write "Marty McSwirl." Years ago, I had just finished raking leaves and the kiddos immediately began rollicking in the pile, exactly the way kids should. Despite the chaos, a squirrel joined the fray, apparently looking for acorns. I thought to myself, "He must be a tired dad squirrel gathering food for a big family," and thus was born "Marty McSwirl".
Do you consider writing to be a career?Not yet, but like my fourth grade autobiography predicted, I hope it will be one day.
What kind of writing process do you use?I sit down at my grandmother's old roll-top desk, slide a piece of paper into my nearly 100-year old Royal typewriter, and tap away. I started using a typewriter years ago after reading an opinion in the newspaper lamenting the lost art of letter-writing. Sharing an admiration for things that have stood the test of time, I determined to resurrect that lost art, yet my handwriting is terrible. So I bought an old typewriter and now, when I sit down in front of the Royal, I drift away to wherever my imagination leads me.
How did you publish your book?
After writing "Marty McSwirl," it lay dormant for years, gathering dust among the pile of unpublished works in a desk drawer. Eventually, I applied for a copyright through the Library of Congress and once granted, a number of publishing companies contacted me asking if I would like to publish. I ended up choosing Dorrance Publishing, who walked me through the project.
Who are some of your favorite authors and why?Julia Donaldson is the first author who comes to mind. I've been reading to the kids every night since birth and they always responded best to books that told a good story in the form of a poem. When I began writing "Marty McSwirl" it was with my kids in mind, hoping to create a book that I could one day read to them before bed.
What are you working on now?I have a few unpublished works ready for an eager illustrator and book agent.
Please include a brief description of your bookMarty McSwirl is the tale of a squirrel who invents an acorn harvester with the help of some friends. Their efforts meet with success and Marty decides to share the fruits of his labor with family, friends and neighbors. In essence, the story is a woodland creature Thanksgiving origin story.
Please include an excerpt from the book"When Marty came back with his acorn sack at the end of each long day,
Mrs. McSwirl was there with a hug,
His children snuggled upon the rug,
But despite all his care, the cupboard lay bare, he must find an easier way."

title: 2025 resolution: Get involved. Be part of solution
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
2025 resolution: Get involved. Be part of solution

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Well, it has been a while since I have written. While we were in the process of moving to a retirement community, at least two important things have happened for Cambridge. They are the mayoral election and the governor's ENOUGH Act grant award to Moving Dorchester Forward for Cambridge and Dorchester County.The election occurred on our moving day, and I was happy to have had the chance to vote for Lajan Cephas, the mayor-elect. The ENOUGH Act award occurred about a week later. Each are steps forward for a community that has had its challenges but is now on a positive path.
To keep things continuing to move in the right direction, many things must happen. The one thing that the Cambridge and Dorchester communities need to do to help ensure that things continue to move in the right direction is to become involved. That means you.
The political process and governance do not mean that the people that are routinely impacted by them simply take a step back, claim that their job is done because they voted and let those elected or fulfilling the obligations of state or federal grants to simply do their work without communicating with and reporting to the public.
That means for the work of the new City Council and the mayor you need to go to the meetings or at least watch them on Town Hall streams. Those meetings are recorded so you can watch them any time. You can also join CAN, the Cambridge Association of Neighborhoods, and become involved that way. The city provides over the internet the agendas for all its public meetings including supporting documents for some of them.
With the ENOUGH Act grant and other grants that the city receives from the state and federal governments, for that money to benefit the community it needs to be used correctly and spent in such a way that the community benefits and more funding can become available. For instance, the grant awarded to Moving Dorchester Forward is meant to help Cambridge and Dorchester County develop a program to address child poverty and be awarded an even larger implementation grant of up to $5 million.
In this grant cycle, three Maryland communities were able to receive grants of $3 million each because of the work that they had already done. The work of the Moving Dorchester Forward team has only just begun. If you participate in a nonprofit addressing children's issues or a church community, find out more about where and when they are meeting and what is being done.
Why do you need to do this?
Because if you do not, you will receive information from friends and family or others from social media that will be inaccurate, biased or intended to lead you to think differently than the facts can show if you are personally involved. Our society has become too lazy and relies on what someone else tells them as we make our decisions about who to elect or who we want to be appointed to a committee or board that addresses issues of interest to the community.
Glenn Steckman, the new city manager, is eager to hear from you and to speak with and listen to community groups to learn more from you about your concerns so that city staff and the Cambridge Police Department can be more responsive to what is happening or not happening in the community.
For instance, I know that juvenile delinquency is often a topic of discussion. Here is a link to a police report on juvenile delinquency in Cambridge from almost a year ago, choosecambridge.com/DocumentCenter/View/2422/Juvenile-report.
Another link is from a fall 2024 crime report found at choosecambridge.com/DocumentCenter/View/2580/2024Q3-Public-Report- It will show you on Page 28 what the juvenile statistics are for the city.
If you want to learn more, you can attend the city police advisory committee meetings that happen on a regular basis and are open to the public. Get involved. Be part of the solution. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Easton Town Council vote on cannabis moratorium delayed - Tabled measure leads to heated discussion among council members

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - A move by Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus to continue a hearing on a proposed cannabis moratorium drew strong reactions from other council members.A tense back-and-forth exchange between Gunsallus and Ward 3 Councilman David Montgomery toward the end of Monday's council meeting stemmed from the council president's executive decision to delay a vote on the moratorium for an additional three weeks.The nine-month moratorium on cannabis businesses, introduced this summer, was originally slated for a public hearing and vote at the council's Sept.18 meeting. The matter had been tabled until Monday so all five council members could be present to vote.The moratorium, if passed, would place a pause on applications, approval, construction, expansion, processing or issuance of building permits for a business that grows, processes or sells cannabis within the Easton town limits.The moratorium would also allow the town to consider and adopt a revised zoning ordinance.Easton's existing zoning ordinance already contains definitions and permitted zoning districts for medical cannabis dispensaries and growing and processing facilities, but does not include language on standards for recreational facilities.Montgomery strongly objected to Gunsallus' continuance, saying the council president did not have the authority to do so. Gunsallus affirmed that he did."Sir, you will contain yourself please," Gunsallus said, speaking over Montgomery, who started to make a comment.Gunsallus reaffirmed he had the power to continue discussion on the moratorium until the next meeting, explaining that he wanted to wait until the town's planning commission made an additional recommendation later in the week.However, in August, the commission unanimously gave a favorable recommendation to approve the ordinance.Montgomery called for a vote on the continuance, questioning Gunsallus' authority."The fact that four of us could reveal that we want to vote now means nothing to you, that you will override the wishes of the council because you are sitting there as the town council president," he said.Town Attorney Sharon Van Emburgh chimed in, saying the council can override the president's action. But in the past, the council has typically given members additional time to vote as a courtesy.Montgomery pointed out that the council had already given an additional month for consideration.Gunsallus reemphasized the upcoming planning commission meeting would provide more clarifying information."Excuse me, what information will that be?" Montgomery said."(The planning commission's) recommendations, as I've stated, so please contain yourself - you've already spoken more than permissible," Gunsallus said.Montgomery motioned to overrule Gunsallus and vote on the ordinance as presented.Ward 2 Councilman Don Abbatiello interjected, saying while he understood Montgomery and "definitely" disagreed with how the decision had been handled, he agreed that granting additional time to decide was in line with past council actions.Mayor Megan Cook, a former council president herself, interrupted the quarreling, calling for the councilmen to settle down."I agree that we are a group of five where you all are independent and you all have various opinions - absolutely.We must respect ourselves - the fighting, we need to" she said, trailing off and moving her arms to motion to calm down."Please." Ward 4 Councilman Rev.Elmer Davis Jr. initially seconded the motion, rescinding his vote just minutes later to agree with Abbatiello's stance on the council's precedent. He voiced worry with how the situation was handled."We have never had such a dialogue that we had tonight regarding issues and concerns," he said. "That dialogue - I'm quite concerned about things that have been said, I've never seen this on this council in all my days." The council will again table voting on the ordinance until its Monday, Nov. 6, meeting.Uncertainty still remains on the moratorium. During Monday's meeting, council members and town residents raised questions on the moratorium's duration, specifics on licensing for both recreational and medical facilities and zoning laws for both types of establishments.The Easton Planning Commission will discuss zoning requirements for adult-use cannabis dispensaries at its Thursday, Oct. 19, meeting. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY TOWN OF EASTON
 
Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus pauses his comments during a tense moment at the Monday, Oct. 16 council meeting.
 
COURTESY TOWN OF EASTON
 
Ward 3 Councilman David Montgomery, left, prepares to make a comment during a tense exchange at a council meeting Monday, Oct. 16.
 
COURTESY TOWN OF EASTON
 
Easton Mayor Megan Cook gestures with her hands for the council members to settle down.

title: Caroline commissioners consider committee to review their pay
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline commissioners consider committee to review their pay

 September 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At their meeting Tuesday, the Caroline County Commissioners discussed appointing a committee to review their compensation rate.According to a draft bill presented at the meeting, the committee would be created to review the commissioners' current compensation rate and make recommendations for a new rate based on state and local laws.
A potential pay raise for the commissioners, which would take in effect in the next commissioners term, was suggested by county staff, County Attorney Stewart Barroll said.
"Staff have brought to the commissioners' attention that it has been since 2009 that their compensation has been reviewed," he said. "The cost of living has greatly increased and so has the time it takes to be a good commissioner. So we've brought it to the commissioners' attention because it's long overdue."
The commissioners' annual pay is $15,000, and the commissioners president makes $16,000. This figure is similar to some surrounding counties. According to the Talbot County charter, county council members make $14,400 per year.
Compensation is much higher in other Maryland counties. The Montgomery County Council president makes $171,912, while other council members make $156,284.
Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter had some questions about the draft bill and how the committee would properly calculate the hours the commissioners work.
"I think the question that I would have would be, I'm not sure that committee would be able to really understand or have information on the hours," Porter said. "I mean we all serve differently.
"For example, the president of the commissioners is asked to do things that the other members are not. In other words, the president represents the commissioners… there's hours in here that we don't, I don't know if this committee would even recognize or understand."
Barroll made a suggestion that Kim Raeder of the Office of Law help make the appointments to the committee. Barroll said committee members could interview the commissioners to make a proper evaluation.
The commissioners will not have a say in whether their compensation is raised or not. The appointed committee will make a recommendation after its investigation into the work of the commissioners.
The committee would have to report back by Dec. 15, and the commissioners would have 60 days to act on the recommendation.
The commissioners voted to introduce the draft bill that would create the committee and move the legislation to a first reading at their next meeting. If the bill is passed, Barroll and Commissioners President Travis Breeding said the committee is likely to be formed in early November.

title: Cardin threatens to end military sales to Egypt
author: Fatema Hosseini; Capital News Service
content:
Cardin threatens to end military sales to Egypt

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Fatema Hosseini; Capital News Service | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 677
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Sen. Ben Cardin, D-Maryland, the newly appointed chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has announced plans to block future U.S. military aid and arms sales to Egypt unless that country shows "concrete, meaningful, and sustainable steps" to improve its human rights record."It is imperative that we continue to hold the government of Egypt, and all governments, accountable for their human rights violations," Cardin said in a statement.Cardin's decision marks a significant shift in U.S. policy towards Egypt, a long-standing ally in the Middle East.The senator plans to block $235 million in foreign military assistance that the Biden administration approved on Sept.14.The move starkly contrasts with the actions of Cardin's predecessor, Sen.Bob Menendez, D-New Jersey, who was indicted Sept. 22 for allegedly accepting bribes to influence U.S. policy in favor of the Egyptian government.Cardin's action is colliding with the Biden administration's efforts to foster closer ties with Egypt.State Department spokesman Vedant Patel said in a press briefing Wednesday that the United States aims to advance a strategic partnership with Egypt that ensures regional security and fosters significant progress on human rights issues.Patel added that Secretary of State Antony Blinken believes waiving certain conditions for Egypt's foreign military financing in fiscal 2022 aligned with U.S. national security interests.A total of $1.215 billion in military aid has been allocated for Egypt and discussions with Congress and Egyptian partners are ongoing, Patel said."I was very open in my disappointment in the administration using the waiver on the use of funds, but I want to have a chance to meet with the administration," Cardin told Politico.Before assuming his current role, Cardin had criticized the Biden administration for overriding a human rights prohibition on $320 million of military aid to Egypt.He was among a group of senators, including independent Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Chris Murphy of Connecticut, Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, Sherrod Brown of Ohio, Dick Durbin of Illinois, Jeff Merkley of Oregon, Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, Tim Kaine of Virginia, Tom Carper of Delaware that urged the Biden administration to withhold the $320 million from Egypt.The senators argued that the Egyptian government had failed to make "meaningful progress in addressing human rights concerns" and that withholding the funds was "required by law" in the fiscal 2022 spending bill.In a July 28 letter to Blinken, the senators charged that the Egyptian government had "not only failed to investigate allegations of human rights abuses, it has also continued to commit 'significant human rights' violations such as extrajudicial killings, enforced disappearance, torture and life-threatening prison conditions, and severe restrictions on freedoms of expression, assembly, and association, as documented in the State Department's latest human rights report." According to Amnesty International, Egyptian authorities severely restrict civil liberties, including freedom of expression and assembly.In the lead-up to the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP27) in November 2022, 895 political prisoners were released but nearly triple that number were arrested, according to Amnesty International."Sexual and gender-based violence remained prevalent, amid the authorities' failure to adequately prevent and punish it," Amnesty International said. Workers' rights and religious freedoms are also suppressed, and refugees are mistreated.The decision to freeze aid could have geopolitical implications.As a result of the aid hold, "the anti-America(n) camp will be empowered domestically," Haisam Hassanein, an adjunct fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, told Jewish Insider.He predicted that the group would publicly push for Egypt to strengthen its relations with Russia and China."This could force President (Abdel Fattah El-) Sisi in his current election campaign to release some (inflammatory) statements to save face in front of his constituents," Hassanein said.On Wednesday, Cardin also announced plans to halt security assistance to Azerbaijan due to its "brutal campaign" in the Nagorno-Karabakh region, effectively erasing its Armenian population.Cardin emphasized the need to document war crimes and atrocities and to support efforts to repatriate prisoners of war.He called for increased humanitarian support for ethnic Armenians who have left Nagorno-Karabakh and for the United States to continue supporting democratic reforms in Armenia. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Gunsallus to run for reelection as Easton Town Council president
author: Konner Metz
content:
Gunsallus to run for reelection as Easton Town Council president

 January 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus is running for reelection in the town's election this spring.Gunsallus, who has served as council president since September 2023, announced his candidacy last month. He is a member of the Easton Rotary Club and works with Disaster Aid USA, a nonprofit that delivers disaster relief worldwide.
"Over the past term, I have had the privilege of working alongside dedicated council members, community leaders, and residents who are passionate about shaping Easton's future," Gunsallus wrote in an email to The Star Democrat. "The trust placed in me to lead our town council is both humbling and inspiring, and I believe there is more work to be done to ensure Easton remains a vibrant, welcoming, and prosperous community."
The current president will have at least one opponent, as Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello announced his candidacy for the head council seat earlier this week. Abbatiello has been the Ward 2 representative since 2019.
Gunsallus says his main priorities if reelected are public safety and infrastructure, affordable housing, community engagement and economic development. On the topic of housing, he said it's an "ongoing challenge" and the town's making "significant strides."
In 2023, Gunsallus won a special election for the presidential seat after previous president Megan Cook assumed the town's mayoral seat. At 35, he began his term as the youngest council president in Easton's history.
With more than a year under his belt, Gunsallus said he's learned "the immense value of collaboration and listening."
"I have learned that effective leadership requires balancing the immediate needs of the community with a long-term vision for sustainable growth," Gunsallus wrote. "This role has also reinforced the importance of adaptability and resilience, especially when navigating the challenges that come with governing a dynamic town like Easton."
In addition to council president, there will be Ward 2 and Ward 4 elections this spring. The filing deadline for candidates is April 7.

title: College junior feels jealous of friend
author: Harriette Cole
content:
College junior feels jealous of friend

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am a junior in college, and I'm struggling with feelings of jealousy toward my friend. It seems like everything comes so easily to her, and it's hard for me not to compare our paths.Recently, my friend received a $10,000 scholarship for a study abroad program in Japan and landed an internship at one of the top investment banking firms in the United States. She applied to only one internship and only one scholarship, and things fell into place effortlessly. It's as if a fairy comes in every night while she's sleeping and throws magic pixie dust at her to make everything work out. Meanwhile, I feel like I have to fight tooth and nail just to make half as much progress. Every day is a continuous struggle to accomplish the goals that I have. I try hard to be positive, but obstacles pop up constantly. How can I deal with these feelings of envy and move forward with a more upbeat outlook on life? - Jealous DEAR JEALOUS: It is understandable that you would be envious of your friend for what appears to be an easy life. As you also know, it is toxic to dwell on what other people have. No good will come out of that longing. Instead, you must focus on yourself. Do your best to view your life as your perfect challenge. You are gaining resilience as you live through each experience.Claim your small victories.To keep on track, create a vision board. Look through magazines and newspapers for images that reflect the things you want for your life. Cut them out. Brainstorm words and ideas that represent your dreams.Write them down. Next, on a large piece of cardboard or paper, place the images and words together. Make a simple art piece out of this collection of ideas to create your vision board. When thoughts creep in about your friend's success - or anyone else's - wish them well and pivot back to planning your own life. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Adkins Arboretum to host second plein air event
author: Contributed
content:
Adkins Arboretum to host second plein air event

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 328
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "En plein air," a French term that means "in the open air," refers to the practice of painting entire finished artworks outdoors.Where an observer may see only a glimpse of a landscape, an artist sees light and atmosphere, shape and color, subject and form, all combining in a blaze of inspiration that compels the artist to capture it in paint.On Sat., Nov. 4, Adkins Arboretum will host the second annual Plein Air Adkins, a plein air paint-out, exhibit and sale, on the Arboretum grounds.The public is invited to explore the forest, meadows and wetland and observe as artists paint their original works.Artists will begin painting at 10 a.m. At 12:30 p.m., they will bring their completed works to the Visitor's Center for exhibition and judging.The juror is Alison Berry, a painter who exhibits in Maryland and Virginia and has participated and placed in numerous plein air events.Prizes will be awarded for first, second and third places and for honorable mentions. An Artist's Choice Award will also be given.Beltway Bistro, Blue Monkey Street Tacos and Ten Eyck Brewery will have food and drink for sale beginning at 11 a.m., and Fine Times will provide music during the exhibition and sale.All works created during Plein Air Adkins will be for sale during the exhibition.The event is open to any artist who wishes to participate. The artist registration fee is $20, and artists may register in advance or on the day of the event at adkinsarboretum.org. Observers are admitted free of charge.The event will take place in light rain or shine. In the event of heavy rain, it will be rescheduled for Sunday, Nov. 5. For more information, visit adkinsarboretum.org or call 410-634-2847, ext. 100.Plein Air Adkins is sponsored in part by the Caroline County Council of Art, Choptank Electric Cooperative and Unity Landscape Design|Build.

title: 'Flower Power': Easton art galleries host new exhbit
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Flower Power': Easton art galleries host new exhbit

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 189
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Spiralis Gallery and The Zebra Gallery are presenting a new exhibit "Flower Power."The exhibition runs through May 31.
The Spiralis Gallery and The Zebra Gallery are both located at 5 N. Harrison Street in Easton.
"The exhibit will explore the myriad ways that floral motifs make their way into art. The show celebrates the intricate and extraordinary magic flowers bring to a piece of artwork," according to an announcement.
The Spiralis Gallery is owned by Gail Patterson and features Contemporary Afro Caribbean art. The Zebra Gallery is owned by Susan Schauer John, an award-winning local fiber artist.
"Joy, sorrow, birth, death, serenity and exuberance — all of these emotions and human experiences are marked with flowers," said Gail Patterson.
Featured artists in the Zebra Gallery will include Howard Lapp, Ingrid Matuszewski, Charlotte Harron, Susan Fay Schauer John, Sheryl Southwick, Carol Newmeyer, Cindy Winnick, and Elizabeth Casquerio. Featured artists in the Spiralis Gallery will include Tejiri Esewhaye, Hezekiah Obidare, Lee Mason York, Zsudayka Nzinga, Ernesto Beckford, Gerard, and Fares Micue.
"Artists have long used flowers to express these subtleties, and this show will examine the connection," said Schauer John.
For more: visit https://spiralisgallery.com/ and https://www.thezebragallery.com/.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Thanks for blessing received
author: DENZIL CHEEK Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Thanks for blessing received

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DENZIL CHEEK Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 129
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Have you ever heard a prayer that went something like this?"Now I lay me down to sleep. I pray my e-mail to keep. I pray my stocks are on the rise and that my therapist is wise.
"I pray my cell phone always works and that my microwave will always cook. I pray my health club doesn't close and that my money market always grows.
"And if I die before I wake, I pray my Lexus they won't take"
That's a silly prayer, but it is one that is, in some form or another, probably prayed by a lot of folks.
Where are the thanks for blessings received?
Prayer must be a core value in our lives and a core value of the church. When we talk about prayer, we're not just talking.

title: Chesapeake Music bringing Ensemble/132 to Ebenezer Theater
author: Staff Writer
content:
Chesapeake Music bringing Ensemble/132 to Ebenezer Theater

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Music will present an exciting program for its Interlude concert on March 10 at 2:00 p.m. at Easton's Ebenezer Theater."A piano quintet of artists from ensemble/132 will delight the audience with a one-of-a-kind chamber music experience. The quintet includes pianist Sahun Sam Hong, violinists, Abi Fayette and Stephanie Zyzak, violist, Luther Warren, and cellist, Zachary Mowitz. Chesapeake Chamber Music patrons will remember Sahun Sam Hong and Zachary Mowitz as members of the Trio St. Bernard, the 2018 Lerman Gold Prize winner of the Chesapeake Chamber Music Competition" the Easton-based music nonprofit said in a press release promoting the performance.
"I'm particularly excited for ensemble/132 to bring this delightfully eclectic program to Chesapeake Music. It shows so much of what chamber music can be. Every piece has something entirely unique to offer, whether it's Haydn's exquisitely and cleverly crafted trio, a dramatic cast of characters such as those in Schumann's Carnaval, Perkinson's thrilling blend of a jazz idiom with a classical approach to counterpoint and form, or Petrouchka with its timeless story, its folk dances, and its symphonic scope. It doesn't hurt that Sam's arrangements — Carnaval and Petrouchka — capture the essence of these wonderful pieces while bringing a new palette of colors that we all get to explore together," Cellist Zachary Mowitz said.
Ensemble/132 is comprised of eleven chamber musicians. Marcy Rosen, Artistic Director of Chesapeake Music, is the artistic advisor to ensemble/132.
For more information and to purchase tickets, please visit the Chesapeake Music website at https://chesapeakemusic.org. There you will find information for upcoming events including the 11th International Chamber Music Competition on April 13, community concerts featuring Competition finalists on April 14, the Chesapeake Chamber Music Festival running June 7 through June 15, the Steven Philip Harvey Octet on July 20, and the Isidore String Quartet on October 5.
Based in Easton, Maryland, Chesapeake Music is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to bring renowned jazz and classical musicians to the Eastern Shore.

title: School bus crash sends 11 to hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist. 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A school bus lays on its side in the roadway following a Monday morning crash involving this SUV.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A cadet field manual lies next to the overturned bus and some broken glass. The bus was delivering Caroline County NJROTC students to Easton High School. Eleven people were injured in the crash.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A member of Maryland State Police inspects the bottom of the bus that turned over at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road on Monday, Oct. 30. The rear and roof escape hatches are open.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Although the bus crash occurred at the intersection of Route 328 and Three Bridge Branch Road, side roads were blocked off. They closed off Route 328 at Black Dog Alley. They closed off the other side of Route 328 at Councell Road. They would only let the parents of the students through and emergency services.

title: Regional detention facility agreement needs work, Caroline commissioners say
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Regional detention facility agreement needs work, Caroline commissioners say

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 508
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Tuesday at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting, officials spent an hour and 10 minutes discussing the draft agreement for the potential regional detention center in Queen Anne's County.Caroline County skepticism about the agreement could halt the joint effort on the new 388-bed facility that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners.
The commissioners' concerns largely dealt with who would manage and staff the new facility, as well as how authority over the facility would be divided among the three participating counties.
"All the employees would be Queen Anne's county employees," Caroline County Commission President Travis Breeding said. "The Warden, and all the way through the chain of command would be Queen Anne's workers, and honestly, I'm really struggling with the investment."
The potential detention center would be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill.
The center aims to address the growing need for modern and efficient detention facilities in the region, where counties are struggling to finance renovations or replacements of their aging detention facilities.
Last year, Caroline County sent a letter expressing interest in participating in the project. But Tuesday, the commissioners made it clear that they were not quite ready to sign on.
Caroline County Commissioners proposed a regional authority to manage the detention center, which is not mentioned in the drafter agreement.
"The item that we are still trying to hammer out is the agreement, we were under the impression that we were going to form a regional authority to manage the detention center," County Administrator Katheleen Freeman said.
The majority of the authority over the center will be in Queen Anne's County hands, according to the draft. All decisions and disagreement must go through Queen Anne's County Commissioners, and if they may have a disagreement it will be mediated.
The Caroline County commissioners also expressed concerns about the autonomy and authority of the the new facility's warden. According to the draft agreement, "The Board shall appoint a Warden to operate the Facility with the consent of the County Commissioners of Queen Anne's County."
The draft agreement also states that "The Warden's contract shall not be terminated without the Board's consent"
The commissioners voiced that they believed under the draft that Queens Anne's county could decide after a certain amount of time to remove Caroline or Kent county from agreement, regardless of the amount of money that was put up. To remove one or both of the other counties from the agreement, according to the draft, Queen Anne's County must give the other county a two-year notice to take all their prisoners and house them somewhere else.
The commissioners said they understood Queen Anne's County's decision to conduct the draft agreement this way, but they requested further negotiation and discussion to establish a partnering jurisdiction.
"It was never really any discussion by the prospective members that we would form an authority or develop this regional detention center via agreement with our partner jurisdiction," Freeman said.
Caroline County believes that the draft agreement can work, but before they sign on, changes must be made. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County to light up green for veterans
author: Contributed
content:
Talbot County to light up green for veterans

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 390
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In advance of the upcoming Veterans Day holiday, the Town of Easton plans to illuminate town and county buildings green from Nov. 6 through 12 - part of Operation Green Light for Veterans.The nationwide initiative, led by the National Association of Counties, raises awareness around the unique challenges faced by many veterans and the resources available at the county, state and federal levels to assist veterans and their families.The Town of Easton will be working together with the Talbot County Government on this project, with plans to light up Town and County buildings along with encouraging local businesses and residents to join in support of veterans.Now in its second year, Operation Green Light is spearheaded by NACo and the National Association of County Veterans Service Officers, building upon successful efforts by the New York State Association of Counties and the NYS County Veteran Service Officers' Association in 2021.In 2022, over 300 towns and counties participated in Operation Green Light."It's a great way to remind our community of all that our veterans have done for our country over the years," said Easton Mayor Megan Cook."In addition to the green lights on our buildings, we also want to shine a light on the employees in our organization who have served, and in some cases continue to serve our country. We are so proud of and inspired by the veterans and service members on our team. This is just a great opportunity to honor them and let them know what they mean, n to us."In addition to lighting buildings and other meaningful landmarks, residents, businesses and other organizations are encouraged to participate by simply changing one light bulb in their home to a green bulb.This can be an exterior light that neighbors and passersby see or an interior light that sparks a conversation with friends."Operation Green Light is a gesture of support and appreciation for the public service of our veterans," said NACo Executive Director Matthew Chase. "With hundreds of towns and counties coming together to light everything from bridges to courthouses, we know veterans across the country will see and feel the gratitude we all feel for their service and sacrifices."Counties and residents across the country are sharing their participation on social media using the hashtag #OperationGreenLight.For more information on Operation Green Light, visit https://veterans.mary-land.go v/op e ration-g reen-light/.

title: Port Street housing project nearing completion
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Port Street housing project nearing completion

 August 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Nine affordable housing units and a new headquarters for a local nonprofit organization are nearing completion on Port Street. The Port Street Commons, a project led by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, is slated to finish construction in October.The project includes nine apartments — seven two-bedroom units and two three-bedroom units — and approximately 10,000 square feet of space for The Arc's new regional headquarters, featuring offices and a behavioral health suite.
On Tuesday afternoon, Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc, gave a tour of the 24,000-square-foot space to Jake Day, Maryland's secretary of housing and community development.
Construction workers were in action on the site, and drywall and insulation was installed on the first and second floors of the three-story building. Day called it a "great looking building."
Rondeau pointed out the importance of bringing immediate assistance to those in need of housing in the Easton area, which is why his team has worked to aim for completion in under four years. The site was identified in July of 2021, and construction began last June. "We want to move quickly," Rondeau said.
$6.5 million of the project's approximate $11-million price tag has been raised, and The Arc is nearing the end of its capital campaign. Rondeau told Day that The Arc is financing the gap of around $4.5 million.
"If we wanted to raise the full $11 million, that would've taken us about eight years," Rondeau said.
Day was impressed with the pace of the Port Street project, asking Rondeau, "can we set you up with lots of other developers to help guide them through the process as speedily as The Arc has gotten through?"
A ribbon cutting is planned for Nov. 7. Rondeau said the first batch of tenants will move in Dec. 1, with a second batch coming in on Jan. 2. The Arc's headquarters will open in January.
Eight of the nine units will accept tenants based on a public lottery system. The ninth unit is designated to the Talbot Interfaith Shelter to house someone transitioning out of the shelter.
"Because of the site plan, all nine units are slightly different," Rondeau said, "which was not the most economical, but it was the only way we could maximize getting nine units into the available square footage."
All of the units will feature free Wi-Fi and appliances including a microwave, along with "solid surface countertops" and carpet in bedrooms to save money in the back end for property management. The units will be managed by Chesapeake Neighbors, a housing subsidiary of The Arc.
Rondeau said two of the units on the first floor are "universally designed," with accessible bathrooms and appliances meant to accommodate those with disabilities.
As Day and other members of the Department of Housing and Community Development toured the space, Rondeau pointed out how the office spaces will support The Arc's overarching goal of providing counseling and assistance to those with intellectual and developmental disabilities.
The headquarters are expected to add around 35 jobs to the area. Rondeau said employees at the Easton site will have health insurance. A full-time nurse will also be in the building.
"Three years ago, The Arc decided to self-insure our health insurance for our employees," he said. "And we have a partnership. We provide free urgent and primary care to all of our employees."
Rondeau is excited for The Arc's services to continue expanding outside of Anne Arundel County, which is where the organization was founded and has the largest presence.
"We've grown significantly over the last 25 years here in Easton," Rondeau said. "We wanted to have an Eastern Shore headquarters."
The project is the first building in Easton to fall under the town's mixed-use waterfront zoning district regulations, Rondeau said. Passed in 2019, the zoning code emphasizes connecting the Easton Point waterfront to the town's downtown area. Rondeau said The Arc made sure to have the front doors of the project facing Port Street as part of the zoning expectations.
After the tour, Day thanked Rondeau and expressed his support for The Arc's fast-moving efforts.
"It's an awesome project, it's an incredible project," Day said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
GVFD honors Risley, Haddaway, and Thomas for years of service

 February 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 463
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Saturday evening, Jan. 27, the Grasonville Volunteer Fire Department hosted their 65th annual Installation of Officers and Awards for 2023 to its members. The program took place at the Bay Country Moose Lodge in Queenstown.Fire department President Matt Coursey welcomed everyone, firefighter J.T. Clarke provided the opening prayer for the event. Twenty-five different local businesses and organizations were recognized for their contributions and support to GVFD in 2023.
One of those, the Kent Island American Legion, Post 278, in Stevensville, presented checks totaling $9,500 to the fire department at the banquet.
Fire Chief Jason Anthony, Sr., gave a summary report of events for the fire department for 2023. A few of the highlights included three major donations of $10,000 each from the Didonato family, the Narrows Restaurant (the Hardesty family), and the Rob and Fran Marsh family to the building fund towards the new fire house to be built.
Anthony added, "The fire department responded to 834 emergency calls in 2023. August was the busiest month with 103 calls."
In June, the Queen Anne's County Planning and Zoning approved the plans for the new fire house. In October, Fire Prevention Month activities were held at Grasonville Elementary, Little Lambs Schools and Grasonville Head Start, to impress upon young children the importance of fire safety.
Major service awards were then presented. For years of service, Cory Holm was awarded his 10-year pin. Keith Thomas received his Life Membership recognition, receiving a plaque, his 20-year pin, and his 20-year membership card. "Skippy" Haddaway received a special commendation from Governor Wes Moore, presented by Queen Anne's Commissioner Phil Dumenil, for his 45-years of active service to the fire department.
Topping the years of service awards, former longtime Fire Chief Pete Risley also received a commendation from the governor for his 55-years of active membership. Both Haddaway and Risley were presented unique plaques for their fire department service, and standing ovations from those who were attending.
The Rookie of the Year award was presented to four young firefighters who are recent graduates of the fire department's Cadet program, Jason Anthony, Jr., Caleb Bargerstock, Colby Bargerstock, and L.T. Blake, Jr.
EMS Provider of the Year Denise Ornduff, who was also to Top EMS Responder, responded to 211 emergency calls in 2023. Firefighter of the Year was presented to Dave Bell, Chief's Award to Mike Mattison and President's Award to Skippy Haddaway.
The Top Five Fire Suppression Responders for 2023 were: Jimmy Hurlock, Jr. (311 calls), Pete Risley (292 calls), Steve McCombs (275 calls), Dave Bell (266) and Jason Anthony, Sr. (265).
Six members of the fire department received "Medals of Honor" for their roles in saving the life of a heart attack victim in March, 2023. Those members were Captain Matt Coursey and firefighters Pete Risley, Skippy Haddaway, Tom Sheahan, Michael Balsoma and Cory Holm.

title: Don't throw a tizzy. Come to Tilghman
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Don't throw a tizzy. Come to Tilghman

 August 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — When walking into Gina's at the Bridge, it is immediately clear who Gina Lee Werner is.Simply looking at the decor and tasting the unique blend of flavors on the menu tells the tale of the fun and eclectic restaurant owner who makes her staff feel like family, signing each check with a heart or "love, Gina."
Her husband, Michael Joseph Werner, calls it "Ginafying."
Gina Lee Werner been a restaurant owner for over two decades, and the Werners opened Gina's at the Bridge in November. Now eight months in, the Werners have learned that getting out to Tilghman Island — miles past St. Michaels, where tourists usually stop — is worth the drive.
"I hear people all the time. They're like, 'oh, my God, it's so far. I just can't do that drive.' It's the extra 10 minutes passing St. Michaels, and it's just something about that drive," Michael said.
In an effort to encourage people to come to Tilghman and connect more local businesses, the Werners are purchasing a shuttle van, which can hold around 14 people. They plan to provide shuttle services from St. Michaels and beyond.
The current proposed name of the shuttle is "The Tizzy." It will begin operation in next week.
In addition, the Werners are planning to purchase a center console boat to provide shuttle service on the water.
Ginafying Tilghman
Gina opened Gina's in St. Michaels in 2011, which she still runs. But she always wanted to buy the property she could operate out of.
The new restaurant is situated on Knapps Narrows right next to the historic Tilghman Island Drawbridge.
It is the busiest drawbridge in the nation, and on a nice summer day, the bridge could be raised up to 50 times, according to PropTalk Chesapeake Bay Boating.
The restaurant sources crabs, oysters and fish directly from local watermen, emphasizing extreme freshness while fostering strong community relationships on the island. Along with local seafood, the Werners make a point of collaborating with local artists and businesses like the Tilghman Island County Store and the Little Big Market.
Gina firmly believes in a "rising tide raises all ships" mentality.
She was inspired to open her first restaurant, Gina's Cantina, after a bad experience at a restaurant she formerly worked in where she didn't feel supported after returning from maternity leave.
"I was working all the way up until eight months pregnant, but I went back and everything changed," Gina said. "It just fueled me."
20 years later, that fuel remains ignited, but not out of spite. Her motivation is fostered through an environment where staff are happy yet hardworking and the customers love the food but also feel at home.
To Gina, it is more important to prioritize a relaxed customer experience, where guests can enjoy the view.
"I definitely believe that the restaurants have been such a way for me to put my heart out there so I can still do my art and I can also make a living because I'm not selling my art," Gina said. "The art is when people come in and they're like, ah, yeah." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2 new Dorchester Board of Education members sworn in
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
2 new Dorchester Board of Education members sworn in

 July 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 192
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester Board of Education's newest members were sworn in prior to Thursday evening's board meeting.Brandy Dawson Cumberland and Christine LaMonica were appointed by the Dorchester County Council to fill the District 1 and District 3 seats, respectively, following the resignations of former board President Mike Diaz and Vice President Susan Morgan.
Newly-elected Vice President Talibah Chikwendu said she's excited to have a full board once again.
"More voices and more perspective will be a benefit to the students of Dorchester County and the staff of Dorchester County," Chikwendu said at the end of Thursday's meeting.
Cumberland and LaMonica join newly-elected President Sherri Hubbard, Chikwendu and Chris Wheedleton as members.
DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson welcomed Cumberland and LaMonica and said he hopes the new board can work together to improve the district's current last-place ranking out of Maryland's 23 counties.
"I look forward to doing big things with Dorchester County Public Schools, and most importantly, taking our school district from 23rd to 15th," Thompson said. " … Every decision that we make as a board and as a school system, in my mind, needs to be centered around moving us from 23rd to 15th."

title: Realty Navigator Celebrates Grand Re-Opening Of Kent Island Offices
author: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat

 CHESTER - On a cool, but festive December afternoon, the team at Realty Navigator in Chester, invited family, friends and business colleagues to come and celebrate the grand re-opening of their offices at 110 South Piney Road, Suite 110. Members of the Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce, Mid-Shore Board of Realtors and Queen Anne's County Commissioners were on hand to join the celebration.Realty Navigator is comprised of a group of hand-selected realtors who have been very successful in both listing and selling homes, land, and light commercial properties, and conducting rental transactions and property management.
They have worked with buyers and sellers to achieve their personal and investment needs for both short-and long-term goals. Individually they have all worked with developers and builders, business owners, and charitable groups and have created a broad database of clients and business associates that help to sell or acquire what their clients request, by direct word-of-mouth referral.
With the corporate drive of demanding high agent counts within larger franchises, which isn't necessarily reflective of a quality sales team, Realty Navigator focuses more on relationship building and disseminating information through their database, digital and print marketing and internet/social media to meet or exceed their client's individual needs.
Realty Navigator has 60+ years of combined sales experience within their select group of realtors.
This affords Realty Navigator the opportunity to provide topshelf Real Estate Services while catering to their client's unique needs. Their preferred service area expands from Annapolis and Anne Arundel County to Prince George's, Charles, Calvert, and St. Mary's County in the south, in the West and North we cover Montgomery, Frederick, and Howard counties, and East.
Realty Navigator has experts in Chester in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot, Kent, and Dorchester Counties, and a broad network of strong referral partners across the entire state of Maryland, the country and even Europe.
If you decide not to renew your current listing agreement, if you are ready to put your house up for sale for the first time, move up, or size it down a notch, let Realty Navigator conduct a market analysis and marketing plan organized to meet your goals, or, if you are ready to buy your first, second, vacation home or investment property Realty Navigator has an agent for you. 
 
 Caption: ERIC SYLVIA

 Petra Quinn and Vince Payne cut the ribbon officially opening their new location in Chester.
