title: READY TO ROAR - Lions eye repeat in tough North with designs on deep playoff run
author: William Haufe; bhaufe@chespub.com
content:
READY TO ROAR - Lions eye repeat in tough North with designs on deep playoff run

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: William Haufe; bhaufe@chespub.com | Page: A32 | Section: Sports 
 
 1532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There will be no rematch in the Bayside Conference volleyball championship this year.Oh, defending North and overall conference champion Queen Anne's County High should again be one of the Bayside's best. The other half of last year's title match, North Dorchester, hasn't exactly fallen on hard times, and also figures to have another strong season.But with volleyball returning to Mardela this season, North Dorchester was moved from the South Bayside to the North - where it competes in every other sport it has - making the division possibly as tough as it's ever been."Kent Island's pretty heavy," said Queen Anne's head coach Nevada Brice, who twice last season watched her team defeat the Bucs in five sets, including a come-from-behind victory in the Class 2A East Region II championship. "And North Dorchester. I hope these other North Bayside teams don't forget about them." "I think you're not going to have to count out Easton and North Caroline," Kent Island head coach Glenn Brainer said."And North Dorchester, for a smaller school she (head coach Carol Hubbard) does a great job." "It should be very good," North Caroline head coach Amanda Vanskiver added of the North. "Both good and terrifying." W hile North Dorchester will be a new opponent for the North's 2A schools, the division will also have a new face on the sideline this fall, as James Foo takes over as head coach at Easton after Jen Powell stepped down unexpectedly after 17 seasons.Here's a look at this year's teams.COLONEL RICHARDSONHead Coach: Lesley Staehli.Who's Where: Jazmine Meredith (Sr., SET/OH); Tyla Dickerson (Sr., OH); Eileen Johnson (Sr., MH); Kendall Sann (Sr., SET/H); Faith Thomas (Sr., DEF); Emily Burke (Sr., MH); Montana Davis (Jr., LIB); Kylie Rhinehart (Jr., OH); Madison Shufelt (Jr., SET); Anijah Hammond (Jr., SET/MH); Takaila Rich (Jr., OH); Alohna Lynch (Jr., SET); Kailey Cummings (Jr., MH); Jazmir Jackson (So., MH); Aubrey Taylor (So., DEF); Emma Brewer (So., DEF).Outlook: Staehli will look to build around Dickerson, Meredith and Johnson, who were all-North Bayside honorable-mention picks a year ago.A healthy portion of the squad was on the softball team that reached the 1A East Region I championship in the spring so they know how to win."The talent's there," Staehli said. "Once they start clicking they're going to be good. They've just got to get rid of that softball swing. I've got all softball girls; (they need to) go to that volleyball swing. We'll get there."EASTONHead Coach: James Foo.Who's Where: Ayden Jimenez (Sr., OH); Bree Stevens (Jr., MH); Faith Walstrum (Sr., LIB); Kaleigh Hammond (Sr., MH); Siang Sama (Sr., OH); Taylor Rash (Sr., DEF); Hannah Webster (Sr., RSH); Parker Jimenez (So., SET); Mary Claire O'Connor (So., OH); Annie Whelan (Jr., RSH); Ava Beck (So., DEF); Kennedy Grove (Jr., DEF).Outlook: Sam Mason, the North Bayside's co-player of the year last season, has graduated, but Ayden Jimenez, Kaleigh Hammond and Bree Stevens, who all received all-North recognition last season, return."I'm very lucky. I have big shoes to fill taking over a very nice program that coach Powell has developed," Foo said. "I'm working with a bunch of kids who are willing to learn. We're doing things a little bit different. I have a lot of new things that I'm showing them. I think we'll do quite well. But I guess it depends on how fast we are learning. I'm showing them a lot of stuff that they're not familiar with. But it's working." It worked during Tuesday's season opener, as the Warriors swept James M.Bennett, 25-16, 25-16, 25-11.KENT ISLANDHead Coach: Glenn Brainer.Who's Where: Kendra Coffey (Sr., SET); Lilli Dauses (Sr., MH); Taylor Harding (Sr., DEF); Melanie Murphy (Sr., LIB); MacKenzie Smith (Sr., MH); Rylie Corn (Jr., OH); Alaina Dlabich (Jr., SET/H); Abbigail Fisher (Jr., LIB); Gianna King (Jr., OH); Macayla Kirk (Jr., OH); Emiley Mayo (Jr., DEF); Gabby Polk (Jr., SET); Kennedy Quevedo (Jr., DEF); Lauren Wigglesworth (Jr., MH); Alana Van Ornum (So., OH).Outlook: The Bucs had Queen Anne's on the ropes twice last season before losing the regular-season finale and the 2A East Region II title match in five games."That's something we need to move on from," said Brainer, who begins his fifth year as head coach.Four starters return from last year's 11-4 team, including first-team All-North picks Dauses and Murphy.That duo along with fellow starters King and Kirk should again make Kent Island a contender in the North and region."We've got some talent," Brainer said. "Whether we'll be as good as we were last year, I don't know. You never know how things are going to shake out."NORTH CAROLINEHead Coach: Amanda Vanskiver.Who's Where: Julie Christopher (Sr., SET); Anna Hutchison (Sr., RSH); Brooke Gauck (Sr., LIB); Morgan Rizer (Sr., MH); Julia Myers (Sr., OH); Riley Walstrum (Sr., OH); Ali Thomason (Sr., DEF); Mariah Price (Jr., RSH); Ashley Kercheval (Jr., MH); Tamara Holloway (So., MH).Outlook: "We're ready I think," Vanskiver said.The Bulldogs graduated Zoe Fretterd, the North Bayside co-player of the year, but return seven seniors and five juniors, including Hutchison, an all-North first-team pick last season, and Rizer and Walstrum, who were also all-North choices.And though there's plenty of experience on the team, Vanskiver's biggest concern is avoiding a repeat of last year, when the Bulldogs had a tendency to fall behind early and play catch-up the rest of the match."They're starting off really strong, so I'm feeling really good," Vanskiver said. "But we have to start strong every match. And be mentally tough."NORTH DORCHESTERHead Coach: Carol Hubbard.Who's Where: Maggie Hubbard (Sr., MH); Katelyn Hopkins (Jr., SET); Brooke Outten (Jr., OH); Emily Freeman (Jr., MH); Lexi Lednum (Jr., RSH); Maddie Nagel (Sr., OH); Mackenzie Lewis (Sr., LIB); Haleigh Leonard (Sr., OH); Zoey Willey (So., RSH); Jules Vroman (So., RSH); Alissa Bickling (So., OH).Outlook: The Eagles return six from last season's team that won its first 14 matches en route to winning its first division title before losing to Queen Anne's in the Bayside championship, and Snow Hill in the 1A East Region I final."I'll be honest with you I was a little apprehensive coming into this year," said Coach Hubbard, whose team finished 15-3 a year ago."But the girls have definitely stepped up and exceeded my expectations. I'm happy with what we've seen so far."QUEEN ANNE'sHead Coach: Nevada Brice.Who's Where: Autumn Huber (Sr., LIB); Baillie Pinder (Sr., MH); Caroline Taylor (Sr., OH); Kayce Titus (Sr., SET); Sydney Pinder (So., MH); Mackenzie Doyle (Sr., OH); Jensen Nutleey (PH); Jory Long (So., SET).Outlook: The Lions weren't only the Bayside's winningest team a year ago - going 17-1 - but were also perhaps the toughest mentally. Queen Anne's rallied from a 2-0 hole to defeat Kent Island in the regular-season finale, then came back from a 2-1 deficit to beat the Bucs for its secomd straight regional title.This year's goal?"They want to take it to the end," said Brice, whose team's unbeaten run ended in last year's state quarterfinals."They want to go to states; the championship." The talent and motivation certainly looks to be in place.Taylor, Pinder and Titus, all first-team North Bayside selections a year ago, are back, as are Pinder and Huber. Then there are the new faces."The fillers are coming in now from all the travel clubs," Brice said. "It's nice to see a few girls who have been touching a volleyball for a few years." The Lions will continue their one-match-ata-time approach, then push for another North and division title before bidding to become the first Bayside school to win a state volleyball championship since North Caroline won the 1A title in 1990."They're the most motivated group of kids that I've ever coached," Brice said."Self motivated. They want to do well for each other.And that makes a big difference on the volleyball court and even our practices."I think they have it all," Brice continued. "We still start at the basics, our foundations, and we really focus on our mental game. I know they have the skill. We've seen it throughout the year.But I think the biggest part, especially with volleyball, is that mental game."GUNSTONHead Coach: David Henry.Who's Where: Jessica Hammond (Sr., LIB); Phoebe Kelly (Jr., OH); Emma Nkanza (So., SET/RSH); Scotia Hopper (Fr., SET); Mia Walker (Jr., MH); Liv Labrador (Fr., OH); Kate Andrews (So., MH); Olivia Arthur (Jr., RSH); Chloe Bennett (Fr., LIB/RSH).Outlook: The Herons have already matched last year's win total with Wednesday's 3-0 sweep of Key School, and Henry starts his second year thinking the potential is there for more."Tight-knit group, lots of potential," said Henry, who will be assisted by Jill Labrador."I think they'll be a good team if they're hitting on all cylinders." Gunston competes in the four-team Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference, which also includes Saints Peter and Paul, Salisbury Christian and Worcester Prep.Editor's Note: Information on Kent County and Saints Peter and Paul was unavailable at presstime. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY WILLIAM HAUFE
 
Baillie Pinder (8) and defending Bayside Conference and 2A East Region II champion Queen Anne's County are looking for a deeper postseason run this year.
 
PHOTO BY WILLIAM HAUFE
 
Lilli Dauses (21) and Kent Island have the potential to again battle Queen Anne's County for North Bayside supremacy this year.

title: Teacher for a Day brings community into the classroom
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Teacher for a Day brings community into the classroom

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 808
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Community members were behind teachers' desks this week thanks to the "Teacher for a Day" event organized by the Education Foundation of Cecil County Public Schools at schools across the county."Our goal here at Rising Sun was for our teacher of the day to see several different classrooms and different teaching styles," Rising Sun Elementary School Principal Sherri Isaac said.
Various business leaders and community members visited elementary schools, middle schools and high schools throughout the county from March 3 to 13.
Josh Hayhurst of Superdojo Martial Arts had participated in the former "Principal for a Day" at Rising Sun Elementary but found this experience to be more fruitful as he got to attend both Rising Sun and North East elementary schools — the largest elementary schools in the county — and sit in on classes, and facilitate a gym class for a more immersive day.
Isaac enjoyed this initiative more than any other.
"I feel like our teacher for the day got to experience more of what educators do than when he was following me around for a day," Isaac said.
Hayhurst spent time with each elementary grade in both schools to see the full scope. He pointed out that — contrary to the popular narrative of low test scores reflecting badly on CCPS — "these kids were ridiculously good readers and the teachers are rockstars."
Hayhurst said that he sees a lot of the same kids at his Superdojo, so he enjoyed being able to connect with them both in a space outside of martial arts. At Superdojo, he focuses on taking abstract ideas like how to create a positive environment and making them relevant in his teaching of martial arts, which he brought into facilitating the gym class with a fun twist on a jump rope activity.
Hayhurst also brought dry erase markers to replace the dried up ones for a teacher, and created "reading buddies" — pom poms with googly eyes — to make reading activities more fun for the kids. His efforts to bring in new elements made a positive impact on the students and the faculty.
"Go into the classroom and believe that you're a leader and you can make a difference with the kids just by being a positive role model," Hayhurst said.
He was impressed with the students' math abilities. He joined in on a multiplication table competition doing as many problems as quickly as possible, thinking he would win. But to his surprise, "I look up and there's a girl that had been finished for like 10 seconds just looking at me like, 'What took you so long,'" Hayhurst said.
Hayhurst valued the opportunity to connect with students and teachers and encouraged others to do the same.
"That connection is really important, and we've lost it in our community. We don't even know who our neighbors are, but we can find our neighbors in our local schools, and everybody, I think, should be a part of the schools," Hayhurst said.
Darius Humphries with Chesapeake Care Resources said he enjoyed his time at Elkton Middle School where he sat in on a math class where the teacher pushed the students to think critically and strategize. He plans to volunteer more with public schools in the future because of his experience with "Teacher for a Day."
School officials said that situations such as these were the goal of the entire experience.
"We really just wanted our community to see what goes on, the amazing things that go on in our school every day and see what the kids are learning," Isaac said.
Nick LaBrant with Utilitrain had the opportunity to teach a Cherry Hill Middle School social studies class about the history of power lines. With an informative presentation and power line props, LaBrant immersed himself as a teacher.
"It was actually an incredible class," LaBrant said. "I was able to give the students a little bit of an industry insight on something that really matters in the class."
The students had just learned about the history of railroads, so LaBrant's presentation fit right into the curriculum. LaBrant also educated students about soft skills necessary for the work force.
"I know that they're still in middle school, but I got to talk to them about teamwork and accountability and integrity from someone who's been out in the industry," LaBrant said.
LaBrant added that he was impressed with the students' engagement with his lesson.
"For every student to be paying attention, have questions, remaining engaged, I think it says a lot of good things about our public school system here in Cecil County," LaBrant said.
As a parent himself, this initiative reminded LaBrant to get more involved in Cecil County schools, while seeing how much patience and gratitude the teachers have toward their students to be successful.
"We would welcome an opportunity to have another 'Teacher for a Day' next year and hope that people continue to take advantage of it," Isaac said.

title: Traffic concerns derail proposed apartment complex - Board of Zoning Appeals denies Aspire Apartments' special exception request
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Traffic concerns derail proposed apartment complex - Board of Zoning Appeals denies Aspire Apartments' special exception request

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1093
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - After four and a half hours of testimony and deliberations, the Easton Board of Zoning Appeals denied Aspire Apartments' request for a special exception to use a property off of Mathewstown Road as a multifamily apartment complex.Almost every seat was full in the meeting chambers Tuesday evening as supporters and opponents waited for a chance to weigh in on the contentious proposed complex - and to hear the long-awaited decision on the project's requests.Brought forth by Aspire Outdoors LLC, a company owned by Easton resident Derick Daly, the project proposed a six-building, 162-unit apartment complex with 27 units in each building.The property is situated on the south end of Camac Street, southwest of the existing Hunters Mill neighborhood and adjacent to the Gannon Range, previously known as the Estates at Gannon Farm, planned unit development. It's also located within the R-10A zone, a residential district within the Town of Easton.A multifamily apartment complex within the district requires a special exception granted by the Board of Zoning Appeals, which prompted Daly's request.Daly also requested a variance to allow reduction of the rear setback dimension for the apartment buildings and parking area to be reduced from the town zoning code's required 75 feet to 50 feet due to the unusual size and configuration of the area.The project first came before the town planning commission last December, where Hunters Mill residents voiced concerns about traffic and accessibility.The proposal was initially slated to be heard by the Board of Zoning Appeals in April, but was delayed by 180 days to address ongoing concerns.Within the last few months, both town planning staff and the planning commission recommended approval of Daly's application with conditions, which included project phasing, addressing traffic mitigation and ensuring adequate wastewater capacity.The proposed phasing suggestion, which was incorporated into plans shown at Tuesday's meeting, indicated that access to the first phase of buildings would be via Camac Street.The second phase of construction would include access to the complex via Gannon Range and Camac Street. An additional entrance for the third phase of development was yet to be determined.To Daly, inspiration for the apartment complex was drawn from the opportunity to provide "much-needed housing" to Easton. About 25% of the profits are going to another one of Daly's ventures: Polaris Village Academy, a free private school located in the Port Street area.Daly said the complex was intended to be a higher-end property to serve employees of the new regional medical center, which has yet to begin construction.Board of Zoning Appeals member Gary Molchan questioned why Aspire Apartments couldn't have its own entrance like other complexes instead of running through residential neighborhoods. Daly said he was limited by wetlands, which would require a different set of approvals.Questions were also raised about the number of parking spaces for the entirety of the complex, the possibility of parking spilling over onto Camac Street and adequate public facilities.A significant portion of the meeting was spent discussing traffic - a primary concern of Hunters Mill residents.Betty Tustin, a senior project manager for The Traffic Group, said once fully developed, the apartment complex would generate 875 average daily trips. The number was one she deemed as sufficient for what was permitted under town standards.But to Troy Brestel, a professional engineer and project manager with Traffic Planning and Design, Inc. who testified on behalf of the project's opponents, said that he agreed with the number of average daily trips listed in the developer's traffic study, but disagreed with amount of average daily trips on Camac Street once the apartments were developed.John Franczak, the vice president of the Hunters Mill Homeowners' Association, led opposition to the apartment complex on behalf of the neighborhood."We feel that the town comprehensive plan should be followed, no variances or exceptions," he said. "The rules are there to protect people."The Town of Easton is also installing a long-promised park in the neighborhood, which means more young children and families out walking - a dangerous situation if there's heavy traffic flow from an apartment complex, Franczak said.Several members of the public took the opportunity to comment at the end of each side's presentation.The board's discussion on the variance request was brief, with members acknowledging its minimal impact - the property's use was more important. Approval of the variance request was unanimous.More detailed deliberations ensued on the special exception request.Molchan voiced concerns about the change in character of the surrounding area and traffic congestion."I would support that the Town of Easton needs apartments like this, but these apartments should not affect a community that already exists," he said. "What we're doing to the people on Camac we're turning a quiet residential neighborhood into a bustling thoroughfare for cars and delivery trucks and contractor vehicles, and that's after the apartments are built, that's not while they're being built. Who knows what that will be?"Board member Zakary Krebeck raised similar points, speaking about the "unrealistic" provision of parking spaces and the impact it would have on Hunters Mill.To board chairman Peter Cotter, traffic and congestion were the two main issues he was grappling with."I don't see how it's currently configured, how I can get to a yes using Camac Street," he said, "because I just think that regardless of how the plan is, that's going to be what is used."A motion to deny the special exception was promptly voted on, earning a unanimous consensus.In a phone interview Wednesday afternoon, Daly said he was "disheartened" by the special exception's denial, but understood why the board chose to do so. Looking forward, he plans to make adjustments to his proposal and come before the board again.Because the board denied the application, Daly must wait a full year before returning with the same proposal, per the town's zoning ordinance. A revised plan could be heard in less than a year if it's substantially different from the previous application. The denial can also be appealed in the county circuit court.In spite of the denial, Daly expressed gratitude to the board for hearing him out, along with thanks for positive recommendations from the planning commission, Easton Utilities and town staff.Franczak said while he didn't think the apartment proposal was bad, the project didn't go well with the adjacent single-family house neighborhood. The opposition wasn't personal; Franczak felt he was allowed to defend his house, neighborhood and the safety of both."Bottom line: no hard feelings," he said. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT Residents attending the Easton Board of Zoning Appeals meeting on Tuesday, Oct. 24 look to a projector screen with a depiction of the proposed Aspire Apartments complex site plan.

title: Filing auto insurance claims
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Filing auto insurance claims

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Car insurance is a funny thing. You pay a small fortune to get it and keep it.Then, if you have the blatant audacity to actually file a claim, the company either increases your premiums or cancels you altogether.OK, that may be a bit extreme, but you get my point.While the world of insurance can at times be so confusing as to be maddening, going without basic automobile coverage is simply not an option. The financial risk is just too great. But there are some things you can do to make sure you don't stand out to the company as an intolerable risk.You should file an auto insurance claim if: There are injuries, even minor ones. It's crucial to report the incident to your insurer to ensure your coverage applies, preventing unexpected bills and safeguarding you from potential lawsuits by injured drivers.Another driver is involved.Contact your insurance company whenever you're in a crash with another driver, especially when fault isn't clear. Reporting the incident to your insurer helps make sure the blame is assigned fairly and shields you from excessive liability.There is damage to vehicles or property. Insurance is there to help you with costs when things get damaged, so you don't have to pay a big lump sum. That's why you pay monthly premiums.You shouldn't file an auto insurance claim if: You are the only person involved. If the incident is your fault and does not involve injuries, not telling your insurance company will help protect your premium.There is only a small amount of damage. Even if you have collision coverage in your car insurance, you might decide not to file a claim if your car has only minor damage.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services.Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/, "Ask Mary." CO PYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Bucs, Sabres set sights on titles
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Bucs, Sabres set sights on titles

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 1389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The postseason is a long ways off, but Saints Peter and Paul High's boys lacrosse team has already faced its toughest competition this season.The Sabres' first five games of the regular season featured Calvert Hall, which is ranked No. 2 nationally in the latest USA Lacrosse Magazine poll, and No. 1 in the state. Sts. Peter & Paul also has had games against three other top-20 ranked teams in Maryland — No. 5 Bullis Prep; No 16. Good Counsel; and No. 19 Severn.
"It's everything I wanted," Sabres head coach Todd Wolters said of the opening gauntlet. "I'm very happy with what we have."
Though Sts. Peter & Paul lost its first five games before routing James M. Bennett 17-1 last week, Wolters said he's not concerned with his personal record, but is focused on preparing his team for another run at a Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference title after falling shy in last year's championship game.
Though Kent Island has yet to begin its regular season, head coach Bobby Woolley has also been impressed with what he's seen from his team during a tough preseason slate that included dates with No. 18 DeMatha, No. 22 Broadneck and No. 23 South River before Monday's final exhibition against Springside Chestnut Hill Academy of Philadelphia.
"We put our necks out there right away and just started learning about ourselves," said Woolley, whose preseason also included Sherwood, Fallston, Cape Henlopen and Archmere Academy. "I feel like we got a lot of what it takes."
Easton will look to send longtime head coach Dennis Keenan off as a winner. The Warriors graduated the majority of their firepower from a year ago, but look to have the goods for another solid season, along with Queen Anne's and North Caroline.
While Keenan begins his farewell tour, two Mid-Shore teams welcome new head coaches, with Ben Joiner taking over at Kent County, and Teddy Peyton at Gunston. There is also a new kid on the block, with North Dorchester beginning its first year of varsity play under the direction of veteran head coach Steve Hurley.
"We don't have much experience so we're going to learn a lot of game this year and next year," said Hurley, who has 18 out for the team. "We're having fun; kids are learning."
Here's a look at this year's teams.
CAMBRIDGE-SD
Head Coach: Brendan Bromwell.
Who's Where: Goalie: Andrew McMichael (Sr.); Defense: Christian Dockins (Sr.); Jeffrey Sellman (So.); Juan Slaughter (So.); Midfield: Gavin Weber (So.); Tabrion Watts (Sr.); Kimir Lake (Sr.); Attack: Charles Spedden (Jr.); Gibby Robinson (So.); Nate McClaren (Sr.).
Outlook: The Vikings are fast and athletic defensively, led by four-year man Dockins. Bromwell applauded McMichael, who has stepped in at goalie.
"I'm proud of him," Bromwell said. "We didn't have anybody and Andrew came to me and said, 'Hey, I know we're kind of struggling in this spot, I'll give it a try.' And he's done good."
There is also athleticism at the midfield with Watts and Lake. Bromwell likes Weber's old-school style of play and will have him facing off.
Spedden, whose growth in the game is "insane", according to Bromwell, quarterbacks the attack.
EASTON
Head Coach: Dennis Keenan.
Who's Where: Goalies: Mason Quicke (So.); Randall Mills (Sr.); Defense: Eddie Whelan (Sr.); Ethan Finlay (Sr.); Max Smith (So.); Nathan Lapp (Sr.); Ethan Ballance (Jr.); Darren Foxwell (Sr.); Midfield: Spencer Gunshenan (So.); Conner Hensley (Sr.); Logan Friend (Jr.); Cole Murphy (So.); Finn Gunshenan (Sr.); Landon Chaney (Sr.); Blake Royer (So.); Colin Keenan (Sr.); Luke Stanco (Jr.); Grayson Buritsch (Jr.); Miles Chaney (So.); Blake Newton (Jr.); Attack: Campbell Taliaferro (Sr.); Jackson Wieland (Jr.); David Rogers (Jr.); Trace Haddaway (So.); Miles Abell (Jr.).
Outlook: The Warriors lost the bulk of their scoring with the graduation Drew Schmidt (54 points) and Hudson Royer (43 points), who are both at Lynchburg (Va.), and Tyler Rardin (50 points).
While there looks to be plenty of offensive options, Keenan said defense is the team's strength, and was impressed with Quicke's 12-save effort against North Caroline in Friday's opener.
"We're building," Keenan said. "They listen. They're willing to be taught."
KENT ISLAND
Head Coach: Bobby Woolley.
Who's Where: Goalies: Quinn Burns (Fr.); Chris Lemme (Sr.); Cody Jones (Sr.); Defense: Gavan Henry (Sr.); Ryan Austin (Sr.); Robert Hottel (So.); Eric Hofmann (Sr.); Grayson Corn (So.); Connor Byrne (Jr.); Finn McGrath (So.); Midfield: Keegan Green (Sr.); Connor Gardner (So.); Marshall Dandy (Jr.); Aidan Henry (Sr.); Attack: Mark Rees (Sr.); Brian Rees (Jr.); Colton Schneck (Sr.); Liam Dermer (Sr.); Face-off: Ricky Verger (Sr.); Roy Scott (Jr.).
Outlook: The Bucs' bid last year for a third consecutive Class 2A state title was foiled in the semifinals by eventual state champ Glenelg. All-North Bayside Offensive Player of the Year Tucker Claxton graduated along with fellow first-team all-North picks Owen Wynot and Micah Quinn.
But Woolley thinks this squad is in a more stable place heading into this season compared to last year, when he and his staff seemed to be forever patching holes. A strong returning cast, including all-North first-teamers Gavan Henry and Green, St. Mary's transfers Hottel and Dandy, and promising freshman class figure to have the Bucs challenging for a 10th Bayside Conference title in 13 years.
But nobody has thrilled Woolley more than the return of Hofmann, who missed all last season with an injury.
"Having Eric back is a game-changer, as far as controlling the field between the restraining lines and putting pressure on people to get the ball into their offensive zone," Woolley said.
There's been a three-way battle for starting goalie between Lemme, Jones and freshman Burns, who has really turned heads.
"All in all, I feel like we're more of a complete team heading into this year than we were last year," Woolley said. "We're positioned with high expectations and talent to back it."
NORTH CAROLINE
Head Coach: Gavin Houseman.
Who's Where: Goalie: Koen Jackson (Sr.); Defense: Derek Jones (Sr.); Gabe Holt (So.); Sam Heimbuch (Fr.); Midfield: Jimmy Cohoon (Jr.); Owen Walstrum (Jr.); Dylan Robinson (Jr.); Charlie Fleshman; Attack: Jake Hoofnagle (Fr.); Mason Ratcliff (Jr.); Corey Bunce (Sr.)
Outlook: The Bulldogs finished .500 in the regular season a year ago, and after a solid outing in Friday's opener against Easton, Houseman thinks there's potential to improve.
"We thought we'd have to take a step back with having younger guys taking more of a senior role but we really haven't had to," Houseman said. "We've picked up pretty much where we left off last year. We played pretty strong against Easton. We had minor hiccups, which I think are easy to fix."
QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY
Head Coach: Brad Niesz.
Who's Where: Goalie: Brian Maleski (Jr.); Defense: Brett Bast (Sr.); Ethan Hahn (Sr.); James Rath (Jr.); Conner Cheezum (Sr.); Ryan Lee (Sr.); Brian Patrick; Midfield: Tanner Lyon (Sr.); Conlan Nagle (Sr.); Carter Hercher (So.); Casey Ryan (Jr.); Midfield-Attack: Tyler Crist (Jr.); Charlie Schmidt (Jr.); Jackson Shiley (Jr.); Sam Yetman (Jr.); Attack: Jamison Kendall (Jr.).
Outlook: The Lions graduated a lot of experience, particularly on the defensive end. Gone is first-team all-North Bayside goalie Dino Blue. Niesz said the loss of defenseman Hunter Kelly will also hurt, but the return of Lee, a first-team choice a year ago, should anchor the defense.
"We've had to move around a number of players," Niesz said. "We are a relatively small program in terms of numbers so we're going to ask guys to fill multiple roles."
SAINTS PETER & PAUL
Head Coach: Todd Wolters.
Who's Where: Goalie: Hank Wolters (Jr.); Defense: Porter Bishop (Jr.); Daniel Schwaninger (Jr.); Jackson Jancosko (Fr.); Langdon Anderson (Jr.); Cole Philip (Fr.); Drake Stolba (Jr.); Midfield: Grant Messick (Jr.); Lane Williams (Sr.); Mason Roland (Fr.); Jamir Demby (Fr.); Eddie Albright (Fr.); Attack: JJ Rardin (Jr.); Noah Zimmerman (Sr.); Andrew Steinhardt (So.); Liam Durnbaugh (Jr.).
Outlook: The Sabres lost in last year's MIAA B Conference final to Archbishop Curley, but may be stronger this season.
The defense could be among the conference's best with Hank Wolters back in goal, fronted by Bishop, who Coach Wolters has called one of the best in the country, Schwaninger, Jancosko and Anderson.
The offense also appears loaded with the return of Rardin, Zimmerman, Steinhardt and Durmbaugh. The biggest concern — other than staying healthy — may be between the restraining lines where the midfield struggled through the first five games.
"We're nowhere near full strength," Todd Wolters said. "But they've seen what good teams are like. I'm here to win a B Conference championship and these are the games that will help us."

title: The IRS deserves good leadership
author: Staff Writer
content:
The IRS deserves good leadership

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Was anyone surprised to learn that the latest IRS commissioner — Billy Long — has left his position after being on the job for only two months?(Mr. Long is now expected to be nominated as the U.S. Ambassador to Iceland.) He was the fifth commissioner or acting commissioner in a period of seven months.
You have to wonder why the president would have chosen Billy Long to serve as the IRS commissioner in the first place.
He was a congressman from Missouri from 2011 to 2023. His background was as an auctioneer and real estate agent. According to news sources, the only tax credentials he had ever received were a designation as a "certified tax and business adviser," a title given after taking a short class from a business in Florida.
After getting his certificate, he was involved with companies that assisted businesses and nonprofits in applying for the Employee Retention Tax Credit, a credit available in 2020 and 2021 for employers during the COVID-19 pandemic.
From my own experience as both a tax preparer and taxpayer, I have found the civil servants who work for the IRS are some of the smartest and most competent in the federal government. It makes me wonder how these tax professionals kept up their morale with Mr. Long as the commissioner.
Add to that the effects of the DOGE project on IRS employees. Since January of this year, thousands have left the agency.
More than 266 million tax returns were filed with the IRS in fiscal year 2024, collecting more than $5 trillion in tax revenue and $98 billion in enforcement revenue.
Given the enormous, looming debt we are facing, tax revenue is crucial to keep the government functioning and to pay the interest due on this debt.
I feel fortunate to live in a country where, at least until now, I can file my tax returns and feel confident that they will be processed by an agency that abides by the rules, keeps my records confidential, sends me refunds or credits my payments in an orderly and efficient manner.
Stability and consistency in tax administration are also necessary for a thriving American business community.
The IRS deserves good leadership in order to maintain public trust. A healthy U.S. financial system depends on a well-functioning Internal Revenue Service.
ELAINE TAMA
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Mary Ellen Clark
content:
Mary Ellen Clark

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8A | Section: Obituaries 
 
 311
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Mary Ellen Robinson Clark of Chestertown, Maryland died on Saturday October 14th at Whispering Pines Assisted Living in Rock Hall. She was 78. Born on April 25, 1945, she was the daughter of the late Walter and Delma Phillips Robinson and the sister of the late Janet Robinson Cerny.Mrs. Clark was a graduate of George Washington University, earning a Bachelor's Degree in sociology. After college, she moved to Boston to start her career with Jordan Marsh as a buyer in the bridal department.After many years, she returned to MD to care for her aging parents on the family farm in Chestertown. During this time, she began her career with Kent County Public Schools.She worked as a Career Counselor for over 20 years before retiring in August of 2008.She will be remembered for her encouraging words and guidance to countless students in their career pursuits.She married her long time partner, C. Wayne Clark in 1998, and they made their home in Chestertown. He predeceased her on July 28, 2014.Mrs. Clark enjoyed serving God through her caretaking and service to friends, neighbors, and her Church. She was an organist and active participant in St. James United Methodist Church. She often volunteered her time for community events. One of Mrs.Clark's favorite pastimes was walking around town and enjoying the nature of her beloved Kent County.She is survived by her stepchildren, Dulin Clark (Crystal) and Meredith Lefort (Will), and grandchildren, Connor and Caiden Lefort and Mikala and Mikey McCracken. She is also survived by her two nephews, Steve Cerny and Dave Cerny.A Celebration of her life will be held on Monday, November 6, 2023, at 10:00 AM at St. James United Methodist Church in Worton, MD. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to a charity of your choice or perform an act of service in Mary Ellen's memory. www.fhnfuneralhome.com

title: Brief talk OK for worried diner

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I ran into a woman the other day whose face was vaguely familiar.We were at a restaurant, and I was dining with other people, so we said hello but no more.As I was leaving, she asked if I was still working at a company that I left more than 10 years ago.I told her no and shared what I am doing now. Then I left.Clearly this woman remembers me. I don't really remember her. I was kind to her, though. Should I have stopped to chat moreft I was with a group of people, and we were leaving a restaurant.- Was I RudeftDEAR WAS I RUdeft: It sounds like you were appropriately polite to this woman.You greeted her and later answered her question.The moment didn't call for more than that. You were not rude.Yes, you could have lingered a bit longer if it felt right to do so, but acknowledging each other warmly, quickly updating her on your current work situation and keeping it moving was perfectly fine.If she wants to talk more, she may try to reach out.You told her where you work now, so if she really wants to reach you, she probably can, either there or on social media. title: Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sen. Arthur Ellis (D-Charles) introduced a bill on the first day of the General Assembly that would create something that Maryland has never had before — a state fruit.Native to Maryland, persimmons can be found just about everywhere in the state, with the exception of Garrett County due to the mountainous nature of the region.
In May and June, persimmon trees flower, but the fruit isn't ready until the fall, leading to many seasonal recipes and drinks. Persimmons have especially been used for fine wines, jams and baked goods.
The trees are known for their resilience, being able to thrive for years when they are below the canopy of a forest.
Prices for persimmons have gone up significantly in recent years, reaching about $6 per pound, and many have not heard how easy it may be to source their own, according to Ellis.
"I have persimmon trees in my yard," Ellis said. "They grow naturally, and they're beautiful and delicious."
Ellis introduced the legislation to raise awareness for the fruit, as many Marylanders do not realize it is a part of their state and its history.
Indigenous people of the region used the fruit not only for food but medicinally as well. Sore throats and indigestion were common ailments that the use of persimmons attempted to treat.
Throughout the Civil War, persimmon seeds were used as a coffee substitute when trade routes were impacted.
The usefulness of the persimmon tree doesn't end with the fruit. The wood of the tree is extremely strong, and is commonly used within shoes, golf clubs, flooring and musical instruments.
If Senate Bill 74 makes it through both state legislative houses and is signed by the governor, it would become effective Oct. 1.

title: From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy
author: Konner Metz
content:
From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — John North was more than just a well-respected judge.The former Talbot County state's attorney and judge of the District and Circuit courts wore many hats during his professional and retired life, serving as a protector of the Chesapeake Bay, log canoe racing aficionado and vintage automobile enthusiast.
In recent days, family, friends and the Talbot County community have remembered North for his roles in all of those capacities and more.
North died in St. Michaels on Sept. 19. He was 94.
Oldest son David North remembered his father as "competitive with compassion." He was supportive and thorough in everything he did, his son said.
"Right through the end, he was showing us how to have fun under not very good circumstances and how to stay competitive," David North said. "And how to laugh."
North was Talbot County state's attorney from 1962 to 1971. He then served as judge for 12 years in District Court and five years in Circuit Court before his appointment as the first chairman of the Maryland Critical Area Commission, the state agency responsible for protecting the health of the Chesapeake Bay and enforcing laws at a local level.
Pete Lesher, current Talbot County Council vice president, reflected on North's impact with the commission and as one of the founders of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum in the 1960s.
"He lived and played on Chesapeake waters," said Lesher, also the museum's chief historian. "He valued the health of these waters and I think relished that role of caring for them in the capacity of the Critical Area regulation."
Ren Serey, former executive director of the Critical Area Commission, worked closely with North for many years. "The Judge," as North was widely known, brought the necessary judicial expertise and temperament to chair the commission, Serey said.
North was responsible for implementing local critical area programs at a time when the Bay's environmental needs clashed with rural growth and development patterns, Serey said. But North struck the perfect balance in adjudicating such matters.
"Having Judge North up there at the head of the table facing 29 people who were debating these issues was just the perfect role for him," Serey said. " ... He knew how to listen, he knew how to interject, he knew how to keep the discussion without certain boundaries."
Those that worked closely with North said he was widely trusted for his fairness and loyalty.
Lesher recalled a time in the early 2000s when the state committed funds for repairs to the Chesapeake Bay's skipjack fleet. But the state didn't fully lay out how the money would be doled out among skipjack captains in Tilghman Island and Deal Island.
Judge North, though, stepped in.
"Who was going to be the trusted arbiter if it came down to a Deal Island versus Tilghman Island? It was Judge North," Lesher said. "He was trusted by these watermen."
North's wife of 64 years, Ethel Towers North, died in 2019. He is survived by sons David and Daniel and their wives Joan Hoge-North and Margaret Enloe-North, along with grandchildren Drew North, Dylan North, Campbell North, William Spencer North and Nathaniel Vivian, and former daughters-in-law, Sallie North and Carrington North. He is also survived by Comber McHugh, a companion of later years.
In addition to his esteemed roles with the courts and the Critical Area Commission, North was a local log canoe captain. He wrote a book on sailing log canoes, which was published by the Maritime Museum in 2018.
"The Judge" skippered Island Bird, the 27-foot-4-inch log canoe built by North's great-grandfather in 1882.
David North said his younger brother Daniel took up his dad's sailing hobby. They both have kids who continue sailing on the Chesapeake Bay.
"It's a piece of our family. It's a piece of our heritage," David North said.
In his spare time, "The Judge" was a lover of feral cats, a keen reader and a sculptor. Some of his sculpting works are displayed at The Trippe Gallery in Easton.
David North said he followed his dad's footsteps in the world of automobile restoration and car shows. Judge North especially loved Bugattis and Duesenbergs.
North was a founder of the St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance, an annual car showcase nearing its 20-year mark. Luke Phipps, the festival's current chair, said it began as simply an oyster roast at North's house in St. Michaels, where friends of "The Judge" would bring their vintage cars to his front lawn. Then, the tradition grew into a solidified event.
The 18th St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance was hosted Sept. 26-28 at the Kent Island Yacht Club. Despite heavy rain the night before the festival's last hurrah on Sept. 28, Phipps said it was a "beautiful" and sunny Sunday.
Phipps said all he could think of was North — a close friend and valuable mentor — smiling down on Sunday.
He recalled North as a "sharp" and an "eloquently spoken" man.
"There'll never be another one like him," Phipps said.

 WORTON — During the Kent County High School Job Shadowing program, high school sophomores in the STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) program got a taste of real world occupations, visiting a variety of local businesses.A supporter of the program for 13 years, Zane Carter explained, each year, eight leading Kent County businesses open their doors to share their expertise with students starting to plan out their futures.

title: Trappe Planning Commission approves changes to Lakeside plans
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Trappe Planning Commission approves changes to Lakeside plans

 August 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — Last Tuesday evening, Trappe's Planning Commission approved the changing of three lots set aside for spray irrigation into one parcel for the Lakeside Wastewater Treatment Plant. This change will help the plan meet requirements from the Talbot County Health Department.Ryan Showalter, Lakeside's attorney, said new representatives of the Health Department had waited to provide comments on the preliminary and final plans for Lakeside until they receive approval from the Maryland Department of the Environment.
MDE requested two changes to the final plan. The first relates to the Health Department's signature approval block. The approval block before referenced the parcels that are associated with the treatment plan. According to Showalter it basically said they're approved as lots for development purposes.
The second change pertains to the lots for the spray irrigation field. According to Showalter, there were three lots for the spray field, which was everything north of the treatment plant, the storage lagoon and the reserve spray field was a lot.
MDE is requesting all the lots to be on a single parcel, essentially erasing boundary lines on the plan.
"And so that's the only change, is to remove those internal division lines so that what was three lots is now Lot C."
According to Robert Rauch, this change in no way alters the boundaries or acreage of the parcels.
"We had three parcels associated with the spray field they wanted to incorporate into a single parcel," he said. "Didn't change any of the boundaries. Didn't change every acreage, but we had to switch them to a single parcel instead of three separate ones."
The planning commission unanimously approved a motion to authorize Commission President Edgar to sign the revised plats when they are approved by the Health Department and MDE.
Rauch shared with the commission that the wastewater treatment plant is now meeting effluent requirements and the Health Department and MDE approved that the treatment plant can start discharging to the lagoon starting last week.

title: Eastern Shore singers perform at D-Day ceremonies in France
author: SUBMITTED NEWS
content:
Eastern Shore singers perform at D-Day ceremonies in France

 July 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SUBMITTED NEWS | Section: Local News 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NORMANDY, FRANCE — Each year on the sixth of June, visitors from all over the world gather in Normandy, France to honor the sacrifices made during the D-Day invasion on that day in 1944 and this year included Queen Anne's Chorale.Many special events and wreath laying ceremonies take place to commemorate D-Day and the landing of Allied Forces on its shores during World War ll.
Each year the premier All-American D-Day Band and Community Chorus is assembled to perform at some of these commemorative events. The band and chorus are comprised of instrumentalists and singers from across the United States. With their music, they are the American musical ambassadors to France.
An invitation to sing in the All-American Community Chorus was sent to a local group, the Queen Anne's Chorale in Centreville. In addition to this honor, their Artistic Director, Robert Huntington, was chosen to conduct the chorus. Fourteen singers, along with family and friends, participated in this memorable trip.
Before leaving, however, they met several times to practice so they were ready to rehearse with the other singers upon arrival in Paris. The concert repertoire with an "Americana" theme included "Down to the River to Pray," "The Yellow Rose of Texas," "Swinging on a Star" and "Let There Be Peace on Earth."
Their itinerary for the nine-day trip began with a special guided tour, stopping at several significant areas dedicated to the D-Day battles of Normandy Campaign. Both the Chorus and Band joined forces for a Wreath Laying Ceremony at the Utah Beach Memorial. The Choir traveled to the American Cemetery at Omaha Beach and were able to tour the solemn place of honor. The Chorus presented concerts in the town square and in the Church in Sainte-Mere-Eglise as part of the Musical Salute to Liberation. They also participated in the annual D-Day Memorial Parade held there.
Before returning home, the Chorus also had an opportunity to explore Paris and perform an afternoon concert at La Madeleine Cathedral.
As Chorale singers began planning their trip to France, they found that their town of Centreville had yet another connection to D-Day, 1944. Sadly, one of its young men, U.S Army Private First-Class William H. Quillen, fought with the 29th Infantry Division and lost his life on the sixteenth of June 1944 during an ensuing battle. He received the Purple Heart and is buried in the Normandy American Cemetery.
Upon learning about Private Quillen, the Chorale, with the assistance of the Queen Anne's County Library in Stevensville, researched and identified his grave site coordinates. On June 5, Chorale members placed a flag on his grave in Normandy honoring his courage and sacrifice for the United States and the Allied Forces. A picture was taken with Chorale singers holding flags from both Queen Anne's County and the town of Centreville.

title: Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories
author: LINDA EVANS
content:
Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS | Section: Columns 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Editor's note: This column originally appeared in the Star Democrat on Oct. 17, 2021. It is repeated here after Jimmy Carter celebrated his 100th birthday this week.It was the mid-seventies and I was a young Washington, D.C., Republican staffer with the rare opportunity to work as a personal assistant for the Honorable and Mrs. George Romney (Mitt Romney's parents).
Pretty exciting for a farm girl from the Eastern Shore of Maryland. When the Romneys invited me out to formal occasions, as a member of their staff, I was occasionally mistaken for Mitt's sister, Lynn.
It was cherry blossom time, and a longtime friend who drove me to the Tidal Basin that day happened to be an employee of the Secret Service. As we walked around the Tidal Basin, a long, black limousine pulled up and my friend yelled, "It's the president."
I nonchalantly responded, "The President of what? What company?"
He repeated, "It's President Carter! It's Carter!
As a government employee, he knew to position us near where the president's car door would open, with the idea of taking a photograph of the president, if possible. When President Carter emerged from the limousine, I was indeed one of the first in line, and even though I was a staunch Romney Republican, I did what any American would do, outstretched my hand and shook the hand of the president of the United States. Many would be lost for words at that point, but I somehow found the presence of mind to say sincerely, "Thank you for being our president."
President Carter, apparently touched by my sincerity, thanked me. My friend had his old Polaroid camera with him and asked the president if he would mind posing for a photo. The president quickly agreed, and then said to no one in particular: "Isn't she beautiful?"
What a compliment for me. I smiled for my friend's camera and that was the end of the exchange; my friend and I were off to tour the cherry blossoms with hundreds, possibly thousands of others that evening.
The Polaroids turned out so-so, but my friend, being politically minded, said he had seen White House photographers there. In fact, since I had my new black velour jacket over my arm, he said he felt the Secret Servicemen were carefully watching me for the president's safety.
"Why don't you call the White House and see if any of them got you on film?" he suggested. What an outlandish thought, but tempting. The next day, I looked up the White House switchboard number and hesitantly dialed 212-456-1414, and asked for the White House press secretary, as I had been instructed by my friend.
"Hello, this is Karl Schumaker," the voice on the phone answered with a German accent. Since I am also of German descent, we had something in common. I said, "Sir, you won't believe it, but the president of the United States told me I was beautiful yesterday at the Tidal Basin. "
Pause.
"What were you wearing?" he asked.
"I was wearing a pink jumpsuit and pink scarf."
"You are beautiful," Karl said. "I have three photographs of you. Would you like me to mail them to you or would you like to come to the White House and pick them up this week?"
I chose the date of Thursday that week because my sister would be in town, and we not only got autographed photos that day, but a tour of the Oval Office and presidential memorabilia. I showed the photos to our parents and then I filed them in my big, old file cabinet, with only one of the photos on my office wall, seen by almost no one. I'm still a Romney Republican and always will be, but also a Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter fan.
And a fan of someone else in the White House, the Press Secretary Karl Schumaker, who would teach the importance of customer service and taking extra time out to make memories that have lasted over 40 years. It was President Carter's birthday on Oct. 1 (he turned 100), and he received the Nobel Peace Prize also on Oct. 11 (in 2002), which reminded me of this occasion.
"To this day, Jimmy Carter looks back on a life of faith and service, and ahead to a more peaceful world," Mark K. Updegrove wrote in an article titled "Building a Better World," found in in Parade Magazine, Feb. 18, 2018.

title: Easton considers ordinance to crack down on seafood processing odors
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton considers ordinance to crack down on seafood processing odors

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 811
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Amid resident concerns, the Easton Town Council is considering an ordinance to adjust zoning and place restrictions on seafood processors.The legislation, sent to the council for review following approval from the Planning Commission, was created in response to odor complaints from residents living near the business Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue.
At Monday's Town Council meeting, councilmembers heard mixed reviews on the ordinance from residents and business owners, opting to leave the public hearing open and explore options such as moving the business out of a residential area.
Under the ordinance's proposed definition, seafood processing would be defined as "harvested seafood" being "cleaned, cut, eviscerated or otherwise prepared or cooked for sale in bulk, with a resulting by-product."
If approved, seafood processing would remain permitted in the industrial zoning district but only allowed in business commercial through a special exception. That exception would require that by-products are "stored within a closed or refrigerated vehicle," with operators required to install "odor control technology" so "no odor from any product or by-product can be detected outside the building."
Ward 4 Councilmember the Rev. Elmer Davis, who said he's heard the complaints from many of his constituents, took issue with the fact that the proposed ordinance requires existing businesses to comply by Jan. 1, 2026 instead of sooner.
"I don't think it's fair for the individuals who live in that area to have to go through another summer dealing with the odor," Davis said. "It's unfair. So I'm going to advocate that it be six months."
Davis added he doesn't think seafood processing should be allowed in business commercial zoning at all. Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello agreed with Davis' perspective but asked that the council consider the legislation's potential impacts on other seafood businesses.
"My only concern would be that we have several other seafood facilities in town who don't have these issues," Abbatiello said. "And I would hate to see them get caught up in a similar scenario, where they're getting, for lack of a better term, punished."
Council President Frank Gunsallus asked if the town had a plan to aid smaller seafood businesses if they're forced to comply with the costly odor mitigation requirements.
"If we're going to be potentially imposing regulations on businesses that have significant financial impact to the point which some have claimed would put them out of business, I think we should take pause with that," Gunsallus said.
"I'm not quite concerned about that, personally," Davis responded. "I'm more concerned about the constituents in the neighborhood. … What you're just saying (makes) it seem like it's a hardship on the business when they probably haven't even tried."
Zach Smith, attorney for Chesapeake Brand Seafood owner/operator Mitchell Hughes, provided a letter to the council to be read aloud during the public hearing on the ordinance.
If passed, the ordinance "will put Mitchell out of business and will cause significant economic harm to him, his families, his employees and the local watermen that he supports," Smith wrote.
The attorney said Hughes has taken "reasonable steps" to mitigate the impact on residents as they have brought up concerns. However, he says buying new equipment isn't doable.
"While Mitchell has tried to be a good neighbor, he cannot reasonably install equipment that prohibits any smell from being detected outside of his building," Smith wrote. "Mitchell has looked into what will be necessary to satisfy this proposed regulation, and such technology is not feasible and will be extremely cost prohibitive."
RESIDENT CONCERNSDuring the public hearing, many residents voiced impacts Hughes' business has had on their quality of life. Resident Philip Bernot said he's lived next to grain processors, metal fabricators and plumbers at the site since 2001, never before experiencing any issue that brought him to a town meeting.
"Not a single one of these businesses has ever brought me up here to complain," Bernot said. "Not a single one of these businesses has repeatedly caused a gut-wrenching stench to take over the entire neighborhood."
A representative for Sea Watch International said the business on Glebe Park Drive would be "swept up into new legislation." Bruce Cole, owner of Cole's Seafood House & Deli, echoed this, saying the ordinance would negatively impact his operation on North Washington Street.
"(The) impact that he has is going to impact me," Cole said, noting equipment may cost around $100,000. " … I don't have any complaints."
Following the public hearing, Ward 1 Councilmember Maureen Curry asked the council to pause on taking action. She emphasized the operation of the business under scrutiny is different from businesses like Cole's.
"They're not doing it for retail, they're doing it for wholesale and to push out a product," Curry said. The council left the public hearing open for the Nov. 18 meeting.
Curry added that she hopes the council can work toward a "best case scenario" in which Chesapeake Brand Seafood moves out of its current location to a more appropriate one away from residents.

title: Bridge - The exception to the rule
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The exception to the rule

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Yesterday I pointed out that if one side thinks it is right to play on a suit, it isn't right for the other side to play on the same suit - but, as you knew, not always!Today's unusual deal is an example.North's slightly optimistic sequence showed four spades and gameinvitational values.(Normally, don't look for game when your combined maximum count is 25.)Then South bid three notrump because he liked the idea of trying to score up a vulnerable game.The apparently hopeless contract was kept alive by a fourth-highest heart lead around to South's nine.Mentally shrugging his shoulders, declarer played a low club: nine, 10, jack.To defeat the game, East needed to cash one or both of his top clubs, but following the principle mentioned above, East returned a heart. West took declarer's jack with his queen and exited with a spade, won by South's king.Declarer cashed the diamond king-queen and spade queen before playing a spade to dummy's ace.After taking the 13th spade and the diamond ace, South exited with dummy's last diamond. West won with the nine and cashed the heart ace, but he had to concede the last trick - declarer's ninth - to the heart king.Bridge is a tough game!Receive daily instructive and entertaining quizzes from Phillip by subscribing for only $10 per month at www.bridgeforeveryone.com. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Thanks for blessing received
author: DENZIL CHEEK Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Thanks for blessing received

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DENZIL CHEEK Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 129
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Have you ever heard a prayer that went something like this?"Now I lay me down to sleep. I pray my e-mail to keep. I pray my stocks are on the rise and that my therapist is wise.
"I pray my cell phone always works and that my microwave will always cook. I pray my health club doesn't close and that my money market always grows.
"And if I die before I wake, I pray my Lexus they won't take"
That's a silly prayer, but it is one that is, in some form or another, probably prayed by a lot of folks.
Where are the thanks for blessings received?
Prayer must be a core value in our lives and a core value of the church. When we talk about prayer, we're not just talking.

title: Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fraudulent marijuana operation is targeting University of Delaware students and Newark residents by illegally offering marijuana deliveries, according to state officials.The Delaware Division of Alcohol & Tobacco Enforcement issued an alert to the public on Thursday indicating that the agency is investigating reports of flyers and business cards that are being distributed around Newark. The ads falsely claim to be associated with Fresh Cannabis, the licensed medical and recreational marijuana dispensary on Ogletown Road.
"The impostors are attempting to mislead potential customers into purchasing marijuana products illegally," said Jon Peterson, a spokesman for DATE.
One of the ads includes a cartoon of a marijuana leaf character holding a joint and targeting UD students with the words "UDEL-iver? Yes we do!"
"Quick delivery for on-campus students only! (DoorDash/Uber Eats Style!)," reads the ad, which includes the Fresh Cannabis logo and a promise of a free sample of marijuana for students who sign up.
Another ad also includes the Fresh Cannabis logo and shows a menu of offerings. It notes that the business delivers 24/7.
Peterson emphasized that no licensed marijuana dispensary in Delaware is permitted to deliver marijuana or marijuana products.
"Any business claiming to offer delivery services is operating illegally," he said. "Delaware's adult-use marijuana marketplace includes strict regulations and testing standards designed to ensure consumer safety. Products sold through illegal channels bypass these safeguards and may contain dangerous contaminants such as mold, pesticides or heavy metals."
Though Delaware legalized recreational marijuana, it remains illegal to sell it outside of licensed dispensaries.
Tips about this or similar cases can be sent to Cpl. Tristin Burris at tristin.b.burris@delaware.gov.
"DATE's Marijuana Enforcement Unit is actively investigating this matter and encourages anyone with information about these fraudulent materials to come forward," Peterson said.

title: Community BBQ hosted to show support for DCPS middle schooler
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Community BBQ hosted to show support for DCPS middle schooler

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 841
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Circulating videos of an incident where a Mace's Lane middle schooler's hijab was pulled off her head brought people from near and far to the corner of Washington Street and Greenwood Avenue for a community barbecue.The May 8 event, organized by mosques in Baltimore and Philadelphia, was created to support sixth grader Tori Gibbs, who is Muslim, and to give attendees the opportunity to learn about Islam.
"Everybody's invited," Anwar Wright, an administrator at the Germantown Masjid in Philadelphia, said at the event.
The community barbecue came to fruition after religious leaders at Masjid Al-Hidaayah in Baltimore received videos of the incident, which happened off of school grounds.
"What was relayed was our young Muslim sister was being bullied," said Sabur Carter, an administrator at Masjid Al-Hidaayah. "Us Muslims, we're not going to tolerate that. That doesn't mean, as everybody may think, that we're going to react with violence. We're going to react with education."
According to a letter signed by Baltimore's Masjid Ad-Da'wah Ilat Tawheed Imam Raha Batts, the videos shows Gibbs "being verbally and physically attacked with her hijab being violently snatched from her head."
The letter says that those involved chanted Islamic phrases to "taunt" Gibbs. It also says Gibbs was physically assaulted in the presence of the assailant's father.
Gibbs' mom, LaToya Gibbs, said in an interview May 9 that it's been heartbreaking and devastating to see her daughter go through this.
"It's been really hard on her mental health and mine," she said.
She said Tori Gibbs will be doing home hospital schooling through the end of the year due to her mental health.
Carter said that when he saw the video, he felt outrage.
"Everybody should feel safe," he said.
At the barbecue, organizers grilled hamburgers and hot dogs and offered pamphlets and books about Islam for people to peruse.
Along with offering learning opportunities to people in the community, Carter said they came to help foster a peaceful resolution between the children and parents involved in the incident. He said he was able to help make that happen in the early afternoon before the barbecue began.
"We're not protesting or anything like that," Carter said about the event. "But we are calling for change. We're calling for education, and we're calling for change."
The same day as the barbecue, LaToya Gibbs said she and faith leaders sat down with Dorchester County Public Schools Interim Superintendent Jymil Thompson. Although she said the district had given her "the runaround" in the past, she said the meeting was a positive one.
"Unfortunately it took for my brothers and sisters to make a post and bring more awareness than I could," she said about finally getting that meeting.
LaToya Gibbs said that at the meeting, she talked to Thompson about how better communication with parents could have stopped the situation from getting as bad as it did.
According to a statement from DCPS, Thompson called the meeting constructive and said the Gibbs family's concerns were taken seriously.
"The school and community need to work together to prevent small issues becoming big," he said about Imam Raha Batts' suggestion to work together on a bullying awareness program. "It is sensible to use school, where the community's youngsters come together, to further education against bullying. I look forward to working with the Imam on this project."
In an email, DCPS Communications and Community Outreach Specialist Valerie Goff said that following the meeting, Thompson will be monitoring the situation and checking in with the family.
In an interview May 9, Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said that on April 5 the department began investigating the incident, which took place outside a Mace's Lane Middle student's home on March 26. He said police did a detailed investigation that included getting video footage of the incident from social media and from city street cameras.
Todd said Rian Johnson, a parent of one of the children involved in the incident, has been charged with conspiracy of assault in the second degree, conspiracy of reckless endangerment, reckless endangerment and contributing to the condition of a child. He said one of the children involved was identified as a juvenile offender but has not been charged. He said the Dorchester County State's Attorney is looking into whether the offender's actions could be considered a hate crime.
LaToya Gibbs said the community barbecue resulted in five attendees taking their Shahada, which means they made the decision to convert to Islam. She said two of those five attendees were the fathers of girls in the video that showed Tori Gibbs being attacked.
Tori Gibbs' great aunt, Kandy Waller, said she just wants her niece to be OK. She said the bullying has been a constant, and she hopes the barbecue results in an end to the bullying and harassment.
"I just want her to be able to enjoy her childhood like everybody else without the threat of violence," Waller said.
LaToya Gibbs said the barbecue had a positive effect on her Tori.
"She did say she was more confident (seeing) all the people come together and show support for her," LaToya Gibbs said.
This story has been updated to include comments from DCPS.

title: Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As many regions in the United States prepare for a significant heat wave in the coming days, Maryland's Mid-Shore could see temperatures nearing triple digits next week.According to the National Weather Service, Easton is projected to see highs around 95 to 97 degrees beginning Sunday through Wednesday. Highs are expected to remain in the 90s later in the week across Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.
The Dorchester County Health Department is encouraging people stay out of the sun when temperatures peak in the late mornings and early afternoons.
A press release from the department noted the following groups should take added precautions: babies, young children, pregnant women, older adults, outside workers and those without air conditioning.
Local health officials recommend regularly hydrating, limiting time outdoors and monitoring for signs of heat exhaustion — heavy sweating, cold skin, cramps, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, etc.
The Maryland Department of Health said in a press release this week that Maryland saw 26 heat-related deaths last year. The state department added that parents and guardians should never leave children in cars.
"Remember to check on those who are particularly vulnerable to heat, including young children, senior citizens, and people with chronic diseases — and confirm that they have the resources they need to stay safe during the hottest months," said Maryland Secretary of Health Dr. Meena Seshamani in the release.
EASTON FIRE PREPARES
As temperatures heat up, volunteer fire departments across the Mid-Shore remain on call. Due to the physically intensive work of firefighting and the heavy gear that must be worn, some departments are asking for water donations from the community.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson says his department has received enough cases of water from thoughtful community residents and businesses to get through next week's heat wave. Dobson is encouraging residents to contribute to other fire departments in need in Talbot County.
Whether it's lending bottled waters or assisting with manpower on a call, Dobson says local fire departments work together well.
"The other fire chiefs talk a lot, and we're always here to help one another," Dobson said.
The fire chief noted that as farmers in the area start to cut their wheat, field fires could pop up, a risk fire officials are keeping their eyes on.
Weather projections are accurate as of Friday afternoon.

title: Federalsburg council member: misuse of town funds brought to state prosecutor
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg council member: misuse of town funds brought to state prosecutor

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Town of Federalsburg announced on Facebook Tuesday morning it had investigated allegations of misappropriation of town funds.The investigation was conducted by the mayor and the council. They learned of town funds being used to purchase personal items, financial errors costing the town to spend money, personnel policies that were not followed, inappropriate purchases and employees engaging in inappropriate discussions in the workplace, the post said.
"The Town was reimbursed for the personal and inappropriate purchases and the interim town manager is working to rectify and improve personnel and financial management of the town," the town said.
While the internal investigation was completed, District 1 Councilwoman Brandy James said she reported the investigation findings to the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor, where she said the investigation is ongoing.
"It was only me who went to the office of the state prosecutor and said, 'Hey, this is what's going on in the town and has been historically happening,' So, they got involved, and they started to investigate like toward the end of February into March. It's to my knowledge they're still investigating," James said.
James said the fiscal year budget of 2024 brought attention to some of these issues.
"So a lot of what's going on is historical misuse of funds, it's historical stuff," James said. "Since I have gotten there, it has always been a rush to pass the budget. There was things in the budget that just did not add up. There was line items to pay somebody to cut grass for a crazy amount of money."
According to James, toward the end of November 2024 she received a complaint from a individual about misuse of funds in the town office and the alleged individual wanted the complainant fired.
James said she immediately reached out to town leadership and suggested they call a meeting to discuss the allegations further.
"Everybody on the dias said, 'Oh, we have holiday plans, we have this.' I was put off again. So we never got around to addressing the allegations until we had a meeting in January," she said.
Through closed session meetings that followed, the town ultimately decided to let go a member of the town staff, James said.
"While we feel it is important that our citizens are aware of the issues the Town faces, we have decided to not release the specific complaints received at this time to avoid the risk of liability for releasing confidential personnel information," the Town said in the Facebook statement.
The Star Democrat repeatedly tried to reach out to Mayor Kim Abner Tuesday, but she could not be reached for comment.
