title: James saves U.S. from big upset
author: Bill Haufe
content:
James saves U.S. from big upset

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LeBron James saved the U.S. from what would have been a stunning loss.James' layup with 8 seconds left was the go-ahead basket Saturday, and the U.S. Olympic team that'll soon head to the Paris Games escaped with a 101-100 win over South Sudan in London, rallying from a 16-point deficit to avoid perhaps the biggest upset in the program's history.
South Sudan, the African nation that gained its independence just 13 years ago and is about to play in the Olympics for the first time, led for more than half the game and had a chance to win at the end. But Carlik Jones' runner off the glass missed with about 4 seconds left, and the Americans survived.
"I'm going to be honest: I like those better than the blowouts," James said as he walked off the court. "At least we get tested."
Oh, they got tested — by a team that came into the game as 43.5-point underdogs , according to BetMGM Sportsbook.
"A good reminder that when we play against teams, it's the biggest game of their lives," U.S. coach Steve Kerr said. "We have to expect everyone to play like that."
Down by 16 at one point, the Americans dug out of that hole with an 18-0 run in the second half — then needed heroics at the end anyway. JT Thor's 3-pointer with 20 seconds left gave South Sudan a 100-99 lead, then the Americans called timeout and put the ball in James' hands.
He made it look easy: He waited, waited, waited, then drove and laid it in with ease to put the U.S. back on top, and the Americans got the stop they needed at the end.
James finished with a game-high 25 points, six rebounds and seven assists for the U.S., which improved to 4-0 with one game left — Monday vs. World Cup champion Germany — on its pre-Olympic exhibition tour. Anthony Davis added 15 points and 11 rebounds for the Americans.
Marial Shayok had 24 points for South Sudan and Jones had a triple-double — 15 points, 11 rebounds and 11 assists.
The teams will meet in group play in the Paris Olympics on July 31.
"It's basketball. It happens," U.S. guard Stephen Curry said. "You want to play perfect every game; it doesn't happen. But can you dig deep and do the little things that help you win? Offense can come and go, but defense is the thing that helps you win championships, medals, all that stuff."
It should have been a mismatch, and for the first half, it was — just not in the way anyone would have expected.
The U.S. roster has 12 players, all of them All-Stars or NBA champions or both, with a total of 189,038 points in their regular-season careers, with 7,832 combined starts. South Sudan has four players who have appeared in an NBA game. They've scored a combined 1,228 points and started 19 games.
Didn't matter. It was 8-0 U.S. after 2 1/2 minutes. The rest of the half: South Sudan 58, U.S. 34. The Americans allowed South Sudan to shoot 61% in the first half and got outscored 21-3 from 3-point range in the first 20 minutes.
"I did not do a great job preparing our team," Kerr said. "We did not focus enough on what they're capable of, and that's on me. I think that really allowed South Sudan to gain confidence early. ... They were great. They played a wonderful game and the ending was good for us, just to feel that, to feel what it's going to be like in Paris and Lille."
An 18-0 run in the second half — James involved in most of it — was what really saved the U.S., turning a 76-65 deficit into an 83-76 lead.
South Sudan led by 16 late in the first half — 58-42 — before the Americans got the last basket to cut the deficit to 14 at the break.
But the 18-0 run was key. James had four assists during the spurt and Curry, from about 35 feet, connected on a 3-pointer late in the third that gave the U.S. its first lead since the first quarter at 79-76.
Wenyen Gabriel banked in a 3-pointer to get South Sudan within 85-84, but James — his former teammate with the Los Angeles Lakers — connected on a 3 on the ensuing U.S. possession, and the Americans would eventually pull through by the slimmest of margins.
"Today we were able to represent our country with pride and we put up a good fight and showed the potential of our country," Gabriel said. "I think it was a proud moment for a lot of people."
Davis said the team got to the arena late, thrown off by standstill London traffic, and that routines going into the game were disrupted. Maybe so, but South Sudan showed the U.S. that nobody at the Olympics will concede anything to the four-time defending gold medalists.
"Doesn't matter when it comes to how close the game is," James said. "We went out there to get better."

title: Limits on how much a drug should cost
author: Susan Estrich
content:
Limits on how much a drug should cost

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Susan Estrich | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. government last week released the list of the 10 medications that will be the first to be the subject of the new price negotiations under the Medicare reform bill, and my arthritis drug, Enbrel, made the list.To make the cut, you either had to be taken by millions of people, like Eliquis, or cost a fortune. Enbrel costs a fortune.I'm one of 47,000 Medicare recipients lucky enough to receive a drug that my old rheumatologist, who originally prescribed it for me, described as a miracle.When he was a young doctor, he told me, his waiting room of patients with rheumatoid arthritis was full of crippled people. With the advent of "biologic" drugs like Enbrel, the crutches and wheelchairs are gone. I count myself very lucky to be mostly symptom-free, which, with RA, is saying a lot. As I say, I'm lucky and blessed. And well-insured.And able to cover the out-ofpocket costs. Which are also substantial.This is the hard part of medical miracles.One month, when I was switching insurance companies, I ran out of Enbrel. I made the mistake of thinking I could actually pay for my weekly shot out-of-pocket if I couldn't get the insurance situation straightened out. "How much would it be?" I naively asked the pharmacist. Enbrel is a SureClick pen; it comes in a pack of four. That would be $1,700 for one pen and $7,000 for the pack.Excuse me? Who can afford that?I managed to get a sample from the doctor's office to tide me over and never asked again. Every month when the specialty pharmacy calls me to renew my Medicare prescription, they confirm my $350 co-pay and I don't so much as murmur a word of complaint, because what can I say? The drug saves my life. But I'm lucky I can afford it. That's why Enbrel belongs on the list.Medicines like Enbrel cost billions to develop, and it is only fair that those costs be recouped. But there are limits, and there is no reason that the market should be foreclosed from working freely when it comes to the prices for these prescription drugs. Enbrel costs too much, but there is nothing that I, one consumer, can do about it. We need to stand together, which is to say, we need government to stand up for us and negotiate for us and give voice to our needs.What is stunning about these negotiations is that it took an act of Congress to authorize the government to use the power of the people on behalf of the people to negotiate fair drug prices.The power of the pharmaceutical industry was so great, so much greater than the power of the American people, that it was literally the law of the land that Medicare could not use its bargaining power on behalf of the American taxpayer.When the bill allowing price negotiation passed last year, the Congressional Budget Office predicted the program would save Medicare more than $100 billion during the next 10 years.Just stop and consider that for a moment: the biggest purchaser of health services unable to use its bargaining power, on behalf of you and I, leaving the industry's power to set prices unchecked. And yet this is precisely what government is for, precisely what government is meant to do, to stand up for and give voice to we the people. The pharmaceutical industry continues to fight against negotiations in the courts. "Today is the start of a new deal for patients where Big Pharma doesn't just get a blank check at your expense and the expense of the American people," President Joe Biden said in announcing the list.It's about time.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

author: Angela Price
content:
Mid-Shore Calendar

 Author/Byline: Angela Price | Section: Calendar 
 
 3057
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those seeking to have an event published in the Star Democrat's calendar are asked to email details to community@stardem.com.FRIDAY NIGHT DINNER, 5 to 7:30 p.m., VFW Post 5118, 355 Glebe Road, Easton. Community invited. Held every Friday.
A SENSE OF PLACE, 10 to 11:30 a.m., via Zoom. This course is a discussion and exploration of our perceived special places. It celebrates the individuality and mutability of places and times. Readings will be suggested. Participation is a requirement. Three sessions, May 17, 24 and 31. $40. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.

World War I and II, a sharecropper's cabin, new Buffalo Soldier exhibit, among many other artifacts and stories about Caroline County. A docent is on hand for tours. Free to the public. Festival held rain or shine. Free admission. For information or to rent table space call: 410-228-6916 or 410-330-4790.
MEMORIAL DAY PARADE, 10:30 to 11:30 a.m., Talbot Street, St. Michaels. Featuring over 50 exhibits including military and veteran groups, classic cars, and community groups. The parade is in remembrance of those who gave the ultimate sacrifice.
COMMUNITY YARD SALE AND BREAKFAST, 7 a.m. until, Scotts United Methodist Church parking lot, 3748 Main Street, Trappe. Tables $10. Vendor tables $20. Breakfast $12. Contact Robin Watson at 410-829-4790.
STRAWBERRY CHASE 5K, 8 a.m., Martin Sutton Park, Ridgely. The course is a flat loop including the town's rail trail and scenic farmland west of Ridgely. Registration opens at 7 a.m. on 4th Street near the skate park. The 200-yard Strawberry Dash for children ages 3-5 is at 7:45 a.m. and is free. Info: ridgelylions.org.
STRAWBERRY FESTIVAL, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., Martin Sutton Memorial Park, Ridgely. Musical entertainment, food and craft vendors, and children's activities.
YOGA CLASS, Oxford Community Center, 200 Oxford Road. 1 p.m. Yoga for advanced beginners with Suzie Hurley. Info: 410-226-5904 or oxfordcc.org.
YOGA ON NAVY POINT, 5:30 to 6:30 p.m., Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michaels. Instructor Colleen Morrison will lead participants through an all-levels class on CBMM's waterfront campus. Registration is required and open now at bit.ly/CBMMYoga2024. The cost is $20 for a single session or $70 for all four sessions in May or June, with a 20% discount for CBMM members on all pricing.
YARN AND NEEDLE GROUP, 12:30 to 3 p.m., Brookletts Place Talbot County Senior Center, Easton. Every Tuesday. Some help may be available for knitting and crocheting. Open to anyone 60 years of age or older at no cost. Info: 410-822-2869.
NATIVE PLANTS FOR LANDSCAPED SPACES, 1 to 2:30 p.m., Easton Family YMCA or via Zoom. Join Mikaela Boley, from the University of Maryland extension office here in Talbot County, as she walks us through the building blocks of creating a sustainable landscape that can provide us with years of enjoyment without negative impact on the environment. Three sessions, Tuesdays May 28, June 4 and 11, plus a field trip by car, Friday June 7. $40. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
WEDNESDAY MORNING ARTISTS, weekly at 9:30 a.m., 900 Peachblossom Place, Cambridge. All are welcome, from beginners to pros. There is always opportunity and something interesting to learn and see. Group shares our artwork at meetings and collaborates with many different forms of media. Artists' work displayed in the window of Vintage Venue on Race Street in Cambridge. Facebook: wednesdaymorningartists. Email is: wednesdaymorningartists@gmail.com
THE TALBOT COUNTY OF FREDERICK DOUGLASS, 10 to 11:30 a.m., Easton Family YMCA. What can Frederick Douglass, Talbot County's most famous native son, teach us as America continues struggling with racial divisions, the legacy of enslavement, and the quest for a just, free, and embracing society? Join Jeff McGuiness and Lance Morris in a discussion of the eloquent words penned by Douglass himself, juxtaposed against the very landscape that bore witness to the genesis of his quest for a society that transcends differences and dismantles the constancy of hate. Two sessions, May 22 and 29. $30. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
PLANNING FOR OUR FUTURE BEFORE IT REACHES US, 1 to 2:30 p.m., Easton Family YMCA or via Zoom. Join experts Gordan Fronk and Elena Sallitto as they demystify estate and elder planning, ensuring that you are well-prepared for the future. "Planning for Our Future Before It Reaches Us," delves into the intricate world of estate and elder law to safeguard your assets, make informed decisions, and prioritize the well-being of your loved ones. Two sessions, May 29 and June 5. $30. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
OYSTER GARDENING 101, 4:30 to 6 p.m., Pickering Creek Audubon Center. Oyster gardening provides import nursery habitat as well as filtering the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries; oyster reefs are a vital part of conserving the Chesapeake Bay. Come learn about a new spat growing program, the challenges these bivalve face, and the research methods we use to analyze the success of oyster nurseries. Sign up at pickeringcreek.org/programs/upcoming-programs/.
BUCKETS OF WARM SPIT, 10 to 11:30 a.m., Easton Family YMCA or via Zoom. Join Raymond Vergne, M.D., as he turns his focus on the intriguing lives and careers of selected vice presidents from the 20th century. This course is the final chapter in his comprehensive series, offering a deep dive into the often overlooked but fascinating world of Vice Presidents. Three sessions, May 23, 30 and June 6. $40. To register, visit chesapeakeforum.org.
NATURE AT NIGHT HIKE, 8:30 to 10:30 p.m., Pickering Creek Audubon Center. Explore Pickering Creek's Farm-to-Bay Loop at night and use special UV flashlights to reveal nocturnal wildlife and unique plants and fungi not usually visible to the human eye. By the main parking lot, stop by a mothing station with the opportunity to see Luna moths and other impressive early summer species. Sign up at pickeringcreek.org/programs/upcoming-programs/.
FRIDAY NIGHT DINNER, 5 to 7:30 p.m., VFW Post 5118, 355 Glebe Road, Easton. Community invited. Held every Friday.

title: Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 824
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the tavern of a formerly demolished village, a group of brave adventurers is approached by well-dressed, albeit frail-looking, elders who offer a reward of 700 gold to whoever is brave enough to investigate the lizard folks lair in order to gather information on their military weapons.Lauren Fierman, a board member of the Delmarva Pride Center and host of the center's Dungeons and Dragons program, moves around the conference room of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship in Easton.
With every sentence, Fierman provides history, landscape and heart to the world the group of players has carefully developed.
Delmarva Pride Center hosts an open-for-all Dungeons and Dragons, a fantasy tabletop role-playing game, on the fourth Saturday of the month.
What started as a small game event has turned into a growing community, providing a safe environment during a heightened political climate for members of the LGBQT+ community and allies to explore gender identity, sexuality and imagination.
Fierman, who acts as dungeon master (game organizer and participant in charge of creating details and challenges for the game), said the game understands and respects the personal boundaries of its players.
From allowing players to choose the character's pronouns to deciding whether or not they will act out in regional accents, the comfortability of players is key to a successful game.
In Fierman's experience, Dungeons and Dragons provided the first space for them to use different pronouns.
"I'm playing with gender, (and) I'm playing with sexuality in my characters, and it's just such a wonderful avenue to explore different identities and sexualities," Fierman said. "As a fluid person myself, it was very healthy for me to be in a very safe space with people that I trust to express those parts of me through this game."
Allie Silver, one of the local group's players, said historically Dungeons and Dragons has had a white, straight, male focus. But in recent years, the game has been claimed by LGBTQ+ people who have found the fantasy and community aspect comforting, especially if they feel isolated.
"Just creating that space of safety for yourself and for the people at your table is so important because it can become such a beautiful thing," Silver said. "And it's OK if it's not transcendent. If you just play a silly game and kill a bunch of goblins, that's fun.
"But just the joy of friendship at the table of community collaboration is what makes this game so good. Especially now more than ever, community is what we need."
Though character building is an important aspect of the game, other players said the game provides an opportunity for them to create LGBTQ+ representation that is frequently left out in the media.
Zack Parreco, a player, said often LGBTQ+ characters' stories use "queerness" as something that is othering and aimed at larger audiences to gawk at. In Dungeons and Dragons, LGBTQ+ people can build characters and stories where they can control what is important and what is normal.
"There is no pressure for queerness to be a performance for others. It is allowed to just exist," Parreco said. "Maybe we make it big or maybe it's just a normal trait in the world. Either way, we get to fully control our queerness and its expression."
Outside of the game world, players are able to take aspects of their fictional characters into their real lives. Some bring with them new pronouns, and others, like Silver, bring back more courage.
Silver shared that when she started playing, she was "an anxious little mouse," and, when she was comfortable, she began playing a bold character whose main trait was being able to stand up for everybody.
"It was a really fun character, and in the process it gave me permission to find my own courage in my real life and now, in my professional life," Silver said. "I'm an adviser for a Pride group. I volunteer in a bunch of different spaces, and I work to help people and I think that's something eight years ago I would have been terrified to do."
According to Fierman, this space is particularly important due to the rise in policies rolling back LGBTQ+ protections since President Donald Trump's inauguration. These policies include executive orders prohibiting gender-affirming health care for those under 19 and designating that the country recognizes only two sexes.
Fierman said now more than ever community and joy needs to be prioritized. This game provides a space to escape from the pressures of the outside and create a physical, mental and emotional space for anyone that needs to get away.
"The goal of a lot of these anti-LGBTQ policies and misinformation is to take away our joy. They want us to go away, and I think combating hate with love and combating hate with joy is the most powerful thing you can do because that's what's going to keep us going. That's what kept our community fighting back for generations."
Delmarva Pride Center hosts monthly events including Gender Expression Movement, Elder and Intergeneration Social and Parents and Allies Groups.

title: Easton traffic dashboard gives residents detailed look at crash trends
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton traffic dashboard gives residents detailed look at crash trends

 July 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Residents can now easily access traffic statistics online thanks to a new traffic dashboard released by the town last week.The Easton Interactive Traffic Dashboard allows users to view up-to-date vehicle, pedestrian and bicycle data from 2018 to the present.
It includes maps, charts and filters that allow users to see crash information based on time of day, where the crash took place and the weather circumstances. Residents can find specific information on categories such as drunk driving, Route 50 and distracted driving incidents.
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said it will be a valuable resource for the community to better understand where an alarming number of accidents or traffic citations may happen.
"We are focusing on making transportation safety in Easton better," Lowrey said. "We're trying to take a methodical approach, a thoughtful approach to it. … Here is a resource, here's a transparent resource to see what is going on in the town where you live."
Ron Engle, a former town council member, helped spearhead the project, along with the Washington College Geographic Information Systems Program and the Maryland Highway Safety Office. Engle has a background in law enforcement and with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Sean Lynn, the GIS program manager at Washington College, presented the tool to the Easton Town Council on Monday.
"Hopefully it allows the folks here in the town to be able to get the information quickly," Lynn said.
Ever since the pandemic in 2020, Lowrey said it's been hard to recruit officers. With limited human resources but a need to improve traffic safety, Lowrey began to think about solutions from an "engineering" standpoint.
"An officer sitting at a location, the impact ends soon after the officer leaves," he said. "Engineering (and) other means are more of a 24-hour solution."
Lowrey added that it'll help not just residents, but his team of officers as well. The department will be better-equipped to answer questions such as, "How many of these are left turn-related? How many of these are red light-related?," Lowrey said.
The dashboard is a step in completing a Strategic Highway Safety Plan for the town. Engle, Lowrey and Mayor Megan Cook have been working to develop the plan.
Lowrey said a Strategic Highway Safety Plan will open up the ability for the town to acquire grant funding. He pointed to Salisbury as a local jurisdiction that has embraced the state's "Vision Zero' initiative that was passed by the state legislature in 2019.
"Behind it is the notion that you try to reduce fatalities and serious injury accidents down to zero," Lowrey said. "It's a pretty big goal, a really difficult one."
According to Lowrey, a plan outline for Easton will be completed in about a month. Engle told council members on Monday that a lack of data was perhaps the "biggest problem" for the town in terms of developing a highway safety plan.
Engle said the dashboard will be a "strong compliment" to developing the plan in line with the Vision Zero initiative.
"I would hope by fall that we're at a place where we can present a finalized plan before the council with a pretty good idea that they're going to approve it," Lowrey said.
The interactive traffic dashboard can be accessed by visiting https://eastonmd.gov/196/Police and clicking on the dashboard image. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hurlock man sentenced to 18 years after being caught with 11,000 grams of cocaine
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Hurlock man sentenced to 18 years after being caught with 11,000 grams of cocaine

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Crime 
 
 267
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — In Queen Anne's County, a Hurlock man pleaded guilty to possession with intent to distribute nearly 12,000 grams of cocaine.According to State's Attorney Lance Richardson, Ta'Bron Latray Todd entered the plea of guilty on Oct. 2 for possession with the intent to distribute and the serious traffic offense of fleeing and eluding a police officer on foot.
Todd was sentenced by the Hon. C. Lynn Knight of the Queen Anne's County Circuit Court to 20 years, execution of the sentence suspended as to all but 18 years to serve for the drug offense and one year, suspended, consecutive, for the traffic offense. Upon his release from incarceration, Todd will be on 36 months of supervised probation.
The conviction was based on an April 13 incident in which Maryland State Police and Queen Anne's County Sheriff's deputies were on the look-out for a stolen vehicle, Richardson said. During attempts to make a stop on this vehicle, the driver fled. The vehicle pursuit ended in a foot chase behind a residence on Wye Mills Road in Wye Mills.
Richardson said when Todd was apprehended, he was in possession of suspected cocaine, which was submitted for analysis at the Maryland State Police Crime Lab. The lab confirmed 11,892.2 grams of cocaine, a schedule II controlled dangerous substance. Further investigation by the Queen Anne's County Drug Task Force revealed Todd possessed this cocaine with the intent to distribute it. Members of the Task Force estimated the street value of this cocaine to be over one million dollars.
Todd also had a 2019 conviction from Talbot County for Possession with Intent to Distribute.

title: Supreme Court handed Democrats a gift
author: Susan Estrich
content:
Supreme Court handed Democrats a gift

 August 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Susan Estrich | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The decision of the United States Supreme Court in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization overruling Roe v. Wade may be the best worst thing to happen to Democratic politics in recent years.It is moving voters, and if there was any doubt of that, look at the results in Ohio this week, where a thinly disguised referendum designed to make it more difficult to pass a constitutional amendment protecting abortion rights failed at the polls on Tuesday.Republicans had proposed an initiative to require a supermajority of 60% to amend the state Constitution - a special new requirement intended to make it more difficult to pass an abortion rights amendment come November.The biggest supporter of the initiative was the D.C. based Susan B.Anthony Pro-Life America.Voters smelled a rat - and turned out in record numbers to vote no. The amendment lost by 14 points in a state that Donald Trump carried by 8 points.We may not be as narrowly divided, not on every issue, not nearly as polarized, as the purveyors of fake news would have you believe.That bodes well for the efforts that began this week in another key state, where the effort is to place a constitutional amendment on abortion on the ballot in November 2024.The more states with abortion on the ballot in November 2024, the more the issue will drive votes to Joe Biden.This week, prochoice groups in Arizona announced that they had united and would begin a petition drive to collect enough signatures to put an amendment on the ballot in November 2024 protecting a woman's right to choose abortion prior to viability.The logic behind these efforts is simple and straightforward.Abortion drives votes. The polls are clear. Choice dominates.More than 60% of all Americans support Roe v. Wade. The Republican Party doesn't know how to deal with that without offending its base, which expects it to be proactive with a losing hand, a strategy that is doomed to failure.So it continues not only to fight losing battles against constitutional amendments proposed by pro-choice coalitions but also to engage in expensive and poorly conceived efforts like the one in Ohio, which was designed to circumvent the coming constitutional battle; Ohio is the only state with abortion on the ballot this November, and both sides have raised millions of dollars.The coalition supporting the Arizona initiative includes the American Civil Liberties Union of Arizona, Planned Parenthood Advocates of Arizona, NARAL Arizona, Affirm Sexual and Reproductive Health, Arizona List and Healthcare Rising Arizona.Current law in Arizona bans most abortions after 15 weeks. The proposed amendment provides for a right to choose abortion prior to viability, typically 22-24 weeks of pregnancy, with exceptions for the life or health of the mother.The opposition is ready for a fight.In a statement, Cathi Herrod, president of the Center for Arizona Policy told reporters, "Our initial viewing of the measure reveals an extreme power grab by an industry that sees no limits to abortion." Maria Birnbaum, the Arizona state director for Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America, told reporters the proposal was "repugnant to the values of our state," because "Arizonans believe in protecting the unborn and serving their mothers." The point is: If the coalition can collect enough signatures, the voters will decide. And they will be the same voters who will be choosing who Arizona sends to the Electoral College.In a statement released on Tuesday, Democratic Gov. Katie Hobbs expressed her support for the coalition's effort and said she was "confident that Arizonans will vote for reproductive freedom next November." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Jay Hudson appointed St. Michaels Commissioners President
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Jay Hudson appointed St. Michaels Commissioners President

 June 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 164
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Commissioners Jay Hudson was appointed by the Commissioners of St. Michales to be the new commissioners president this month.Every year the commissioners select a new president, vice president and treasurer.
Commissioners Vice President Katrina Whittington retained her position and Commissioner Alexis Roiter was appointed to treasurer.
Hudson and Roiter were elected in during the 2024 election, along with {span}David Wojciechowski.
Whittington was elected in 2022 along with Alfred Mercier.
While Hudson said he is not one for titles, he hopes to continue to serve the town the best he can.
"I'm happy to serve my community," Hudson said. "I've never been a title guy, but it's nice to to be recognized for for doing good work.
"This is probably the highest honor someone can be given as recognition for trying to do good by the community. So, I'm very humbled by the nomination and I look forward to serving as president as well as I can and continue to serve my community the best I can.

Led by local beekeeper, Jim Scoggins, this course will provide insights into the world of hobbyist, sideliner and commercial beekeepers. title: New virtual museum displays artifacts from home of Harriet Tubman’s father
author: Konner Metz
content:
New virtual museum displays artifacts from home of Harriet Tubman’s father

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 520
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new virtual collection of historic artifacts is shedding light on the early life of abolitionist Harriet Tubman and her father, Ben Ross.Archaeologists for the Maryland Department of Transportation led efforts in uncovering many items, such as plates, bowls and pitchers, in work done at Ross' home deep in the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge in Dorchester County.
Experts spent the last four years finding and identifying hundreds of artifacts. Julie Schablitsky, MDOT's chief of cultural resources, said it all began when they found an 1808 half-dollar coin on the site.
"That coin gave us inspiration to keep on digging and keep on working," Schablitsky said.
Earlier this week, the department announced the artifacts and unveiled The Ben Ross Homeplace, an online museum since the physical site isn't open to the public.
Some of the artifacts provide insight into Ross' life as an enslaved person in the 19th century, as well as Tubman's early years, during which she learned how to live off the land.
Archaeologists found a lock to a door, which Schablitsky says may indicate Ross had some form of independence from his enslaver, Anthony Thompson.
"That's a bit of negotiated independence that not everybody would have had who was enslaved," she said.
Schablitsky pointed out a tobacco pipe with a bald eagle. While many may assume it's a patriotic symbol, she says it could be a "subtle signature" of defiance.
"I wondered that, in his hand or the hand of Harriet Tubman and her mother, … if that was somehow a way of resistance — (if) that symbol was there for freedom rather than allegiance to the United States," Schablitsky said.
Schablitsky and MDOT media relations manager David Broughton say the process of working in the wetlands of Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge was demanding due to weather conditions, mosquitos, snakes and more.
While the team knows the approximate area Ross' home was in, it didn't locate the exact markings or corners of the home. The exact location is "lost to time," Schablitsky said, but the online museum preserves as much as possible.
"It could be a valuable tool … for teachers and their children," Broughton said.
'RUSH AGAINST TIME'
Archaeologists aren't just battling the elements. They're working on a limited clock.
"Climate change, sea level rise made digging very, very difficult," Schablitsky said. "Within the next decade, I know that I'm not going to be able to return there."
Schablitsky said even when work began back in 2021, environmental conditions impacted their work. Holes already dug would fill up with water after just a lunch break, Schablitsky said.
Sea level rise makes the preservation and historical work even more pressing, experts say.
"We're definitely in a rush against time," Schablitsky said. "The waters are coming up, they're percolating up through the ground."
Amid the challenges, descendants of Tubman and Ross were able to join archaeologists at the wetlands of Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge. Schablitsky said the humility and gratitude they expressed to be able to dig at the historical site was impactful.
"The most meaningful part of the process was to have the descendants of Harriet Tubman and Ben Ross down on the site, walking where they walked, in her footsteps, in his footsteps," she said.

title: The Zebra Gallery: a place for 'evolutionary' artists
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
The Zebra Gallery: a place for 'evolutionary' artists

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 696
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For Susa Schauer, art has stayed consistent in her life no matter her career. Whether it was being a professional woodturner or a neuroscientist, her heart has kept its love for creativity.Schauer's The Zebra Gallery has provided Easton with a collection of "evolutionary" art and artists.
Her journey to opening the business began during the COVID-19 pandemic, when she was diagnosed with cancer. She described her diagnoses as a wake-up call. It pushed her to make her dream gallery a reality.
"I thought if I'm ever going to open a gallery, maybe I should (now)," Schauer said. "Life is short. So this beautiful spot across in the Tidewater came open, and I kind of leapt into it."
Schauer's decision to not wait allowed her to create a place that would not only help her through the pandemic and her illness, but also helped her establish a community she loved.
Schauer said her choice in name for her gallery came as a bit of surprise to her. She did not have a particular connection with zebras growing up, but one day she received a text from her daughter-in-law saying her grandson, who was 3 years old at the time, had just been diagnosed at Johns Hopkins with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, an illness that affects the skin, joints and blood vessels.
After some research, she learned the symbol for Ehlers Danlos Society is a zebra. The symbol called to her and she decided to name her gallery after the animal. Additionally, she made a commitment to give 10% of proceeds to Ehlers Danlos research.
"So I took the name Zebra Gallery, and thought it was destined to be," Schauer said. "It has made just perfect sense for me in terms of where I am in my life, making this more than just about me, selling other people's art, but in fact, also giving back to some degree. So it feels like a really nice circle."
Now, Schauer's gallery features local and international artists. Schauer said when looking for artists to feature in her gallery she seeks art that is evolving, risk-taking and intriguing. Though she has a love for traditional art, she said she wants to help foster high-end art with a contemporary spin.
In her own work, she has worked in a variety of media including portrait painting, woodturning and thread painting.
Ingrid Matuszewski, a featured artist at the Zebra Gallery, said she had been a long time admirer of Schauer's art and it has been a pleasure to work with Schauer in her gallery. Matuszewski, who got into portrait painting later in life, said working with Schauer has established a community of growth for her and her art.
"I think Easton has amazing galleries, so I think the Zebra Gallery complements the other ones in a way that maybe hasn't been there before and represented before because it's more of a contemporary take on art," Matuszewski said. "I think Susan tries to get in touch with artists who just kind of have different viewpoints on things."
Adam Himoff, a muralist at the Zebra Gallery, said Schauer's gallery is the first gallery he had been featured in. Her excitement for his work was magnetic, and her love for art in general drew him in.
"I met Susan, and she lights up a room and has some amazing energy," Himoff said. "And we talked about my art and her art, and I shared photos of my other work. She had seen the mural before. And she was amazing. She just lit up, and without a millisecond passing just expressed so much excitement and interest in the work. And so it just seems clear that energy was very convincing."
Schauer said she loves the people on the Eastern Shore, and the opportunity to have her gallery feature local talent, she said, has been wonderful.
"There really are so many spectacular people in this town and visiting this town, it's why I came here from grad school and never left 40 years ago," Schauer said. "It's a beautiful area, and we have a remarkable group of both artists and buyers, and they're all wonderful people who have great stories to tell. So every day is a kind of learning and creating."

title: 'A testament to our shared values' - Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast marks 40th anniversary Oct. 26
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'A testament to our shared values' - Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast marks 40th anniversary Oct. 26

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 965
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - For 40 years, the prayer breakfast hosted by the mayor of Easton has brought local leaders together to break bread, support each other and invoke the help of God, with inspiring messages from those living out their faith in the community.Celebrating this milestone Thursday morning, Oct. 26, were about 150 Talbot County elected leaders, county and town administrators, law enforcement officers, clergy and citizens.They prayed, sang along to familiar songs and hymns, and connected over a buffet breakfast at the Tidewater Inn.After Easton Police officers presented the colors and led the Pledge of Allegiance, Katherine Tooley of Immanuel Lutheran Church in Easton led the singing of "God Bless America." Amy Steward served as mistress of ceremonies, and Mayor Megan Cook greeted the attendees."Gathering together each year is a testament to our shared values and our dedication to fostering a sense of community," Cook said."It allows us to celebrate our friendships, nurture new ones and reinforce our duty to support one another." Also attending the event were former Mayor Robert Willey and his wife Betsy, who, representing the First Baptist Church, read scripture from the New Testament.Both Cook and Willey were honored with official citations from the Maryland General Assembly, delivered by State Sen. Johnny Mautz, R-37, and Del. Chris Adams, R-37B."When you look at the news and walk down the street, you know now, more than ever, we need prayer amongst the business community and our political leaders," Adams said.Mautz said the morning was "very significant" and called for applause to mark the occasion.The guest speakers were two local servant-leaders who work primarily with youth and are active in their local churches. They shared very different testimonies of how they see God working in their lives and the lives of others.Claudia Reyes emigrated from Guatemala as a child and serves in Hispanic youth ministries with her husband Eliud, the pastor of First Hispanic Baptist Church in Easton. They have been married for 29 years and have four children.Her ministry in the Talbot County Detention Center, where she hears stories of addiction and exploitation, has convinced her that "evil is all around us." "We live in bad times, and if you saw the news last night or have seen the news for a couple weeks, you know exactly what I'm talking about. I can assure you that God sees the evil and through God, lives are being transformed," Reyes said. "As much as we have seen evil and destruction here in our community, we see more of God's grace and mercy." Referring to the rise of drug addiction and sex trafficking she is aware of, Reyes said, "Our youth here in our community are not for sale for evil. They are to be rescued.They are to be saved." Reyes encouraged attendees to pray because "prayer is very powerful," to become aware of the problems youth face and to "do something." Raised on a farm near Cordova and active in the 4-H program, Linda Saathoff Brown is a lifelong member of Immanuel Lutheran Church. She called herself a "farm girl, teacher, wife, mother and Nana." She has been married to Wesley Brown for 46 years and has taught in Talbot County Public Schools for 47 years.Sprinkling her talk with Bible verses and contemporary praise song lyrics, Brown shared "My Story, God's Glory," borrowing a title of one of her favorite songs by Matthew West.On the exact one-year anniversary of a surgery following a life-threatening fall that could have left her paralyzed, Brown shared ten miracles she said were evidence of God healing her through the prayers of friends from Cordova to Trinidad.Despite dire indications that she may never walk again because of five vertebrae that were either "crushed or cracked," Brown was able to return home without a walker and celebrate Thanksgiving with Amish friends from Lancaster, who brought a van load of food and the greeting, "Our fervent prayers are answered," she said."Thanksgiving took on a whole new meaning" and she "has been blessed beyond measure," Brown said.Local clergy reading scripture and leading prayers were the Rev. Demetrius Price of Union Baptist Church; the Rev. Elmer Davis, a district superintendent in the Peninsula-Delaware Conference of The United Methodist Church; Kennedy Siaw, youth minister of Oasis Church; and C.B. Nagel of Cru, formerly Campus Crusade for Christ International.Before leading a prayer for leadership, Siaw challenged attendees to reflect on their reason for attending the breakfast and reminded them that "true leadership is to become the servant of all," after the example of Jesus Christ.The Rev. Christian Jensen of Denton has been chaplain of the Maryland General Assembly for 23 years and attended the first Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast and "most of the intervening 40," he said.He is also the Maryland representative for the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C."It's a blessing to see an important tradition like this carry on through, regardless of what changes there are in political administration," Jensen said. "To see something like this continue on is a good reflection on everyone's ability to get along with one another and understand what's important." 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
From left, Easton Mayor Megan Cook, the Rev. Demetrius Price and Amy Steward share the dias at the 40th annual Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
From left, State Sen. Johnny Mautz; former Mayor Robert Willey; Mayor Megan Cook; and Del. Chris Adams pose with citations marking the 40th annual Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast Oct. 26.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, left, and State Sen. Johnny Mautz share a light moment at the buffet during the Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Cordero Proctor of the Easton Police Department rolls the U.S. flag after the Pledge of Allegiance that opened the 40th Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast Oct. 26.

title: Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is complete

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 1257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — The Lakeside wastewater treatment plant is built, running and ready for the next step in the Lakeside development plan, which is transferring ownership to the town of Trappe.Two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented during a recent Trappe Council meeting. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
This controversial project has faced lawsuits, petitions and an array of public outcry over environmental concerns, but it is an essential step in moving forward with the Lakeside development.
First proposed over 20 years ago, the planned 2,501-unit Lakeside at Trappe development spans more than 850 acres off of U.S. Route 50. The development is slated to include a mix of single-family homes, townhouses and apartments, and commercial and retail spaces.
Trappe's existing plant has the capacity to take on wastewater from the development's first 120 homes. That flow will eventually be diverted to the new wastewater treatment plant serving the development, a plan approved by county legislation and via an MDE wastewater discharge permit.
Spray irrigation systemThe new plant, set with enriched nutrient removal technology, uses a spray irrigation system to discharge treated wastewater onto nearby fields.
According to the Pennsylvania Water Science Center, the sprayed wastewater either evaporates into the air, soaks into the soil or percolates through the soil and recharges the groundwater.
Robert Rauch, president of Rauch Inc., a project management and civil engineering firm for Lakeside, said spray irrigation has been recognized for years by states and the federal government as a preferred method of treated wastewater disposal.
"It is an exceptional re-use method of disposal that recharges groundwater and can provide needed nutrients to agricultural ground covers," he said. "Generally, spray irrigation does not require the highest levels of treatment, so valuable nutrients are available for plants to reduce farmers' costs for additional commercial fertilizer."
Raunch said this is based on Lakeside's developer's voluntary election to provide enhanced nutrient removal level treatment to avoid groundwater nutrient increases. The MDE discharge permit establishes strict limitations on the discharge of treated wastewater, which results in the application of a fraction of the nutrient uptake requirements of the grass planted in the irrigation field.
Raunch said that due to the high quality of the Lakeside wastewater effluent and the nutrient needs of the ground cover, there is no practical scenario in which the spray irrigation of treated effluent will negatively impact surface or groundwater.
"Ironically, the nutrient levels of the treated effluent will be so low that the farmer will have to apply fertilizer to the spray irrigation field to maintain a vigorous and healthy crop cover," he said.
Alan Girard, advocacy director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, argued that nutrients absorbed into groundwater could eventually discharge into nearby impaired rivers and streams like the Choptank River.
"I don't think people understand that the state is claiming that there will be zero discharge of nutrients to groundwater," Girard said. "The state has already demonstrated that there's a link between groundwater and surface water and surface letters that are tarred right near the discharge. So the state needs to be accountable for that issue."
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation and ShoreRivers filed separate petitions for judicial review of the permit in, citing concerns about the spray irrigation of treated wastewater and specifics of a nutrient management plan not being made available during the permit's public comment period in 2020.
Matt Pluta, Choptank riverkeeper and director of riverkeeper programs for ShoreRivers, said that the wastewater issue has been a concern for ShoreRivers due to the existing Trappe plant and how poorly it has been functioning and treating the wastewater before discharging it into Trappe Creek.
According to Pluta, the Lakeside Plant is making noticeable improvements that were not seen in the old Trappe Wastewater Plant.
"I'll go on and say that one thing that's very clear and obvious is that there will be more treatment from this new plant," Pluta said. "The wastewater will be treated to a cleaner standard. That's what we want to see. We support that. The thing that concerns us with the new plan is just the method of discharge. That's where they'll be spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields."
Pluta said the way the state permits spraying the treated wastewater onto nearby farm fields is under what he calls "legal fiction or false assumptions." When someone is spraying wastewater on a farm field, that wastewater gets taken up by the plants.
Through studying agricultural practices, Pluta has learned of the impacts of runoff and pollution on groundwater. He said there are different incentives for someone operating a wastewater treatment plant compared to farmers caring for local crops.
Pluta stated that no farmer is applying nutrients to their crops every day throughout the whole growing season. There is an incentive for wastewater treatment operators to focus on controlling their volume and not so much on a healthy crop, which Pluta said is concerning for the sake of adding too much pollution to these fields.
Each farm that receives spraying from the plant needs a nutrient management plan on how many nutrients can be put on the fields. Those plans were not public information, but because it was part of the treatment process, ShoreRiver argued to make that information public.
It was through the 2020 filed lawsuit that the permit was remanded to the Maryland Department of the Environment, which issued a new permit with fewer homes and less wastewater.
A separate lawsuit was filed against MDE by concerned residents in May 2022 asking to revoke the permit and suspend any work with a sewage system as inconsistent with the county's comprehensive plan. Though the suits was ultimately dismissed last June, MDE issued a revised discharge permit for Lakeside, approving a significantly smaller wastewater treatment plant.
The revised permit allows for an average flow of 100,000 gallons per day. A vast decrease from the 540,000 gallons per day initially requested by the developer.
OversightIn part due to the outcry and lawsuits made by residents and environmental organizations, a wave of resolutions were brought forward to better address concerns involving the Wastewater Treatment Plant.
One that stood out to many was Resolution 338, which amended Talbot County's Comprehensive Water and Sewer Plan. It requires an amendment to the comprehensive plan for any future expansion of the new Lakeside wastewater treatment plant.
Though this was deemed favorable to the environmental organizations, there were many, including members of Trappe's council, that opposed the Lakeside resolutions.
During a public hearing before the vote of Resolution 338, Brian Schmidt, Trappe Town Council president, commented opposing the resolution and stated that the county was treating Trappe differently than other towns, hurting the municipality's growth.
"We did not ask this council to intervene," Schmidt said. "MDE is the controlling authority in matters of wastewater discharge, not the county. Disguising growth legislation as wastewater discharge is not proper procedure is only impeding the town's authority to control its own growth."
Next stepsDuring the June 5 Trappe Town Council meeting, two Lakeside transfer agreements were presented. These agreements are the first steps in eventually passing over ownership of the wastewater treatment plant to the Town of Trappe.
According to Showalter, Once the initial phase of the wastewater treatment plant is complete and turned over to the town, the developer remains responsible for any deficiencies between the costs of operation and maintenance and the sewer revenues collected by the Town from Lakeside residents. Additionally, the developer remains responsible for the incremental expansion of the wastewater treatment plant as the capacity is utilized.
Further discussion on the transfer agreements will be discussed and reviewed during the Town Council's next executive session.

title: Mainstay's classical music series summer concert set for Aug. 25
author: Staff Writer
content:
Mainstay's classical music series summer concert set for Aug. 25

 August 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sunday, Aug. 25, is the date for The Mainstay of Rock Hall's summer classical music concert that is part of the Hedgelawn Classical Series at The Mainstay in honor of Judy Kohl.Mainstay Executive Director Matt Mielnick praised the musicians and the program when he announced the Sunday afternoon event.
"Jason Love and Daniel Lau are both exceptional musicians and performers," Mielnick said. "The innovative and exciting program they have planned will attract a broad range of classical music lovers as well as those who are not as familiar with this genre of music."
The program is titled "Looking Forward, Looking Back." It includes a look back at classic pieces such as Claude Debussy's Sonata for Cello and Piano and Johannes Brahms's Sonata No. 2 for Cello and Piano. It also includes Jessica Meyer's Swerve, a piece originally written for viola that, since its premiere in March 2017, is attaining iconic status among musicians and audiences alike. In addition to the pieces for cello and piano, Love and Lau will each perform solo pieces.
Love is an award-winning cellist, conductor, and educator, and the former music director and conductor of the Columbia Orchestra. As a cellist, Love has performed and premiered a wide array of concertos with leading U.S. orchestras. He has performed with the Columbia Orchestra Piano Trio for more than a decade.
Lau has appeared in recitals and with orchestras throughout North America and Europe. His solo and chamber performances have been well received by audiences and critics alike. He performs frequently with Camerata Philadelphia, the Port City Music Festival Players, and Amici Music. He is a founding member of the Ravel Trio that has been praised for its "Splendid interpretation, vigorous and nuanced playing."
Love and Lau are both graduates of the Peabody Conservatory of Music of Johns Hopkins University.
Showtime for this Mainstay concert event is 4 p.m. Tickets are $15 in advance of the show and can be purchased online at mainstayrockhall.org.

title: Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An experimental pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones saw some success in its first semester being implemented at Caroline County Public Schools.Cellphone pouches created by the company Yondr were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last semester.
"We've been pleased with the outcome, Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "You see attentiveness much higher in classrooms, kids learning how to talk to each other, even in the cafeteria. It's been really cool to see at the middle schools."
The students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phone are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
Every classroom in Caroline County comes equipped with a wired phone for use in case of an emergency, and teachers have been given a special pair of scissors to cut through cellphone pouches if needed.
For students with health needs, the schools offer special services allowing students to check their phones for medical purposes only.
There have been talks within the county of expanding cellphone pouches to ninth graders in coming years, but that determination has not yet been made, district officials said.
In determining whether the pouch program will be expected, the district still has to weigh the pros and cons, officials said. They hope that by the end of the school year they will have a solid understanding of the program's successes and shortcomings.
SUCCESSES
The pouches have done a good job at keeping students off their phones during the school day, district officials said. But beyond that, the middle schools where the pouches have been implemented have seen some other benefits from the program.
The cellphone pouches help prevent cyber bullying in the school during the school day, they said. Students have needed less disciplinary intervention since the pouches were rolled out.
"We've seen about a 21% reduction in discipline incidents," Simmons said.
Simmons also said teachers report that taking cellphones out of the picture has allowed them to better focus on instructing students.
"We ask a lot of our teachers, most of our class sizes average 20 to 20 plus students, so if you're asking them to improve reading or improve mathematics on top of being able to see if they're on cellphones it's a lot," Simmons said. "With the pouches they don't have to be the cellphone police."
Although schools don't yet have test scores back for last semester, the superintendent said pass rates have gone up with the cellphone pouches.
DIFFICULTIES
Reception of the cellphone pouches has not been entierly positive among students and parents in the district, Simmons said.
Students have tried to tamper with or break into their pouches during the school day on multiple occasions.
"They're not indestructible, they're not the end all be all, but they are a great preventative tool to put in place," Simmons said. "They're easy to tell if somebody's tampered with one, It's also easy to tell if a kid has their phone or has a phone out because they don't want their pouch or pouches to look empty."
Some parents do not like the idea of the phone pouches because they prefer to have a direct line of communication with their child, Simmons said.
Students have not yet been polled on their feelings about the pouches, but the districts plans to weigh student attitudes toward the program in any future decisions made.
"I think overall, we're seeing a positive impact on the academics, on the social skills piece. If we asked kids if they'd rather have access to their devices, I'm sure they would," Simmons said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Broncos, Dobbins reach 1-year deal
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Broncos, Dobbins reach 1-year deal

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The Denver Broncos beefed up their offensive backfield on Tuesday, agreeing with free agent running back J.K. Dobbins on a one-year deal worth up to $5.25 million.A 2020 second-round pick by Baltimore, Dobbins has an extensive injury history, including an ACL tear in 2021 and a torn Achilles tendon in 2023, but he's been productive when healthy.
He gained a career-best 905 yards on 195 carries and tied his career high with nine rushing touchdowns last year with the Los Angeles Chargers despite missing four games with a sprained knee.
Word broke of Dobbins' acquisition just as the first day of the Broncos' mandatory minicamp was wrapping up, and coach Sean Payton was coy when asked about, saying, "I'm not going to answer to any reports. I think we're close."
When Dobbins visited the team last week, Payton said: "It's just another opportunity to possibly bring in another good football player to help us win."
If healthy, Dobbins figures to be one of the primary ballcarriers along with rookie R.J. Harvey, a second-round draft pick out of Central Florida. Other running backs on the roster include second-year pros Blake Watson and Audric Estime, third-year player Jaleel McLaughlin and fourth-year pro Tyler Badie.
A lot will be expected of Dobbins on third down after the Broncos lost their best pass protector in their backfield when Javonte Williams left for Dallas in free agency.
One of Dobbins' best games last season was at Denver in mid-October, when he rushed 25 times for 96 yards and a touchdown in the Chargers' 23-16 win.
"Yeah, he's a good back, especially when healthy," Broncos safety Brandon Jones said. "We kind of go back a little bit to high school and college, so I'm very familiar with him as a person and his game on the field. Yeah, he's a baller. He was one of the running backs that had the better rushing games against us last year.
"So, I'm super excited for him to be here."

title: Farm museum seeks donations for facilities
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Farm museum seeks donations for facilities

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While work continues on the new structure at the Cecil County Farm Museum and Regional Agricultural Center in Elkton, volunteers with that non-profit organization are fundraising to cover costs beyond what grants CCFM has received."We're looking to raise $100,000," said Matt Stauffer, president of the board of directors. "A portion of that $100,000 is to finish the building."
The bulk of those funds will go toward fees and expenses to run septic to the new bathrooms and commercial kitchen under construction at the museum at 820 Appleton Road.
"We're mandated to run a sewer line," Stauffer said, adding the museum was connected to water via the Cecil School of Technology.
The septic system will get connected to the line the county is running to its new Emergency Medical Services building planned for Elk Mills. Stauffer said that would run to the south of the museum and be the closer connection. However, the timeline on that is not set because the county has not yet awarded the contract, Stauffer said.
CCFM received $95,000 in a 2021 bond bill from the Maryland General Assembly and $150,000 from the Upper Shore Regional Council. Museum directors figure $80,000 is needed to make the sewer connection.
Anyone wishing to make a donation should go online to: https://www.paypal.com/donate/?hosted_button_id=H7E3DZ35WTSGW
Stauffer said that, regardless of the status of the sewer line, the building will likely be opened to the public sometime next year.

title: Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1051
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump is intensifying his push to eliminate federal funding for National Public Radio (NPR) and Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) stations."NPR and PBS, two horrible and completely biased platforms (Networks!), should be DEFUNDED by Congress, IMMEDIATELY," Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform Thursday.
"Republicans, don't miss this opportunity to rid our Country of this giant SCAM, both being arms of the Radical Left Democrat Party. JUST SAY NO AND, MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!!!," Trump said.
Earlier this week, Trump also said from the Oval Office he backed eliminating federal funding for public media.
Congressional Republicans are looking at funding for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which helps fund PBS and NPR stations nationwide.
CPB received $535 million in the most recent annual federal budget. The nonprofit was created by Congress in 1967.
"Reducing or eliminating CBP funding would save the federal government little (maximum of $535 million) while having dire though not universally fatal consequences for public broadcasting," said Michael Montgomery, a political scientist and professor at the University of Michigan-Dearborn.
Montgomery contends the funding elimination push from Trump and conservatives is about their objections to what they see as NPR's and PBS' liberal slants.
"Make no mistake, if it happens, killing CPB will not be about saving money - this is about quieting voices and content that those on the right find objectionable or inconvenient," Montgomery said.
Some of Trump's most ardent supporters in the GOP-controlled Congress also want to eliminate government money for public media.
"We will defund NPR and PBS!!," said U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Georgia, in a social media statement responding to Trump. "The American people will NOT pay for disgusting Democrat propaganda anymore!!."
Greene is critical of PBS' coverage of LGBTQ communities, including saying at a congressional hearing Wednesday that it promotes a "trans agenda" pointing to a local affiliate's airing of a segment featuring drag artists.
During the same hearing on CPB funding Wednesday, U.S. Rep. Brandon Gill, R-Texas, grilled NPR President CEO Katherine Maher about her progressive social media posts on white supremacy, reparations and civil unrest in 2020 and 2021.
Maher became NPR boss in 2024.
She said her views have evolved, that NPR was working to offer a wider variety of perspectives in its coverage and had created new protocols to avoid bias, stressing the need for editorial independence.
Maher also stressed the need for public media in rural and lower-income communities.
"Public radio is very often the only news service in places where market economics does not support the expense of local news," she told the House panel.
Montgomery said NPR gets approximately 1% of its funding from CPB compared to roughly 14% for PBS.
"At the local level, an end of CPB funding would hit public TV harder than radio but public broadcasters of both types are likely to cut back, consolidate, or go silent," he said.
Public TV and radio stations and programs they produce would have to backfill any lost federal funding with money from other sources including donors, foundations and corporations.
Rick Ellis, founder and managing editor of Minnesota-based AllYourScreens.com (which tracks media news and industries), said defunding has been a desire of conservatives who either don't like government money for media outlets or "what they consider to be liberal programming."
"They haven't been able to eliminate the spending in the past in large part because the areas that would be most impacted by the cuts are rural areas that are also Republican strongholds. And overall, government financing for public media is pretty popular with voters," he said.
Ellis points to a Pew Research Center poll released Wednesday showing 24% of respondents favor nixing government funding for PBS and NPR, while 43% support public media funding and 33% are not sure.
"In theory, it would probably be politically less complicated for public media to move away from government funding. But while it is overall a small slice of public media financing, it's tough to replace any other way," Ellis said.
He said larger public media outlets in bigger, more affluent cities will survive the funding loss.
"But it would be enough of a loss to decimate outlets in Alaska, Hawaii and a number of Midwestern and Southern states, which are smaller and already struggle to get funding from foundations, viewers and listeners," Ellis said.
A number of local and statewide NPR and PBS stations have not yet responded to requests for comments about defunding and how they might navigate a new financial landscape, including their ties to universities and community colleges (which are also under fire from Trump).
The Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 has called for defunding CPB in its austerity blueprints, citing liberal biases and questioning the necessity of government outlays.
Elon Musk, who owns the X social media platform and runs Trump's Department of Government Efficiency efforts, has also echoed conservative calls to defund public media, in particular NPR. Trump said earlier this week DOGE efforts could also target public media funding.
Irina Tsukerman, president of New York-based Scarab Rising Inc. (a geopolitical consulting firm) said funding cuts could result in public media jobs cuts, less local programming and potentially station closures.
She also sees wider media impacts.
"Public media plays a unique role in the media ecosystem, providing high-quality, in-depth journalism that is free from the commercial pressures faced by corporate media," Tsukerman said, pointing to investigative, cultural and educational content that might not be pursued by other outlets.
'The removal of federal funding would push these stations to rely more heavily on private donations and corporate sponsorships, potentially influencing editorial independence and leading to content shifts that prioritize profitability over public service," she said.
Trump and his populist backers are vehement critics of many traditional media outlets, accusing them of liberal bias.
Trump routinely calls journalists "enemies of the state," frequently characterizing critical coverage of himself and his administration as fabricated or "witch hunts."
A number of major U.S. media outlets and social media platforms are owned by conglomerates such as the Fox Corp. and Walt Disney Co. or some of the wealthiest persons in the world such as Musk, Amazon founder and Washington Post owner Jeff Bezos and Meta/Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg.
The latter trio were all front and center at Trump's inauguration in January inside the U.S. Capitol.
"A weakened public media sector benefits those who prefer a media environment dominated by private interests, where corporate-backed outlets and partisan networks can exert greater influence over public discourse," Tsukerman said.

title: County council approves change to alcohol code allowing for possible liquor store in Trappe
author: Natalie Jones
content:
County council approves change to alcohol code allowing for possible liquor store in Trappe

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 239
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council on Tuesday approved a change to the county's alcoholic beverage code, paving the way for a liquor store to be considered and established in Trappe.The bill, first introduced in November, came after a request from several Trappe residents hoping to develop a liquor store within the town.
The existing county code included certain restrictions on the issuance of off-sale licenses, or licenses that allow the sale of alcohol for off-premises consumption.
According to Patrick Thomas, the county attorney, a formula limits the number of off-sale licenses that can be issued.
Thomas said Trappe does have some off-sales licenses, but the town does not have a Class E license, which is required to open a liquor store. It's the only municipality in Talbot County that does not have one.
"This would allow any municipality to have up to one Class E establishment, so that way, residents of Trappe would have the same access to a store that others in the county have," he said.
Town residents currently have to drive to Easton or Cambridge to shop at a liquor store.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher emphasized that the council does not issue liquor licenses — the county liquor board does — but the bill enables that the board to be able to review one for the town.
"Without this legislation, a new business would not be possible," he said. "So this is enabling legislation for sure."
The bill was approved unanimously.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: It takes a village
author: T.D. Nichols Denton Church of the Seventh-day Adventists
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: It takes a village

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T.D. Nichols Denton Church of the Seventh-day Adventists | Section: News 
 
 238
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Wherever we live, work or interact with others within or across communities, all of us benefit and are affected to one extent or another in sharing and collectively seeking solutions.We need each other to be engaged in building, improving, expanding, making our communities, making centers that are safe, friendly, economically stable, prosperous, spiritually uplifting, culturally welcoming, diverse and nurturing because this is indeed, our community our village.
The Bible supports the idea of the ancient African proverb, "It takes a village to raise a child." The future of our community, as well as the future generations of communities, will only be as strong as the community we create by working together. I want to encourage you to find ways to get involved in your community (village). You will grow and the village will be blessed.
Today, we are often influenced by external suggestions and realities.
Social media, personal devices, broadcastings from numerous sources., and from others promoting and soliciting our support are bombarding our isolation, our values, our "joining" or "acceptance" endlessly.
Just remember, Jeremiah 10:23, informs and cautions us that it is not in us as humans in isolation nor under the influence of others to "direct" our ways. We can always turn to God's Word and enhance our abilities to participate within and across our communities in responsible, just ways that will position our contributions to work together with others to the benefit of all and meet God's approval.
