title: DCTC Masonry instructor surprised by coworkers on last day
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCTC Masonry instructor surprised by coworkers on last day

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On his last day of teaching at the Dorchester Career and Technology Center, Masonry Instructor Eddie Bailey wasn't the only one sporting a baseball cap, grey sweatshirt and jeans.More than 10 of his coworkers showed up and showed out in Bailey's well-known uniform. Some of his doppelgängers even brought their own fake metal detectors — a hobby of Bailey's.
After eight years teaching at DCTC, Bailey is hanging up his trowel and picking up his metal detector.
"You know, I love metal detecting, so I'll probably go find the Holy Grail or something," he said about what he will do in his retirement.
When Bailey came in for his last day of teaching, right before winter break began, it took a little while for him to figure out what his coworkers had done.
"I'm like, 'Wait a minute, something don't look right,'" he said. "Then, when I saw the metal detectors, I was like, 'Ohh, they got me good!'"
DCTC Principal Ashley Robinson came up with the idea.
"I was just trying to really think about how we could celebrate his time here in a way that he would enjoy and that he would feel appreciated," she said. "So I really thought the best way to do that would be with humor, since that's something he really enjoys."
In order to keep it a surprise, Robinson said she made it a part of the school's holiday spirit week.
"So he thought everyone was just dressing in comfy sweatshirts," she said. "And I let everyone else know we were really just dressing like Mr. Bailey."
Bailey, who was surprised by his coworkers' plan, thought it was funny.
"It was so great because I wasn't expecting it," he said. "I would have never expected that."
Bailey said he knew Robinson had something to do with it.
"She comes up with such cool stuff," he said, adding that she gave him a plaque with a trowel on it to commemorate his time teaching at DCTC.
He said there's a reason he would wear the similar outfit that his coworkers knew so well to work everyday.
"Working in the masonry, you can't really go in there with real good clothes on," he said. "You gotta wear your oldest stuff. Like, inside my car, all you see is dust."
Robinson said Bailey, like the rest of DCTC's staff members, epitomizes the importance of CTE education.
"The majority of the teachers here have worked in industry in their field, they have those life experiences and then they chose to come back and give back and work with kids to set them up to be successful," she said. "We were happy to have (Bailey) and happy that he was able to do this."
Bailey has had a few different careers over the years. He owned a masonry business, was a prison guard and spent four years in the Marine Corps. But teaching is in Bailey's blood. His father taught at James M. Bennett High School in Salisbury.
"He was football coach, track coach," Bailey said. "And we lived right across the street from Bennett, so I was at school every day. I knew it from top to bottom."
He has memories of cigarette smoke "flying out of the teachers' lounge" and teachers coming over to his family's house to play cards with his father.
"I mean, that was the good old days," he said.
Looking toward his retirement, Bailey has plans to further explore the hobby his DCTC coworkers know he loves.
Bailey said the Career and Technology Center staff knew about his metal detecting because he would send them photos of some of his finds.
Over the last five years, Bailey said he has gotten more and more into metal detecting. His neighbors, known as The Hoover Boys on YouTube, post metal detecting videos. They have over 100,000 YouTube subscribers. When they moved next door, Bailey said they started giving him their hand-me-downs.
Over the years, Bailey has found all sorts of things — from shoe buckle frames to Civil War bullets to cannonballs. Two of his major finds were a rare George Washington inaugural button and a pine tree shilling.
Although he has plans to do more detecting, Bailey said he'll miss his students.
"A lot of them played sports, and I'd hook them up with a sub," he said. "It was always a sub, a red Gatorade, orange Doritos."
As he moves on to his next chapter, Bailey now has fond memories of his own teaching experience to look back on.
"Oh I loved it," he said.

title: DURRIE'S DEDICATION
author: Bill Haufe
content:
DURRIE'S DEDICATION

 July 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The late Durrie Hayes would have enjoyed the afternoon of May 28, 2024, his light mustache unable to conceal that Cheshire cat-like smile.A large collection of friends, former players and assistants gathered in a loose, elongated semicircle inside the right-field foul line at Easton High's softball field on that spring day fit for a doubleheader.
Soon bats would be swung, pitches hummed, ground and fly balls collected, and runs scored as part of the school's inaugural alumni softball game.
Not everyone had come to play, but all had come to catch the pregame that featured speeches thick on compliments, and the unveiling of the newly erected scoreboard behind the center-field fence in Hayes' honor. And those who knew him well can pretty much imagine Hayes' reaction once his eyes settled on his name emblazoned across the top of the scoreboard in big, bold orange letters outlined in white on a black background.
"I can just picture him smiling that little smile he had," said Casey (Dulin) Baynard, a star on Hayes' early teams and now a Warrior assistant. "I think he would have been very proud."
Dr. Ed Baker, the longtime umpiring legend who said, "Hayes was by far the best softball coach that I every umpired a game for," agreed.
"Durrie was a very humble person," Baker said of Hayes, who died April 2, 2020 at age 70 after a brief battle with cancer. "Naturally he would be very, very pleased and honored to see such a scoreboard. But he was never looking for his name to be in flashing lights."
Jay Cappa, an assistant during Hayes' 13 years at Easton, perhaps pegged the former head coach's reaction best.
"He would have said, 'Who'd a thunk it?'" Cappa said. "I do believe he would have said, 'Who'd a thunk it?'"
Actually, it was Byrd Dog Wheeler who first thunk Hayes be memorialized, initiating the drive for a scoreboard honoring the school's Hall of Fame coach four years ago.
"It's incredible what that guy did," said Wheeler, another longtime friend and one of the ceremony's speakers. "And that one run he had there; what the last eight years? Jeez Louise."
Hayes coached the Warriors from 1995-2007, compiling an impressive 232-46 record that included seven Bayside Conference championships, six regional titles and three state championships. Wedged in that 13-year stretch was an eight-year run (2000-07), where the Warriors went 162-18 that included a 23-0 season in 2004 — an unbeaten streak that was extended to 30 games the following year — three state championships and three state runner-up finishes.
"He put in all that time going to Little League girls softball games and travel team softball games, and talking to the parents and getting them involved, and getting them to buy into the program at such a young age," Wheeler said. "By the time they got up to ninth grade they were on track and knowing what to expect and ready to play. No one else did anything like that.
"One thing he couldn't say is that, 'There's others out there that deserve that a lot more than I do.' Not a chance he could say that," Wheeler added.
Well, now hold on there big dog.
There was in fact somebody who would have penciled himself into the leadoff spot to protest that very point — Hayes.
"It was always about the girls," Wheeler conceded. "It wasn't about Durrie Hayes."
Others could easily see Hayes lobbying for his players' names to be adorned atop the scoreboard, instead of his.
"I think deep down he would have been very honored," longtime friend Debbie Urry said. "But I think he would have been embarrassed because it should have gone to the girls. He was always about the girls. He never wanted that kind of attention. I think he would have been very humbled and surprised. And he would have given credit to all the girls he ever coached."
Jay Chance, who coached with Hayes at Easton and Chesapeake College, watched the skipper consistently direct praise his players' way.
"He never really made it all about him," said Chance, who presented Hayes during the induction ceremony for Easton High's inaugural Athletic Hall of Fame class in September 2019. "It was more important to make a difference in the girls' lives than it was to win a game. That's what I liked so much about him. Although on game day you would never know that [laughing]. On game day it was about winning."
Oh, and the fun Hayes would have had filling out the lineups for both teams in the alumni game.
"He definitely would have loved the alumni game that we had after that," Baynard said.
As the ceremony wrapped up, Cappa and Chance reminisced and joked about what Hayes' take would have been on this big to-do.
"Jay said, 'Watch it. He's libel to send down a lightning bolt,'" Cappa said laughing. "I told Jay, 'He's not going to do it 'cause they're going to play a softball game. He ain't going to ruin the softball game.' He said, 'Yeah, I guess you're right.'"

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are the 10 stories that attracted the most page views on The Star Democrat's website this week. The stories are ranked in order of number of page views as of Wednesday evening.1. Caroline County animal abuse case moves to circuit court
A Caroline County District Court case concerning a Talbot County woman charged with animal cruelty has been transferred to the Caroline County Circuit Court.
Barbara Lemaire, 29, was charged in December on 34 counts of animal cruelty, including aggravated animal cruelty and failure to provide for the animals.
2. Caroline County police officer charged with second-degree assault
Caroline County Sheriff's Office Sgt. Keith Collison faces a second-degree assault charge from a domestic violence incident on Monday involving he and his former wife, according to court documents obtained by The Star Democrat.
Collison is one of three county officers assigned to patrol the town of Ridgely as part of a memorandum of understanding between Ridgely commissioners and county police.
3. St. Michaels commissioners pass ordinance on leaf blowers
After a five-year discussion on leaf blowers, the Commissioners of St. Michaels passed an ordinance limiting contractors' use of leaf blowers to certain times and days.
4. Easton election: Gunsallus, Abbatiello weigh in on housing, growth and more
Town Council president candidates Frank Gunsallus and Don Abbatiello both recognize the need to monitor and manage Easton's growth, but they each indicated different strategies on how to do so in editorial board interviews with The Star Democrat last week.
5. Strand Beach project not yet approved for completion
Although new grasses have been planted, Oxford Town Manager Holly Wahl said the town has not yet signed off on final completion of the Strand Beach project, which contractor Underwood and Associates was required to finish by April 19.
6. Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
A four-seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while landing at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville. Queen Anne's County officials said upon landing, the aircraft veered off the side of the runway into a marshy area, coming to rest partially in the water. The sole occupant was uninjured.
7. Federalsburg council member: Misuse of town funds brought to state prosecutor
Councilwoman Brandy James said she reported town investigation findings on misappropriated funds to the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor, where she said the investigation is ongoing.
8. Federalsburg says town funds were misappropriated
In a Facebook post Tuesday morning, the Town of Federalsburg released information about allegations involving misappropriation of town funds.
According to the post, the town discovered through investigation that town funds had been used to purchase "personal items."
9. 'Open up worlds': Donor gifts $1 million to BAAM girls program
Building African American Minds will be expanding its girls program thanks to a $1 million gift made by Dr. Eileen Amy Ryan of Rochester, New York.
10. Talbot County man convicted of sexually assaulting a child
Kevin Halmiton Manning, 34, was convicted of sexually assaulting a 3-year-old child in Talbot County. Manning pleaded guilty to 10 counts between two cases in the Circuit Court for Talbot County.
To read these stories and more, visit stardem.com.

title: World War II veteran celebrates 100th birthday
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
World War II veteran celebrates 100th birthday

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Private First Class Kernie Thompson's nickname was "Young Boy" when he served overseas in the U.S. Army's 599th Ordnance Ammunition Company during World War II.That's because Thompson, at age 18, was the youngest of the 40 soldiers assigned to that all-African-American unit when he joined in 1943, the start of a two-year stint in which fought alongside his comrades in England, France, Belgium, Holland and Germany.
On Wednesday (Jan. 15), that veteran once known as Young Boy celebrated his 100th birthday, a milestone marked by a party in the Community Living Center at the Perry Point VA Medical Center, where the Baltimore native has resided since 2020.
There were party hats, lots of balloons, a beautiful birthday cake and Thompson's favorite candy — Hershey's Kisses, which he calls "silver bells." The party room was packed with people, including Thompson's fellow veteran residents, VA staff and members of his church family.
Among the party guests were Army officials, including Maj. General John Cushing, who is the Commanding General; and U.S. Army Combat Capabilities Development Command (DEVCOM) Command Sgt. Major Brian Haydt.
Thompson reportedly was his usual upbeat self during the party. Thompson relies on a wheelchair and is "not able to eat regular by mouth," but he remains "sharp as a tack" mentally, one longtime friend described. The new Centenarian has outlived his children and his friends from childhood and young adulthood.
Also at the party was the woman Thompson married more than 40 years ago, Clarice Thompson, his second wife, whom he nicknamed "Reesey." Thompson reportedly gets excited whenever he hears her name or learns that "Reesey" has come to visit him.
"He is the love of my life," Clarice said, before referencing his necessary VA residency and remarking, "I miss him, but I know that he is where he is suppose to be."
Thompson is soft-spoken and is strong in his Christian faith, according to a few party attendees who were interviewed.
He served more than 40 years as the chaplain at the oldest African-American owned and operated nursing home in the state, Maryland Baptist Aged Home in Baltimore, where he volunteered once a week.
A longtime member of a city Baptist Church, where he served as a deacon until age 94, Thompson also was active for more than 40 years in the Baptist Deacons Conference of Baltimore. In addition, Thompson provided usher, or deacon, training to parishioners throughout Maryland and other states, as part of an usher ministry associated with another one of the faith-based groups that he served.
"He's the kind of man who walks humbly and talks humbly. When he speaks, you listen," Clarice said. "He's the kind of man I would recommend any young people to just take a photograph of him in their mind and take on some of his characteristics — other than Jesus' characteristics."
Clarice added, "Not only was he disciplined in the military, he's a disciplined man as he walks with God."
One of the party attendees, Joseph Miller, president of that Baptist Deacons Conference of Baltimore, and his wife have been friends with Thompson and Clarice for more than 30 years.
"He is a wonderful guy. His smile is what gets you. He seems like a quiet person. His mannerism is quiet until you start talking to him. He's powerful. He talks softly, but carries a big stick," Miller commented with a chuckle. "He loves to talk."
Along those lines, Thompson's favorite topic of discussion: The Bible.
"He loves the word of God, and he will share it with you. When I come here to the VA center and talk to the residents, they always tell me what he taught them about the word of God," Miller said.
After retiring from his career as a Baltimore City maintenance worker, Thompson worked as an usher during Baltimore Orioles home games. He had that gig for three decades and was quite popular among spectators and all employees in the Baltimore Orioles organization.
"I was there when he got his 30-year ring, and he was proud of that (ring). They knew him well at the Baltimore Orioles, from the general manager, the manager, the players, the vendors, the mascot, and they all loved Kernie Thompson," Miller said.
An only child with an interest in woodworking, Thompson entered the U.S. Army at the tender age of 18 in 1943. Defending this country during World War II is among the many admirable contributions Thompson has made during his 100 years on this earth, thus far.
Thompson left his parents' West Baltimore home and traveled to Georgia, where he completed basic training. The military then sent Thompson to Camp Breckinridge in Kentucky, where he was put in the Army's 599th Ordnance Ammunition Company, which saw combat action after its deployment to Europe.
During a Cecil Whig interview two years ago, Thompson recalled, "Being overseas at war was a great experience, but some days were pleasant and some days were scary."
The following is an excerpt of some of the World War II remembrances Thompson shared during that interview:
Thompson noted that he enjoyed talking to not only his fellow soldiers, but citizens of the countries they were deployed to about their life and what it was like living in their country.
"They would ask about the United States and we would ask about their country and we would always talk to the people, we had a good relationship," Thompson said. "With the soldiers, we would play cards and everyone always had something to say to make you laugh."
But when Thompson and his fellow soldiers weren't playing cards, telling jokes or talking with citizens, they were receiving ordnance shipments, supplying soldiers with ammunition and exercising their knowledge from basic training — something Thompson said his survival was contingent upon.
"What they teach you is important to your life, especially in combat," said Thompson. "Your life might depend on what you were taught in basic training."
Thompson recalled that that training saved his life late one night in 1944, when his company was waiting for the arrival of a munitions shipment. After his group laid down to rest before the shipment arrived, they were awakened by the sight of enemy flares falling from the skies.
According to Thompson, flares were used to illuminate areas at night so planes and infantry could properly identify enemy soldiers, weaponry and other valuable targets — such as the ammunition holds that Thompson's unit was responsible for.
"Basic training taught us that when they drop flares, don't move and turn your face to the ground," said Thompson. "If you look up, the planes could see the glare of your face and it could mess up the dilation of your eyes. It was a scary night."
In 1945, after two years of his service, Thompson — who was then 21 — received word that the war was over.
"When we heard the war was over, it was a big joy," Thompson said. "We shouted and we celebrated. When I got back, the first thing I did was go with my mother to see my grandmother and we had a nice dinner and celebrated."
Following the war, Thompson got married, had a daughter and worked.
Reflecting on his wartime military service, Thompson commented, "Being a part of the Army and serving my county was one of the most rewarding things because I felt like I was fulfilling a duty that I owed to my country and it makes me feel good,"
Thompson then remarked, "I am a blessed man to be here."

title: Black watermen share about challenges, changes on the Chesapeake
author: ANNIE HASSELGREEN Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Black watermen share about challenges, changes on the Chesapeake

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANNIE HASSELGREEN Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 847
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Van Lennep Auditorium was packed on Saturday, Feb. 17, for "Troubled Waters: Black Watermen," co-hosted by the St. Michaels Community Conversations on Race, the St. Michaels Community Center and the American Association of University Women.Panelists included Captain Lamont Wright, Reverend Dr. William Wallace, Edzel Turner and James "Captain Buck" Lynch, all of whom have been longtime watermen in varying capacities.
The men came together to engage in a dialogue about the successes and challenges of being African American watermen in honor of Black History Month.
They shared their diverse experiences on the waterways of the Chesapeake Bay with a crowd eager to learn more about the history of Black watermen on the Eastern Shore. Though the men shared similar perspectives, their roles on the water ran the gamut, but all agreed that conditions in the waters have changed drastically during their careers spanning many decades.
"My family owned a seafood factory in Bellevue," said Edzel Turner. "Back then, we'd catch so many crabs that my arms would hurt."
All of the panelists agreed that government regulations have drastically shifted the profession in many ways.
"Regulations and sanctuaries will eventually drive away most watermen," Lynch said, "and disease and the Conowingo Dam are decimating populations. We keep having to go further south (to catch anything)."
Panelists concurred that Black watermen in particular are an aging population that can't be replaced quickly enough.
"The youngest Black waterman is 60," Lynch said, "and there won't be any left in 10 years."
Many of the men are actively advocating for programs for young people to learn about life on the water so they can take the mantle for future generations.
Present in the audience was Vince Leggett, named "Admiral of the Chesapeake Bay" in 2003 by then Governor Parris N. Glendening. This is the highest honor a Maryland Governor can bestow on a private individual in the environmental arena ,and Leggett has been working for more than 30 years on preserving Black Americans' contributions to the maritime and seafood processing industries, and the Chesapeake Bay's rich culture and heritage.
In 1994, the Blacks of the Chesapeake Foundation began documenting this through a range of historical, cultural and educational activities. This included the "Chesapeake Bay Through Ebony Eyes," a book that offers a history of African American contributions in the Chesapeake's maritime industries and includes a collection of seafood recipes, poetry, photographs and sketches; and a book entitled "Blacks of the Chesapeake: An Integral Part of Maritime History," which provides a photographic history of African Americans at work as ship captains, sail makers, watermen and seafood processing plant employees.
Leggett joined the panel to echo the sentiments of his fellow watermen about the challenges facing the industry and to continue to support their common desire to honor the legacy of Black Americans who have contributed so much to it.
"African Americans have spent their lives feeding the state of Maryland," said Wright.
Conversation also included experiences shared by many of the men having been targeted by racially-motivated repercussions.
"It wasn't uncommon for the marine police to check the oysters of Black watermen and fine them, but didn't check those of the white watermen," Wright said.
Turner had a similar experience: "I've seen police come to an area with 10 to 12 boats and ticket only the Black watermen."
Lynch has been on the water for 53 years and articulated the challenges for Black watermen to success in the industry. "Blacks were unable to borrow money," he said. This meant that "white watermen had better boats and better rigs."
Although receiving loans for their businesses and inequitable fines have been a challenge, Wallace stated that watermen on the whole are a supportive group.
"There is a camaraderie among Black and white watermen. That isn't what perpetuated the division," he said. Instead, he says, unfairly targeting Blacks occurred mainly by the marine police and those charged with seafood counts.
"When I was a kid, my dad was a waterman, and I noticed that he was always the lowest on the leaderboard. He always had the lowest numbers," Wallace said. "There was a white man who I figured out was throwing a lot of his catch into an uncounted float."
Black representation in the watermen industry remains stunted. Of the 30 members of the Queen Anne's County Watermen's Association, for example, there are three Black members and 27 white, Lynch said.
But there is an active group of Black watermen and their supporters who continue to advocate for acknowledgement of the tireless efforts of their community. Also present in the audience were Drs. Dennis and Mary DeShields, founders of the Bellevue Passage Museum.
Dennis DeShields, a fourth-generation descendant of Bellevue, resolved to preserve the town's rich heritage and is leading the charge alongside wife to present this history to a wider audience and "serve as a center of cultural conservation for the community."
For some of the panelists, being out on the water daily is a collection of fond memories, but Captain Buck still ventures out most days — and wouldn't have it any other way.
"If you're a waterman, you get up with the sun," he said. "And I'm my own boss."

title: Bridge - Deception by deduction
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Deception by deduction

 December 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A7 | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 John Ruskin, who was an English art critic, discussed painters when he wrote, "The essence of lying is in deception, not in words." In bridge, sometimes you lie in words when you make, for example, a psychic bid.During the play, sometimes you lie by false carding. In today's deal, a defender fooled declarer by dropping an unnecessarily high card. However, it helped that he had calculated his "generosity" couldn't cost a trick.
In four hearts, declarer won the first trick with his club ace and cashed the heart ace, "dropping" West's queen.
Worried that East had four trumps, South immediately ran the diamond 10. East kept up the good defense, ducking his king. Suddenly fooled, South repeated the diamond finesse, but East won with the king and gave his partner a diamond ruff.
West cashed the club queen, and the heart jack was the fourth defensive trick.
Cool - but how did West know he could afford to play the heart queen? Well, if South had started with A-Jx-x of hearts, he would have played a heart to dummy's king and taken the trump finesse. So, when South started with the heart ace, East was marked with the jack. Dropping the queen was safe. Also, it couldn't mislead East, because South was marked with four hearts from the auction. (If South had opened one no-trump with five hearts, he would have drawn two rounds of trumps before taking the diamond finesse.)
However, remember, when trying a deceptive defense, be careful not to deceive your partner more than declarer.

title: Celebrating Hispanic art and artists with poster contest
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Celebrating Hispanic art and artists with poster contest

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 456
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From iconic Hispanic icons like Frida Khalo, to colorfully rich portraits of Guatemala landscapes, to a tree with all the Hispanic flags hanging from its branches, the Academy Art Museum was filled with a variety of portraits.In celebration of Hispanic cultural heritage, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center hosted a poster competition and invited community members to rejoice in the submissions.
Every year, the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center asks the Hispanic community to participate in choosing a theme for the annual celebration. Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director for Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said the theme for this year is "Ser Hispano, es Ser Valiente," which translates to "Being Hispanic is Being Brave."
The top three posters win prizes, and the first place poster will be used as the official poster for the 2025 Hispanic Heritage Month in Easton.
Roxana Tapia, judge of the competition, said the first, second and third place winners this year came from various ages and ethnicities. But they all had the common goal of celebrating Hispanic heritage.
"You don't even have to be a Latina in order to participate," Tapia said. "What I liked about this year is that we have people from all ethnicities. So if for any kids, I invite them to come over and participate, it's always fun. (Artists) should be proud of their work."
The winners of this year's competition were Piper Hambleton and Ellis Williams for their collaborative work. Their poster portrayed a large tree with flags from every Latin American and Hispanic country attached to its branches.
Alberto Gamez, a judge and ChesMRC board member, called the colorful art piece "The Tree of the Nations."
"I love that it was like a tree of life, but each branch had a different nation, and they covered a lot of them. So I love that it included everybody," Gamez said.
Gamez said he enjoyed all the art submitted this year and the various stories attached to the works, including third place winner Ahias Murillo, whose portrait "I Paint My Own Reality" showed Frida Khalo with an array of Latin American flags behind her. According to Gamez, the piece spoke on the identity and growth of Latinos.
The second place winner Majo Arrivillaga, whose portrait of two faceless individuals was meant to depict the different faces migrants have while traveling to the United States, also included a colorful landscape of Guatemala.
Arrivillaga said she loves drawing because it allows her to show people the beauty within the Latino community and encourages Latino artists of all ages to take the leap and share their work with their community.
"Being Hispanic, for me, is being a person who works, studies and centers their family," Arrivillaga said. "We are multifaceted and we can do it all. That's what makes us brave."

title: Top-sdded Mavs oust Easton
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Top-sdded Mavs oust Easton

 November 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 650
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GLEN BURNIE — It had found multiple ways to win since early October.Easton High's field hockey team had won in overtime and double overtime. It had won with 11 seconds remaining in regulation. It had won on a penalty stroke and in a 1v1. And it continued to find paths to victory no matter how big the game.
But Wednesday night against top-seeded Manchester Valley, the Warrior offense rarely found its way into the circle and had its storybook season ended in a 3-0 loss to the Mavericks in a Class 2A state semifinal at Glen Burnie High School's Pop Whayland Stadium.
Manchester Valley (16-0) advances to Saturday's 11 a.m. Class 2A state championship game where it will meet three-time defending state champion Glenelg (16-0) at Stevenson University's Mustang Stadium.
"I'm so proud of them," said Easton head coach Kim Neff, whose team had its eight-game win streak ended, finishing the year at 12-4. "Taylor Bowen again had so many shots on her that she was able to save. They battled many corners clear. It was a defensive-heavy game and they handled it very well."
Indeed, the Mavericks, who had blanked their previous three playoff opponents by a combined 27-0, were held to their lowest goal total of the postseason.
"Their whole team, they played hard," Manchester Valley head coach Denean Koontz said. "They did a very nice job of doubling us. They took us out of our game plan a little bit. They stepped to the ball very well. Defensively, they were on us everywhere. They did a very nice job of smothering the ball and smothering our players."
The Mavericks finished with 11 corners before Easton earned its first with only 1 minute, 26 seconds remaining in the game.
By then the No. 1 seed had already built a three-goal cushion that was started off a pair of first-quarter corners.
Bowen, Easton's freshman goalie, and her defense weathered Manchester Valley's first two corners in the opening 5 minutes. The Mavericks were awarded their third corner less than 3 minutes later and converted, as Lily Brookhart scored off Shelby Wurzburger's assist for a 1-0 lead.
Manchester Valley earned its fifth corner with 13 seconds remaining in the first quarter, and again capitalized, with Allie Largent setting up Brookhart's second goal with no time showing on the clock.
"They were aggressive," Neff said of Manchester Valley, which held Easton scoreless for the first time since a 1v1 loss to Queen Anne's on Oct. 1. "And their stick skills were incredible."
Bowen made a save on the Mavs' first corner of the second period, and watched her teammates foil a second corner near the end of the period.
But Easton generated little offense, the long rushes downfield by Olivia Orrell and Addie Knox were often and quickly stopped well short of the circle.
"I do feel like my girls held their own," Neff said. "And I think this is where it really comes into play not having a turf field, and not being able to practice on a turf field, and play on a turf field. It's hard to keep up with the competition. Their whole team was just fast."
Manchester Valley picked up three more corner chances in the third, but could not add to its lead as Bowen registered two more saves on corners.
"Our defense, our middies, they all stepped up," Neff said. "I will say I feel like each quarter we came out a little more aggressive cutting to the ball better. I feel if we had one more quarter you might have seen maybe a goal."
Manchester Valley put away one more goal with only 4 seconds left on the third-quarter clock, when Carroll County scoring leader Amanda Herrold scored on a breakaway.
Though they continued battling, the Warriors mounted few threats and got their first corners in succession with 1:26 left, when Mavericks' goalie Makayla Shoaf registered her lone save.
"They played hard," Koontz said of Easton. "They did a great job."

title: CWDI and Dorchester County Council not in violation of Open Meetings Act
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI and Dorchester County Council not in violation of Open Meetings Act

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 785
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Maryland's Open Meetings Compliance Board has found Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. and the Dorchester County Council not in violation of the state's Open Meetings Act for a Nov. 13 closed meeting held by CWDI.In its opinions delivered Feb. 1, the OMCB stated that CWDI was not in violation of the act because it is not a public body. It did not find the County Council in violation of the act because the council did not go into a "meeting" at the Packing House Nov. 13.
At the meeting, which brought together city and county officials and development consultants, CWDI justified going into closed session using two exceptions listed in the Maryland Open Meetings Act: "to consider a matter that concerns the proposal for a business to locate, expand, or remain" and "to discuss a matter where public discussion would adversely impact the public body's proposal process."
CWDI, a nonprofit that was formed by the City of Cambridge, Dorchester County and the State of Maryland, has been tasked with planning and developing space along the Cambridge waterfront, known as Cambridge Harbor.
Plans include public spaces like a promenade and parks, a boutique hotel and residential and mixed-use spaces along the Choptank River.
CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard said that during the meeting, CWDI talked about business deals it is working on.
Before CWDI entered into closed session on Nov. 13, WHCP reporter Jim Brady and Star Democrat Executive Editor Jim Johnson objected to the meeting being closed to the public.
Following the meeting, the Star Democrat and WHCP sent a complaint to the OMCB, alleging nine potential violations of the Open Meetings Act, including that the agenda topics were not consistent with the exceptions CWDI used to justify the closed meeting. The complaints were directed toward CWDI and the Dorchester County Council.
Although City of Cambridge staff and elected officials were also present at the November meeting, the Star Democrat and WHCP did not allege violations regarding the city's involvement in the meeting.
City Council voted against going into closed session at the Nov. 13 meeting, and one commissioner left so the city would avoid an Open Meetings Act violation.
OMCB OPINIONSAccording to the Feb. 1 opinions document, the OMCB found that CWDI didn't violate the Open Meetings Act because the non-profit is not a public body, and the act only applies to public bodies.
To determine whether CWDI could be considered a public body, the OMCB looked at how the entity was created and how its members were appointed to the board.
"As we have said before, '(p)erhaps the Maryland General Assembly might decide at some point to broaden the definition, so as to encompass all entities that carry out public functions,'" the opinions document says.
Leonard said he was not surprised by the decision made by the Compliance Board. He said it affirmed what CWDI "has said since it's beginning" — that it is a private corporation set to a public mission.
The reason CWDI listed the Open Meetings Act exceptions before going into closed session, he said, was to make CWDI's public partners feel comfortable.
"We list those exceptions, although we're not required to," Leonard said. "It's something we've done as a courtesy out of respect for our public partners since the beginning."
Brady, who objected to the Nov. 13 closed meeting, said it would be good for the state legislature to review what is considered a public body.
"I just find it unfortunate and unfathomable that an organization that's spending that kind of public money and ruling over that kind of land is not open to the public," he said.
The OMCB found that the Dorchester County Council didn't violate the Open Meetings Act because the Nov. 13 "gathering" wasn't a County Council meeting.
According to the opinions document, although all members of the council attended the gathering, the question was whether the Council "convened to consider or transact public business."
The OMCB said it could not conclude the gathering was a meeting based on the record presented.
"As we understand it, then, the Councilmembers attended the gathering to receive information, but the discussion was not a step in the Council's decision-making process regarding an item that was certain to come before the Council," the document says.
Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said he was glad to see the decision that was made.
"There was never an intention for the Dorchester County Council to be violating any confidence of trust," he said.
In its opinions, the OMCB noted that "the appearance" of business being secretly conducted doesn't "serve the purpose" of the Open Meetings Act to "increase the faith of the public in government."
"Our conclusion in no way condones the action of a quorum of the (Councilmembers) in creating what was, at the least, an appearance of impropriety," the board said.

title: Interim executive director named for Chesapeake Music
content:
Interim executive director named for Chesapeake Music

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In early September, career nonprofit professional and consultant Margaret Enloe-North assumed the leadership at one of Talbot County's premiere organizations for bringing amazing artists and performances to the Mid-Shore."We are very pleased to welcome Margaret as part of the Chesapeake Music team!" says Board President Barry Koh. "I know that her nonprofit experience will prove to be invaluable as we move forward and ultimately search for a new, permanent Executive Director in the spring."Enloe-North has spent her 30-year career entirely in the nonprofit sector. Having launched her new business, the Firebird Coaching & Consulting in 2021, she now serves as a coach for individual clients and small businesses and provides nonprofit clients with expert support in the areas of leadership, master planning, strategic communications, programming and fundraising."I really love serving as an Interim ED for organizations that are doing great work! My role allows a Board of Directors the opportunity to deeply reflect on the organization's future while also knowing that daily operations will continue to work smoothly," explains Enloe-North. "And I am really looking forward to working alongside the Board as we envision and lead Chesapeake Music into a new era. I have always appreciated both jazz and classical music and am delighted to help them bring renowned and up-and-coming musicians to the MidShore that delight and surprise our audiences."Based in Easton, Chesapeake Music is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to bring renowned jazz and classical musicians to delight, engage and surprise today's audiences, and educate, inspire, and develop tomorrow's. They have been doing it for more than 35 years. To learn more about Chesapeake Music or to purchase tickets to this concert, visit their website at chesapeakemusic.org. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Pictured is Margaret Enloe-North, new interim Executive Director of Chesapeake Music.

title: 25-year-old set to bike from Easton to Canada
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
25-year-old set to bike from Easton to Canada

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hayden Kessinger, 25, is set to bike from Easton to Canada beginning Saturday. It isn't his first cross-country bike ride.In 2023, Kessinger biked from Baltimore to San Francisco in 70 days.
Kessinger's motivation for biking across the country came from a book called "The Happiness of Pursuit" by Chris Guillebeau.
"I kind of initially had an idea to do some sort of long-distance bike ride and specifically bike across the country after reading a book," Kessinger said. "... It just sort of inspired me to think about doing something kind of crazy in the eyes of the most people or embarking on some sort of adventure or just exploring more."
Shortly after reading the book, Kessinger learned about the Ulman Foundation, a company the specializes in supporting young adults with cancer. The foundation participates in holds a bike-riding fundraiser, and Kessinger signed up.
The group raised $161,828 during their 2023 ride to San Francisco. Kessigner raised $7,431.
With new hopes on the horizon and used biking gear, Kessinger's sets his eyes on biking from Easton to Montreal, Canada this summer.
Although Kessinger will not be raising funds during this ride, his friend Keisuke "Jima" Nakajima, who will be joining Kessinger from Baltimore to Montreal, is raising funds for the Ulman Foundation.
Nakajima then will take transportation back to Baltimore from Montreal, leaving Kessinger by himself for the grueling bike home.
"The decision to go from my home in Easton to Canada is sort of born out of like being able to go somewhere that I've never been and do it all under my own power," Kessinger said.
During Kessinger's trip in 2023, the other bikers on the trip had built relationships in the past to find places for the group to stay the night. They also had help from the foundation.
But for his trip this summer, Kessinger plans to coordinate sleeping arrangements, showering and food through meeting new people and an app called Warm Showers.
"It's specifically for cycle tourists, so people doing long-distance bike rides, and you can make an account, and you can be a host on there. And so you can connect with these hosts who are all over all over the world," Kessinger said.
Kessinger's job as a dog sitter, gave him opportunity to train for the grueling bike ride. He biked from client to client. Kessinger established a savings with money from high school work and an internship after he graduated from the University of Maryland.
Kessinger's message to anyone scared of taking on new opportunities or trying something different is to just "give it a go."
"Try it," Kessinger said. "Say say when all of those reasons come up of why you know this can't work or you shouldn't do it. Just see what it feels like to ignore those and what it feels like to to say yes, because you'll figure out the rest later."
To follow along with Kessinger, follow is his blog at teamtahoe.substack.com/.
.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Nov. 15
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Nov. 15

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 369
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Nov. 15, 1864, late in the U.S. Civil War, Union forces led by Maj. Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman began their "March to the Sea" from Atlanta; the campaign ended with the capture of Savannah, Georgia on Dec. 21.Also on this date:
In 1777, the Second Continental Congress approved the Articles of Confederation.
In 1806, explorer Zebulon Pike sighted the mountaintop now known as Pikes Peak in present-day Colorado.
In 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt laid the cornerstone of the Jefferson Memorial in Washington, D.C.
In 1959, four members of the Clutter family of Holcomb, Kansas, were found murdered in their home. (Richard Hickock and Perry Smith were later convicted of the killings and hanged in a case made famous by the Truman Capote book "In Cold Blood.")
In 1966, the flight of Gemini 12, the final mission of the Gemini program, ended successfully as astronauts James A. Lovell and Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin Jr. splashed down safely in the Atlantic after spending four days in orbit.
In 1969, a quarter of a million protesters staged a peaceful demonstration in Washington against the Vietnam War.
In 2012, the Justice Department announced that BP had agreed to plead guilty to a raft of charges in the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill and pay a record $4.5 billion, including nearly $1.3 billion in criminal fines.
In 2019, Roger Stone, a longtime friend and ally of President Donald Trump, was convicted of all seven counts in a federal indictment accusing him of lying to Congress, tampering with a witness and obstructing the House investigation of whether Trump coordinated with Russia during the 2016 campaign. The president commuted Stone's 40-month sentence days before he was to report to prison.
In 2022, the world population reached 8 billion, based on United Nations projections.
Today's Birthdays: Singer Petula Clark is 92. Actor Sam Waterston is 84. Classical conductor Daniel Barenboim is 82. Pop singer Anni-Frid "Frida" Lyngstad (ABBA) is 79. Fashion designer Jimmy Choo is 76. Actor Beverly D'Angelo is 73. News correspondent John Roberts is 68. Former "Tonight Show" bandleader Kevin Eubanks is 67. Actor Jonny Lee Miller is 52. Actor Sean Murray is 47. Golf Hall of Famer Lorena Ochoa is 43. Actor Shailene Woodley is 33. NBA All-Star Karl-Anthony Towns is 29.

title: Talbot County resident named to Maryland Humanities board
author: Contributed
content:
Talbot County resident named to Maryland Humanities board

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BALTIMORE - Maryland Humanities, a statewide, educational nonprofit, welcomed nine new members to the organization's Board of Directors recently, including Easton resident Jill Ferris.Ferris and the other new board members join nineteen other volunteers in service.She is the vice president of education and interpretation at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum. Previously a teacher in Queen Anne's County, she received the 2014 district teacher award from Maryland History Day, a program of Maryland Humanities.Ferris has also been awarded the Queen Anne's County Outstanding Teacher Technology Award, Colgate University's Award for Excellence in Teaching and a Fulbright Fellowship to Taiwan. She is an active member of the Chesapeake Curling Club and coaches junior curling.She has her masters of arts in history museum studies from the Cooperstown Graduate Program at State University of New York at Oneonta."I have been actively engaged with Maryland Humanities' numerous programs and initiatives since I first moved to Maryland in 2011," Ferris said. "From my first involvement as a volunteer judge for Maryland History Day, my connections have grown and deepened over time. I am excited to be a part of the continued success of Maryland Humanities now in this new capacity!" According to a press release, Maryland Humanities creates and supports bold experiences that explore and elevate our shared stories to connect people, enhance lives, and enrich communities.For more information, visit www.mdhumanities.org.

title: National Day of Prayer draws big crowd in Caroline County
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
National Day of Prayer draws big crowd in Caroline County

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Hundreds of Caroline County residents joined together on the county courthouse green to pray Thursday afternoon.The Caroline County Christian Clergy Association hosted National Day of Prayer ceremony, an annual event highlighted with prayers and singing.
"As a part of this community for so many years, it's just wonderful to see everybody come out for prayer and to recognize that we need God at work in our land in order for him to do great and mighty things," said Doug Morely, Greater Impact pastor and president of Caroline County Christian Clergy Association.
The Caroline County Sheriff's Office presented the colors for the national anthem. Grace Notes, the choir at Calvary Baptist Church in Denton, sung the anthem and multiple songs throughout the event.
Grace Notes has sung at every National Day or Prayer event in Caroline County, except for last year's.
"It's a privilege," Maureen Twining, singer and pianist, said. "Especially two of us are going through some really difficult times physically, and we know that it's a blessing that we're here today. It's wonderful."
Denton Mayor Abigail McNinch, Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker shared proclamations at the event.
Paul Twining, National Day of Prayer coordinator and pastor at Calvary Baptist Church in Denton, presented the keynote speech, highlighting multiple scriptures and reasons why prayer is so important in 2025.
"The response of the people today and the people that participated, I thought it was so on target," Twining said.
After the keynote, multiple clergy members began to pray for various groups in the county, including churches, government, families, media, schools, military, first responders and businesses.
After all prayers, Caroline County municipalities served free hot dogs and chips to residents.

title: Easton minister detained by ICE
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton minister detained by ICE

 July 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 507
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A beloved Easton minister was detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, taken to Salisbury and is now at the Baltimore ICE detention center where he is awaiting his next transfer, according to his daughter.Honduran born Daniel Fuentes Espinal has lived in the United States since 2001 and has served as the minister of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015. According to his daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, Espinal was arrested by ICE agents early Monday morning after stopping by Lowe's to pick up material for a job site.
"He didn't see anything suspicious. He put the material in the car, but then when he went to McDonald's to get something for breakfast, he saw a car behind him that looked kind of weird," Cordero said.
ICE agents followed Espinal to the Easton pool, ultimately arresting him on Route 322. He was taken to the Salisbury holding center. "He preached to them all the way to Salisbury," Diaz said.
From 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., Espinal's family had no clue of his whereabouts. "We were about to do a report on a missing person because we didn't find out until almost 12:30," Diaz said.
Diaz said Espinal had no criminal record.
Since President Donald Trump took office in January, immigration arrests have doubled in the state of Maryland. More than 600 immigrants arrested during this time had no former criminal charges, according to the Deportation Data Project.
Espinal has three children and a large extended family that he cares for, Diaz said. Tred Avon Strategies principal Len Foxwell referred to him as a pillar of the community.
Earlier this month, Espinal spoke at Foxwell's son Darren's funeral. Diaz said Darren and her brother were best friends and his death has been hard on Espinal and the family.
Diaz said she has received over 10 character letters on her father's behalf since his arrest yesterday morning, including one from Foxwell.
"It wasn't until I got to know him, however, that I saw how he honors and embodies the values of Christ in every aspect of his life," Foxwell wrote in a letter to ICE.
Espinal's family has tried obtaining citizenship legally for years, but due to backlogs and expenses, Espinal remained undocumented, Diaz said.
"He's contributing to this country, and we're just trying to do it the right way," Diaz said. "You know, unfortunately, with everything going on, everyone's a criminal apparently, but we're just hoping for the best and just to get him out of there."
Diaz said each phone call Espinal makes from the detention center costs $50 for a 20-minute call and bond amounts for release currently range from $10,000 to $15,000.
"I've heard stories that people say, 'But why didn't you do it the legal way? Why aren't you doing it the legal way?' It's not easy," Diaz said. "You know, if you're not in that person's shoes, you shouldn't be judging, and you shouldn't be criticizing."
Espinal's family is relying on their faith and are hopeful that he will return home.
ICE could not be reached via phone to comment on this incident.

title: Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 517
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Up before dawn, the team came with pallets of salt, ready to get their jobs done and help local businesses stay open, despite icy weather.Darrell Doupnik, the owner of Greenshore, an Easton-based landscaping company, has been providing salt and snow plow services in the winter for 40 years.
He met with his crew Friday morning to discuss their strategy for keeping walkways and parking lots ice-free for the company's roster of commercial clients.
Some members of the team, like foreman Jerry Widener, have years of experience with winter weather.
"I have been doing this for 15 years," Widener said. "I got up at 5 this morning. It's no big deal. I am used to it."
"In the winter we are clearing snow. When it snows, we are out here pushing snow. I am a pushing guy today, but I will do whatever it takes," he said.
According to Widener, Friday's temperatures, though frigid, were high enough to keep the workload manageable for the team.
"If it gets too cold, the salt doesn't work," Widener said. "I am the foreman today. I have five guys working for me. But for this, today, it is not too cold, and the salt works well."
Rock salt, lots of it, gets put in a spreader, which is attached to the back of a pickup truck for crews to drive around clients' roads and parking lots.
Doupnik said the team used over 100 40-pound bags of salt to handle Friday's workload, purchased from Site One landscaping supply.
"It is not cheap. Salt costs $450 a ton," he said. "We get them in 40-pound bags. You can put six bags at a time in the tailgate salt spreader."
Friday's storm brought upwards of three inches of snow to Easton and upwards of four inches to the town's north and east, according to the National Weather Service.
In more intense winter weather, Doupnik said, the team requires even larger quantities of salt, and staying ahead of the icy roads can be a strain on their bodies.
"This (storm) is a piece of cake. It is not really blowing. The six- to 10-inchers, you are out for two days. It sucks. You go home and try to get some rest, and then you are back out fixing it up. You just go back out there," he said.
In his 40 years of plowing snow, Doupnik has learned the value his team's hard work provides to not only his customers, but to the community as a whole.
"For commercial clients, you kind of have to provide it. They like an all-inclusive package," he said. "We do a lot of banks, we do these private schools and the churches. People still go to church. People still bank, and they have got to go to school. These places have to be open — especially the banks. We were out early this morning getting the banks opened up. Since schools are out, we do them last."
Doupnik said the community often shows appreciation for what his crew does.
"My guys get treated very well. My customers give them stuff a lot — especially at Christmas time," he said. "These are good guys, hard workers."

title: A yacht to do: Bay Bridge Boat Show comes to Kent Narrows
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
A yacht to do: Bay Bridge Boat Show comes to Kent Narrows

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS — Setting sail into the boating season with a new charter, the Bay Bridge Boat Show is coming to the Kent Narrows area at Safe Harbor Narrows Point April 11 through April 13.After 26 years at the Bay Bridge Marina, the new venue at Safe Harbor Narrows Point promises to retain the spirit attendees love while strengthening community fellowship alongside even more amenities and better parking.
"We are extremely excited that we were able to keep the Bay Bridge Boat Show in Queen Anne's County and think the new location at Safe Harbor Marina Kent Narrows will only enhance the economic impact to the region," Heather Tinelli, director of Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development said. "It is our hope that patrons of the boat show will stay overnight, enjoy all of our wonderful dining options, shop locally and of course buy a boat."
Whether boat enthusiasts looking to buy a new vessel or those looking for a day on the banks of the Chesapeake Bay, the powerboat show is complete with services, products, exhibitions and shipshape retail therapy.
Community and conservation are a focus of this year's spring power boat show, according to Annapolis Boat Shows' President, Mary Ewenson.
Committed to sustainability and conservation and environmental impacts, the boat show is proud to welcome numerous non-profits, and environmental organizations highlighting resources with free seminars, including the Department of Natural Resources, Coastal Conservation Association of Maryland, and the Department of Agriculture.
"Getting people excited about boats is a good way to get excited about the Chesapeake Bay. If you don't get out on the Bay you don't know it needs protecting, Ewenson said.
She is excited that by partnering with local businesses and building connections with the community, the show really connects with the community and emphasizes local involvement.
Welcoming attendees by land and water, both local and away, the boat show offers a unique opportunity to showcase the culture of the surrounding Kent Narrows, including additional shopping, restaurants, hotels, businesses, and the Cross Island Trail.
"It will really benefit the whole area. This is not a convention center, this is people's lives and businesses," Ewenson said of this year's show venue.
In addition to showcasing the local area, the boat show also seeks to provide accessibility to anyone with maritime interests, with onsite hands-on training available to make any land lubber sea worthy of a new vessel.
With new powerboats on the market to behold, an expanded demo dock will offer attendees the opportunity to climb aboard a wide array of powerboats of every style and size. From fishing boats and trawlers to pontoon boats and luxury cruisers, last year's powerboat show saw more than 250 boats, and at least as many are expected this season, she said.
"If you're a seasoned boater or a first timer, the show will offer something new for everyone to explore," said Annapolis Boat Shows' General Manager Sheila Jones.
Marine industry career networking opportunities will also be available alongside information about nearby boating clubs and schools.
And a great aspect of spring shows is that you can take your new boat out on the water right away, she said.
"Whether you're here for the boats, the education, or the food and entertainment, it's always a ton of fun. And the beautiful new venue means visitors may board even more exciting new powerboats and shop everything from gear and accessories to electronics, communication equipment, education, clubs, and more."
Shuttles will run between the lot at the old outlets off Exit 41 and the show.
An event certainly not to 'skiff', you can 'ketch' more information about the Bay Bridge Boat Show and other local shows at BayBridgeBoatShow.com.

title: Songs about the water - Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum continues Changing Chesapeake series
content:
Songs about the water - Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum continues Changing Chesapeake series

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 703
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Back in the early 1990s, Peter Panyon was taking part in a weeklong workshop for college professors focused on the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries when inspiration struck while cruising the Patuxent River."It occurred to me: Wait a minute, there's a story to tell here," Panyon remembered."I was thinking, 'Man, somebody should write a song about that, and nobody's going to do it if it's not me.'" A biology professor by trade, Panyon would write and re-write the song over the years on the way to perfecting "Can't Work the River." The ballad tracing a watermen's struggles was included on his band Big Tribe's debut album in 2014, and its music video is now part of the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's special exhibition The Changing Chesapeake.At 7 p.m. on Sept. 28, Panyon and his Big Tribe bandmates Bonnie Eyler and Joe Huette will present "Songs About the Water," an evening of songs and stories with a dose of science at the museum's Van Lennep Auditorium.This "Changing Chesapeake Coffeehouse" concert will feature fare provided by Blue Heron Coffee of St. Michaels and highlight songs drawing inspiration from local rivers to the Gulf oil spill and hurricane disasters.The suggested ticket price is $15 per participant for this event, which is sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center. To register and get more information, visit cbmm.org/SongsAboutWater.Panyon has married two of his passions in coming up with a catalog to fill a concert like this.The Calvert County resident is now retired after a lengthy career teaching biology at the University of Maryland, Catholic University and Prince George's Community College.As a musician, Panyon has written hundreds of songs, dating back to his teenage years. Recently, he's catalyzed Big Tribe, which has released two albums of eclectic rock tracks with a new one, "Postcards from the Mission," due out later this year.Those experiences have helped Panyon carve out a unique lane as a songwriter with something to say."Your normal rock and roll about cars and girls, that's not what we do," Panyon said. "What we're really up to is trying to hit people with music that, while they're having fun with it, there's a message in there that hopefully we get them to think about." The "Can't Work the River" video debuted in 2016 at a conference on teaching science through alternative media at the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center.Now, the 5-minute, 25-second video that features two watermen from different generations grappling with the realities of working the Patuxent River is finding a new audience as part of The Changing Chesapeake, which is on exhibit through next March."I want to at least crack open the door that leads to thinking about this scientifically," Panyon said. "Yes, it's a story about a guy, and he lost his woman, and he's having trouble making a living, but when you dive beneath the surface of that story, there's this other story about what's actually going wrong. Why is this way of life that's millennia old getting more and more iffy?" In concert, Panyon aims to expand on these important themes.While Big Tribe's albums feature big sound from a full band with bass drums, electric guitars, and an array of complementary instruments, its acoustic shows with Panyon, Eyler, and Huette are more easygoing, free-flowing, and even interactive."It's not just music," Panyon said. "We're going to throw a little science in, and we're totally open to having a dialogue." The set list for these live shows goes in different directions with various meditations on the importance of valuing our waterways, including another track with roots in the 1990s and a literal earnestness to its title, "We Are the River." As he prepares for his CBMM gig, Panyon is excited that he's found a perfect partner to help him share these songs that mean so much to him."Most bands are looking to play big venues like stadiums," Panyon said with a chuckle."For us, it's museums. We want to do as many museums as possible, and once we've conquered the museum world, then we're going for the stadiums." 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum will welcome Peter Panyon and Big Tribe to campus on Thursday, Sept. 28, for "Songs about the Water," an acoustic concert of songs and stories with a dose of science. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation discusses birds, trails and historic preservation
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation discusses birds, trails and historic preservation

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: General Assembly 
 
 881
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Eastern Delegation of the Maryland General Assembly brought forth topics pertinent to constituents, including the avian influenza recently swooped into the area and developments of community connectivity at its first weekly delegation meeting of this session Jan. 17.Secretary of Natural Resources Josh Kurtz presented updates regarding avian influenza outbreaks and noted the Department of Natural Resources has expanded its long-term contract with the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service to provide more wildlife technicians to dispose of dead birds that could be carrying the disease.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) noted disappointment with DNR's recent response to the avian influenza and reiterated better communication is needed for concerned citizens to get help they need without a runaround.
Kurtz noted the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control was also following a similar model and the two states are now working to stay consistent in informing the public on available tools.
Kurtz noted additional DNR developments for the Eastern Shore, including working with Caroline County on a public lands bill to assist Program Open Space funding.
Funds that come into DNR's "user pay, user benefit," model go directly to programs to benefit the community, he said.
DNR recently received one million dollars from the Middle Chesapeake Sentinel Landscape Resilience Project for easement purchases near Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge and Fishing Bay, according to Kurtz.
DNR also received a grant from the Environmental Protection Agency for $43 million to improve forest management on 1,000 acres of the Eastern Shore and help develop a regional forestry management plan, he said.
TRANSPORTATIONFocusing on long term strategic planning to improve operating rail lines, the Maryland Department of Transportation is moving toward the establishment of a public-private partnership, according to Jaclyn Hartman, assistant secretary of transportation investments.
The Eastern Shore has a total of 92 miles of rail line, with 65 in active use. The rail lines are currently owned by the Maryland Transit Administration and operated by the Maryland and Delaware Railroad Company, Hartman said.
With the current operating lease is expiring, MDOT is thinking strategically about how to secure a long term operator and improve service delivery and maintenance on those routes.
Moving to a public-private partnership will ensure one entity has authority, rather than it being split between the operator and the state. The partnership will instigate long-term plans for the rail lines, "and unfortunately that's one of the things that we're kind of lacking today," Hartman said.
For the maintenance of the rails, MDOT would establish a private financing, expecting the private operator to invest some of its own money in the rail lines with the ability to keep those revenues in the future as a return on investment.
MDOT considered the project a win-win opportunity that most closely resembled the successful Seagrit Marine Terminal public private partnership established in the Port of Baltimore in 2008, Hartman said.
In the next couple of months, MDOT will begin industry outreach and move forward on requests for proposals for the private operator.
MARITIME MUSEUMPresenting an outline of program facilities preserving the cultural legacy of the state, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum officials sought the Eastern Shore Delegation's help replacing aging HVAC systems in two buildings filled with irreplaceable artifacts.
Pete Lesher, chief historian for the museum, noted since 1965, CBMM has been dedicated to visitors and locals alike, preserving the environment and cultural heritage of the area as a tourism center, as well as a community museum.
CBMM preserves 90,000 objects of historical significance and tell local stories of the Bay at its campus in St. Michaels.
The museum also serves as a key economic driver for the Eastern Shore, bringing in visitors and millions of dollars to the area, said Jeff Vogel, CBMM Government Relations Committee chair.
Recognizing it was an exceedingly difficult budget season, Del. Chris Adams (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) noted CBMM was more than a local asset, but a landmark of history for the state.
TRAIL NETWORKSeeking to connect the area and strengthen community through the Maryland Eastern Shore Trail Network, Owen Bailey, director of land use and policy of the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy, and Patti Stevens, chair of the Worcester County Bike and Pedestrian Coalition, presented visions and goals to connect communities through a safe and sustainable trail network.
The mission of the Eastern Shore Trail Network Group is to galvanize a coalition of communities to support, plan, promote and advocate for diverse trail systems, Bailey said.
Smaller municipalities in particular on the Eastern Shore wanted more trails but lacked capacity, expertise, and funding to plan, develop and design, according to Bailey.
While the Eastern Shore represent 30% of the state's landmass and areas of recreation and economic development impact, it only included about 9.2% of the state's roads-separated trails, Stevens said.
This deficit came to light with updates to MDOT's five-year bike and pedestrian plan, according to Stevens.
Interactive mapping across the state marked trails as green and while urban areas like Baltimore and Annapolis had so many green off-road trail markings "it looked like plates of robust pesto spaghetti," Eastern Shore counties merely had "little flecks of parsley," according to Stevens.
Trails have benefits to economic development as well as to health, and as a safe transportation alternative, Stevens said.
Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said electric bicycles are good options for mobility but speed can be issues on trails and should be addressed. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Be careful what you vote for
author: Staff Writer
content:
Be careful what you vote for

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Be careful what you vote forLast Sunday, Easton resident Larry Pifer's piece on "authoritarian government" was published in the Star Democrat. He spoke to real impacts of authoritarian governments of the past, but also to those currently taking hold, around the world and potentially, right here in America.
Larry's thoughts, observations and quotes, particularly this one, from Trump, himself, "I will be a dictator but only for a short time" should give all Americans reason to carefully consider who steers Good Ship America in the upcoming four years.
We do not have to rely on what other people say about who, or what, Trump is; he, himself, tells everyone that tunes in to national media many opportunities to hear it, directly from his own mouth. Granted, there are many, many other media outlets and pundits that will spin who and what he is, and what he will do for you, if you vote to elect him. However, many of the promises he made during his first presidential run, were never fulfilled, for example:
I'll build a great wall and Mexico will pay for it. NOPE.
I'll repeal Obamacare and give you better, cheaper health care, NOPE.
I'll bring manufacturing back to America, NOPE. Under his watch manufacturing jobs remained relatively flat, until they fell off the cliff as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
I'll grow the economy by 4% per year, NOPE. Actually, his best year was 2018, when the economy grew by 2.9% over the previous year.
I'll cut taxes for everybody, NOPE. While many, but not all, benefited, marginally, from Trump's tax cuts, the vast majority went to the rich and to corporations, some of them not even American.
I'll terminate Obama's executive orders on immigration, NOPE. While one program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, (DACA), was challenged in our courts, it remains in effect, yet today. A second program, Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA), never was implemented, so Trump could not terminate it.
If you listen to Trump now, he is regurgitating some of the same promises he failed to fulfill during his first term in office, even though he enjoyed Republican majorities in both the U.S. House and the Senate for his first two years in office. Which brings me to a word, or two, of caution to those who choose to vote in the upcoming elections.
Be careful of those who don't keep their promises and be careful of the would-be dictator you vote to elect; you don't always get the kind of dictator you think you will, when you voted, based on what he and his minions tell you, and it is very hard to get rid of dictators.
WILLIAM C. KEPPEN
Easton
