title: O'Connor, Easton top Kent Island
author: Bill Haufe
content:
O'Connor, Easton top Kent Island

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Kent Island High head football coach Zach Davis has seen enough of Mikey O'Connor."I'm glad he graduates," Davis said of Easton High's senior quarterback. "He basically beat us by himself. I told him before the game, I thought he was a great player. And he showed it tonight."
O'Connor ran for two touchdowns and threw for two, including a 43-yard connection to Diontaye Copper with 2 minutes, 15 seconds remaining Friday night, as the third-seeded Warriors defeated the No. 2 seed Buccaneers, 28-21, in a Class 2A East Region second-round playoff at Andy Schipul Stadium.
After going 1-9 a year ago, Easton is 8-3 and now awaits for the state tournament to be re-seeded for next weekend's state quarterfinals.
"We didn't score the whole second half," said O'Connor, whose 3-yard touchdown run with 1:17 left in the first half helped Easton to a 21-14 halftime lead. "They were really stopping us and we were just thinking, 'First down. Next first down.' So we were taking it one play at a time. And when you do that, you put a bunch of good plays together, and you bust one, that really turned the tide."
After a scoreless third quarter, Kent Island (7-4) tied the game 4 seconds into the fourth quarter on quarterback Gavan Henry's 1-yard sneak. Spencer Chappell's point-after kick tied the game at 21-all.
Easton's ensuing possession ended with a fourth-down incompletion. Kent Island punted the next time it had the ball.
The Warriors took possession at their 20-yard line with 6:17 remaining. On third-and-11, O'Connor hit Colin Mooney for an 11-yard pick-up and a first down. Five consecutive O'Connor runs set up a third-and-five at the Bucs' 43. O'Connor hit Copper on an out route, then watched his receiver cut toward the middle of the field and outrun everyone into the end zone for a 27-21 lead. Dominic Stanco drilled his fourth straight point after for a 28-21 Easton lead.
"You try to stop him running the football and he throws on you," Davis said of O'Connor.
Kent Island got the ball back on its 37 with 2:15 left. As the Bucs lined up on first down, Easton called time to make a defensive adjustment. On the next play, Copper intercepted Henry, giving the Warriors the ball at the Kent Island 49 with 2:09 left.
"Luckily for us we were able to make one more big play than Kent Island tonight, on both sides of the ball," Easton head coach Matt Griffith said. "Big drive. Drove down and scored with like 2:15 left. And then get a huge pick. Call a timeout to see the formation, made a quick adjustment on our coverage, and, man, played it perfect."
O'Connor picked up two first downs to kill the remaining 2:09, cementing the victory.
"They came through when they needed to and that was at the most important time," O'Connor said of his offensive line. "When we got those first downs, it was all them. Like I didn't get touched literally until I had the first down."
Easton took a 7-0 lead, when O'Connor busted loose around right end for a 41-yard touchdown just over 2 minutes into the game. Stanco added the PAT.
Kent Island fumbled on its first play of the game, giving Easton the ball on the Bucs 45. The Warriors drove to the Bucs' 13, setting up Stanco's 30-yard field goal attempt that drifted wide right.
Henry's 1-yard sneak and Chappell's extra-point tied the game at 7-7 with 32 seconds left in the first quarter.
The Warriors moved back ahead with 8:50 to go in the second quarter, when O'Connor hit Mooney with a 23-yard touchdown pass in the left, front corner of end zone for a 14-7 lead.
The Bucs again pulled even, as Nate Green was sprung for an 11-yard touchdown run with 2:26 to go before halftime.
Easton responded. Dustin Blue broke free on a 50-yard run on his first carry. O'Connor carried for 12 yards and then raced around left end and squeezed down the sideline for the go-ahead touchdown and a 21-14 halftime lead. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Library To Host Photographer Capturing Female Boat Captains
author: Contributed
content:
Library To Host Photographer Capturing Female Boat Captains

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 201
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - Photographer Kristin Rutkowski will be the speaker for the December Lunch and Learn at the St Michaels Library on Monday, Dec. 4, at noon.Rutkowski is the founder and photographer of Her Helm, a portrait celebration of women leading the way on the water.Dedicated to sharing the inspiring stories of female captains, each portrait share their own unique backgrounds and experiences.The project honors these women for their resilience and determination in forging their own path in the maritime world.She raises the voices and highlights the lives of women through insightful interviews and powerful portraits. Rutkowski traveled the length of the Chesapeake Bay for over two years to include women boat captains in this project.The Chesapeake Bay edition of Her Helm project culminated in a fine art portrait book.The first half of the book features each of the 51 women in the project, while the second half of the book includes invited writers and artists around the Bay sharing their own perspective of living on the water.The Lunch and Learn Speakers series is sponsored by the Friends of the Library. Coffee and dessert will be provided.For more information, visit tcfl.org or call 410-745-5877.

title: 'Heartbeat of Easton Utilities' legacy lives on
author: JOHN ENGLEHART
content:
'Heartbeat of Easton Utilities' legacy lives on

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHN ENGLEHART | Section: Columns 
 
 1208
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Jan. 13, Vicki Petro retired as vice president of human resources at Easton Utilities after 31 years of dedicated service. To some, this may seem like the closing chapter of just another HR career. But to those of us who had the privilege of calling Vicki a colleague, a mentor or a friend, this marks the end of an extraordinary era in the Mid-Shore community.Vicki began her journey with Easton Utilities on Nov. 2, 1993, as the organization's sole HR professional, reporting to the business manager. Over the past three decades, she has shaped the careers of countless employees, directly overseeing the hiring of 324 individuals during her tenure, guiding many through the retirement process and supporting the training and development of many more.
She's ensured payroll ran seamlessly more than 750 times, served as a trusted adviser to two CEOs and been the go-to resource for employees seeking guidance to navigate their careers. She has served as mentor to many at Easton Utilities and in the Mid-Shore community, having a profound impact on them both professionally and personally.
I first met Vicki in 2021 when I interviewed for a position with another organization. She had been invited to serve on the interview panel to lend her expertise and help them make an informed decision. From the moment she spoke, I was struck by her professionalism, warmth and rare passion for HR — a field where such genuine excitement can sometimes feel scarce.
I remember thinking, If I ever have the chance to work for her, I'll take it, because there's so much I could learn from someone like her. That opportunity came in 2023, and over the past two years, I've grown immensely—not just as an HR professional, but also as a leader and as a person—thanks to her guidance.
Easton Utilities, like any organization, can be thought of as a living body. The linemen could be viewed as the muscles, the water/wastewater operators perhaps viewed as the backbone, the customer service representatives perhaps the face, and—if you ask the engineers, they might claim to be the brain. But at its core, Human Resources is the heart. It keeps the organization alive and thriving, circulating energy and support to every part.
For 30 years, Vicki was Easton Utilities' heartbeat, sustaining the organization through storms, challenges, and triumphs alike.
Her impact reaches far beyond Easton Utilities' walls. If a gas technician safely resolved a leak in your home, it's likely Vicki played a role in hiring them. If a Velocity technician helped you as a rural customers get connected to much needed high speed internet, chances are Vicki was there to interview them. When linemen braved ice storms to restore power to your neighborhood, she likely contributed to their onboarding. And when you've interacted with our professional and compassionate customer service staff, you've experienced the result of Vicki's discerning eye for talent.
In sum, if you've been impressed with Easton Utilities' service over the past 30 years, it's because Vicki had a hand in it — not only by selecting individuals who embody Easton Utilities core values but also by shaping the training that helped them excel. She has also been a great mentor to others through her Leadership Maryland classmates, impacting professionals around the State of Maryland.
Vicki's influence wasn't confined to hiring or compliance—it was deeply human. She understood that when employees face challenges, they carry those burdens home to their families. Time and again, she offered them support, showing them how to navigate their struggles so they could be present for their loved ones.
As her retirement approached, Vicki demonstrated the same grace and foresight that defined her career. This graceful departure reminds me of a lesson from sports. As a Baltimore football fan, I think of the legendary Johnny Unitas. He was the greatest quarterback of all time, but even he struggled to hang up his cleats. In a twist few like to remember, Unitas ended his career not in Baltimore but in a San Diego Chargers uniform, a move that seemed out of place for such an icon. It's a lesson in knowing when it's time to step aside. Vicki, however, has shown impeccable timing. She embraced the evolving needs of the organization, mentored her successors, and made way for the next chapter—all while ensuring Easton Utilities' heart continues to beat strong. Some leaders struggle to step aside, holding onto their roles even as the times and needs of their organizations evolve. But not Vicki. She embraced the opportunity to mentor and prepare the next generation, ensuring Easton Utilities' heart continues to beat strong long after she steps away.
One of my favorite movies is The Dark Knight. A memorable quote from that movie is Harvey Dent's reflection on heroes: "You either die a hero or live long enough to see yourself become the villain." In my years of observing HR leaders, I've seen this sentiment play out. Many HR Directors depart their roles amid controversy or burnout, others retiring from their organization leaving behind employees that are happy to see them go rather than admiration. But Vicki defied that trend. She is retiring on her own terms, as a universally respected leader—beloved by employees, admired by executives, and deeply respected throughout the mid-shore community.
After Jan. 13, as the days, weeks, months and years go by, Vicki's name will be heard less and less around Talbot County and Easton Utilities. New employees will join, and those who knew her best will retire. The stories of the great things she achieved as the heart of Easton Utilities will fade, as the stories of legends often do. But I can guarantee her name will be spoken one more time, 20 years from now …
When my time comes to retire, and I am the "old-school" HR director trying to understand the up-and-coming HR leaders looking to replace me, I'm sure I will observe them make some kind of mistake — fall flat on their face in a way that only experience can teach to avoid. And just like Vicki, I'll be there with some kind of sage advice to help them learn from it. When they ask me, "Who taught you that?" my answer will be simple: "Vicki Petro taught me that."
And with that the legend of Vicki Petro will continue.
No one asked or paid me to write this. I did so because some contributions deserve recognition, and Vicki's story is one of them. Over the past two years, I've had the honor of working with her and witnessing her remarkable leadership firsthand. Vicki has been an exceptional HR professional, a trusted advisor, a compassionate mentor, and an inspiring leader. She has not only shaped Easton Utilities but has left it stronger and better for the next generation in our mid-shore community.
For now, Vicki rides off into the sunset to begin the next chapter of a legendary life — as a grandma spending time with her grandbabies, traveling with her husband to new places across the globe and enjoying the fruits of her labor. And I'm sure in those new adventures, she will be the heartbeat of those moments, just as she has been the heartbeat for so many years at Easton Utilities and the Mid-Shore community.
Enjoy your grandbabies, Vicki. Thank you for everything. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lesher withdraws name from Easton Utilities Commission consideration
author: Konner Metz
content:
Lesher withdraws name from Easton Utilities Commission consideration

 March 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 174
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Following lengthy discussion of his potential appointment last week, Talbot County Council Vice President Pete Lesher has withdrawn his name from consideration for the Easton Utilities Commission, according to Easton Mayor Megan Cook.Lesher, originally appointed to the commission by Cook, was not confirmed by the Easton Town Council last week. Some town councilmembers raised concerns over Lesher simultaneously serving on the County Council and utilities commission.
Town officials said the legality of serving on both bodies would depend on if the utilities commission is considered a "trust and profit" office, since state law doesn't allow someone to hold two such positions.
Town Attorney Sharon VanEmburgh said at the March 3 meeting that while the town "would probably get to the conclusion that it is not a second office of trust and profit," it would be best to first review case law and attorney general rulings.
The appointment was made to fill the role of current commission member Buck Duncan. His time expires this May, leaving ample time for a new appointment, the mayor said.

title: Meet the Wednesday Morning Artists
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Meet the Wednesday Morning Artists

 September 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 172
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every Wednesday at 9:30 a.m., you can find a group of artists gathering at Peachblossom Place, enjoying each other's company and showcasing their latest projects.Yesterday morning was no exception.
Though I'm not a member of the group, I was greeted warmly with coffee and smiles. The artists got up one by one to show off their hand-made jewelry, woodworking and pottery.
One of the members created something she calls the "baconator" which is a ceramic bacon cooker that collects the grease at the bottom. She created two cylinders to hold the bacon so that it can fit a whole pound.
The artists also chatted about topics outside of art. Wednesday Morning Artists encouraged member Bill Pavin before he was to speak in front of elected officials in Washington, D.C., to advocate for the funding of research of rare diseases to continue.
Members went over logistics, enjoyed their coffee and pet the incredibly cute and fluffy Basil, Robert Gladney's mastiff, as they walked out the door.
Read the story and others here. Thanks for reading!
— Lily Tierney

title: Imaging a horror show
author: Staff Writer
content:
Imaging a horror show

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 190
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's hard to imagine that the protesters in Cambridge outside of an Andy Harris event really thought that the congressman would waste his time meeting with any of them. Cambridge Indivisible founder and chair Michelle Fowle said, "Harris' constituents just want answers." She wanted a town hall with the congressman. It's hard even imaging that horror show.Why would anyone subject themself to the shouting and abuse from such a meeting? We have already seen these same embarrassing displays on TV before. Another protester Ms. Frost said that she was concerned that Harris' agenda was more aligned with DOGE than with his constituents.
News Flash. Mr Harris was elected by the constituents who voted for him, not against him. Obama once said, "Elections have consequences."
I'm assuming the group looking to elect progressive leaders missed that message from Barack Obama himself. Harris' agenda is rightfully aligned with the party that won the election just as it should be. His true constituents are quite happy with Congressman Harris right now.
Maybe this Cambridge group should contact Bernie Sanders for a town hall since his socialist agenda seems much more in line with theirs.
RICH ADRIAN
Easton

title: Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 615
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Talbot County is seeing increases in juvenile crime, along with upticks in petty thefts and some violent crimes, according to the county's top law enforcement officials.Updates on local crime trends from each law enforcement agency in the county dominated discussion at Talbot County's latest Police Accountability Board meeting on Tuesday, Nov. 14.Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble reported a 19% increase in calls for service and a 13% increase in reported crime handled by the sheriff's office, including some small increases in assaults and drug charges. Crimes relating to fraud of older residents are likely the biggest financial loss in the county, he added.Gamble identified juvenile crimes in schools as a particular issue for the sheriff's office, which has uniformed officers serving in most of the public schools.Recently implemented state juvenile justice reform laws have barred police from charging anyone under 13 with most crimes.Gamble said Easton High School and Easton Middle School are where police see most of the incidents involving children, and over 30% of this year's reported incidents involve children under 13."We have 12-year-olds that are punching other kids in the face time and time again in the schools, or assaulting other kids, and there's no services for them," he said.Police Accountability Board members acknowledged the concerns, asking what officers can do to better handle issues with youth under 13 and if police can work with the schools.Gamble said the school system doesn't have leverage to handle discipline other than resorting to suspensions.Looking forward, Gamble hopes to see movement within state leadership in Annapolis during the upcoming General Assembly session to push legislation to tackle issues with the juvenile reform laws.Outside of juvenile crime, those at the meeting discussed several recent local incidents.In Easton, two homicides occurred within town limits in the last few months - one on Blake Street in early August and a second at the Sidetracked Saloon in late September.Several thefts and robberies have also occurred in town, said Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey. Those include a series of burglaries at vape stores where individuals are seeking Delta-8 THC cartridges, a non-regulated and legal psychoactive substance with effects similar to recreational cannabis.Another issue of great concern to Easton residents is crime on the Rails to Trails pathways throughout town, Lowrey said, citing a serious assault on the trails in the summer.To alleviate those concerns, the town's police department is increasing patrols on the trails and issuing more citations, Lowrey said. Those efforts include repopulating the department's bike unit, which is down due to lower staffing levels.In St. Michaels, Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald didn't note any specific crime trends, though he did mention two car thefts, which are "extremely unusual" for the town, he said. The town's tourist season is coming to a close, which means St. Michaels will have a lower population and more shops closed up for the winter.The small St. Michaels Police Department is down a few officers, though two new officers are starting soon, Oswald said. The department was also able to secure higher starting salaries and increases for current officers."Things are looking up. It's just going to be a little while," he said.Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner did not report any major issues, adding that Oxford is a "very safe little town." The town's three-member police department was fully staffed until a few weeks ago, but Oxford's town commissioners recently agreed to increase the department to four full-time officers, Kellner said. The town is now looking to hire one additional officer. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Members of the Talbot County Police Accountability Board, seated to the right, listen to the county's top law enforcement officials during a Nov. 14 meeting. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center

 December 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The tall, welcoming windows in the classrooms of Building African American Minds Inc.'s new academic center in Easton don't just bring in sunlight. They connect the surrounding residents to new opportunities.Three stories high and nearly 25,000 square feet, the center will house classes, tutoring, youth programs, community gatherings and more. It sits on Jowite Street, next to the BAAM Athletic Center and across from a large residential area.
James Bell, director of instruction, academic support and community wellbeing for the nonprofit, believes the space fits within the organization's mission of creating an educational and social space for underserved children in the area.
"The excitement really is looking out of the windows and seeing the potential," Bell says. "So when you see the community, out of every window here in the facility, it lets you know that it's an opportunity for them as well."
Saturday, Building African American Minds will cut the ribbon on the academic center, which is expected to be up and running in January. The center will allow the nonprofit to significantly expand how many children it serves in after-school and summer enrichment programs.
There is a library, media center and multipurpose dining room on the first floor. Above are eight classrooms, as well as speciality rooms for esports, art and music.
Classrooms are designed with desks situated for full-group, small-group and individual learning.
Dina Daly, executive director of Building African American Minds, pointed out a wellness wing, which will be a private space for health, counseling and more. She added that BAAM's sister agency, private school Polaris Village Academy, will operate out of the academic center in 2025.
While the organization's focus has been serving under-resourced youth in the nearby neighborhoods, its reach isn't limited to children or Talbot County residents, Daly says.
Adult workforce programs will be hosted in the new academic center during the day. On the third floor, Chesapeake College will begin hosting GED and English second language classes in February.
"We had a vision from the beginning," Daly said. "So we're just following up on our vision for what we thought needed to happen, not just for the youth."
In its 20th year, Building African American Minds has long hoped for an academic center like the one that sits on Jowite Street today. Its previous hub, the athletic center next to the new building, isn't going anywhere either.
However, the new academic center was about a $10 million project, Daly said, more than double what the athletic center cost. Private donors, community donations, and state and federal funding made it possible.
"We build for the future," Daly said. "From the inception of BAAM, we always talked about building a school and academic center. It's more than a school now. It's more like a community center, really."
Daly said it's been a long process, but she knows the wait was worth it. Starting small and meeting a select group's needs instead of going too broad, such as when the organization began as a boys-only nonprofit in 2005, was the path to success.
Reflecting on the fact that a 20-year goal is finally coming to fruition, Daly hopes the journey of Building African American Minds can inspire others to start small and dream big.
"That's why I tell people, 'don't give up on your dreams,'" Daly said. "Make smaller goals, make them achievable, and then just keep building it up. And look at what we've accomplished." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 89 million voting eligible Americans didn't vote in the 2024 elections, according to the latest tallies collected by the University of Florida's Election Lab.That accounts for more than 36.4% of the U.S. total electorate of 244.7 million people (voters and nonvoters).
There are still some votes being counted in California and Arizona.
But as it stands as of Thursday, Nov. 14, there were 13.2 million more nonvoters than supporters of now President-elect Donald Trump in the 2024 White House race.
Trump — who defeated Vice President Kamala Harris — has received close to 75.9 million votes, according to tallies Thursday from The Associated Press.
That accounts for just over 50% of the popular vote. But if nonvoters are included Trump got 31% of the electorate (voting and nonvoting).
Harris, the sitting U.S. vice president, has received close to 72.9 million votes, as of Thursday's counts.
That is more than 16.2 million fewer votes than the number of non-voters. As it stands, Harris got 29.7% of the total U.S. electorate.
Harris was installed at the top of the ticket after President Joe Biden was pressured by Democratic Party leaders and donors to quit the race in late July over concerns about his advanced age. There were some polls showing U.S. voters viewing that installation as 'undemocratic.'
Biden got close to 81.3 million in 2020 when he defeated Trump. That is more than 8.3 million more votes than Harris got in 2024. There were also more than 4.1 million fewer voters overall in 2024 compared to 2020.
Ani Ruhil, associate dean for research and planning and professor at Ohio University's Voinovich School of Leadership and Public Service, said ongoing vote counts could impact final turnout figures.
But Ruhil sees lower turnout as a key trend line in the 2024 race that saw Trump return to the White House.
"Only seven states exceeded their 2020 turnout rate — Georgia, Michigan, North Dakota, Vermont and Wisconsin," Ruhil said. "Washington, D.C., had an especially poor showing compared to 2020. So did Oregon, New Jersey, Maryland, Alaska, Illinois, and Utah."
The number of voters casting ballots in 2024 was down 11.6% in New Jersey, 11.2% in Illinois, 8.9% in Oregon and 4.6% in Washington state compared to 2020.
Nationally, turnout stands at 63.6%, according to the University of Florida. Ruhil said turnout in 2020 — which totaled 66.6% nationally — was a political aberration.
The Biden-Trump 2020 race occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw more than 1.1 million deaths in the U.S., millions of workers facing job cuts and reduced hours, mask mandates and closures of schools, business and social events.
"Turnout was fanned by fear and anger," he said.
"In comes President Biden, with the singular charge of steering the country through the pandemic, and of making sure the economy did not fall to pieces. But by 2023, as we came out of the pandemic, inflation had taken its toll. Now was not the fear of a virus, but rather of gaping holes in the pocketbook. But there was no comforting plan being put forth by the White House," Ruhil continued.
He sees some voter fatigue with continued efforts by federal and state prosecutors to go after Trump.
Seventy percent of voters said the U.S. is headed in the wrong direction, with two-thirds stressed about inflation and the economy. Prices are up more than 20% since the pandemic and from when Biden and Harris took office in 2021, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Voters worried about the economy and high prices favored Trump in the 2024 race, according to exit polls.
The war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas after the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks also challenged Harris.
Anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab Americans) are upset with U.S. military support for Israel. In the other corner, supporters of Israel (including more conservative Jewish voters) didn't trust Harris to continue U.S. support for Israel . The U.S. has allocated $17.9 billion war aid to Israel since Hamas's 2023 attacks, according to Brown University.
Harris got just over 80,000 fewer votes in Michigan, where the Israel-Hamas war is an issue for Arab-American and Muslim voters, than Biden 2020.
She lost to Trump by just over 80,600 votes in Michigan.
Ruhil said the enthusiasm was let out of the turnout balloon for many Democratic voters.
"The late switch, fevered fundraising, and a hastily assembled campaign did nothing to instill confidence," he said, stressing the lack of a convincing economic message from Harris.
Harris' campaign raised more than $1 billion and had another $649 million in backing from outside groups, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Trump raised $381.5 million and was aided by $711 million in outside spending, according to CRP.
Harris' campaign focused heavily on support for abortion rights, casting Trump as a fascist threat to democracy and procuring celebrity endorsements including Oprah Winfrey, Jennifer Lopez, Beyonce, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen.
The effort fell short with Harris underperforming Biden by 8.4 million votes (or 10.3%) nationally. She saw lower turnout or flat support levels in key Electoral College battlegrounds that Trump won.
Harris got 6.6% fewer votes than Biden in Arizona.
There was also the dynamic of Trump carrying states such as Montana, Missouri, Arizona and Florida, where there were abortion rights measures also on the ballot.
Those measures all passed and in Florida an abortion rights measure got 57% of the vote (failing to meet the state's 60% threshold). Trump got 56% of the vote.
In Montana, Trump carried the state with 58%. An abortion rights measure got the same percentage.
Trump favors allowing states to decide the abortion issue versus Harris, who backs nationally enshrining abortion rights.
Abortion rights groups were among the top backers of Harris.
"This result is devastating. There has been no greater champion for reproductive freedom than Vice President Kamala Harris," said Mini Timmaraju, president and CEO of Reproductive Freedom for All, a leading abortion rights advocacy group.
"We know the American people are with us, and they showed us that when they passed ballot measures and elected candidates in key states to protect their rights, said Timmaraju, who worries about Trump and the GOP in charge of the White House and Congress.
Harris and Democrats had hoped for a wave of women voters supporting abortion rights in the race against Trump.
But exit polls showed Trump carrying a majority of white women who voted, and voters were more evenly split on which presidential candidate they trusted on the abortion issue than in pre-election polls.
Abortion rights opponents argue Harris' focus on expansive abortion rights turned off some voters.
"Kamala Harris and Tim Walz support abortion anytime, anywhere, and under any circumstances. Supported by the abortion industry and its allies, Harris and Walz campaigned with fanatical fervor on abortion — and the voters rejected them," said Carol Tobias, president of National Right to Life.
Trump carried 58% of the Catholic vote versus 40% for Harris, according to NBC News exit polls. In 2020, Biden and Trump were evenly split with Catholics (49% to 50%), according to the Associated Press.
Trump won 63% of the votes from white working class women, made inroads with Hispanics (especially Hispanic men) and edged Harris with working class households, according to NBC News exit polls.
According to the University of Florida, there were 15.5 million fewer early votes in 2024 compared to 2020 (85.9 million versus 101.45 million).
That's a 15% drop.

title: Eating out on a tight budget
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Eating out on a tight budget

 September 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On those super busy days when you just don't have time to cook at home, but eating out is too expensive, "semi-homemade" - combining quick-service food with home cooking - is a great way to merge the best of both worlds.PIZZABy purchasing premade pizza dough along with my own sauce and toppings, I can have fantastic pizza on the table in no time. I often rely on this option, especially when we have last-minute guests. It's impressive to quickly produce a high-quality, delicious pizza; it's my little secret.READY TO ROLLThe takeout pizza store in my neighborhood sells ready-to-roll pizza dough.I can buy a large ball of dough for $3.50, which makes a 16-inch pizza.Not all pizza stores sell their dough (the national chains in my area look at me as if I have three eyes when I inquire), but independent shops are typically more than happy for the business - any business.In fact, one store near me even lists this on their menu board.READY TO GOMy local supermarket sells ready-to-bake pizza dough in the deli section for $3.49 (enough to make one 12-inch pizza).Now is the time to start planning how to replace a regular meal more economically.You're smart, so I am confident you will come up with ideas and strategies I haven't considered.YOUR TURNThese are only a few ideas for combining quick-service foods with home cooking to create semi-homemade meals.What are your favorite tricks and tips? We'd love for you to share them in the comments at EverydayCheapskate.com/semihomemade.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." title: No end to this game?
author: Staff Writer
content:
No end to this game?

 March 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 473
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the introduction of the latest resolution by the Lesher/Melkie team, we again find ourselves at a new beginning in the ongoing attempt to control the growth in the Town of Trappe. Unfortunately, this "new" resolution is nothing more than a repackaging of the same resolutions we have watched the county wrestle with for more than a year with no outcome in sight.Changing a few numbers and giving it a new title does not in any way change the obvious intent of all this legislation, which is to keep the Lakeside development under the control of a minority group with their own agenda. What that agenda is has been unclear but obviously their intent is to drag out the process in any way they can to buy time for more interference.
A recent letter to the Star Democrat went so far as to imply that the Town of Trappe needs to be ready to build schools for the new students from Lakeside. Since when did small towns begin building and paying for their own schools? Isn't that a county function? I thought that's what we pay county taxes for?
The implication was that citizens in Talbot County shouldn't have to educate Trappe children. Does that mean Trappe taxpayers shouldn't pay for schools in other parts of the county? That is not how government works. What next? Does Trappe need to build it's own hospital?
I have paid county taxes for the 25 years since retiring here. I would like to know what my taxes go for. I see many expenditures approved at County Council meetings using funds that include my taxes. Why should I feel guilty when I expect to be treated like any other county citizen?
The Lakeside development is simply Trappe's attempt to make up for years of lackluster or nonexistent growth so that our town can enjoy a tax base that can provide the funding needed to function as a modern, financially stable municipality. The county also will benefit in the long run with additional residential and commercial taxes, more housing for county residents, not to mention jobs to reduce unemployment in the area.
Why doesn't anyone want to look at the positives of a planned development instead of focusing on the negatives? This whole situation has dragged out long enough and doesn't need new legislative smoke and mirrors in an attempt to drag it further. All of this waste of time and resources is an unnecessary cost we should not be forced to bear.
And on a final note, I really want to express my disbelief that Mr. Lesher and Ms. Melkie would insult the intelligence of their constituents by their attempt to blatantly force their old legislation through as something new, just by making such a minute change, which will only add one to three years more to an already time-consuming process.
MICHAEL SULLIVAN
Trappe

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/March 19
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/March 19

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On March 19, 2003, in a televised address, President George W. Bush announced that coalition forces had begun an invasion of Iraq. (Bush would declare victory just over five weeks later in his "Mission Accomplished" speech.)Also on this date:
In 1931, Nevada Gov. Fred B. Balzar signed a measure that made the state the first to legalize gambling.
In 1945, during World War II, more than 800 service members were killed when a Japanese dive bomber attacked the carrier USS Franklin near Japan.
In 1953, the 25th Academy Awards ceremony was the first to be televised; "The Greatest Show on Earth" would win the Oscar for Best Picture.
In 1965, archeologist E. Lee Spence discovered the wreckage of the SS Georgiana, a Confederate ship that had sunk near Charleston, South Carolina, exactly 102 years earlier.
In 1966, Texas Western (now the University of Texas at El Paso) became the first team to start five Black players in the NCAA basketball tournament's championship game; they defeated top-ranked Kentucky in the final, 72-65.
In 1987, televangelist Jim Bakker resigned as chairman of his PTL ministry organization amid a sex and money scandal involving Jessica Hahn, a former church secretary.
In 1995, 17 months after announcing his retirement from basketball, Michael Jordan returned to play in the NBA with his former team, the Chicago Bulls. (He would go on to win three more NBA championships alongside the three he and the Bulls had already won.)
Today's Birthdays: Actor Ursula Andress is 89. Singer Ruth Pointer (The Pointer Sisters) is 79. Actor Glenn Close is 78. Actor Bruce Willis is 70. NFL coach Andy Reid is 67. Actor Ebon Moss-Bachrach is 48. Comedian-podcaster Theo Von is 45. Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin is 43. MLB pitcher Clayton Kershaw is 37.

title: Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden;
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Voter turnout: 13M more nonvoters than Trump backers; Harris got 10% fewer votes than Biden;

 November 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1204
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 89 million voting eligible Americans didn't vote in the 2024 elections, according to the latest tallies collected by the University of Florida's Election Lab.That accounts for more than 36.4% of the U.S. total electorate of 244.7 million people (voters and nonvoters).
There are still some votes being counted in California and Arizona.
But as it stands as of Thursday, Nov. 14, there were 13.2 million more nonvoters than supporters of now President-elect Donald Trump in the 2024 White House race.
Trump — who defeated Vice President Kamala Harris — has received close to 75.9 million votes, according to tallies Thursday from The Associated Press.
That accounts for just over 50% of the popular vote. But if nonvoters are included Trump got 31% of the electorate (voting and nonvoting).
Harris, the sitting U.S. vice president, has received close to 72.9 million votes, as of Thursday's counts.
That is more than 16.2 million fewer votes than the number of non-voters. As it stands, Harris got 29.7% of the total U.S. electorate.
Harris was installed at the top of the ticket after President Joe Biden was pressured by Democratic Party leaders and donors to quit the race in late July over concerns about his advanced age. There were some polls showing U.S. voters viewing that installation as 'undemocratic.'
Biden got close to 81.3 million in 2020 when he defeated Trump. That is more than 8.3 million more votes than Harris got in 2024. There were also more than 4.1 million fewer voters overall in 2024 compared to 2020.
Ani Ruhil, associate dean for research and planning and professor at Ohio University's Voinovich School of Leadership and Public Service, said ongoing vote counts could impact final turnout figures.
But Ruhil sees lower turnout as a key trend line in the 2024 race that saw Trump return to the White House.
"Only seven states exceeded their 2020 turnout rate – Georgia, Michigan, North Dakota, Vermont and Wisconsin," Ruhil said. "Washington, D.C., had an especially poor showing compared to 2020. So did Oregon, New Jersey, Maryland, Alaska, Illinois, and Utah."
The number of voters casting ballots in 2024 was down 11.6% in New Jersey, 11.2% in Illinois, 8.9% in Oregon and 4.6% in Washington state compared to 2020.
Nationally, turnout stands at 63.6%, according to the University of Florida. Ruhil said turnout in 2020 — which totaled 66.6% nationally — was a political aberration.
The Biden-Trump 2020 race occurred in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which saw more than 1.1 million deaths in the U.S., millions of workers facing job cuts and reduced hours, mask mandates and closures of schools, business and social events.
"Turnout was fanned by fear and anger," he said.
"In comes President Biden, with the singular charge of steering the country through the pandemic, and of making sure the economy did not fall to pieces. But by 2023, as we came out of the pandemic, inflation had taken its toll. Now was not the fear of a virus, but rather of gaping holes in the pocketbook. But there was no comforting plan being put forth by the White House," Ruhil continued.
He sees some voter fatigue with continued efforts by federal and state prosecutors to go after Trump.
Seventy percent of voters said the U.S. is headed in the wrong direction, with two-thirds stressed about inflation and the economy. Prices are up more than 20% since the pandemic and from when Biden and Harris took office in 2021, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Voters worried about the economy and high prices favored Trump in the 2024 race, according to exit polls.
The war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas after the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks also challenged Harris.
Anti-war voters (including Muslims and Arab Americans) are upset with U.S. military support for Israel. In the other corner, supporters of Israel (including more conservative Jewish voters) didn't trust Harris to continue U.S. support for Israel. The U.S. has allocated $17.9 billion war aid to Israel since Hamas' 2023 attacks, according to Brown University.
Harris got just over 80,000 fewer votes in Michigan, where the Israel-Hamas war is an issue for Arab-American and Muslim voters, than Biden 2020.
She lost to Trump by just over 80,600 votes in Michigan.
Ruhil said the enthusiasm was let out of the turnout balloon for many Democratic voters.
"The late switch, fevered fundraising, and a hastily assembled campaign did nothing to instill confidence," he said, stressing the lack of a convincing economic message from Harris.
Harris' campaign raised more than $1 billion and had another $649 million in backing from outside groups, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. Trump raised $381.5 million and was aided by $711 million in outside spending, according to CRP.
Harris' campaign focused heavily on support for abortion rights, casting Trump as a fascist threat to democracy and procuring celebrity endorsements including Oprah Winfrey, Jennifer Lopez, Beyonce, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen.
The effort fell short with Harris underperforming Biden by 8.4 million votes (or 10.3%) nationally. She saw lower turnout or flat support levels in key Electoral College battlegrounds that Trump won.
Harris got 6.6% fewer votes than Biden in Arizona.
There was also the dynamic of Trump carrying states such as Montana, Missouri, Arizona and Florida, where there were abortion rights measures also on the ballot.
Those measures all passed and in Florida an abortion rights measure got 57% of the vote (failing to meet the state's 60% threshold). Trump got 56% of the vote.
In Montana, Trump carried the state with 58%. An abortion rights measure got the same percentage.
Trump favors allowing states to decide the abortion issue versus Harris, who backs nationally enshrining abortion rights.
Abortion rights groups were among the top backers of Harris.
"This result is devastating. There has been no greater champion for reproductive freedom than Vice President Kamala Harris," said Mini Timmaraju, president and CEO of Reproductive Freedom for All, a leading abortion rights advocacy group.
"We know the American people are with us, and they showed us that when they passed ballot measures and elected candidates in key states to protect their rights, said Timmaraju, who worries about Trump and the GOP in charge of the White House and Congress.
Harris and Democrats had hoped for a wave of women voters supporting abortion rights in the race against Trump.
But exit polls showed Trump carrying a majority of white women who voted, and voters were more evenly split on which presidential candidate they trusted on the abortion issue than in pre-election polls.
Abortion rights opponents argue Harris' focus on expansive abortion rights turned off some voters.
"Kamala Harris and Tim Walz support abortion anytime, anywhere, and under any circumstances. Supported by the abortion industry and its allies, Harris and Walz campaigned with fanatical fervor on abortion — and the voters rejected them," said Carol Tobias, president of National Right to Life.
Trump carried 58% of the Catholic vote versus 40% for Harris, according to NBC News exit polls. In 2020, Biden and Trump were evenly split with Catholics (49% to 50%), according to the Associated Press.
Trump won 63% of the votes from white working class women, made inroads with Hispanics (especially Hispanic men) and edged Harris with working class households, according to NBC News exit polls.
According to the University of Florida, there were 15.5 million fewer early votes in 2024 compared to 2020 (85.9 million versus 101.45 million).
That's a 15% drop.

title: Gov. Wes Moore, a friend of Maryland newspapers
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Gov. Wes Moore, a friend of Maryland newspapers

 June 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Columns 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Wes Moore recently vetoed a Maryland House bill that would have been crippling to state newspapers."There is also a vital public interest in ensuring the existence of thriving independent local media," Moore wrote in his veto letter. "In fact, democracy can not function effectively in the absence of a free press that provides objective information to the citizenry about crucial events in government and in our communities."
The legislation, House Bill 1258, would have taken public notices regarding estate administration, currently published in newspapers, and allowed them to be posted on a state-operated website. The cost to state newspapers was estimated at $1.7 million. If the legislation had taken effect Oct. 1, there is no doubt that by the dawn of the new year would have seen significantly fewer newspaper journalists working in Maryland.
In his veto letter, Moore noted public notice advertising "have helped sustain much of the local print media in Maryland' as advertising dollars have dried up and the media industry has consolidated and downsized.
Moore had some tough words for the newspaper industry, whose lobbying group did not engage in hearings, testimony or conversations about the bill. That was a serious oversight by the Maryland-Delaware-D.C. Press Association, an oversight that could have had disastrous effects on the newspapers that pay dues for the association to represent them in legislative discussions. Moore, without a doubt, bailed out newspapers with his veto.
Sticking on the theme of state politics, the race to replace U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin started hot and continues to sizzle. Democrat Cardin decided not to seek reelection, which set off a ferocious primary battle between Congressman David Throne and Prince George's County Executive Angela Alsobrooks. Despite being outspent 9-1 by Trone who dumped tens of millions of his own money into his campaign, Alsobrooks easily won the nomination.
Alsobrooks will face former Gov. Larry Hogan in November. Hogan is hoping to appeal to Democrats to cross over and vote for him as they did when he was elected governor. Hogan started the morning after the primary, releasing a video showing prominent Democrats praising him during his days when he was governor. The video featured clips of Wes Moore, Barack Obama, Bill Clinton and even Angela Alsobrooks. The message: Hogan has a history of working across the aisle with Democrats.
That message was on display last week when Hogan visited Cambridge where he picked up a couple of endorsements from Dorchester County Councilman Ricky Travers, a Democrat, and County Council Vice President Mike Detmer, a Republican.
"This is especially nice because it's a bipartisan thing," Hogan told Star Democrat reporter Maggie Trovato. "I've always been somebody that reaches across the aisle and tries to find consensus and tries to get things done with Republicans and Democrats working together."
For Travers, it's not about Democrat or Republican when it comes to the Senate seat.
"It's about who's the best person for the job," he said in an interview. "That's the bottom line."
Hogan drew fire from his own party after he posted on Twitter prior to a New York jury finding former President Donald Trump guilty on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in connection with hush-money payments during the 2016 campaign to cover up an affair with adult film actress, Stormy Daniels.
"Regardless of the result, I urge all Americans to respect the verdict and the legal process," he posted on X, formerly Twitter. "… We must reaffirm what has made this nation great: the rule of law."
That drew criticism from Republicans.
"You just ended your campaign," Chris LaCivita, a senior adviser to Trump's presidential campaign, responded minutes later.
Buckle your seatbelts, we are in for a wild ride with this campaign.
Congratulations to Talbot County Council member Keasha Haythe who became a grandmother on March 17 with the birth of Declan James Alexander Haythe. Declan is the son of Marcus Leandre Haythe Jr. and Beatrice Anne Gorman. Keasha Haythe beams when she talks about her grandson.
Jim Johnson is the executive editor of the Star Democrat.

title: 'Spirit of the Shore' CBMM celebrating Watermen's Appreciation Day
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Spirit of the Shore' CBMM celebrating Watermen's Appreciation Day

 July 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum.is celebrating a Watermen's Appreciation Day in St. Michaels on Sunday, Aug. 11.The event runs 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.
The appreciation day honors the men and woman who work throughout the Chesapeake Bay (including harvesting crabs and oysters). In an announcement, CBMM said the event celebrates "the vibrant spirit of the Easter Shore."
The museum is partnering with the Talbot Waterman Association for the appreciation day which features a boat docking contest, steamed crabs, live music and kids activities.
Tickets are on sale at cbmm.org/watermensday.
"Watermen's Appreciation Day is a time-honored celebration of our Chesapeake Bay heritage, showcasing the skill and dedication of those who work the waters every day," TWA President Jeff Harrison said. "It's a wonderful opportunity for the community to come together and support our local watermen."
Starting at 11 a.m., TWA members will serve steamed crabs at a cost of $40 per dozen, plus an ear of corn. There will also be hot dogs, hamburgers, ice cream and more available for purchase.
The boat docking contest is at noon.
There will also be live music from Bird Dog and the Road Kings at the historic Tolchester Beach Bandstand as well as local arts and crafts vendors as well as a silent auction to benefit TWA.
The Phillips Wharf Fishmobile traveling aquarium will be at the Aug. 11 event along kids activities highlighting the Chesapeake Bay.
Tickets can be purchased in advance online or at the door. Admission is set at $22 for adults, $19 for seniors (65+) and students (17+), $10 for active and retired military members, and $9 for children ages 6-to-17, with all children 5-and-younger admitted free.
CBMM members receive discounted pricing to Watermen's Appreciation Day and other annual festivals throughout the year. Adult member tickets are $10, and all children of members (17-and-younger) receive free admission. To support CBMM's mission as a member and discover all the terrific benefits of membership, visit cbmm.org/memberships or contact Membership Services Coordinator Debbie Ruzicka at 410-745-4991 or druzicka@cbmm.org.
All licensed watermen and their immediate families receive free admission to the festival by showing an active license at the door.
During the festival, additional free event parking will be available at St. Michaels Middle/High School, with a free shuttle service running to and from CBMM.

title: CAMBRIDGE CITY COUNCIL/Aug. 11
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
CAMBRIDGE CITY COUNCIL/Aug. 11

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Dorchester 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Cambridge City Council met Monday, Aug. 11, and the following actions were taken:Mayor Lajan Cephas opened the meeting with a moment of silence for members of Cambridge's immigrant community after a number of arrests by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement last week. Cephas also honored former Cambridge Commissioner Gorton McWilliams, who died Monday, with a moment of silence.Commissioners heard a presentation from RTC Solutions and Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson about programming targeting violence among students in Dorchester County Public Schools. The city agreed to discuss the violence prevention initiative further by setting up a meeting with stakeholders who could help fund the program.Commissioners heard a presentation from the Alpha Genesis Community Foundation about an event proposal from Blacks of the Chesapeake Foundation. The event, which will take place Oct. 25, is seeking a special event permit from the city. The event will feature resources from community organizations, historic information highlighting contributions of the African American community and rides on schooner Pride of Baltimore II.The city attorney introduced a resolution that would amend the city charter so that the Cambridge City Council's president would be elected by members of the council on an annual basis.Commissioners held the second reading for an ordinance establishing an article in the city code that creates procedures for the city to petition the district court to appoint a receiver to rehabilitate, demolish or sell blighted, abandoned or vacant properties in the city. The ordinance was passed unanimously, with Commissioner Frank Stout absent from the meeting.Commissioners unanimously passed an ordinance allowing for the city's purchase of property at the future Mace's Lane Community Center for $1.Commissioners unanimously approved an amendment of the city's Community Development Block Grant funding agreement with the Department of Housing and Community Development to reflect an additional $800,000 in funding to go toward construction at the Mace's Lane Community Center.Commissioners unanimously approved an amended parade route for the Groove City Culture Fest Caribbean Carnival Parade on Saturday, Aug. 16.Commissioners unanimously agreed to place an order for a new fire truck for $1.4 million. Commissioners also approved an amendment to the motion that directs the city manager to compile a forecast for large city purchases over the next several years, which the commissioners said would better help them understand the overall state of city finances when approving large purchases.Commissioners heard a quarterly presentation from the Cambridge Police Department that suggested that overall offenses were down about 5.5% from the second quarter of last year.

title: Ghrist sponsors DAF storage bill
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Ghrist sponsors DAF storage bill

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State Del. Jeff Ghrist introduced legislation Feb. 9 aimed at giving local jurisdictions the authority to regulate the storage of dissolved air flotation by-products, otherwise known as DAF residuals."I want to make sure that the local governing bodies can do that on their own without any ambiguity, because small counties like Caroline … can't afford to be sued," Ghrist (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) said in a Feb. 21 interview.
House Bill 1404 was co-sponsored by Del. Steve Arentz (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) and Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) as well as two Cecil County legislators and three from the western shore. It is cross-filed with Senate Bill 1149, sponsored by Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Ghrist's bill addresses an issue the Caroline County Commissioners have been dealing with in their legislation process since mid-December. He said he discussed the DAF storage issue with the commissioners, the Eastern Shore delegation and the Maryland Farm Bureau.
Neither the state's Department of the Environment nor the Department of Agriculture have jurisdiction over regulating or controlling the storage of DAF residuals, "and so we have at least one person taking advantage of that loophole in the law," he said.
"Whether or not (Love's bill) removes any ambiguity (regarding) how much control the county commissioners have in storage, that remains to be seen," Ghrist said. "But I just want to make sure that after this legislation is passed that one, it goes far enough to ensure that we're not going to have DAF being stored anywhere near our towns, and two, if it doesn't go far enough, I want to make sure that the local governing bodies can (restrict it) on their own, without any ambiguity."
Ghrist said he wanted to make sure that the case would have no standing in court if "anybody decided to sue the county."
The bill is "just a placeholder," Ghrist said. If a separate bill, HB991 sponsored by Del. Sara Love (D-Montgomery) addresses the DAF storage issue and is passed, Ghrist said he may consider withdrawing his.
If enacted, HB991 would establish an industrial sludge utilization permit administered and enforced by the Department of the Environment.
Ghrist's bill will be considered 1 p.m. March 8 by the Environment and Transportation Committee.
Love's bill will go to the same committee 1 p.m. March 5.
For more information on legislation in the 2024 Maryland General Assembly, visit mgaleg.maryland.gov.

title: Corn fields, corn cribs and corn recipes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Corn fields, corn cribs and corn recipes

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1351
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Riding the country roads throughout the Eastern Shore brings back so many memories of the past.The cornfields of today have not changed — the beautiful green rows of corn stalks slightly moving in the hot breeze. But how these fields were planted and will be harvested has changed.
Those modern, expensive, air-conditioned tractors with radios make life easier on 90-to-100-degree days. But the farmer's workday is still not easy — exposed to all kinds of environments, no guarantee of a successful harvest, seeds and chemical prices skyrocketing, getting farm workers is almost impossible. Yet that farmer keeps going and praying he has a good crop this year.
As we turn onto West Line Road, some of the corn fields are there — not many, but still a few. The memories begin to surface as I see where the barn once stood.
This barn housed the cows, and the second floor, known as the hayloft, held the hay. Many funny stories linger in that memory (another column for another day).
Behind the barn were the hog pens, where a lot of the corn was eaten, and the corn stalks made clean bedding.
The corn crib is a slender shed and had a roof, wooden floor, latched door and slatted walls that allowed air and light to help keep the corn from molding. The corn in here had some husks on them, but by fall they had dried. We would peel off the dried husks and throw them onto the ground in the pig pen, then hand shelled the corn into the hog trough.
In those days, the older kids watched the younger kids when the parents had to attend events without their children. One day my parents left my older sister to watch us.
My sister was an "undercover smoker." We were not allowed to smoke, but she did whenever and wherever no adults were around.
As soon as the car pulled out of the driveway, she got her "smokes" out and went outside, taking my brother with her, and they proceeded to "puff."
Suddenly my parents' car pulled in the driveway. Apparently, they had forgotten something.
Well, my brother and sister shoved their lit cigarettes in the slats of the corn crib, which sparked a fire, and smoke soon billowed. My mom came out of the house, smelled smoke, ran in her "dress clothes" to get the water turned on for the hose while screaming for my dad to get out and help.
My brother never smoked again, but my sister smoked "undercover" for many more years.
A few tips for buying corn at your local produce stands this year:
Don't buy pre-shucked corn, as it starts getting starchy once the stalk is off.Examine the silk. Older corn silk will look brown/black and dried out. Fresh corn on the cob will have silk that's a lighter color.Look for husks that are bright green, and avoid husks that are brown, bruised or dried-out looking.Hold each ear of corn to find the heavier ones, which are juicier.
Enjoy today's corn recipes.
STEAMED CORN6 ears corn (husked), 2 tbsps granulated sugar, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tsp salt.
Fill a pot full of water and bring it to boil. Stir in the sugar, lemon juice, and salt. Place the corn into the boiling water. Let the water return to a boil. Once boiling again, cover with a lid and turn off the heat. Cook the corn for 8-10 minutes or until tender.
SWEET CORN RELISH10 fresh ears of sweet yellow corn (husks and silk removed, slice kernels off the cob with a sharp knife), 2 large red bell peppers (cored and finely chopped), 2 large green bell peppers (cored and finely chopped), 8 ribs celery (finely chopped), 1 large yellow or sweet onion (finely chopped), 4 cups apple cider vinegar, 2 cups sugar, 1 tbsp ground mustard, 3 tsps salt.
Combine all the ingredients in a pot and bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Reduce the heat to medium and simmer uncovered for about 20 minutes until the vegetables are tender. Ladle the relish into hot sterilized jars and seal with lids. Process the jars in a water bath for 10 minutes. Keep stored in a dark, cool place. Will keep at least one year. Once opened, store in the fridge for up to two months. Makes approximately 8 pints. Wait a week or two before eating the relish to allow time for the vinegar to mellow out. Use it on hamburgers, hot dogs, sandwiches, fish, serve it with roasted chicken or mix with tomatoes/onions/cilantro for a Summer salad.
CORN PUDDING RECIPE5 large eggs, ⅓ cup butter (melted and slightly cooled), ¼ cup white sugar, ½ cup milk, ¼ cup cornstarch,1 ½ cups steamed or cooked corn or 1 can of kernel corn, 2 (14.75 ounce) cans cream-style corn.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Grease a 2-quart casserole dish. Whisk eggs lightly in a large bowl. Add milk, melted butter, sugar, and cornstarch; whisk until well combined. Stir in drained corn and cream-style corn until fully blended. Pour mixture into the prepared casserole dish. Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, about 1 hour.
CORN FRITTERS3 cups oil for frying, 1 cup sifted all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking powder, ½ tsp salt, ¼ tsp white sugar, 1 large egg (lightly beaten), ½ cup milk, 1 tbsp shortening (melted), 1 12-ounce can whole kernel corn (drained).
Heat oil in a heavy pot or deep fryer to 365 degrees. Combine flour, baking powder, salt and sugar in a medium bowl. Beat egg, milk and melted shortening together in a small bowl. Stir egg mixture into flour mixture. Stir in corn. Working in batches, drop fritter batter by spoonful into the hot oil. Fry until golden. Remove fritters with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
BARBECUE GRILLED "CORN RIBS"BBQ Seasoning Blend: 2 tbsps chili powder, 1 tsp smoked paprika, 1 tsp packed light brown sugar, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, salt.
BBQ Sauce: 1 cup ketchup, 1 cup apple cider vinegar,1 /4 cup yellow mustard, 3 tbsps packed light brown sugar, 1/2 tsp hot sauce, salt.
Corn Ribs: 4 ears corn (shucked), Canola or vegetable oil (for the grill grates), 1 scallion (thinly sliced).
For the BBQ seasoning blend: Stir to combine the chili powder, smoked paprika, brown sugar, cayenne pepper and 1 tsp salt in a small bowl.
For the BBQ sauce: Whisk together the ketchup, apple cider vinegar, mustard, brown sugar, hot sauce, 1 tsp salt and 1 tbsp of the BBQ seasoning blend in a small saucepan over medium-high heat. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to medium and simmer until the sauce has reduced and thickened, 10 to 12 minutes.
For the corn ribs: Using a large chef's knife and a large steady cutting board, cut off the ends of the corn cobs to make them flat. Using your hands, break the cobs in half crosswise. Stand a cob on one flat end and carefully and slowly cut down through the core, rocking the knife back and forth if necessary, to split the cob in half lengthwise. Repeat with all the cobs. Lay a split corn cob on its flat side on the cutting board and cut lengthwise through the cob, pressing down and rocking the knife back and forth if necessary, to make 2 long corn ribs. Repeat with the remaining cob halves. (You should have 32 ribs total.) Place on a rimmed baking sheet and set aside.
Prepare a grill for medium-high heat and lightly oil the grates. Sprinkle the corn ribs with 1 tablespoon of the seasoning blend. Brush the ribs with 1/2 cup BBQ sauce. Place the corn, cut-side down, on the grill and close the lid. Cook until the cut edges are beginning to char and caramelize, about 8 minutes. Flip the ribs to the second cut side, close the grill lid and cook until the edges are caramelized and the corn kernels are crisp-tender, another 6 to 8 minutes. Transfer the corn to a platter. Brush with more sauce and season with a pinch of the BBQ seasoning blend (reserve the remaining blend for another use). Sprinkle the scallions and serve with the remaining BBQ sauce.

title: It's time for Mid-Shore regional planning
author: DAVID REEL
content:
It's time for Mid-Shore regional planning

 June 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Activate 
 
 588
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, the Greater Baltimore Committee (GBC) released a new 10-year strategic plan calling for (in their words), a "sea change," to boost economic opportunity in Baltimore city and five Maryland counties adjacent to Baltimore — Anne Arundel, Baltimore, Carroll, Harford and Howard.Founded in 1955, GBC is a not-for-profit organization with approximately 400 members.
Their membership includes large, mid-size and small businesses, not-for-profit organizations, foundations, educational providers and health care institutions in the Baltimore region.
All the geographic areas served by GBC are unique, but all recognize the value of mutually beneficial collaborative efforts on economic development matters.
In an ever-changing world, GBC 's new strategic plan acknowledged a pressing need for changes on a better definition of their traditional purposes and their traditional goals.
Accordingly, their new plan includes new purposes and new goals to guide private and public investment and regional collaborations designed to result in transformational positive change in the Baltimore region.
Specific GBC goals are included in three broad areas of economic development. They are:
Industry and innovation.Place and community.Talent and people.
Ultimately, GBC's vision is to position the Baltimore region's residents, businesses and quality of life amenities, as a globally recognizable and competitive brand.
The overall success of GBC's new plan is based not only on new purposes and new goals. It also depends upon on a continuing commitment to collaboration from businesses, political leaders, developers, educators, workforce providers, nonprofits, entrepreneurs, current economic development organizations and other key stakeholders in Baltimore City and the five surrounding counties.
Based on past measurable successes with GBC, they understand they do best by not competing against each other but by working together to compete globally for current and emerging economic engines that provide good jobs, good wages, good benefits and economic stability.
They also understand the needs of the leaders such economic engines. These leaders are much less interested in artificial human-made geographic boundaries that delineate county and municipal borders and are much more interested in what a region can provide in terms of a long-term, reliable and positive business environment along with a supply of skilled workers.
No doubt any discussion of any changes leading to a new regional approach to economic development for the Mid-Shore region may be unsettling to some. It is new, and it is different.
I suggest now is the time for the leaders in Talbot, Dorchester and Caroline counties (at a minimum) to immediately engage in meaningful discussions on the feasibility and benefits of launching a Mid-Shore version of a regional economic development organization comparable to the GBC.
The key words are comparable to the GBC, not identical to the GBC.
I am not suggesting Mid-Shore leaders adopt GBC's purposes and goals without modifications that work best for the Mid-Shore now and going forward. I further suggest we already have an outstanding organization in place to serve as a new leader in regional economic development.
That organization is Chesapeake College.
The college has served the Mid Shore region with distinction since it was chartered as Maryland's first regional community college in 1965 and opened in 1967.
Offering a wide range of adult learning opportunities, they have extensive experience in developing and conducting workforce-training programs. The availability of these programs is great selling point for economic development prospects.
I also suggest that in addition to a new regional economic development organizational model, the Mid-Shore must have an open and transparent process for developing regional economic development goals based on citizen input to maintain and advance the Mid-Shore's position in Maryland as the "Land of Pleasant Living."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 782
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent flash flood tragedy in central Texas resulted in seeing the best and the worst of American society.The best has been an outpouring of sympathy, caring and support for the flood victims, their families and the survivors. There have been countless reports of selfless rescue and recovery efforts by first responders and volunteers, some from well beyond the immediate flooded area.
The worst has been numerous messages on social media and other media platforms — e.g., a newspaper editorial cartoon — that were vile, hateful and some of which were vulgar.
Many of them chose to blame Trump supporters or policy decisions of the Trump administration for this tragedy.
Far too many did not include expressions of sadness or sympathy for the deaths of innocent children and adults or compassion for the lifelong impact on all the flooding survivors.
The level of vitriol in these messages is so offensive, I will not repeat any of them in this column.
The only thing they have in common is they are devoid of any sense of decency and civility.
Somewhat surprising has been dismay and even outrage expressed from unexpected sources over these vile messages.
Nina Turner is a former national co-chair for the Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign.
She recently said, "It takes a serious lack of humanity to see children to be in a politicized discussion and respond something like lines of "that's what they [voters in Texas] voted for."
Turner's closing one word comment says it all — "Shameful."
John Favreau and Tommy Vietor are co-hosts on the left of center, Pod Save America.
Both worked for Barack Obama prior to and during his presidential administration.
Both have condemned social media posts that blame local Texans and the Trump administration for all who died as a result of the recent floods.
Favreau said: "I think the really gross stuff was, I saw some people be, like, 'Well, Texas, you voted for Trump, and this is what you get.'"
Favreau has challenged suggestions that staffing levels at the National Weather Service in Texas had anything to do with the tragedy. Favreau has said, "It seems like the National Weather Service, like I said, did send out a timely warning, it just didn't get to people. And that's, you know, not the Trump administration saying that; independent meteorologists and experts have all said this."
Vietor has said that while questions about the effect of weather services cuts could be "an important question going forward, I could have done without the, like, instant, you know, leap to blame name-your-political-opponent for this tragedy on Twitter."
The "blame your political opponent" campaign on this tragedy is already well underway.
Shortly after news broke on the flooding, Sen. Chuck Schumer demanded the Commerce Department's inspector general investigate vacancies at National Weather Service offices and whether the purported vacancies resulted in a higher death toll in in Texas.
Schumer has suggested that proposed but yet-to-be-implemented Trump budget cuts resulted in unfilled weather service positions in Texas were to blame. Sen. Chris Dodd has said likewise.
Schumer proclaimed: "The American people deserve answers."
Yes, we do, but not from you two or anyone who wants to advance a political agenda from this tragedy.
We deserve answers only if the following investigative guidelines are agreed to, in advance of, and are strictly adhered to during every phase of any investigation. At a minimum, the investigation must focus less on assigning blame for what happened or did not happen with regard to timely and effective flash flood alerts.
The laser like focus must be on what can be done going forward to help ensure it never happens again.
Differing opinions must be welcome and considered provided they follow the timeless observation of former U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who once said, "Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but not their own facts."
One new previously unreported fact comes from a recent Washington Post article headline — "Camp Mystic's leader got a 'life threatening' flood alert. They evacuated an hour later."
We also need to accept that we never have and never will live in a risk-free world.
We can only anticipate risks and take prudent steps to try to avoid them or deal with them if and when necessary. Accidents can never be totally avoided despite plans and best intentions.
Going forward, we desperately need a renewed universal commitment that when tragedies strike, to make sure social media posts and other public reactions reflect common decency and respect for each and every person impacted in any way by that tragedy.
This is especially vital in dealing with those who hold different political party affiliations or different views on a wide range of public policy issues.
We must do so if we have any hope of reversing the steadily declining levels of decency and civility in our society.
