title: Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since news broke last week that federal cuts would deprive the Food Bank of Delaware of 19 truckloads of urgently needed food, the organization has seen a surge of new donors and an increase in visitors to its website looking for ways to help."We have gotten so much groundswell of support from people that maybe didn't even know about the Food Bank, but are learning about the Food Bank now and not wanting to see people in the State of Delaware go hungry," CEO Cathy Kanefsky said.
That community support was on full display Tuesday evening during an emergency food drive sponsored by Newark-area legislators. A steady stream of cars pulled up at the Food Bank's Glasgow warehouse to drop off food donations that were then unloaded by legislators and other volunteers.
Inside, 25 volunteers helped sort and pack food.
"Tonight has been so heartwarming to just stand here and watch all the legislators that have come out to support, and all the people that are coming with food," Kanefsky said.
Food banks across the country were left reeling last week when the Trump administration abruptly paused $500 million in funding for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Emergency Food Assistance Program.
For the Food Bank of Delaware, from April to June alone, the canceled shipments equate to 750,000 pounds of food or 900,000 meals that would have directly benefited residents across the state.
State Rep. Eric Morrison, who has been a regular Food Bank volunteer for 20 years, organized Tuesday's food drive.
"When I learned that they are going to be losing about 50 percent of their food, everybody felt frustrated and I thought I have to do something. Somebody has to do something," Morrison said. "Tonight, we can bring in a lot of food, but we can also bring in awareness, which is really important."
One in seven Delawareans, including one in five children, are food insecure, he added.
"I think some people may have certain prejudices or misconceptions about who uses the Food Bank, but we're talking about your grandparents, your children, your next door neighbor with a disability. It's a lot of people," he said.
Morrison added that in Dover, there are ongoing discussions about how much the state will have to step in to make up for lost funding to the Food Bank and other programs affected by federal cuts.
"It's very hard right now, because with the federal administration, everything is just very day-by-day," he said. "Every day, we're waking up to something new."
Residents can visit fbd.org to learn how they can help the Food Bank.
"We're facing some interesting times, and we've all got to take care of each other," Morrison said.

title: Mental Health experts offer tips for managing New Year's resolutions
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mental Health experts offer tips for managing New Year's resolutions

 January 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The new year is here, and what comes with it, for many people, is a fresh start.New Year's resolutions are infamously tied to failure of goals, but mental health experts share that if people are seeking positive change in their lives, understanding mental health will allow people to not only accomplish their goals but to be kinder to themselves if they are unable to achieve their goals within an expected time frame.
Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications at For All Seasons, said the connection between mental health and New Year's resolutions are heavily tied together.
"Mental health is foundational to how we think, feel and act," Theeke said. "When we care for our mental health we feel better, and people will often see their quality of life and relationships improve. Without awareness and care for our mental health, it's very difficult to have the motivation and commitment to fulfill our hopes and goals for the new year."
According to Centerstone, a national nonprofit specializing in mental health and substance use disorder, there is an unspoken rule that resolutions should be all or nothing extremities. This mindset it often leads to difficult-to-accomplish resolutions and then ideas of self-sabotage and punishment if resolutions are not accomplished, Centerstone said.
Theeke said it is great to think of goals, but what is more important is the little steps and systems that are put into place to steer people in the direction they want to go. Instead of focusing on a big goal like losing a significant amount of weight, she encourages people to try to set up a simple system to start getting healthy, such as walking with a friend each week.
Theeke said it's the small attainable steps that start to build up. If one system doesn't work it's important to evaluate and change the system to something that works better for the individual.
For those who want to make resolutions around mental health, Theeke suggests considering activities that bring positive emotions, whether it be music, walking, exercising, feeding and watching birds, or spending time with friends and family. Prioritizing simple acts of joy, even if it requires carving time out to do so, can have big gains in mental health growth, she said.
For those who find themselves continuing to feel low for more than two weeks at a time, Theeke suggests considering reaching out to a mental health professional. Individuals need to take the time to invest in themselves and investing in mental health can have lasting gains.
But most importantly, Theeke encourages everyone to be kind to themselves regardless of success on their resolutions. If people are able to approach themselves with more kindness and understanding, it can help build the confidence needed to accomplish whatever goals that are made. But most importantly, kindness for self can make moving forward with everyday life easier and improve personal relationships.
"One of the nicest things you can do for yourself in the new year is change your internal dialogue," Theeke said. "So many of us are criticizing ourselves throughout the day. Catch yourself if you are thinking something negative and try out some simple phrases like, 'I am focusing on progress, not perfection.' Or, 'I am getting a little stronger and healthier every day.' There are so many positive affirmations out there. Find a few that feel right for you and try them. Reach out to a trusted friend or a mental health professional if you continue to struggle. There are good people out there who are ready to help."

title: Irene Gurka
content:
Irene Gurka

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Words

 EASTON - Irene Gurka, nee Myshak, died December 16, at Hospice House in Easton, MD. Her husband, Samuel Gurka, preceded her in death.Born and raised in Jermyn, Pennsylvania, she was the daughter of the late Stephen and Antosh Pash Myshak. She was a member of St. Michael's Orthodox Church, Jermyn, as well as a founding member of St.
Thekla Orthodox Church, Easton, Maryland.
Irene celebrated her 100th birthday in September where she was surrounded by family and friends. Baking and quilting were two of her passions. Up until the last few weeks she was still baking cookies.
Surviving are two daughters, Patricia and husband, Kenneth Rogers, Easton; and Sandra and husband, Mark Cassoni, Deerfield Beach, Florida; three grandsons, Paul and wife, Allison Rogers; Michael Cassoni and Matthew Cassoni; four great-grandchildren, Samuel and David Rogers, Lydia and Matthew Periconi.
She is also survived by her brother, Stephen Myshak, Jermyn, as well as many nieces and nephews.
Irene was also preceded in death by her grandson, Edward Rogers; two brothers, John and Paul Myshak; four sisters, Mary Myshak, Anna Mikowich, Dorothy Petorak, and Fanny Gazella.
The family would like to thank Talbot Hospice and the care givers at Hospice House for the comfort and care they provided to Irene and our entire family.
Friends may call at the Fellows, Helfenbein & Newnam funeral home in Easton on Wednesday 5 to 7 PM. A memorial service will be held at 6:30.
The funeral service will be Thursday, December 21 at 10:00 AM at St. Thekla Orthodox Church, Easton, with the Very Rev. John Monto officiating.
A panikhida will be held on Thursday, December 28 at 11:00 AM at St. Tikhon's Monastery Church, Waymart, PA, with the Rev.
John Black officiating. Interment will follow at St. Tikhon's Monastery Cemetery.

title: Young author presents local bird guide to Horizons students
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Young author presents local bird guide to Horizons students

 July 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 743
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Encouraging fellow youths to learn about their local feathered friends, Xaviana Leis, 13, of Edgewater presented her authored and illustrated "Maryland Bird Guide" to Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's students at the Gunston School June 25.Preventing summer learning from going to the birds, this season's Horizons summer program focus is all about birds with high-flying fun. Last week's presenter, Leis shared her knowledge about birds and her experiences as a raptor volunteer and what others can do to support their environment.
Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's programs seek to prevent "summer slide" and provide engaging educational opportunities and events for under-resourced students, according to Emily Murphy, executive director.
This season's theme focuses all on birds and in addition to regular Horizons activities, this summer students are diving into what it means to be a good steward of the environment and strengthen an appreciation for wildlife, Murphy said.
Throughout the summer the students will engage in high-flying activities including bird watching and building an osprey nest, Murphy said.
In keeping with this season's theme, Horizons was excited to welcome Leis, who at the age of 11, authored and illustrated her book "Maryland Bird Guide".
A homeschool student in Edgewater and member of Girl Scout 11023, her passion for birds grew when a rehabilitator with Owl Moon Raptor Center came to present to her troop, she said.
Soon, Leis was volunteering herself at Owl Moon along with her mother, and was captivated by the world of local birds, she said.
Writing and illustrating the self-published "Maryland Bird Guide" as part of a Girl Scout Bronze Star Award when she was 11, Leis seeks to continually educate her community on the wonders of local birds and spread messages about how to help these amazing creatures.
"I wanted to do something that would inspire others to learn more about birds and how they can help them," she said.
Some species of birds like crows are extremely intelligent and can remember the actions of humans that are nice to them and those who aren't so nice, Leis said. Crows also use human tools to their advantage, such as leaving nuts in the road to be cracked by passing cars and then hopping into the road when the traffic light turns red.
Contrary to popular belief, bread is not a suitable food to feed ducks at the park, Leis said.
Bread has little nutritional value for ducks and uneaten bread can also form algae to gunk up the water. Better foods available in your kitchen to toss for ducks include fruit, uncooked oatmeal and rice. Frozen peas thawed by the time you get to the park also make a nice treat, she said.
Leis also noted the impressive wingspan on several species of raptors that truly has to be seen to be believed.
She reiterated the importance of cleaning up litter for the benefit of keeping a natural habitat beautiful for all of us.
Also part of her Scout project, Leis built special tubes to properly dispose of discarded fishing line so it does not get tangled in unsuspecting wildlife.
Everyone can do their part in helping wildlife this summer by picking up trash, including fishing line and disposing of it in proper receptacles.
Going into eighth grade this fall, her goal is to continually educate her community about wildlife.
Birds are more than just pretty things to look at out your window, they are living creatures and helping birds thrive is a necessary part of the functioning ecosystem, Leis said. "They are part of the environment and we need to help them."
"Maryland Guide to Birds" includes over fifty different birds common to Maryland and nearby states alongside vibrant watercolor illustrations by Leis herself. The book contains a wingspan's worth of information including habitats, diet, size, and fun facts.
"You have the ability to make a difference even if you're younger. I want to show others they can have a cause they believe in," she said.
Receiving signed copies of the bird guide, Horizons students were encouraged to "go wild" and use the book through the summer program to help identify local birds in the area.
Leis self-published book is available on Amazon and all proceeds go toward Owl Moon. To date, Leis has raised over $10,000.
"It just feels incredible," she said.
Free copies of "Maryland Guide to Birds" for groups are available by messaging the Girls Making The World A Better Place Facebook page, Dombi-Leis said.
Horizons seeks to provide additional support and summer enrichment opportunities to underprivileged students.
More information about Horizons can be found at https://horizonskentqueenannes.org.

title: Life - Rotarians Holding Food Drive In Honor Of Late Lord Scott
author: Contributed
content:
Life - Rotarians Holding Food Drive In Honor Of Late Lord Scott

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 473
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON. The Rotary Club of Easton and other community partners are teaming up to host the Drop for Scotty Community Food Drive through the end of December.The food drive is named after the late Lord "Scotty" Scott Sr., who passed away in January 2020.Scott was well-known throughout Easton and Talbot County for hosting his annual Operation Christmas Spirit event at the Easton Volunteer Fire Department.Established in the 1970s, Operation Christmas Spirit made the holidays brighter for thousands through a large community meal and gifts for local children, supported by volunteers and donations."Scotty's kindness and love for the community knew no bounds, and this food drive is a way to honor his giving spirit," said Andrew Walsworth, Easton Rotary president. "Our club is privileged to carry on his legacy, continue his good work and provide direct relief to families in Talbot County during this holiday season." Individuals and organizations may drop off non-perishable food at 2023 designated drop sites: ¡ The ARC Chesapeake on N. Hanson Street ¡ BAAM on Jowite Street ¡ Bay Capital Mortgage on E. Dover Street ¡ BSC Group on Bay Street ¡ Critchlow Adkins on N. Magnolia Street or on Glenwood ¡ Eastern Shore Land Conservancy on S. Washington Street ¡ Easton Visitors Center on S. Harrison Street ¡ Easton Family YMCA on S. Washington Street or Peachblossom ¡ 4H Extension Office on Mary's Court ¡ Harris Teeter on Marlboro Avenue ¡ Mid Atlantic Tire on Teal Drive ¡ Provident State Bank on N. Harrison Street ¡ Queenstown Bank on N. Washington Street ¡ Saints Peter and Paul on High Street or S. Washington Street ¡ Shore United Bank on East Dover Street ¡ Marlboro Ave or Elliott Road ¡ Star Democrat on Airpark Drive ¡ Talbot County Library on West Dover Street ¡ Willow Construction on Commerce Drive.In addition to dropping off food, the community may also make a financial contribution to the Easton Rotary's Youth and Community Fund by visiting dropforscotty.com. Funds raised will be used to purchase additional food and critical supplies.All food and financial donations will stay local and will support vulnerable families in Talbot County.The Rotary Club of Easton Maryland is comprised of nearly 100 professional men and women committed to the Rotary Motto, "Service Above Self." They are part of a global network of more than 1.2 million Rotarians who are changing lives in their own communities and around the world.As the world's first Rotary Club in a town of fewer than 10,000 people, The Rotary Club of Easton celebrated its centennial in 2021. The Rotary Club of Easton meets on Thursdays at noon at Scossa Restaurant, with guests welcome. For more information, please visit eastonrotary.org.

title: Butters makes it back home - Missing cat returns to owners 12 years after being lost
author: Isabella Loy; Stanwood Camano News
content:
Butters makes it back home - Missing cat returns to owners 12 years after being lost

 October 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Isabella Loy; Stanwood Camano News | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 471
 Words 

 Read News Document

 All was calm and it seemed like an average day for Angelo and Shelley Castellino as they recently drove to their Stanwood, Washington, home on their 29th wedding anniversary.They had no idea that a phone call would soon give them the shock of their lives.Shelley Castellino received the mysterious call from an unknown number, and at first, she declined it."We figured was a scam call," Angelo Castellino said.Soon enough, the number called again. This time, they decided to answer."The gentleman said, 'I'm from animal control, and I have your cat, Butters,'" Angelo Castellino said."I go, 'Is this some sort of punk call?'" The Castellinos soon discovered it was not a scam - it was Riverside County Animal Control Officer Dalton Churchwell in California, who had found Butters in his yard late at night on Sunday, Oct. 3, and scanned him for a microchip.The couple had been living in San Diego and reported Butters missing 12 years ago in 2011. They had since moved to Stanwood in 2014 and lost hope of ever seeing the cat again.Luckily, the phone number attached to the microchip is the same one Shelley Castellino has today."I was astonished, it was kind of unbelievable," Angelo Castellino said."We figured that he was a meal for some coyotes." Angelo Castellino said he's unsure how Butters traveled so far, but that he was always trying to explore. The couple had adopted Butters and his brother, Barnacles, from a shelter in San Diego as kittens.After the news was shared, the Castellinos knew they wanted to bring Butters to their new home in Stanwood, but the expenses and logistics of flying a cat from California to Washington made for a tricky situation.The Animal Solutions Konnection Foundation, a California non-profit organization supporting the Department of Animal Services, soon heard the story.The organization decided to fund the cost of a flight to Seattle to see Butters safely return to his family."We were thrilled to work with the Department of Animal Services to make this reunion possible," said Carolyn Badger, president of the ASK Foundation, in a news release from Riverside County Animal Control."It was such a wonderful story, and we are very happy to know that Butters is home and safe with his family," she said.Butters' unlikely reunion finally happened Oct. 7, when Riverside County Department of Animal Services' longtime volunteer Larry Rudolph delivered Butters to the Castellanos in Seattle.Butters is now settled in his Stanwood home, and lives happily beside his brother, Barnacles, and the Castellinos' two dogs, Roscoe and Alita.Riverside Animal Services said Butters' defying of the odds was a testament to dedication and teamwork - but also a reminder to microchip pets to ensure reunification. 
 
 Caption: ISABELLA LOY/STANWOOD CAMANO NEWS
 
Butters relaxes after his 12-year adventure.
 
ISABELLALOY/STANWOOD CAMA NO NEWS
 
Butters sits in the lap of Angelo Castallino.

title: Despite split opinions, Easton Planning Commission approves Silo Square townhomes
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Despite split opinions, Easton Planning Commission approves Silo Square townhomes

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 656
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Amid resident pushback and design concerns, the Easton Planning Commission unanimously voted to approve a 28-unit townhouse development at the site of a former Perdue AgriBusiness operation in Easton.The Silo Square development is led by Chesapeake Community Development, a subsidiary of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region. It is a mixed-income housing project on a 2.36-acre lot at 410 Needwood Avenue, within the East End area that the town is aiming to revitalize.
An updated site plan was presented at Thursday's Planning Commission meeting, along with a traffic study that was requested when developers weren't granted approval last month. The project is set to include 16 three-story townhomes and 12 two-story townhomes.
The 10 grain bins currently on the lot, often referred to by community members as silos, would be demolished.
Residents that live near the site spoke during public comment on Thursday, largely in opposition to the design of the townhomes. Developers have stated the architecture is intended to "pay homage" to the Perdue site and fit in the surrounding industrial area.
"This is the core of Easton," resident Tom Ledvina said. "The code and the (comprehensive) plan say it has to look, it has to be compatible with that historic look that makes Easton special. And this just doesn't."
Zach Smith, an attorney representing the developers, asked that the commission look toward the town staff's review and analysis of the project, which noted it does fit within Easton's comprehensive plan.
"We don't have to get the consensus of the neighbors in order to move forward," Smith said. "What we have to do is to comply with the town's requirements."
Resident Maury Schlesinger spoke in disapproval of how the project faces inward toward the parking lot, with its back to the street. He said it will be "distinct" and "separate" compared to the nearby residential designs.
"Is this how we want our economically challenged people to live?" Schlesinger asked the commission. "Is this how we build an inclusive community? And is the desire to approve more housing right now so great that concern for (developers') budgets and timetable overcomes the need to protect the character of the town?
"I'm all for affordable housing, but it shouldn't look like this."
COMMISSION SPLITCommission members Victoria McAndrews and William Ryall, who were not present at the September meeting, expressed their own concerns about the project. McAndrews and fellow member Thomas Klein said they didn't like the design.
"This to me, has an incredibly suburban subdivision feel, as opposed to being an integrated part of the neighborhood," McAndrews said. "And I'm just wondering what is the rationale for not following the existing framework of how the neighborhood is laid out."
Commission Chairperson Philip Toussaint and Vice Chairperson Michael Ports complimented the design of the townhomes and pushed for approval.
Smith did the same, noting that developers fulfilled the requests made by the commission last month to include a traffic study — which revealed no significant impacts — and remove a section of fencing.
"We left this meeting last month with a clear direction that we needed to address the fence and we needed … a traffic study," Smith said. "We've done both of those things, and now we're at a point where we're facing having to come back yet again. This is how workforce housing projects die."
Ryall, who said he liked the design but was "torn" over whether it fit within the surrounding residential area, joined Toussaint and Ports in supporting approval.
"I don't want to let perfection get in the way of the good," Ryall said. "So I'm willing to vote in favor of it."
Ports moved for approval, seconded by Toussaint. All members voted yes, though McAndrews and Klein did so reluctantly, emphasizing their disagreement with the design.
Since the proposal came in the town's planned redevelopment overlay district, it will not require approval from the Easton Town Council. Thursday's vote was passed on the conditions that developers make minor adjustments to the site plan and approval is granted by town staff.

Mid-Shore preps for National Night Out Aug. 5

 EASTON — On Aug. 5, municipalities around the United States will be celebrating National Night Out.According to National Night Out's website, the event is part of an annual community building campaign that helps promote police-community partnerships and neighborhood camaraderie. National Night Out enhances the relationship between neighbors and law enforcement while bringing back a true sense of community.
On the Mid-Shore, multiple municipalities will be celebrating National Night Out with hopes to build better relationships with members of the community.
St. Michaels Police Department Chief Jeffery Oswald hopes National Night Out will help "build better relationships with members of the community."

All of our local partners will be in attendance as we recognize those in the community who have donated their time and care towards a safer St. Michaels."

title: After deadly work zone crashes, a push for change
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
After deadly work zone crashes, a push for change

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — After a pair of deadly work zone incidents cast attention on the dangers of road work, Maryland Gov. Wes Moore enacted a set of protections for workers and their families that his administration describes as "a moral imperative."Hours after the state's legislature adjourned, a bill increasing fines for work zone speed violations and another covering educational costs for families of fallen workers were among the first measures from the 2024 session that Moore signed into law.
At a bill signing ceremony, Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller, a former transportation engineer, invoked two fatal crashes that inspired the new legislation. In March 2023, six highway workers died when a car careened into a work zone on Interstate 695. Nearly a year later, six construction workers repairing potholes atop the Francis Scott Key Bridge were killed when a container ship struck the bridge, causing it to collapse.
"The men and women in the construction industry place themselves in harm's way every day on the frontline of service," Miller said. "We saw it happen on March 22, 2023. And we saw it happen again on March 26, 2024. It's a moral imperative that we protect workers who provide critical service, public service for all of us."
Among the measures to receive Moore's signature was the Maryland Road Worker Protection Act, which Miller championed throughout the legislative session and touted Tuesday, during an event overlooking the site of the I-695 crash to mark National Work Zone Awareness Week.
Effective June 1, the new law permits the installation of multiple speed cameras within a single work zone and raises the fine for speed camera violations to $80. The current penalty in Maryland is $40, among the lowest such fines in the country.
Beginning January 2025, fines shift to a tiered system ranging from $60 to $500 depending on the driver's speed. Fines will double if workers are present at the time of the violation.
The new law is part of a larger effort to change driver behavior in work zones by strengthening enforcement methods and increasing education. Distracted driving, aggressive driving and speeding are the leading causes of work zone crashes, according to the State Highway Administration.
"Most crashes are not accidents," State Highway Administrator William Pines told Capital News Service. "In reality, they're very preventable. The majority of crashes that occur happen because of behaviors with drivers. So if we want to stop the root cause of most crashes, we've got to deal with driver behavior."
But the law offers no safety solutions for incidents like the collapse of the Key Bridge, which was unrelated to driver behavior. Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld told Capital News Service on Tuesday that officials may consider structural solutions to bolster bridge safety but are awaiting the results of an investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board before making any specific policy proposals.
Instead, lawmakers responded to the bridge collapse by recognizing the toll that work zone crashes leave on workers' families.
In the final hours of the legislative session, the General Assembly passed the Protecting Opportunities and Regional Trade (PORT) Act, primarily aimed at providing emergency aid to workers and businesses affected by the closure of the Port of Baltimore.
Moore's administration offered a successful amendment to the bill creating the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program, providing tuition assistance for five years of full-time study or eight-years of part-time study to children and spouses of workers who have died on the job since 2022.
"What happened on the bridge is horrifically traumatic, and I think one of the things that we wanted to do is protect others who are in a similarly dangerous situation," said Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City), who co-sponsored the PORT Act.
"Certainly, we wish there were no one participating in that fund, but sadly, we know how dangerous this work is," he continued.

title: Suicide of a superpower
author: Staff Writer
content:
Suicide of a superpower

 June 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 209
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I'm not sure that it's clear to everyone that one of Trump's cost-cutting measures is doing serious damage to our military power."Suicide of a superpower" is underway, to quote Max Boot in a recent Washington Post column.
Trump's attack on universities and other government-funded research programs is surrendering America's most powerful weapon, our scientific ability. With the help of scientists from abroad (immigrants like Einstein who spent the rest of his career as a physics professor at Princeton), the University of Chicago, Columbia, and Berkeley were major players in developing the atomic bomb that made us a superpower in the first place.
Not only have our scientists given us satellite radio, smart phones and the internet, which we rely on in Talbot County, they have also given us missile shields, drones and other smart weapons. Future conflicts will be fought with high-tech systems — not yesterday's weapons — and we must keep up with their development.
I can understand a certain amount of animosity toward the stereotype professor or scientist, but I can't understand why one would want to harm our research programs and universities, which are the envy of the world. We need to urge Andy Harris and other Eastern Shore leaders to push back against Trump's terrible mistake.
RALPH MEYER
Easton

title: Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TAYLORS ISLAND - A Maryland State Police aviation crew helped rescue a 22-yearold man early Thursday morning after the boat he was operating ran aground, stranding him on a small island in Dorchester County.MSP's Trooper 7, which is based at St. Mary's Airport, was dispatched to the area of Taylors Island around 12:40 a.m. Thursday for a report of a missing boater.The request came from the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department after they had exhausted efforts searching for the subject by boat.Shortly after Trooper 7 arrived in the area, they located the victim in his boat that had run aground in a marshy area. Trooper 7 guided ground rescue crews to the victim location, but conditions proved to be inaccessible by foot or boat.MSP's Trooper 2, which is based at Joint Base Andrews, was dispatched at about 1:20 a.m. to assist with a hoist extraction and take over rescue operations.Once overhead, the pilots on Trooper 2 hovered the Leonardo AW-139 helicopter approximately 50 feet above the marshy terrain while a trooper/paramedic was lowered below to assess the victim.The victim was extracted utilizing the air-lift rescue vest. The trooper/paramedic and victim were hoisted back into the aircraft.Trooper 2 then landed at a landing zone established by the Dorchester County Fire and EMS Department, where the victim was transferred to ground paramedics for a secondary evaluation.The victim ultimately did not require treatment or transport.The Maryland State Police Aviation Command has served Maryland citizens since 1970 and operates a fleet of 10 AW-139 helicopters from seven bases throughout the State. Each aircraft provides coverage 24/7/365 to Maryland residents and visitors.The MSPAC missions include medevac, law enforcement, search and rescue, homeland security and disaster assessment.The success of the missions relies heavily on the cooperative efforts of local fire, rescue, EMS, law enforcement agencies and partners at the U.S. Coast Guard and the U.S. Park Police.

title: Local brewer collaborates with brewery to unveil beer for Waterfowl
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Local brewer collaborates with brewery to unveil beer for Waterfowl

 November 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Some people keep lists of potential baby names. Doug Greene keeps lists of potential beer names."I have a whole list on my phone of beer names," he said.
The Bird Nickel Brewing Company owner's passion for making beer started with a home brewing kit in 2009. Eight years later, Greene took a beer business course, and 10 years later, he incorporated Bird Nickel Brewing. In 2021, he graduated from American Brewers Guild, a brewing school in Vermont.
Although he's still looking for a brick-and-mortar brewery, Greene has done contract brewing, where he employs another brewery to brew beer for him. Through contract brewing, he has created brews with names like "Slick Calm Chesapeake Ale" and "Quite the Mixture."
Greene said the beer names often come from observation or overheard phrases. Slick calm, he said, is a term for when water is "smooth like glass."
Bird Nickel Brewing's latest creation — a limited edition collaboration with Salisbury-based Burnish Brewing Company and Waterfowl Festival Inc. — is "In Flight," a winter lager.
The beer will be released for the Waterfowl Festival so that attendees can sip on the limited edition brew while they throw back oysters and chow down on other Eastern Shore fare.
The lager has subtle notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and pear. Greene said different people might pick up on different notes.
"What we didn't want to do is overwhelm people with cinnamon," he said. "We want to make it enjoyable for everyone."
Waterfowl Festival Executive Director Deena Kilmon said the beer goes perfectly with hors d'oeuvres like oysters.
"Like when you're getting ready to eat dinner and you just really have something special to start," she said.
Greene, an Easton native, has "always wanted to do a beer for the Waterfowl Festival." The festival has been a part of his life for years, whether volunteering as a "duck sitter" in high school or walking the festival on the hunt for food trucks as an adult.
Greene's favorite memories of the event are walking down Harrison Street and seeing all the different vendors.
In the summer, Kilmon reached out to Greene about making a beer for the festival. This is the first year the festival is collaborating with brewers to make a special beer. The idea was one Greene had brought up to Kilmon years ago.
"When I became executive director in March, it was one of our first conversations about how we finally felt like it was the right year to launch it," Kilmon said.
Once Greene got Burnish Brewing on board, it was all systems go.
The label wrapped around the can is also a local effort. Maggii Sarfaty, an Easton artist, designed the label. On it, the festival's mission of conservation, education and research to protect local wildlife and habitats is written.
A portion of the proceeds from beer sales will go toward the Waterfowl Festival to fund education and conservation, Kilmon said.
Greene said having his beer at the festival is an important milestone.
"Especially for my business," he said. "And being able to create something for the festival instead of just being a resident or a ticket holder. I'm actually a part of it."
In Flight will be available at the festival's Premier Night on Nov. 7 in all the art pavilions. It will be free to VIP ticket holders while supplies last. Throughout the weekend, VIP ticket holders can request In Flight in the VIP hospitality suite. In Flight can be purchased at the new Duck Blind Bar located within the Avalon Theatre. Festival participants will also be able to sample the beer in the tasting pavilion located on Dover Street with the purchase of a tasting pavilion ticket. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Altair Apartments residents chained in Friday
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Altair Apartments residents chained in Friday

 May 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Friday, residents of the Altair Apartments were given a notice that strict parking and gate access measures would be in place beginning at 4 p.m.Altair management chained and bolted the fencing at the complex, preventing residents from entering or leaving and causing concern among residents and emergency officials.
"The concern was that there was not an emergency exit or an evacuation route for the residents," said Cambridge Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco, who represents the ward where Altair is located.
Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd said he had no prior knowledge that the complex would take these measures and gave management 30 minutes to remove the chains. Altair staff complied and removed the chains but kept the gates closed, according to Lewis-Sisco.
Altair Apartment staff did not respond to a request for comment.
According to the notice distributed to residents, the measures were put in place for an unauthorized "Freaknik" event scheduled to take place in the area.
Eight arrests were made at a Freaknik event held at the same location last year. Police said in a news release following the 2024 event that officers deployed pepper spray and departmental-issued tasers "to affect arrest and to keep hostile crowds back from officers."
Though this year's event was cancelled, police maintained a heavy presence in the area for the next few days. Todd said the increased presence was due to social media rumblings of a large crowd for the "Freaknik" event. He said the department wanted to ensure the safety of residents and visitors.
"You know, our main goal and our presence, which we always try to keep our presence in all of our higher crime areas or where we've experienced major crimes to keep our residents safe and that's our number one goal and our number one priority," Todd said.
However, Lewis-Sisco said many Ward 2 residents felt differently about the police presence. "The increased police presence and safety precautions that were put in place and implemented on Saturday definitely made residents feel inferior," she said.
Traffic diversions and police presence made navigating the area difficult, Lewis-Sisco said. Some residents informed Lewis-Sisco that they went the entire weekend without medication or aid because health care workers could not reach them due to the gates being closed.
"I think the other part was that residents were infuriated that these precautions were taken for an event when there has been unresponsiveness about complaints that regard their living conditions," she said.

title: CSD's Todd surpasses 1,000 career points
author: Bill Haufe
content:
CSD's Todd surpasses 1,000 career points

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 70
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Senior Le'Asia Todd scored 21 points to surpass the 1,000-career-point milestone Thursday night while leading Cambridge-South Dorchester High's girls basketball team to a 73-10 victory over Crisfield in the season-opener for both teams.Todd added 10 rebounds and three steals. The Vikings were also led by Destiny Johnson, who netted 19 points, seven rebounds and six assists, and Tejanae Ballin, who finished with 16 points and four steals.

title: Bridge - Try to reduce your assets
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Try to reduce your assets

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mark Twain, or Samuel Langhorne Clemens if you prefer, had the right idea when he wrote, "Tell the truth or trump - but get the trick." Sometimes, though, strange as it sounds, you might have too many trumps. If so, you must do something to reduce the number. Today's deal features one such play technique.Against four spades, West led the club ace. When East signaled with the 10, West continued with the club king and a third club. East exited with the spade three: two, eight, king. How should South have continued?South's three-spade rebid was invitational. North, with the two top trump honors, had an automatic raise to game.With all of the side suits safe, declarer's only concern was the trump suit. If that was breaking 3-2, he would have no trouble, but what if East had started with four spades including the jack?(If West had jack-fourth, the contract was beyond resuscitation.) The only chance would be a trump coup. To reduce his trump length to the same as East's, South made the farsighted play of immediately cashing dummy's heart ace and ruffing a heart in his hand.After declarer had played a trump to dummy's ace, getting the bad news, he ruffed another heart in his hand. Then South cashed his three diamond tricks, ending in the dummy. Luckily, East had to follow suit throughout.South was left with the Q-10 in spades, and East had the J-5. When South called for a heart, East's apparent trump trick disappeared in a textbook trump coup.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

States apart, Waterfowl artists build lasting friendships

 November 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 517
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jim Green and his wife, Kara, traveled from Hermosa, South Dakota, a small town with less than 400 people, to Easton this weekend. He's been bringing his wildlife sculptures to the Waterfowl Festival for around a decade.The South Dakota couple was stationed inside of the Waterfowl's main building for the Art at the Armory display. Directly across sat Carol Heiman-Greene and her husband, all the way from Orange, California.
The two artists and their respective spouses aren't just acquaintances. They're friends, or better yet, family.
"I come back year after year, and these are like my families," Heiman-Greene said of the fellow artists she's come to know. Kara Green used that exact same word — family — to describe her and her husband's friendship with the Heiman-Greenes and others.
Carol Heiman-Greene, who's been an exhibitor at the Easton festival for about 20 years, says there's a "core" of artists who have been at Waterfowl and other festivals for a long time. She said when new artists come, it's a joy to welcome them into the family, too.
On Saturday, Heiman-Greene pointed out her painting of a California condor vulture, laughing since Jim Green had a sculpture of a California condor for sale.
Through the ups and downs of travel, sales and weather, Heiman-Greene said artists have "all sorts of tales (they) can share" with one another.
"You come to these (festivals), and you see your friends from last year and years previous," Jim Green said. "It's so nice to connect with people."
Green says he loves those friendships with fellow artists not just for the relationships, but also to expand his work in an environment rich with creative ideas.
"You have a tendency to think of the world as built on artists when you come to these, because you see so many of them," he continued. "And then you get home and you're in this desert of nobody else around you that does this. So it's really nice to have that creativity, that creative aspect of things to bounce ideas off of other people."
For the Green couple, it's not a competitive environment. Last year, Jim Green said someone stopped by to let him know they recreated his raven coat rack sculpture.
"I know there are other artists that would kind of take that the wrong way," he said. "But I was like, 'Yeah, where are the pictures? I love that.'"
Both Carol Heiman-Greene and Jim Green said the people, atmosphere and weather at Waterfowl combine to make the festival one of their favorites. While Green said his sales are typically solid at Waterfowl, even if they weren't, the three-day event is still his "favorite one of the year."
"I love coming here to see the atmosphere and everything there is about Maryland," Heiman-Greene said. "It's really fun. It has such a small-town atmosphere."
Despite living states and plane rides apart, the annual Waterfowl Festival tradition has helped bring the Greens and Heiman-Greenes together as artists and friends. It's a trend Jim Green hopes continues for years to come.
"Art sells art," Jim Green said. "If you can't have all boats rise, you shouldn't be in the boat."

title: Drivers need patience on roadways
author: Staff Writer
content:
Drivers need patience on roadways

 September 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 428
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a senior driver of 70 years driving experience I have finally reached my frustration point in what I (correctly or incorrectly) perceive as unwarranted impatience, if not absolute rudeness and discourtesy, on the part of drivers in Talbot County.I am a competent, not perfect, operator of a motor vehicle, and I do not understand the needs of many other drivers, younger ones in particular, to honk their horns, pass on the right side, ride your bumper or even pass on a double line when I take a needed extra second or two to double check when I am making a turn, entering an intersection, leaving a stop light, or driving at what I consider a safe 40 mph on the narrow, winding and crowned blacktop roads here, many of which have no shoulders only ditches.
You drivers who are speeding and tailgating in our county — and you, in my experience are many —will get where you are going without putting me or yourselves in danger. An absolutely unneeded honking horn is startling and rather than achieving its likely objective of hurrying me along and making me drive in the manner in which you think I should be driving actually slows me down when I look once more to reassess the situation around me before I move away from that light or stop sign or turn against traffic.
You will be senior drivers someday yourself, and you will understand certain facts — namely your reaction time slows a touch, your hearing and vision, though adequate for the task, are not what they used to be and your trust in your own cognition in discerning what is happening around you is quite naturally slightly diminished.
Talbot County and the town of Easton today present challenging driving conditions. The sheer volume of traffic, the narrow streets in town with double parking, and the plethora of large sized pickups and SUVs plying streets and roadways here that were not designed for these types of vehicles are factors, as well as the presence of some dangerous intersections lacking traffic controls — one of these is one I use daily, the intersection of the Parkway and Tristan Drive. I do not need an accident at my age, whether my fault or not. This is a major reason I (and many others of my age) need that extra moment of time to cope safely and competently with the driving situations already mentioned. And I can cope if I get just a minimum amount of cooperation from all of you others on the road.
JOEL S. STROBECK
Easton

title: celebrity update - Wayne Brady OF LET'S MAKE A DEAL ON CBS
author: Jay Bobbin
content:
celebrity update - Wayne Brady OF LET'S MAKE A DEAL ON CBS

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Q: How long has Wayne Brady been hosting "Let's Make a Deal"?A: Ever since CBS' current daytime version began in 2009. Its premiere there made it a rare series to run on three different broadcast networks, since the original show - hosted by Monty Hall, also (along with business partner Stefan Hatos) a creator and producer of it - ran on NBC from 1963 to 1966, then moved to ABC, where it continued until 1976.There also were other editions before the Brady-hosted revival premiered, with NBC attempting it again twice, in daytime with Bob Hilton and (very briefly) in prime time with Bush.Brady has earned two of his five Emmy Awards for his work on "Let's Make a Deal," and by the time he started that job, the idea of comedians becoming gameshow hosts had been accepted. Among examples, Drew Carey assumed the hosting spot on "The Price Is Right" in 2007, and Louie Anderson had guided "Family Feud" from 1999 to 2002 (Steve Harvey started in the latter show in 2010).In interviews, Brady has maintained that he never wanted to be just one thing in the entertainment world not exclusively an actor nor a comic (a skill he has displayed plentifully on the improvisation-oriented "Whose Line Is It Anyway?") nor a singer (he was nominated for a 2009 Grammy Award for his cover of Sam Cooke's "A Change Is Gonna Come"). He also has appeared on Broadway in "Chicago," "Freestyle Love Supreme" and "Kinky Boots." Along with "The Price Is Right," extra episodes of "Let's Make a Deal" have been made expressly for CBS' prime time lineup. That will continue for both shows during the upcoming television season, when they are slated to be seen on Friday nights starting in November.

title: New art exhibit critiques America's 'consumption culture'
content:
New art exhibit critiques America's 'consumption culture'

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new atrium exhibit at the Academy Art Museum debuts Friday, Sept. 15, and runs through August 2024.The exhibition is from South Dakota-based Oglaia Lakota artist Marty Two Bulls Jr.The exhibition "Marty Two Bulls Jr.: Dominion" examines America's "consumption culture, using the metaphor of the American Bison," according to a release from the Easton art museum."We are looking forward to welcoming visitors to Two Bulls, Jr.'s Atrium commission, which serves as a layered acknowledgment of the oppression Native American people have endured in their homelands as well as a critique of consumer culture. The breadth of Two Bulls, Jr.'s practice is incredible: from the immersive, floor-to-ceiling hand-cut prints he amasses on top of one another for his wall-mounted work, to monumental sculptures made from found objects such as bottles and trash cans, Two Bulls, Jr. conjures a mimesis of a crucial sociopolitical reality. We are excited for the interactive dimension of the exhibition, which will allow visitors to scan QR codes to learn the histories of some of the elements Two Bulls, Jr. incorporates into his work, such as barbed wire and the American bison," said AAM Curator Mehves Lelic.AAM's 2022-2023 Atrium Commission is supported by Carol Gordean, Joe Minarick in memory of Carol Minarick, and Mary Ann Schindler.For more: https://academyartmuseum.org/

title: Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair
author: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig
content:
Best in show: 4-H kids work hard to raise, ready animals for fair

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard Special to the Whig | Section: News 
 
 747
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FAIR HILL — In the months leading up to the Cecil County Fair, 4-H members can be found working hard, raising and training their animals to get them ready for the fair.At the fair, the animals are one of the main attractions, housed in the fairgrounds' barns in between the various competitions and showings that take place throughout fair week.
Tails and Trails 4-H club worked together this year to try something new: raising and showing 100 meat chickens.
"They eat and drink a whole lot more than you would ever imagine at this point. We bought a bag of feed yesterday and we are almost out of it," 4-H member Katilyn Carter said.
Carter, 16, is showing meat goats, meat chickens, and doing herdsmen with her pony. Herdsmen entails keeping your animal at the fair all week, ensuring they are fed, watered, healthy and clean, with a corresponding informational board to educate the public and judges about your animal.
To prepare her meat chickens, Carter washes them two to three days before the show to ensure they have a natural oily shine. This paid off, as her chickens won first and second place ribbons at the fair over the weekend.
"It's going to sound really funny, but you actually blow dry them. You want them to be really fluffy…You just want them to look like little chunk balls of fluff and meat," said Carter about preparing her chickens for show day.
In showmanship competitions, you must be very knowledgeable about your animal in order to show the judges that you put in the work to be successful, according to Carter. The 4-H member must present their animal to the best of their ability, demonstrating cleanliness and knowledge on what they eat, their parts, their breed and more, said former 4-H member and long-time judge Carolyn Lawrence.
For meat goats, who are bred and raised to become a meal on someone's plate, the 4-H members start working with them once they are born in January or March. A few weeks later, once they're weaned from their mothers they start training them to walk with a halter and lead line, taking them on mile long walks several times a week, according to Libby Kondracki, Tails and Trails leader.
When it comes to show day at the fair, Carter washes her goat in the morning and covers him to ensure he stays clean white. Since they're raised for meat, she then blow dries the animals to get them looking as fluffy as possible. According to county fair regulations, no baby powder, artificial coloring, or adhesives like hairspray can be used on the animals.
"The power in fitting your animal, and knowing how to fit your animal and showing your animal to make it to where you know you're showing this animal the best you can to its fullest potential. You really have to work with your goat," Carter said.
Before the fair, members get together at least twice a week and meet up as a show team and prepare together. Many of the 4-H parent leaders were 4-H members themselves when they were growing up. And many current members plan to stay involved after they age out at 18 years old to continue to give back to the community that helped shape them.
"I really love teaching them," said Carter about helping teach younger 4-H'ers. "Because they're going to be, you know, when I'm done in two more years, they're going to be the ones that are taking over. So you really want them to be the mentor you kids that you were to them."
Although many 4-H members compete against each other at the Cecil County Fair, they are all a team at the end of the day.
"When one wins, we all win," said Carter.
In addition to the camaraderie 4-H supplies, it also helps educate the public about the livestock they often consume.
Thanks to being involved in the Rising Sun 4-H Club for the past four years, Mason Gentry enjoys educating the public about his animals and their purposes. For example, he explained the importance of knowing that a Heifer is a female cow who has not been bred yet, a cow is a female cow who has been bred and had a calf, and a Steer is a male cow that's been castrated and is meant for beef.
"The goal of the fair is to educate the public about agriculture, give them an opportunity to see where the food comes from," said Mark Barczewki, 4-H Barn Stompers club leader.

title: EPA faults state on offshore wind permit process
author: Lily Tierney
content:
EPA faults state on offshore wind permit process

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has identified that the Maryland Department of the Environment was mishandling a key offshore wind permit by misinforming the public about how to appeal it, prompting both technical corrections and political firestorms.The dispute centers on a permit for US Wind's proposed wind farm off the coast of Ocean City and could temporarily delay or complicate the project's future. According to the EPA findings, MDE improperly issued a federal air permit under the Outer Continental Shelf Air Regulations and MDE has been ordered to reissue the permit with corrected appeal instructions or face legal backlash.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) said that the EPA's ruling was a "major victory for the Eastern Shore, the environment and our local economies that are existentially threatened by this project."
Harris cited environmental risks of offshore wind projects as disturbance of the sea bottom and ocean ecology, toxic hydraulic and lubricating fluids that could leak and the risk of turbine damage.
Harris said a similar project in New Jersey led by Atlantic Shores led to the developer abandoning the project after the appeals. These appeals came after President Donald Trump signed an executive order after taking office in January that froze new federal wind leases and permits while reviewing existing projects.
According to Harris, constituents are concerned over the impacts on Ocean City and commercial fishermen saying U.S. Wind has not honored its promise to keep turbines at least 17 miles offshore and allegedly now plans to build turbines as close as 10 miles.
"Writ large, the problem with Maryland is that we have not had a good energy policy for years exemplified by the fact that we have to import 40% of our power from surrounding states, including West Virginia and Pennsylvania, which generate their electricity from fossil fuels," Harris said. "So it's unclear to me why we would attempt to brag about, you know, going to 100% renewable energy when we know that's probably not possible."
Maryland agencies like MDE may not be fully equipped to handle federal delegations for such projects and ultimate authority is retained by federal agencies. Because of this, companies like Atlantic Shores in New Jersey canceled its project and plans to come back when the political climate is more favorable, according to a PBS news report.
"We received the letter and are reviewing it now. MDE is committed to ensuring all our permit processes are transparent and in accordance with the law," Jay Apperson, deputy director of communications for MDE said in a statement to the Star Democrat.
Harris said he is categorically opposed to offshore wind energy but is not opposed to alternative sources of clean energy like geothermal and small modular nuclear reactors, which he said are much safer alternatives.
"Such as the Vienna Power plant that is scheduled to close in five years, and obviously has permitting to generate power there. Locations like that might be ideal for small modular reactors," Harris said.
While the EPA identified procedural issues with how MDE directed the public to appeal the permit, Harris characterized the letter as validation of broader concerns about the project's approval and local opposition. US Wind did not respond for a comment.

title: Crusaders extend mastery over Sabres
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Crusaders extend mastery over Sabres

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 702
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Sam Gerdano really doesn't have an answer."I've never been able to beat St. Paul's," Saints Peter and Paul High's head ice hockey coach said. "I don't know what it is. I'm just haunted by that team."
Mason Kaplan netted a hat trick and helped set up both of Casey Burkom's goals Friday, as the Crusaders defeated the Sabres, 5-2, at the Talbot Community Center to clinch the second seed in next week's Maryland Interscholastic Athletic Association B Conference playoffs.
St. Paul's (6-2-1) is scheduled to host third-seeded Sts. Peter & Paul (5-3-2) on Monday at 4 p.m. in an MIAA B semifinal at the Patterson Park Ice Rink in Baltimore.
"This has been a really fun season," Gerdano said. "We have a really young team. We have 11 freshmen out of 22 rostered. So it's not surprising that maybe they're lacking confidence at times."
The Crusaders controlled the neutral zone through the first period, and put half a dozen shots on goalie Maddie Maloney in the opening 3 minutes.
"It's exactly what we were asking for; a fast start," St. Paul's head coach Sean Baker said. "We wanted to get pucks behind their D, play down in their end at the beginning of the game to set the tone early."
Despite that dominance, Maloney (25 saves) didn't let anything past her until 3 minutes, 24 seconds remained in opening period, when Andrew Breslin and Burkom set up Kaplan's first goal.
St. Paul's extended that lead to 2-0 just 38 seconds into the second period, when Kaplan fed Burkom, who slipped the puck inside the left post.
"Goals in the first minute of the period and the last minute of the period are always big," Baker said. "You want to keep momentum for the beginning of the period and the end of the period. It's something that we talk about; first and last minute. We want to be the ones that score. We don't want to give anything up."
The Sabres cut their deficit to 2-1 with 3:44 left, as Drew Watson scored off a dish from Mason Roland. Sts. Peter & Paul went on the power play a little over a minute later, but put little pressure on St. Paul's goalie Andrew Dugas (13 saves). The Crusaders killed off the 2-minute minor. then immediately restored their two-goal cushion, as Kaplan — the MIAA B's goal-scoring leader with 21 — scored off Burkom's assist with 30.2 seconds left in the period.
"Obviously that's a big momentum shift, Gerdano said. "You cut the lead in half and they get one right back. That's a little bit of a gut punch. But it's a long game and we're always telling our players you just got to keep fighting to the end."
St. Paul's widened its lead to 4-1 with 1:53 elapsed in the third, as Kaplan and Nigel Wilson-Phillippi set up Burkom's second goal. That lead ballooned to 5-1 with 8:32 remaining, when Brendan Townsend and Burkom connected passes to set up Kaplan in the slot for his third goal.
"We seem to be peaking at the right time," said Baker, whose team has won three straight. "We're looking pretty good right now."
After a brief skirmish with a little under 7 minutes remaining left the Crusaders down a man, Sts. Peter & Paul's Buel Jenson scored unassisted with 6:45 to play. But the Sabres couldn't cut any further into their deficit.
"We absolutely came out flat," Gerdano said. "We were throwing the puck away like crazy. I think we were a little afraid to have the puck on our stick, not quite confident enough with the puck. A little uncharacteristic and it's something we can improve on going into next week. If we find that confidence and find good energy we can absolutely take it to that team.
"When they have that confidence you can tell, and we're really hard to play against," added Gerdano, whose team tied St. Paul's 2-2 earlier this season. "We have great goaltending. We're hard to score on and we got great defense. We just need to find ways to score. And if we do that we're going to be really hard to beat against anybody. We have the recipe."
Note: The Sabres have tied St. Paul's three times under Gerdano's direction. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cooking fresh fish on Delmarva
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Cooking fresh fish on Delmarva

 April 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1090
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A sure sign of Spring on Delmarva is the local catch-of-the-day fish in the seafood stores, fish markets and at the boat docks.This past week and in the upcoming weeks local organizations are having fish fries. Check out the local newspapers and posts at the different stores in town to find the date and location information.
Not only will you be enjoying fresh fish, but you will be enjoying some delicious home cooking prepared by some wonderful Eastern Shore cooks. Most of these suppers have cornbread, turnip greens, stewed tomatoes and fried potatoes as sides — mouth-watering country cooking.
Crab season opened April 1 — one of my favorite forms of seafood. In the summer I will share some recipes and some crabbing stories with you.
Most of all, hats off to the local watermen for their hard work. Let's cook Fish.
GOLDEN FRIED FISH
Combine 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 tablespoon cooking oil and 2/3 cup cold water. Blend well. Beat 1 egg white until soft peaks form, and fold in the flour mixture. Dip 1 pound to 1 1/2 pounds of fish fillets, cut into serving sizes, into this mixture on both sides. Place fillets into a fry pan with 1/2 inch oil and fry until golden brown on both sides. Drain on paper towels and serve warm with some vegetables and red skin potatoes.
OVEN BAKED FISH
Cut 2 pounds of fish, cleaned and filleted, into serving size portions. Add 1 tablespoon salt to 1 cup milk. Dip fillets in milk and roll into 1 cup dried bread crumbs. Place in a well greased baking pan. Sprinkle each piece of fish with minced or chopped butter pieces. Bake in a 500-degree oven for 10 to 12 minutes or until fish flakes easily when touched with a fork. Serve with fresh vegetables and macaroni and cheese.
FRIED CATFISH
Combine 2/3 cup cornmeal, 1/4 cup flour, 2 teaspoons salt and 1/2 teaspoon paprika. Dry 4 cleaned catfish fillets and coat them on each side with the cornmeal mixture. Fry in 1/2 cup oil until golden brown on both sides. Drain on paper towels.
SALMON CAKES
Combine 1 pound fresh salmon meat with 2 beaten eggs, 4 tablespoons bread crumbs and 3 to 4 tablespoons milk — add one tablespoon of milk at a time to determine consistency. Mix and form into cakes. Fry in hot oil until golden brown on both sides.
BAKED FISH WITH TOMATOES
Cut about 1 1/2 pounds fresh fish fillets into serving sizes and single layer fish in a well greased two quart casserole dish. Spread 2 teaspoons of mustard over the fish. Sprinkle 3/4 teaspoon salt, 1/4 teaspoon Old Bay seasoning and 1/4 teaspoon black pepper on top of mustard. Peel and slice two fresh tomatoes over top of mustard mixture. Mix together one cup grated Parmesan cheese with 1/4 cup butter or margarine and spread over the fish mixture. Cover and bake in a preheated 325-degree oven for 30 minutes.
GRILLED MARYLAND BLUE FISH
2 pounds Maryland bluefish fillets, 2 cups Italian salad dressing, 2 lemons (cut in wedges). Place bluefish fillets in a baking dish. Pour dressing over fillets, cover and refrigerate for 2 hours. Place fillets on a hot, oiled grill. Baste fillets frequently with dressing and cook for about 10 minutes. Turn and baste again. Fillets are done when they just begin to flake when tested with a fork. Serve with lemon wedges. For convenient cooking on charcoal grill, cover grill with foil and poke holes in foil to circulate heat.
MARYLAND BAKED PERCH
3 pounds perch (dressed), 1 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1/4 teaspoon pepper, 3 medium sliced mushrooms, 1/2 cup sliced onion, 1/4 cup chopped green pepper, 1 cup orange juice, 3 tablespoons and 1 teaspoon grated lemon rind, 1 tablespoon flour. Preheat the oven to 450. Season fish with salt and pepper. Place fish in a baking dish. In a bowl, combine mushrooms, onions and green pepper. Spread vegetable mixture over fish. Combine remaining ingredients in a saucepan. Cook over moderate heat, stirring frequently until mixture thickens. Pour sauce over fish and vegetables. Bake for 6 to 8 minutes or until the fish flakes easily with a fork.
GARLIC ROASTED SEA BASS
4 whole heads fresh garlic (trimmed), 4 large garlic cloves (peeled and crushed), olive oil, sea salt, 4 to 5 pounds whole sea bass (rinsed and well dried), black pepper, 1 lemon with 1/2 half cut in thin slices and other half juiced. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Slice top 1/4 inch from each whole head of garlic. Remove some of the papery skin from the outside, but do not separate the cloves. Place the garlic heads in the roasting pan. Pour olive oil over each head. Sprinkle it with salt. Set aside. Season the fish with olive oil, crushed garlic, lemon juice, salt and pepper. Place lemon slices and crushed garlic cloves inside the fish. Roast fish and whole garlic heads in a roasting pan, with rack, uncovered, 30 to 40 minutes, basting often.
SIMPLE FRIED BLUEFISH
4 bluefish fillets, 1 bowl of milk, 2 eggs (beaten), 2 cups flour, 1/2 inch olive oil in a large skillet, 3 tablespoons parsley (chopped), 1 teaspoon paprika, 1 teaspoon lemon pepper, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 lemon (cut into wedges). Place all of the fillets in a bowl of milk and let soak for several minutes. Dip fillet in a bowl of well beaten eggs. Season flour with parsley, paprika, lemon pepper and salt. Roll each fillet in flour. Heat oil to medium-high.Place fillets in hot oil. Fry to a golden brown, turning once. Remove fillet from pan and layer over paper towels. Serve hot or cold with wedges of lemon.
GRILLED MARLIN STEAKS
2 large marlin steaks (about 3/4-inch thick), 1/3 cup pineapple juice, 2 tablespoons grapeseed oil, 2 tablespoons sesame oil, 1/2 tablespoon low-sodium soy sauce, 1 large clove garlic (minced), 1/2 teaspoon fresh ginger (minced), freshly ground black pepper (to taste). In a small bowl, combine pineapple juice, grapeseed oil, sesame oil, soy sauce, garlic, ginger and black pepper. Whisk all the ingredients until well blended. Put marlin steaks in a large resealable bag and pour the marinade over. Close the bag and massage/flip it until the steaks are well coated. Transfer to the refrigerator for 1 to 1 ½ hours, turning and massaging steaks once or twice. Preheat barbecue to 500-550 degrees. Place the marlin steaks on a plate and discard the marinade.Transfer the steaks on the hot grill, close the lid and grill for 3 minutes on one side. Flip them and cook for another 2 minutes with the lid closed.

title: An age in America comes to an end
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
An age in America comes to an end

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Columns 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The small town of Oroville, California, drifted into the 20th century as a shadow of its former self.Back in 1848, when gold was discovered in the area, prospectors had poured into the place. But by 1900 the vein had long since petered out, and the town had become little more than an agricultural backwater.
Meanwhile, the modern world marched on. In Los Angeles, California's first movie theater opened for business in 1902. The next year, the Wright brothers made the first heavier-than air flight at Kitty Hawk. And in 1908, Henry Ford brought the automobile within reach of everyday Americans when he introduced the reliable, relatively inexpensive Model T.
Still, news of these wonders would have arrived in Oroville as little more than rumors of a wider, more sophisticated world.
Then, on Aug. 29, 1911, a teenaged layabout named Floyd Hefner strode into the corral of the local slaughterhouse, intending to hitch up a team of horses, and found a nearly naked man leaning unsteadily against a fence-post. The last living member of a Native American tribe had come in from the cold.
Perhaps not surprisingly for the time and place, guns were drawn, dogs were held at bay, and someone used the telephone in the slaughterhouse to call the law. By the time the sheriff arrived, a butcher's cloak had been thrown over the shoulders of the man, who spoke no language anyone understood. The sheriff handcuffed the man, drove him into town in a wagon (the first time in his life he'd ever ridden in a wheeled vehicle), and locked him up in the county jail.
It wasn't long before newspapers throughout the state were reporting the discovery of America's "last wild Indian." Learning of the news, Alfred Kroeber, a renowned professor of anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley, sent a colleague, Thomas Waterman, up to Oroville.
Meeting with the prisoner in his cell, Waterman thought he might be speaking a language related to the Yana tongue. Waterman knew a little Yana, and when he tried it out on the prisoner, the man's face lit up.
For the first time since the only other members of his Yahi band had died, he had heard another human being speak a word or two he understood.
Waterman was able to ask the man his name. Using a combination of gestures and simple Yahi, the man explained that in his culture it was taboo to speak his name aloud to someone else until another member of his tribe had formally introduced him. As this was now impossible, Waterman ended up simply calling him "Man" in the Yahi tongue.
And so it is that this Native American man comes down to us in history under the false name of "Ishi." We will never know what his real name was.
Waterman's fellow professor at Berkeley, Alfred Kroeber, was a remarkable man. He had earned his doctorate in 1901 from Columbia University, studying under Franz Boaz, the father of modern anthropology. Kroeber took Ishi in and gave him a place to live in the university's museum, where Ishi worked as a janitor. This allowed Kroeber and the other anthropologists in his department to study Ishi closely over the remaining five years of his life.
You might expect that much of what Kroeber and Waterman learned from Ishi would have been horrifying. This was a man who, from boyhood, watched his tribe and immediate family whittled down by ceaseless slaughter. Norman Kingsley, an eager participant in one of the last massacres, later recounted that, in the middle of his attack, he exchanged his .56 caliber Spencer rifle for a .38 caliber pistol, because the rifle "tore them up so bad," especially the babies.
But after his introduction into modernizing California, accounts say Ishi didn't speak of the horrors he'd witnessed, nor did he give in to melancholy or despair. He adapted with grace to his new life and embraced many of the changes happening in the world around him.
I learned of Ishi from Alfred Kroeber's wife and fellow anthropologist Theodora Kracaw Kroeber, who, in 1961, wrote "Ishi in Two Worlds," now considered a classic of modern anthropology. I first read the book 40 years ago, and rereading it recently, I found myself placing Theodora Kroeber in the same league as Claude Lévi-Strauss. Without ever leaving any of her anthropological principles behind, she consistently writes clear, compelling prose.
It isn't easy reading the first part of Kroeber's book, watching as Ishi and the remaining members of his band are forced to withdraw further and further from the whites encroaching upon their world; until, finally, they retreat into that world's last untouched cañon, and, ultimately, its last bushy slopes.
But Kroeber's description of the way Ishi handles the world he is then brought into, the way he maintains his Yahi dignity in the face of that world's awesome power (while never losing his ability to see through its sometimes absurd idiosyncrasies) is somehow reassuring. It gave me hope for humanity at large.
I reread "Ishi in Two Worlds" thanks to an Inter-Library Loan, but a copy of the book has now been placed in our collection at the Talbot County Free Library. You'll find it in the Easton library on the Biography shelves under the call letters ISHI. If you're in St. Michaels, you can place a reserve on the book and it will be sent down there for you.
