title: Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 981
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Pew Research Center survey reports that 95% of teenagers in America have a smart phone or have access to one. It also reports that 45% of teenagers say they are online nearly all the time.Many have suggested this has resulted in a measurable and serious negative impact on the learning environment in middle and high school classrooms. Others have suggested this has resulted in a serious negative impact on standardized student achievement test scores.
As a result, countless school districts in America have put or will be putting new or more restrictions on student smart phones during the school day. Two-thirds of schools in Maryland have already. Talbot County is joining them. Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will will require students to lock their phones in secure pouches during the school day.
These restrictions have significant public support. Surveys conducted by the Talbot County school district reported 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
While I understand and respect these opinions, I suggest restrictions in schools are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts among American youth.
I understand and respect these decisions. At the same time, I suggest they are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression, and suicidality among American youth.
In his book Haidt references research showing a measure of anxiety for individuals between ages of 8 to 25 has increased 139% between 2010 and 2020.The measure for depression during the same period, often the result of an inability to resolve interpersonal conflicts or relationship difficulties, has increased 106%.
Haidt suggests three reasons why.
The first is the decline of the what Haidt calls play-based childhood. He maintains children need lots of free play time to prepare them for success as an adult. Out of fears for their safety, many American parents and guardians have reduced children's access to unsupervised free play. The loss of free play and the rise of continual (some may say "smothering") adult supervision has deprived children of what they needed most to overcome the normal fears and anxieties of childhood: the chance to explore, test and expand their limits, build close friendships through shared adventure and learn how to judge risks for themselves.
The second is what Haidt calls rise of the phone-based childhood, which began in the late 2000s and accelerated in the early 2010s. Haidt notes this was precisely the period during which adolescents traded in their flip phones for smartphones. These smartphones were loaded with social media platforms supported by the new high-speed internet and unlimited data plans that has drastically reshaped the social media landscape for adolescents.
The third is what Heidt calls an over reliance on technology that has all but eliminated unstructured face to face interactions from the lives of children and adolescents.
Heidt concludes the negative impact of all three reasons was made worse by many well-intentioned parents, including himself. He writes: "We did not fully understand what was happening in children's virtual worlds and did not grasp that tech companies had designed their online products to be addictive."
As a result, Haidt asserts that all these trends combined, have robbed entire generations of opportunities to develop the resilience, coping skills and independence needed to navigate everyday stressors, and in turn, created unprecedented levels of anxiety at a societal level.
He says these generations have not learned from valuable opportunities to engage in and learn from manageable risks, typical setbacks, failures and healthy social challenges.
What can be done going forward?
Haidt offers the following proactive suggestions for parents and guardians of children in elementary, middle and high schools.
Instead of a giving younger students a smartphone as their first phone, give them a basic phone.
Do not give them a smartphone until high school. Delay the opening of accounts on nearly all social media platforms until the beginning of high school, at least.
Will his suggestions be popular with students? Not likely, especially given the immense power of peer pressure that characterizes life for students in schools at all levels.
One school in Maryland recently surveyed seniors on a new more restrictive smart phone policy to limit the overuse of smart phones during the school day. The questions and answers were: "Do you know overuse of cell phones is harmful? Yes. Do you want to give it up? No."
Are Haidt's suggestions still necessary since efforts are underway when an increasing number of schools are adopting on new or more restrictive rules on smart phone access? Yes.
Despite best intentions and best efforts, schools alone cannot address this problem. One Maryland school district superintendent has observed with thinly disguised frustration — "Students are in school for just 20% of their week. We can't control the other 80% of the time that we don't have them."
Those with some control over most of the other 80% of student's time outside of school are parents and guardians.
Going forward, parents and guardians need to fully embrace two concepts. Success for them is not based on winning a popularity contest with those whom they are entrusted with their care and upbringing. Success for them is measured in part by a willingness to make sometimes unpopular, but necessary decisions on reasonable limits for a young person's own good.
In preparing all our young people for success, they, and our society deserve nothing less.

title: Annual Back to School Resource Fair: Preparing students for success
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Annual Back to School Resource Fair: Preparing students for success

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 494
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, over a thousand people gathered at Idlewild Park for the annual Back to School Resource Fair hosted by For All Seasons.For All Seasons partnered with the Talbot County Department of Social Services to provide families with hundreds of backpacks pre-stuffed with supplies for students. This event not only contributes to the care of students of all ages, but it creates community for residents throughout Easton.
Beth Anne Dorman, president and chief executive officer at For All Seasons, said the resource fair has become one of the largest community events in Easton, bringing together over 25 different organizations and over 1,700 people.
"We are really taking care of all of the kids in the ways that set them up for success," Dorman said. "For school, mental health isn't just about our mental health and talk therapy, but it's also about making sure that children have what they need to be able to show up at the school year authentically and with some safety."
In addition to the school supplies provided by For All Seasons, dozens of organizations set up tables and provided rulers, pens, dental care kits, notebooks and over a hundred children's books.
Marilou Russ, assistant director for Appleseed Books, said the organization provides free children's books to families across the Eastern Shore by collecting donated books.
"We come to programs and events throughout the counties on the mid shore, which would include Caroline, Talbot and now even Dorchester County, and then we give the children out the free books so that they have books," Russ said. "Our belief is that they have their own collection of books that they can call their own."
Included in the event, families had the opportunity to enjoy games, free Rita's Italian Ice, and arts and craft activities.
Mayra Casillas, an event attendee, said she just moved to the area and learned of the fair on Facebook. For Casillas, it seemed a great opportunity to engage with her new community and for her children to have fun.
"It's also great to have backpacks and a bunch of other school supplies," Casillas said. "It helps families that don't have the income to buy for their kids."
Dorman said the event has grown significantly since its origin six years ago. It has reached the point where For All Seasons will be expanding the venue for next year since it has become too crowded for Idlewild Park. Dorman said she is proud of this event and the amount of people it assists.
"There are times where we have an opportunity to dig in a little bit deeper as a community," Dorman said. "This is an example of when we think outside of the box, and we really think about the whole person when we're thinking about mental health. It gives us an opportunity to make a difference in a way that maybe is not going to happen in the four walls of an office, but this is real community outreach and community connection and partnership."

title: Abstract Truths studio art gallery opens in Stevensville
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Abstract Truths studio art gallery opens in Stevensville

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Showcasing a world of inspiration around us, Stevensville's newest gallery and art studio Abstract Truth held an official gallery opening Nov. 29.A retired architect, gallery artist Ray Moldenhauer, of Grasonville, focuses his attention on creating abstract paintings and sculptures with dimension, noting "art is a natural extension of architecture."
Outgrowing his previous space at My Little Studio, Moldenhauer remarked the new location is proving to be a blessing.
Leaning into layers in his art as well as in his gallery, Moldenhauer designed the space to take full advantage of the existing glass enclosed cubicles and provide natural light.
By staggering the paintings from one cubicle to another, the gallery visually takes on a special 3D experience from one space to another. Many of the paintings are mounted back to back on the glass to create an allusion of them floating in the space, according to Moldenhauer.
"At night, the extensive front glass wall of the building just glows and reflects the beautiful artwork within," he said.
"I love the idea of flowing paintings," he said.
Moldenhauer utilizes many different creative techniques for his work. From traditional brushes and sponges, to business cards to even finger painting, Moldenhauer isn't afraid to try something new with his inspiration. Moldenhauer also incorporates resin, cellophane, and even foam to create something completely new.
For Moldenhauer it is the inspiration behind each artwork that brings forth its beauty and meaning and makes it "more than just another landscape or sunset."
Moldenhauer's work typically starts with a Bible verse and lets his inspiration guide his hand, for instance, Moldenhauer sculptures based on the Pillars of Creation present an abstract look of the universe.
As an accomplished SCUBA diver, Moldenhauer also finds inspiration in the natural world of water, sunsets and sunrises.
Moldenhauer also takes inspiration from the surrounding Eastern Shore, has also incorporated his love of the Eastern Shore into his work.
His very first sculpture "Be Still" repurposed an old sailboat skeg and was selected for the Maryland Federation of Art's Off The Walls 2024 exhibition.
According to Moldenhauer Abstract Truths are works that, "in some way, reveal God," and each art piece has a corresponding Bible verse accompaniment for patrons to take to heart.
For artists just starting out, Moldenhauer encouraged finding inspiration around you in what you enjoy doing and where you enjoy being.
"There are so many sources of inspiration if we just look," he said.
Moldenhauer welcomes everyone to discover the work for themselves, noting the studio gallery isn't for the purpose of business or making money, "it's about sharing art," he said.
Moving forward, Moldenhauer looks to collaborate and connect with the surrounding art community and plans to eventually have rotating monthly artists featured and juried art exhibits.
Abstract Truths is located in the Stevensville Art and Entertainment District at 214 Island Plaza Court. and typically open Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m.
Special showings are available by appointment at 410-490-6302.
Moldenhauer is an award winning abstract artist and Maryland Federation of Art juried exhibitor. He is also a Christian author and music writer with a Youtube channel and Instagram account. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Sweets And Treats For Everyone - Food
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
Sweets And Treats For Everyone - Food

 December 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 1452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Everyone loves homemade sweets, but especially at Christmas.From the young cook to the young mother to the grandmother to the older great-grandmother to the retiree and the men in the kitchen - we love baking cookies, making candy and frosting loaf cakes to give as Christmas gifts.
These treats are so appreciated by the teacher, the mail carrier, the delivery person, your co-workers, your elderly neighbor, those who are unable to perform baking chores due to disabilities, anyone working right up until Christmas Eve. Everyone loves baked goods no matter who they may be. So many of us just love watching the faces of the recipients also.
The first step and the most important is to have a list of the cookies, candies and cakes you want to make. The second step is to make a list of the ingredients you will need and the third is to get the correct amount of supplies.
Storage containers for the finished products are important. I save cookie tins throughout the year and purchase other types of paper or cardboard containers whenever they are on sale.
Finally, choose the day or two where you can bake all day undisturbed. Carry out pizza that evening for the family. Maybe you want to reserve a day or afternoon for the children or grandchildren to help.
MISS MARY'S CHOCOLATE FUDGE Mix together one bag of semi-sweet chocolate chips, one small can of sweetened condensed milk and 1 tsp vanilla. Microwave for one minute and stir this mixture and pour into a 8 x 8 inch pan. Refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Remove and cut into squares.
ROCKY ROAD CANDY Melt 1/4 cup butter or margarine and 4 cups miniature marshmallows together in a double boiler.
Stir in 6 cups of Rice Krispies.
Press in a buttered pan.
Chill and cut into desired size. You can press some candy into the squares before chilling - preferably soft candies.
HERSHEY'S THUMBPRINTS Cream 1 cup softened butter and mix in 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tsp almond extract, 1/2 tsp salt and 2 cups flour.
Chill overnight. Roll into balls and place on a lightly greased cookie sheet about 2 inches apart. Push your thumb into cookie balls.
Add a small amount of raspberry preserves into the center of each ball - use about 1/4 to 1/2 tsp. Bake at 400 degrees for 10 to 12 minutes or until brown on the bottom. Chill before serving. You can use any favorite preserves.
CHOCOLATE CHIP COOKIES Blend 2 cups of Crisco with 2 cups white sugar.
Add 4 beaten eggs with 4 tsps vanilla; mix well. Add one cup brown sugar, 8 cups flour, 2 tsps salt, 2 tsps baking soda and blend well. Stir in 2 cups of chocolate chips.
Drop a few tsps on a cookie sheet. Bake at 350 degrees until lightly browned.
OATMEAL COOKIES Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Beat together 3/4 cup shortening, 1 cup firmly packed brown sugar, 1/2 cup granulated sugar, 1 egg, 1 tsp vanilla until creamy. Add 3 cups uncooked oats, 1 cup flour, 1 tsp salt, and 1/2 tsp baking soda. Mix well and drop by rounded tsp onto greased cookie sheets. Bake at 350 degrees for 12 - 15 minutes.
You may add chopped nuts, raisins, chocolate chips, and coconut. Makes 5 dozen.
M & M COOKIES Cream together 1 cup shortening, 1 cup packed brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar, 2 beaten eggs, and 2 tsps vanilla. Gradually add 2 1/4 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda, and 1 tsp salt. Mix well and add 1 1/2 cups M & M's and mix. Drop by tspfuls on ungreased cookie sheets. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes at 375 degrees.
Kids love these cookies and like to help make them.
1950'S HOLIDAY PUNCH 1/4 cup sugar, 1 small jar (8 ounces) maraschino cherries,3 cups grapefruit juice, 1 large bottle club soda, 1 large bottle hi-spot lemon soda, 1 large bottle ginger ale, Citrus fruit slices.Combine first three ingredients; pour over ice into a large punch bowl.
Then add ice-cold hi-spot, club soda and ginger ale just before serving. Liquor if desired; stir gently. Makes about 30 punch cup servings.
TRIPLE TREAT HOLIDAY BARS 1 cup sliced natural almonds, finely chopped, 1 cup packed brown sugar,1 cup butter, softened, 1 egg,1 tsp vanilla (or 1/2 tsp vanilla extract and 1/2 tsp almond extract), 1/4 tsp salt, 2 cups all-purpose flour, 3 cups confectioners' sugar, 1/4 cup margarine softened, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tbsps milk, 1/2 cup diced red candied cherries, 2 squares (2 ounces) unsweetened chocolate, melted and cooled, Whole almonds, for decorating.
Preheat your oven to 300°F. Set aside ¼ cup of the chopped almonds; add the remaining ¾ cup to a large mixing bowl with the brown sugar, butter, egg, vanilla and salt. Use a mixer to cream together until fluffy, then gradually mix in the flour on low speed. Press the cookie dough evenly into the bottom of a 9×13-inch baking pan. Bake for 20-25 minutes until the cookie base is light brown. (It will still be soft.) Remove to a wire rack and allow to cool completely.
Using a mixer, beat the softened butter, confectioners' sugar, vanilla and about 2 tbsps of milk together until fluffy, adding another spoonful or two of milk if the frosting is too thick to be spreadable. Spread the frosting over the crust, then lightly score the frosting into thirds. Sprinkle ¼ cup of finely chopped almonds over one section; in the center section, spread melted chocolate over the frosting.
Decorate the last third with candied cherries, pressing down lightly to make them stick. Chill for about 15 minutes, then cut into individual bars before the chocolate has fully set.
CANDY CANE SNOWBALLS 2 cups butter, softened,1 cup confectioners' sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 3-1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup chopped pecans, 8 ounces white candy coating (melted), 1/3 to 1/2 cup crushed peppermint candies.
Cream butter and confectioners' sugar until light and fluffy, 5-7 minutes.
Beat in vanilla. Gradually beat in flour. Stir in pecans.
Refrigerate, covered, until firm enough to shape, 3-4 hours. Preheat the oven to 350°. Shape dough into 1-in. balls. Place 2 in. apart on ungreased baking sheets.
Bake until lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Remove from pans to wire racks; cool completely. Dip tops of cookies into candy coating, allowing excess to drip off; dip into crushed candies.
Let stand until set.
HOMEMADE PEPPERMINT PATTIES ½ cup sweetened condensed milk, 1½ tsp peppermint extract, 3 cups powdered sugar, 8 ounces dark chocolate chopped, 2 tsp oil. In a medium size bowl mix the sweetened condensed milk, peppermint extract, and powdered sugar together until thick dough forms. Sprinkle some powdered sugar on a flat clean work surface and place the peppermint dough on the sugar.
Using a rolling pin, roll out the dough to about 1/4 inch thickness. Using a medicine cup or other round object, cut out 1 inch circles from the dough. Place onto a wax paper covered baking sheet.
Place the peppermint patties into the fridge to allow to cool for about 30 minutes.
Place the chocolate in a heat safe bowl. Add the oil. Heat the chocolate in the microwave in 15 second intervals until the chocolate is fully melted. Stir until smooth. Using a fork, dip the peppermint patties into the melted chocolate and place back on the wax paper covered baking sheet. Once all patties have been coated, place the tray back in the fridge and allow the chocolate to set for another 30 minutes. Store the peppermint patties in the fridge until ready to be served!
NO COOK CHRISTMAS CANDY 1 box Betty Crocker Home Style Fluffy White Frosting Mix 7.2 oz. box, 1/3 cup light corn syrup, 1/2 cup boiling water, 1 lb. confectioners' sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract or seeds from 1/2 vanilla bean, Assorted holiday sprinkles.
Cover two or more large baking sheets with parchment paper or waxed paper.
In the bowl of a standing mixer fitted with the whip attachment, combine the frosting mix (dry mix), the corn syrup, and the boiling water. Beat on high speed until stiff peaks form, about 5 minutes. With the mixer still running on medium, slowly add in confectioners' sugar a little at a time; mix until just combined. Don't over mix or you'll deflate the batter. Add the vanilla and mix briefly. The finished mixture should be billowy and light, and a little bit stretchy like classic divinity. Drop candy mixture by the heaping tsp onto the prepared pans. Immediately cover with sprinkles, if desired. Let candies stand, uncovered, until dry to the touch, about 6-8 hours. When the outside of the candies feel firm, turn over. Dry 6 more hours, or overnight. Store candies in an airtight container. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES

title: Ballots not cast online
author: Staff Writer
content:
Ballots not cast online

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 81
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I feel the need to clarify part of Rich Adrian's letter that appeared last Sunday. His letter may leave the impression that Maryland ballots printed at home are then cast online. This is not true.After a ballot is printed from the website, the voter fills it out and mails it in. There is no voting online, so there is no hacking. The printed ballot is mailed and treated with the same scrutiny for authenticity as any other mail-in ballot.
JEFF BARRON
Easton
